Other assets, owned via publicly traded Valorem S.A., include a controlling interest in Colombia's biggest TV broadcaster Caracol, shares in packaging maker Biofilm and forestry outfit Refocosta. Born into a rich family with interests in breweries, Julio Santo Domingo took over management of its holdings in 1972 after his father retired. Now Alejandro, a managing director at Quadrant Capital Advisors, a New York-based investment advisory firm, is filling the role he has been groomed for over many years. He also sits on the board of Valorem, and, since 2009, the board of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York. The family owns a private island, Baru, off the Caribbean coast of Colombia. Alejandro's younger brother Andres appears in U.S. gossip columns with socialite wife, Vogue magazine editor Lauren Davis. Julio Mario Jr., half-brother to Alejandro and Andres from their father's first marriage, died in 2009 in New York, reportedly from cancer. Julio Mario's widow, Beatrice Davila Rocha, is also understood to share in the inheritance.

name: Billionaires
bio: Horst Paulmann is a Latin American retail king: he and his family own 63% of Cencosud, one of Latin America's largest retailers, with malls, supermarkets, department stores and home centers, an insurance brokerage, family entertainment centers and a travel agency. He took the company public in 2001. He opened the first Jumbo hypermarket in 1976, and now has 658 supermarkets in Chile, Argentina, Brazil, Peru; all told, his retail portfolio includes some 799 locations. Cencosud is building the region's tallest building in Santiago, the Costanera Center. His three children all sit on firm's board of directors. Last year Cencosud stores in Chile were raided under suspicion of fraud: the Chilean government accused the retailer of sending goods from Argentina and passing them off as earthquake relief in 2010, not paying import taxes, and selling the goods to the government instead of donating them. Paulmann has denied all accusations and said that the deal was always that the government would purchase the goods. The matter has not yet been settled; at one point, politicians threatened to take his Chilean citizenship away. Paulmann immigrated from Germany to Chile as a teenager after WW II. Decades later, he still holds dual citizenship.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gennady Timchenko's investment fund Volga Resources bought a 30% stake in Russian Sea Group, which produces and sells fish products. Together with Novatek partner Leonid Mikhelson, he holds a 37.5% stake in petrochemical producer Sibur Holding. In the late 1980s, Timchenko ran Kinex, a state-owned oil exporter; he became one of its main shareholders when it was later privatized. Today, Timchenko is a co-owner of the Gunvor Group, one of the largest international energy traders (2011 revenues: $80 billion), whose clients include 8 of the 10 biggest oil & gas outfits. He also controls the engineering and construction company Stroytransgaz and owns Transoil, a railway operator that transports oil products. He won several cases against Russian and UK media outfits that wrote about his business successes in relation to his alleged close ties with Vladimir Putin. Timchenko also has Finnish citizenship and lives in Switzerland.

name: Billionaires
bio: Steve Jobs' widow, Laurene Powell Jobs, inherits a fortune that was largely placed into living trusts near the end of her husband's life. Steve Jobs, who died in October, first met Laurene Powell in Oct. 1989 after giving a talk at Stanford University where Powell was a student in the Graduate School of Business. Less than two years later, they were married in Yosemite. The couple had three children together. Powell Jobs, who was the First Lady's guest at President Obama's 2012 State of the Union address, sits on the boards of several non-profits including Teach for America, the New America Foundation and College Track, an organization she founded, which helps low-income students prepare for college. She is also the founder and chair of the Emerson Collective, which works with entrepreneurs to advance international social reform.
title: Investor, Philanthropist
employment: {'name': 'Emerson Collective', 'title': 'Founder and Chair', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers were raised in the U.K. Simon started out importing carpets and buying real estate; David in metals trading. They later joined together in Transworld, a metals trader that invested in Russia and Kazakhstan in the 1990s. The pair took the proceeds and invested in UK real estate. Recently they purchased the Mayfair estate of the famed private military club nicknamed the In and Out Club; they plan to convert it to high end residences. They also agreed to purchase 100% of horse racing and events company, Arena Leisure. Their plans to take data center provider, Global Switch, public were deferred last year due to weak markets; they are hoping to revive it once markets improve. David and Simon are also expanding in US windfarms through Ventower Industries as well as mineral trading - they recently acquired a stake in Indonesian commodities company owned by Uzbekistan's Azam Aslanov. Both take active roles in the Reuben Foundation, which funds health care and educational causes. David resides in numerous locations across the world; Simon resides in Monaco.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dmitry Rybolovlev is best known in the U.S. for his real estate moves. He bought Donald Trump's Palm Beach mansion, Maison de L'Amitie, for $95 million in 2008. He paid $88 million for a Manhattan apartment former Citi chairman Sandy Weill listed, buying the pad for his daughter Ekaterina Rybolovleva, 22; the sale set a new record on price paid per sq. foot. He also apparently paid more than $300 million for La Belle Epoque penthouse in Monaco, where he lives. Rybolovlev has all this money to spend having sold his stake in Uralkali, the fertilizer business that made him rich, for $6.5 billion in 2010. His wife Elena, who filed for divorce in Palm Beach court in 2009, is seeking transfer of ownership of the former Trump mansion and half of her husband's wealth. Rybolovlev started his business with his scientist father in 1990 after studying medicine at the Perm Medical Institute. In 1992, he opened an investment fund and, like other future tycoons, began buying shares of industrial enterprises. He consolidated his shares into a controlling stake and in 1995 was named chairman of the board of Uralkali, Russia's largest producer of potassium fertilizers, founded in the 1930s. The company listed in London in 2007, raising $1 billion. Instead of starting new business projects, Rybolovlev for the present prefers to spend money, not only on real estate, but also on sports: last year he bought the Monaco football club.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shares of buyout investor Harold Simmons' publicly traded holding company, Valhi, have climbed 158% year over year, boosting his net worth by $3.3 billion. A well-known Republican donor, he has given money to nearly all the candidates in the 2012 primaries, mainly through their super PACs. The University of Texas graduate began his career as a bank examiner before buying a single drug store near the SMU campus with $5,000 in cash and a $95,000 loan. After more than a decade of rapid expansion, Simmons sold his business to Eckerd Corporation for $50 million in 1973. At the time of the sale, Simmons' drug store chain had 100 locations across Texas. Today Simmons, through Valhi, has controlling interests in Kronos Worldwide, Titanium Metals Corporation, CompX International, and Keystone Consolidated Inc. A certified pilot, Simmons enjoys watching the NFL's Dallas Cowboys with team owner and fellow billionaire Jerry Jones; Simmons' luxury box is located right next to Jones'.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Oleg Deripaska is battling rival metals billionaire Vladimir Potanin over control of Norilsk Nickel, the world's largest nickel producer. In 2010 his aluminum giant Rusal raised $2.2 billion in a Hong Kong IPO. He came back from the brink during the financial crisis: facing margin calls and billions of dollars in debt, he personally negotiated with the Russian government, banks and other creditors to restructure loan obligations. Deripaska managed to defend the majority of his assets from creditors, including car maker Gaz, energy sector EuroSibEnergo, and Glavstroy construction projects. The debt of his holding company Basic Element is still huge, about $21 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: German Khan's Alfa Group, which he shares with fellow billionaires and college buddies Mikhail Fridman and Alexei Kuzmichev, is the biggest financial and industrial group in Russia. Khan is executive director of TNK-BP, the group's oil business. In February 2011 TNK-BP's Russian shareholders won a London court injunction blocking a proposed share exchange between BP and state-owned Rosneft. BP then offered to buy out the 50% TNK-BP stake held by Alfa and other Russians for $32 billion, but in June 2011 Deputy Prime Minister Igor Sechin-- the former head of the board of Rosneft?blocked that deal. Khan, a Kiev native, came to Moscow to study. With his friends Fridman and Kuzmichev, he started commodities trading outfit Alfa-Eco in 1989; two years later the trio launched Alfa-Bank, now the biggest private bank by capital in Russia. The group bought Tyumen Oil from the state in the late 1990s and merged it with BP's Russian assets to form TNK-BP. Alfa Group also has stakes in two Russian cellular companies and owns the biggest retailer, X5.

name: Billionaires
bio: These continue to be interesting times for Cohen, who is a hedge fund titan and one of the most powerful forces in equity trading. He recently purchased a 4% stake in the New York Mets for $20 million and is believed to be trying to buy the Los Angeles Dodgers. A prolific art collector, Cohen was named to the board of the Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles in January. But his $14 billion hedge fund firm, SAC Capital, has been hit by a fresh wave of legal scrutiny--though neither SAC nor Cohen have been accused of any wrongdoing. In February federal prosecutors indicted Jon Horvath, a tech analyst at SAC's Sigma Capital unit, marking the first time an SAC employee has been accused of insider-trading. Such distractions had no impact on SAC's 2011 performance, however. The firm's flagship fund returned 8% net of fees last year. Cohen and his wife pledged $50 million in 2010 to the North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System, which renamed its pediatric center after them.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Satellite broadcasting mogul Ergen (Dish Network, Echostar), known for his ornery nature and poker face, gave up his CEO title at Dish after 30 years. In May, he handed the reins to former Sirius CEO Joseph Clayton and as chairman, has been focusing on big-picture deals. In April, Dish bought bankrupt retailer Blockbuster for $320 million, then snapped up broadband spectrum for close to $3 billion in a bankruptcy auction. Now Dish is waiting on the FCC to approve a deal that would allow the company to offer a 4G network nationwide. A skilled poker player, Ergen says his moves are like an episode of Seinfeld. "It seemed to all come together in the last couple of minutes." Dish settled a bitter lawsuit with TiVo in May 2011 for $500 million. Ergen got his start as a financial analyst at Frito-Lay. He tried his hand playing pro poker, but switched to selling TV satellites from a truck with his wife in the 1980s.
title: Founder and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'DISH Network', 'uri': 'companies/dish-network', 'title': 'Founder and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: As chairman, Lee Kun-Hee oversees Korea's largest conglomerate, the Samsung Group. Samsung Electronics, with sales of $155 billion in fiscal year 2011, became the world's largest memory chip and flat screen television producer. Samsung Electronics also pulled in its highest revenues ever from its growing mobile phone business, which counts among its products the Galaxy-S smartphone. Lee is also a member of the International Olympic Committee and was influential in bringing the 2018 Winter Olympics to South Korea.

name: Billionaires
bio: In his ninth decade, Rupert Murdoch is both still firmly in control of his media empire and facing what may be the biggest crisis of his career. The phone hacking and bribery scandal at News Corp.'s British newspaper subsidiary has thrown open the question of succession, with heir apparent James Murdoch forced to step back from some duties and elder brother Lachlan appearing poised for a return to the fold. Despite declaring himself "humble" in a Parliamentary hearing, the patriarch continues to make his presence felt, most recently in the decision to launch a new Sunday tabloid. Financially, he has room to maneuver thanks to the performance of News Corp.'s cable networks, particularly Fox News, which accounted for close to half of the cable group's $1.6 billion in 2011 earnings.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'News Corp', 'uri': 'companies/news-corp', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False, 'revenue': 33706.0, 'revenueYear': 2011}

name: Billionaires
bio: Petr Kellner continues to expand his insurance and banking empire. His lender, Home Credit, is growing business in China while also launching new projects in India and Indonesia. Kellner also has big retail plans in Russia where he purchased the remaining 50% stake in electronics retailer Eldorado. He's also placing bets on Sazka, a Czech lottery and betting company. Polymetal, in which his group holds a 20% stake, was reportedly looking to merge with Polyus Gold, controlled by Russian billionaires Mikhail Prokhorov and Suleiman Kerimov. Kellner got his start selling office supplies, then borrowed $1 million against that business and started an investment fund; he used it to buy a controlling stake in Czech insurer during its privatization. Kellner then built media holdings that he later sold to U.S. billionaire Ronald Lauder for $580 million net profit. In December, Kellner got Sting to play at an all-staff Christmas party at Prague Castle to celebrate PPF's 20th anniversary.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 2011, Kinder's pipeline company, Kinder Morgan, agreed to acquire El Paso Corp. for $38 billion in cash, stock and assumed debt. The combined company will boast some 80,000 miles of pipelines. Kinder's bet is that the booming growth of shale plays will generate massive new volumes of oil and gas for his pipelines to bring to market. Kinder's personal fortune has benefited already from a run-up in shares. A former Army captain, Kinder quit as Enron president in 1996 and built a pipeline company with friend William Morgan. He earned both bachelor and law degrees from the University of Missouri.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Kinder Morgan', 'uri': 'companies/kinder-morgan', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Iskander Makhmudov is the main owner of copper producer UGMK-Holding. He is also a shareholder in Transmashholding, Russia's largest maker of locomotives and rail equipment (he partnered with state-owned Russian Railways and Alstom, the French machine-building giant). Born in Bukhara, Uzbekistan, Makhmudov lived in Tashkent; he graduated from a local university with degree in oriental studies. Makhmudov put his Arabic-language skills to use in various Soviet military organizations in Libya and Iraq. His first moves as a businessman were with the Chernoy brothers, the Reuben brothers and their Trans-World Group, once the largest metals-trading operation in Russia. Last autumn, Spanish authorities named him in a money laundering case, which they handed over to the Russian Attorney General's Office for further investigation.

name: Billionaires
bio: The wealth of mainland China's second richest man may be little changed from a year ago, but his Sany Heavy Industry has been busy with a series of moves of late that will push it up in the ranks of the world's construction equipment makers. Sany said in January that it would team up with CITIC Private Equity Advisors of China to purchase Putzmeister, one of the world's largest concrete pump manufacturers, in a deal worth $475 million. In February Changsha-based company announced manufacturing and sales JVs with equipment maker Palfinger of Germany. Liang, who traveled to the U.S. in February as part of a visit by the man viewed as China's next president, Xi Jinping,  is one of four executives from Sany to make this year's billionaires list: the other three are Mao Zhongwu, Tang Xiuguo and Xiang Wenbo.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sunil Mittal was the rare telecom tycoon untainted by India's telecom corruption scandalwhich erupted last year and landed several others in jail. With 243 million customers, his Bharti Airtel is world's fifth-largest telecom firm, with operations in 19 countries. It's losing money in Africa, market it entered in 2010 with $9 billion purchase of African unit of Kuwait's Zain. Faring better at home, where it raised tariffs in bid to end bruising price war and rolled out 3G mobile services. Son Kavin joined Bharti's new mobile internet jv with Japan's Softbank in October. A deal to sell his stake in insurance arm to Mukesh Ambani unravelled. He sits on Unilever's board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hansjorg Wyss is selling his artificial joint maker Synthes to Johnson & Johnson for $21.3 billion in cash and stock. Shareholders approved the merger this past December, and the deal is expected to close in June, pending regulatory approval. Wyss may retire as chairman in April. He owns a 900-acre ranch and vineyard in California, and has focused his philanthropy on bioengineering and conservation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kumar Birla, whose family was the only Indian clan on the first billionaires list in 1987, chairs the $35 billion (revenues) Aditya Birla Group, commodities powerhouse named after his late father. It's among the world's top 10 producers of cement and Asia's biggest aluminum producer. It paid $340 million to buy Domsjo Fabriker, Swedish maker of specialty pulp that's used in textiles. He's reportedly eyeing more overseas acquisitions, notably in coal and is also keen to start a bank. Telecom arm Idea Cellular was hit by Supreme Court ruling cancelling 122 telecom licences in wake of India's corruption scandal. His mother Rajashree oversees philanthropy interests.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Philippines' richest man, Henry started out in his father's bodega and then opened a shoe store. He now controls the Philippines' largest mall developer, with 42 locations; has 5 in China, including one that opened last year. Shares in SM Investments, which makes up bulk of his fortune, popped 50% in past year. BDO Unibank, run by daughter Teresita Sy-Coson, is the country's largest bank.

name: Billionaires
bio: Despite patch up with brother Mukesn that included a much photographed reunion in their late father's hometown, Anil Ambani continues on a losing streak, down $1 billion in past year and down $34.2  billion from his 2008 peak. His group raised $5 billion, partly from Chinese banks. He sold 26% of both life insurance and mutual fund arms to Japan's Nippon Life for $922 million. Is reportedly mulling selling telecom tower arm and a submarine cable unit. Ambani attended his first Academy Awards this year with his DreamWorks Studios' partner Steven Spielberg to celebrate 11 nominations for three of their JV's movies, The Help, War Horse and Real Steel.

name: Billionaires
bio: August von Finck is the son of banker Wilhelm von Finck, the founder of insurance giant Allianz and private bank Merck, Finck & Co.  Both entities were sold to Barclays Bank in 1990. From his tax-free hideaway in Switzerland, he now oversees an investment portfolio that includes real estate, restaurants, hotels, breweries, a chemical manufacturer and an engine builder.

name: Billionaires
bio: Beer heiress Charlene de Carvalho-Heineken inherited a 25 percent controlling stake in Dutch brewer Heineken a decade ago from her late father, Freddy Heineken. The company has more than 170 premium brands in more than 65 countries. A mother of five, Carvalho-Heineken studied law at the University of Leiden. She is a member of St. Moritz's elite Corviglia Ski Club. A delegate member of Heineken's board of directors; her husband, investment banker Michel de Carvalho, sits on the supervisory board.

name: Billionaires
bio: At 71, Galen Weston stepped down from the board of retailer Associated British Foods late last year. He still maintains his role as the Executive Chairman of George Weston Ltd., the Canadian food and retail giant that was founded by his grandfather in 1882. Weston continues to expand his influence in the rag trade, already having purchased department stores including Holt Renfrew in Canada, Brown Thomas in Ireland, Selfridges in the U.K. and de Bijenkorf in the Netherlands. In July 2011 his Selfridges unit  purchased Ogilvy's, one of the most prominent department stores in Montreal, for an undisclosed amount.
title: Owner

name: Billionaires
bio: Ralph Lauren's vision of upper-crust American prep continues to sell, both here and abroad. Lauren sold $850 million worth of Polo Ralph Lauren shares, roughly a quarter of his stake, in a secondary offering in spring of 2010. He said he wanted to diversify. The Bronx native opened his New York City flagship store in the fall of 2010. He started Polo with $50,000 in 1976. The company now sells clothing, shoes, jewelry, home goods, fragrances. His Polo gear will outfit American athletes in the 2012 London summer games. Lauren has dozens of exotic cars (Bugatti, Bentley, Alfa Romeo, Ferrari), vintage watches.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Ralph Lauren', 'uri': 'companies/ralph-lauren', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Extremely discreet, press-shy brothers Alain and Gerard Wertheimer control luxury brand Chanel. The company was cofounded by their grandfather Pierre Wertheimer, who eventually bought out his early partner Gabrielle (Coco) Chanel, designer of the famous little black dress. U.S. resident Alain is chairman of the company, whose Chanel No. 5 perfume is one of world's top-selling scents. Brother Gerard lives in Switzerland and chairs Chanel's watch division. His wife Valerie is president of Action Innocence, a group that combats child pornography on the Web. Brothers own French vineyards Rauzan-Segla in Margaux and Chateau Canon in Saint-Emilion; also thoroughbreds, including horses that have won such races as the French Derby and the Breeders' Cup Turf in the U.S. Alain reportedly collects old time pieces.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dilip Shanghvi founded and runs Sun Pharmaceutical Industries, India's most valuable drug maker. Firm has a new joint venture with Merck & Co. to make branded generics aimed at emerging markets. The U.S. Food & Drug Administration approved Sun's manufacturing plant in the U.S., which had been shut down in 2010 after it cited manufacturing violations. Shanghvi is personally investing in power, a sector lately plagued by bureaucratic delays and an acute coal shortage. His son Aalok works with him.

name: Billionaires
bio: After earning his MBA from the University of Southern California in 1983, Glasenberg joined Marc Rich & Co. in 1984, working as a marketer in the coal and coke commodity department in his native South Africa. By the time the commodity trader was bought out by management and rebranded as Glencore in 1994, Glasenberg had risen to worldwide director of the coal and coke commodity department. Chief executive for the past decade, he recently announced a $90 billion merger with mining outfit Xstrata in February. Glasenberg will serve as deputy CEO of the new entity with a focus on commodities trading. The South Africa-born executive, who became an Australian citizen during a short stint working in Melbourne and now lives in Switzerland, is the firm's largest individual shareholder and has vowed not to sell shares in the company while he works there. After shares shed 35% of their value between Glencore's high-profile IPO and late August, Glasenberg took advantage of the dip by plowing his first dividend, a $54 million payday, right back into the company. He is a former South African race-walking champion and also represented Israel in the sport.

name: Billionaires
bio: James ("Jim") Goodnight co-founded software giant SAS with fellow North Carolina State alum John Sall in 1976. The world's largest private software company saw a 12% increase in revenues to $2.72 billion in 2011, as clients looked to business analytics to sort out where to make money. Goodnight has kept a promise made in 2009 of no layoffs, despite the downturn. The firm is known for worker-friendly policies, wellness programs, on-site daycare centers and free snacks. With Sall, Goodnight also owns tony Prestonwood Country Club, The Umstead Hotel & Spa and local private school Cary Academy. An outspoken proponent of education reform, he has made education the focus of SAS's philanthropy. He also developed educational software that helps schools extend the use of technology as a learning tool.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Giorgio Armani recently signed a 10-year agreement with the Luxottica Group (owned by Italian billionaire Leonardo Del Vecchio) for the design and manufacture of his designer prescription  eyeglasses and sunglasses. Armani owns about $775 million worth of Luxottica shares. The designer to the stars also markets perfume, baby clothes, home decor and expensive watches. The designer has licensed his name for a string of hotels; Dubai's Burj Khalifa hotel opened in 2010 and the 96-room Hotel Armani Milan opened in November 2011. He spent 2 years in medical school at the University of Piacenza before dropping out in 1957 to take a job as a department store buyer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hasso Plattner cofounded German software firm SAP with four former IBM colleagues in 1972. He stepped down from his post as CEO in May 2003 after 30 years of service and now chairs the company's supervisory board. A sports enthusiast, Plattner competitively sails his yacht, Morning Glory, as well as skis, snowboards and plays tennis. He is also an avid golfer, and owns Fancourt Estate, a luxury golf course and hotel in South Africa's Western Cape province. His Hasso Plattner Ventures, based in Potsdam, incubates promising technology companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Masayoshi Son is the founder of Asia's leading internet venture, Softbank, which has become one of Japan's top three mobile networks since 2006 acquisition of Vodaphone Japan. The company has seen strong subscriber growth in recent years, thanks partly to its long-exclusive license to offer iPhones, a legacy of Son's longstanding personal friendship with the late Steve Jobs. But now that rival KDDI also gained iPhone franchise, Softbank is facing increasing competition. Its share price is down over 20% over the past year. Son made headlines with plans to join provincial and municipal governments to co-invest in solar and wind energy in the wake of last year's nuclear disaster in Tohoku. Indeed, Son was the biggest individual donor to earthquake relief efforts; he gave $125 million to a dozen organizations including Japanese Red Cross and pledged all his future Softbank salary pay to support quake orphans.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Patrick Soon-Shiong became a billionaire by building companies that put out good drugs with great timing. Now he's working to bring supercomputing to health care and building the "Bell Labs" of medicine. His dad was a village doctor in China. His family later immigrated to South Africa during WWII. Soon-Shiong finished high school at 16 and became a doctor by 23. He took American Pharmaceutical Partners public in 2001, and spun off a new company, Abraxis, in 2007. He sold APP in 2008 and Abraxis in 2010.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Estée Lauder (d. 2004) and chairman emeritus of the cosmetics company, Leonard Lauder joined the family business in 1958 after attending U. Penn and Columbia University's business school. He stepped down as CEO in 1999 and currently serves on the Board. His Lipstick Indicator Theory holds that people buy more inexpensive luxuries in tough economic times. Lauder's wife Evelyn, whom he met on a blind date, died in November of ovarian cancer. Evelyn Lauder previously survived breast cancer, and co-founded the "pink ribbon" campaign for breast cancer awareness in 1992. A passionate art collector, Lauder is chairman emeritus of the Whitney Museum of American Art, and in 2010, voted in favor of the museum's downtown expansion. His 2008 donation of $131 million is still the largest in the museum's history. He owns one of the world's finest private collections of Cubist works, including Picasso's 1909 "Nude Woman in an Armchair."
title: Chairman Emeritus
employment: {'name': 'Estée Lauder Cos', 'uri': 'companies/estee-lauder-cos', 'title': 'Chairman Emeritus', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: The grandson of a Russian immigrant, Samuel Irving Newhouse - known as "S.I." or "Si" - co-owns publishing powerhouse Advance Publications with brother Donald. Si presides over Condé Nast's consumer magazines, including Vogue, Vanity Fair and The New Yorker; group has lost some of its sheen over the past few years, with titles Modern Bride, Elegant Bride, Gourmet, and Cookie folding in 2009 (Gourmet is back as an online title only). However, ad revenue is starting to come back. Nearly 40% of his fortune comes from stake in Discovery Communications, operator of cable and satellite TV networks like Discovery Channel, Animal Planet and TLC. Also has an extensive collection of modern art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mohamed Bin Issa Al Jaber owns a string of luxury and budget hotels in Europe and Egypt through JJW Hotels & Resorts. He settled an acrimonious battle with Standard Bank in London in December. The bank had accused him of failing to repay a $150 million loan, and Al Jaber claimed the bank made an unauthorized loan deal with his assistant to cover trading losses. As part of the settlement, the court has lifted a freeze on his assets, which included his personal bank accounts. Al Jaber and Standard Bank say they have reached a mutually agreeable settlement.

name: Billionaires
bio: Philip Anschutz has made fortunes in oil, railroads and telecom, but his biggest bets are in entertainment. Through Anschutz Entertainment Group, or AEG, he operates dozens of the world's greatest concert venues, including the Staples Center and Nokia Theater in L.A., London's O2, and Shanghai's Mercedes-Benz Arena. He fills his halls with his own in-house entertainment; AEG controls sports teams like the NBA's Lakers, the NHL's Kings and the L.A. Galaxy soccer team. His music division manages pop stars including Justin Bieber, Taylor Swift and the Black Eyed Peas. His film division has produced the Chronicles of Narnia series. Next up: partnering with Ryan Seacrest and Mark Cuban to re-brand HDNet as a new TV network called AXS. The venture will feature live entertainment from AEG's venues, and offer a new platform for buying concert tickets. AEG also hopes to bring NFL football back to L.A., with plans to build a $1 billion stadium adjacent to the Staples Center and buy a team to go with it. Anschutz has plenty of cash to make the deal, having sold oil and gas fields for $1 billion last year. Anschutz is also passionate about the art of the American West; his collection of Bierstadts, Remingtons and Russells could be the world's best. He also enjoys real-life western vistas; his company Xanterra manages lodges in many national parks. On his own land in Wyoming, Anschutz is developing a wind farm that could boast 1,000 turbines.

name: Billionaires
bio: A shrewd banker, Beal started hoarding cash in 2004 as consumers and companies bathed themselves in debt. He waited until the economy began to crumble in 2007and then set about snapping up loans jettisoned by struggling banks and desperate investors. The combined net income at his two main banks surged. By 2010 he stopped buying because asset prices had become too rich again. Son of a mechanical engineer, Beal scraped together his early kitty fixing used televisions, and sold them to low-income families. He bought a Lansing, Mich. rental home at age 19, and opened the first branch of Beal Bank in Texas 1988. He added a Nevada bank years later. Beal mostly buys loans on the secondary market instead of originating them. A gifted poker player, he took on renowned card sharks Doyle Brunson and Phil Ivey at the Bellagio in Las Vegas in some of the highest-stakes games ever played.

name: Billionaires
bio:
As food demand rises across Asia, Dhanin Chearavanont's agribusiness group Charoen Pokphand is enjoying double digit growth. It derives half of its $33 billion annual revenues from China, where it's known as Chia Tai. Chinese interests include 77 Lotus superstores, Shanghai's Superbrand Mall. Listed Thai flagship Charoen Pokphand Foods, is aquiring 74% of group's Hong Kong-listed China feed
mill operator, CP Pokphand, in $2 billion deal to be completed during first quarter of 2012. Operates more than 6,000 7-Eleven stores in Thailand and country's third largest mobile phone company, True. His father started small shop in Bangkok supplying seeds imported from China to Thai farmers 8 decades ago. Shares fortune with 3 brothers, Jaran, Montri and Sumeth.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers Shashi and Ravi Ruia sold their one-third stake in telecom unit Vodafone Essar for $5.4 billion last July after their plan for listing the holding was opposed by Vodafone. Used proceeds mostly to pay off their Essar Group's debt pile. They were under fire for their minority stake in Loop Telecom, owned by their brother-in-law, which was investigated due to suspicions that brothers were true owners of the shares. In December, the federal investigating agency charged Ravi and other family members for an alleged criminal conspiracy which they are contesting. Due to scandal, Ravi stepped down as chairman of their London-listed Essar Energy whose shares have plunged 75% in past year. A Supreme Court ruling that it was liable to pay stake taxes exceeding $1billion also hit stock. They demerged their ports and shipping businesses in May, listing Essar Ports and Essar Shipping.

name: Billionaires
bio: After ten years as CEO of Google, Eric Schmidt stepped down last year, relinquishing his role to one of the site's two billionaire founders, Larry Page. Riffing on an old joke from when he took over from young Page to prepare Google to float, he tweeted: "Day-to-day adult supervision no longer needed!"  Schmidt has an electrical engineering degree from Princeton and a Ph.D. from UC Berkeley. He began in software at Bell Labs, Xerox PARC, then started pre-IPO at Sun Microsystems in 1983. He rose to chief technology officer and led development of Java technology. Before taking the helm at Google in 2001, he was CEO of Novell. On the eve of the search engine's 2004 IPO, Schmidt, along with founders Page and Sergey Brin, made a pact to stay for 20 years.
title: Executive Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: South African diamond magnate Nicky Oppenheimer made the momentous decision in November to sell his family's 40% stake in De Beers, the world's largest diamond producer, to mining behemoth Anglo American for $5.1 billion. (Anglo American already owns 45% of DeBeers.) Assuming the all-cash deal wins regulatory approval, the sale will mark the end of the Oppenheimers' control of De Beers, a relationship that began when Nicky's grandfather, Ernest Oppenheimer, took over the firm in 1927. After struggling through the recession as demand for luxury goods sagged, revenues surged 53% in 2010 vs. 2009 and came in at $7.4 billion in 2011. Such impressive performance has led some analysts to assert that the offer from Anglo American, a firm that was founded by Nicky's grandfather in 1917, undervalues De Beers. However, says Nicky, "Anglo American is the natural home for our stake." Oppenheimer's passions include flying helicopters, cricket, and conservation. He owns the Tswalu Kalahari Reserve, the largest private game reserve in South Africa.

name: Billionaires
bio: Miuccia Prada, the granddaughter of company founder Mario Prada, runs the luxury goods and clothing company Prada with her husband Patrizio Bertelli. She is lead designer. He is chief executive (and also a billionaire). The company had its initial public offering on the Hong Kong stock exchange in June 2011, valuing the fashion house at a recent $13 billion and helping Prada return to the Forbes list of billionaires for the first time since 2008. Their fiery relationship fuels interesting designs, most recently a Prada menswear show featuring urban-warrior-inspired fashion. While her counterparts Karl Lagerfeld (Chanel, Fendi) and Stella McCartney have designed affordable collections for H&M, Prada contends she will not follow suit.
title: Owner, Fashion Designer

name: Billionaires
bio: Mikhail Gutseriev's BIN Group has been buying up real estate, including the famous Hotel National in Moscow, which he purchased last year from Russia's richest woman, Elena Baturina. Also in 2011, he established fertilizer-producer Slavkaly in Belarus. Gutseriev heads oil company Russneft and holds 49% of its shares; another 49% is controlled by billionaire Vladimir Yevtushenkov's AFK Sistema. Gutseriev's new moves come after he left Moscow for London several years ago following trouble with the government. At end of 2006, Gutseriev was accused of violating terms of his oil license and failing to pay taxes. He denied the charges, sold his oil firm, RussNeft, to billionaire Oleg Deripaska for $2.8 billion, and left the country. In 2010, all charges were lifted and Gutseriev went back to Russia; Deripaska returned the company to Gutseriev. Born in Kazakhstan, where his Ingush family had been deported after World War II, Gutseriev became the president of state oil company Slavneft, but was dismissed in 2002 before privatization. Over a four-year period, Swiss trader Glencore helped Gutseriev buy a number of small Russian oil firms, which he united into Russneft. Yevtushenkov negotiated the deal and his AFK Sistema got a 49% stake.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alexei Kuzmichev's Alfa Group, which he shares with fellow billionaires and college pals German Khan and Mikhail Fridman, is the biggest financial and industrial group in Russia. Kuzmichev met his future partners in college. In 1991 they started Alfa Bank, which is now the biggest private bank by capital in Russia. The trio bought Tyumen Oil from the state in the late 1990s and merged it with BP's Russian assets into TNK-BP. The group also has stakes in two Russian cellular companies and owns the biggest retailer, X5. Kuzmichev heads the company called A1, which manages a portfolio of various assets, including the largest car sale company in Russia, Nezavisimost; two largest cinema networks, Kronwerk Cinema and Formula Kino; a leading provider of IT solutions and services, Systematika; and the largest supermarket chain in Belorussia, BelMarket.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ebay founder Pierre Omidyar is making good on the promise he made when he first became, as he called it, "ridiculously rich," to give away most of his wealth in his lifetime. He reiterated that intention by signing the Gates and Buffett Giving Pledge last year. He also continues to gift eBay shares to the Omidyar Network, his philanthropic investment firm; recent recipients of grants include tech incubators in Nigeria and Kenya. So far, he and wife Pam have given away more than $1 billion to programs spanning a range of causes, from poverty alleviation to human rights to disaster relief. The French-born Iranian moved to the U.S. with his family at age six. He wrote code for his site Auction Web at age 28 and renamed it eBay after his first choice, Echo Bay, was already taken. The first item ever sold on eBay was his broken laser pointer for which he got $14.83. Omidyar became a billionaire in 1998 when the company went public. He ceded executive control to new hire Meg Whitman in 1998; she in turn was replaced by John Donahoe 10 years later. Omidyar remains chairman of eBay.
title: Founder and Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: For 36 years, Carl Engelhorn headed pharmaceutical companies Boehringer Manheim and DePuy. In May 1997, he engineered their sale to Roche for $11 billion. Engelhorn made $4.4 billion on the deal. Engelhorn, whose mother was American, sponsors the Heidelberg Center for American Studies at the University of Heidelberg, funding it with a yearly donation of more than $500,000. He also supports the Reiss-Engelhorn Museum in Mannheim. He is the great-grandson of Friedrich Engelhorn, the founder of German chemical company BASF.

name: Billionaires
bio: Michael Kadoorie is chairman of CLP Holdings, the largest supplier of electricity in Hong Kong, which lately has been looking beyond the former British colony for growth. Shares have risen on investor interest in its steady cash flow, helping to boost the wealth of the celebrated family. Worries about the global economy have been hard on its international hotel chain, Hong Kong & Shanghai Hotels, which lost a third of its value in the past year. The clan is still sitting on a residential property jewel in Kowloon: Kadoorie Estates, acquired by the family in 1931 when it was a barren rock site.

name: Billionaires
bio: Leonid Fedun is a former military man turned financial whiz. While teaching in the Siberian city of Kogalym in the late 1980s, Fedun met Vagit Alekperov, who was the head of the local oil and gas company. In the 1990s he helped privatize Lukoil, which was formed out of the best Russian oil properties. He now works as Lukoil head Alekperov's right-hand man, with a more than 9% stake in the company. Fedun also oversees the investing activities of IFD Capital. He owns the famous Moscow soccer club Spartak, on which he reportedly spends $70 million a year. Construction of the team's new stadium will reportedly cost $333.5 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Michael, Budi inherited clove cigarette maker Djarum from their father but these days get bulk of their fortune from Bank Central Asia, country's largest private bank. Siblings also have palm oil interests, having picked up 65,000 hectares of land in West Kalimantan in 2008. Together they also own Grand Indonesia, a luxury shopping mall, office building and hotel complex in the center of Jakarta. Through their newly created Global Digital Prima Ventures, they also bought Kaskus, Indonesia's most popular website. Their Djarum, banned in the US since 2009 along with other clove cigarettes,  has launched Dos Hermanos, a premium cigar blending Brazilian and Indonesian tobaccos.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of Sweden's richest women, Antonia Johnson succeeded her father as head of the Axel Johnson Group, a diversified trading company, in 1982. The privately held company, founded by her great-grandfather in 1873, has $6.3 billion in sales and has interests in food, security, energy, telecom, real estate and industrial products. Axfood AB, in which it holds a 46% share, is one of the largest food operations in Scandinavia. Johnson attended Radcliffe College in Cambridge, Mass. as an exchange student in the early 1960s. She is an avid horsewoman and member of numerous Swedish charities, including the World Childhood Foundation, which was founded by the Swedish queen.

name: Billionaires
bio: Suleiman Kerimov, an investor in distressed companies, sold nearly all his Russian assets, including shares in Gazprom, government-owned Sberbank and a massive housing development in suburban Moscow prior to Russia's 2008 financial meltdown. With the help of huge loans, he then amassed stakes in Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs, Deutsche Bank, Credit Suisse, and others. When financial crisis hit the U.S., he lost billions. He later recovered and, with the help of still more loans from Russia's VTB, returned to investing in the Russian market, buying a stake in Russia's largest gold mining outfit, Polyus Gold, real estate company PIK, and leading long-distance telephony provider Rostelecom. In the summer of 2010 he bought Dmitry Rybolovlev's controlling stake in Uralkali, the biggest producer of potassium fertilizers in Russia. In exchange he gave Rybolovlev a portion of his stake in Polyus Gold. A native of Dagestan, a republic in Russia's North Caucasus, Kerimov was seriously injured in a car accident after losing control of a Ferrari Enzo on the Promenade des Anglais in Nice in 2006. His recovery was prolonged and painful. He reportedly owns three planes and two yachts.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of Hong Kong's biggest landlords, through his Chinese Estates, Joseph Lau is known for his impressive art, wine collections; he is said to have at least 10,000 bottles of red wine. He once spent $16.7 million for 2 incense burners and another time paid $39 million for Paul Gauguin's "Te Poipoi" ("The Morning").  He owns a home in London's Tony Eaton Square. Son Ming-wai, coming into clearer focus as the heir apparent, was named vice chairman at the end of 2010. He once worked at Goldman Sachs, holds an attorney's license in New York and is now involved in the election campaign for Hong Kong's next chief executive, to be picked on March 25.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder Tsai Wan-tsai and his U.S.-educated sons Daniel and Richard have turned Fubon Financial into one of Taiwan's most successful financial institutions, expanding from a core in non-life insurance to a brokerage-to-bank business. The company is looking to expand through acquisitions and is eyeing China growth through a stake in Xiamen International Bank. Tsai is a major investor in Taipei Mobile and cable stations. Nephew T.Y. Tsai is also a billionaire.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zong Qinghou is one of the world's most successful beverage tycoons. He founded privately-held Wahaha in a minigrocery in the Chinese city of Hangzhou in 1986, and has ridden the wave of growth in Chinese consumer spending, supplying juice, bottled water, tea and juices.   Zong's daughter Kelly was named a woman to watch in Forbes Asia's  "Asia's Power Buisnesswomen" issue in March 2012.

name: Billionaires
bio: Texas-born Charles Butt started out as a bag boy at his father's supermarket at age 8. The Wharton and Harvard grad's H-E-B grocery chain now boasts annual sales of over $15 billion and has stores in Louisiana and Mexico, although it is still a regional chain, headquartered in San Antonio.The firm's Central Market gourmet and organic line increasingly competes with Whole Foods. H-E-B donates 5% of pretax profits to charity.

name: Billionaires
bio:
The richest man in Georgia in fall 2011 came out against Georgian President Mikhail Saakashvili. He created a new political party called Georgian Dream ? Democratic Georgia which is in the opposition coalition to take part in parliamentary elections. Wants to become prime minister of Georgia. Refused of Russian citizenship, intends to sell all of his assets in Russia. Saakashvili had stripped him of Georgian citizenship. Now he has only French citizenship. If before the election he will not get back Georgian citizenship, his wife will head the party of Georgian Dream.
Began building his empire in 1990 when, with partner Vitaly Malkin, he set up Rossiysky Kredit Bank. Over the years, sold businesses he accumulated during Russia's privatization era including ore mining and metals interests; invested proceeds in Russian stock market. Also has interests in elite real estate project in Moscow and two 5-star hotels. Owns Russian drugstore chain Doctor Stoletov. Collects the Impressionists; his most expensive painting is Dora Maar with Cat by Pablo Picasso, which he bought at Sotheby's in 2006 for $95 million. Lives in the Georgian village of Chorvila, where he was born.

name: Billionaires
bio: A New York native and brother of Samuel Irving (S.I.), Donald Newhouse oversees the newspaper portion of Advance Publications, which runs local papers in more than 25 American cities; Si takes care of magazines under the Condé Nast banner. Donald's fortune is up $800 million in the last year thanks to an increase in ad revenue and the stock performance of media and entertainment network Discovery Communications, in which he and Si own a stake. Discovery owns the Discovery Channel, Animal Planet, TLC and others. Although he dropped out of Syracuse University, Donald established the Wellesley Center for the Humanities at his wife Susan's alma mater.

name: Billionaires
bio: Once worth $30 billion and one of the 10 richest people in the world, Kushal Pal Singh's fortune shrunk further this year as shares of his flagship DLF fell. He is apparently looking to sell such assets as Amanresorts, a 17.5-acre plot in Mumbai, and stake in life insurance firm DLF Pramerica, in bid to reduce DLF's $4.8 billion debt load. Faced setback when the Competition Commission of India ordered company to pay $138 million as penalty for delaying the completion of a residential project in its 3,000-acre showpiece township in Gurgaon, near Delhi. DLF is contesting the ruling. A five-day celebration of his 80th birthday last November included a performance by pop star Shakira and the release of his autobiography titled Whatever The Odds:The Incredible Story Behind DLF

name: Billionaires
bio: A patron of the arts, sciences and education, Broad wants to give back more to society. In 2010, he was among the first to sign the Warren Buffett-Bill Gates Giving Pledge, to donate at least half his fortune. In September he weighed in on Buffett's call for the government to raise taxes on the rich. "Those of us who have gained great success have an obligation to pay more taxes," Broad told FORBES. "We've been coddled long enough and have tax breaks that 99.9% of the public don't have, and it's not fair." Broad bought his first patch of land at age 20. He co-founded Kaufman & Broad with $25,000 borrowed from his in-laws and became one of the nation's biggest home builders, supplying parents of baby boomers with affordable housing. In 1971 he bought Sun Life Insurance (later renamed SunAmerica) and sold it to AIG in 1998 for $18 billion in cash and stock. A contemporary art collector and regular face at Art Basel, Broad and wife Edythe created the Broad Art Foundation in 1984. Today they lend contemporary art to institutions around the world. Broad also supports education reform and scientific research in the fields of inflammatory bowel disease, human genomics and stem cells. The son of Lithuanian immigrants, Broad was born in the Bronx and raised in Detroit. Today he lives in Los Angeles, where he is the city's most influential arts patron.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Budi, inherited clove cigarette maker Djarum from their father but these days get bulk of their fortune from Bank Central Asia, country's largest private bank. Siblings also have palm oil interests, having picked up 65,000 hectares of land in West Kalimantan in 2008. Together they also own Grand Indonesia, a luxury shopping mall, office building and hotel complex in the center of Jakarta. Through their newly created Global Digital Prima Ventures, they also bought Kaskus, Indonesia's most popular website. Their Djarum, banned in the US since 2009 along with other clove cigarettes,  has launched Dos Hermanos, a premium cigar blending Brazilian and Indonesian tobaccos.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of Cox Enterprises founder James M. Cox (d. 1957), Kennedy is the company's chairman, after serving as CEO from 1988 to 2008. Since 1988, Cox revenues increased from $1.8 billion to nearly $15 billion. Cox Enterprises now includes cable company Cox Communications, Cox Media Group (newspapers, TV and radio stations), Manheim (car auctions) and AutoTrader.com. Kennedy inherited a 25% stake after his mother, Barbara Cox Anthony, passed away in 2007. Interested in wildlife habitat conservation, he is on the board of the PATH Foundation, a Georgia trail-building non-profit, and he established the James C. Kennedy endowed chair of waterfowl & wetlands management at Mississippi State University in 2008. A former competitive cyclist, he is a past Masters National, Pan American and World Champion in the 3000 meter pursuit.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Blair Parry-Okeden is the granddaughter of Cox Enterprises founder James M. Cox (d. 1957), Parry-Okeden inherited a 25% stake after her mother, Barbara Cox Anthony, passed away in 2007. Not active in family business, Parry-Okeden lives in near anonymity in Australia, making her one of that country's richest residents. Her brother Jim Kennedy, who also has a 25% stake, is chairman of the nearly $15 billion (revenues) group, whose holdings include cable company Cox Communications, Cox Media Group (newspapers, TV and radio stations), Manheim (car auctions) and AutoTrader.com.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chung Mong-Koo is the chairman of Hyundai Motors. Last year, the company ranked fifth automaker in the world by selling 6.6 million cars--including KIA. Sales in the U.S. soared, increasing market share from 3% in 2001 to 10% as of May 2011.

name: Billionaires
bio: He Xiangjian is co-founder of Midea Group, one of China's largest appliance makers and a rival of Maytag, Siemens and Haier. Sales at Shenzhen-listed flagship GD Midea Holding rose 43% in the nine months through September to $13 billion; net profit grew 10% to $460 million. This year the company forged a joint venture in India with U.S. air conditioner manufacturer Carrier, which is owned by United Technologies. That followed the purchase of a 51% stake in a South America joint venture from Carrier last year for $220 million, a move that will strengthen Midea's business in Brazil, Argentina and Chile.  He sold a combined 15% stake in his holding company to units of ICBC International Holdings and CDH Investments for an undisclosed amount at the end of last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hiroshi Mikitani is the outspoken chairman and chief executive of online shopping mall operator Rakuten. The company's stock price is up on it successful expansion abroad: last year it acquired Germany's Tradoria online mall, the UK's Play.com online retail site and others in Indonesia and Russia. Rakuten also has a China online mall in venture with Baidu.com. It is moving into e-books with acquisition of Canada's Kobe e-reader firm. At the same time, Rakuten is petitioning the Japan Fair Trade Commission to examine Yahoo Japan's tie-up with Google as a net monopoly. Mikitani is active on twitter: http://twitter.com/#!/hmikitani and owns the Tohoku Rakuten Golden Eagles baseball team. Rakuten donated $3.7 million to earthquake relief efforts and raised millions more via Rakuten Securities and digital wallet service Edy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Idan and his older brother Eyal inherited a fortune from their father, shipping magnate and formerly Israel's richest man, Sammy Ofer, who died in June 2011. He is the principal of Quantum Pacific Group, which holds the Ofer stake in Israel Corporation, the largest public holding company on the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange; and Pacific Drilling SA, which went public on the NYSE last year. He is also chairman of Better Place, the Silicon Valley electric car infrastructure startup. He shares his father's shipping empire and vast art collection, said to be one of the most magnificent in the world, with Eyal. The brothers inherited the fortune of their father, shipping magnate and formerly Israel's richest man, Sammy Ofer, after he passed away last year. The brothers' fortunes were equal upon their father's passing, and their spokesmen claim that their fortunes are still virtually equal. While we can accurately confirm Idan's public stakes in Israel Corp and Pacific Drilling, we apply more conservative valuations to Eyal's less transparent private holdings. In May 2011, The Ofer Brothers Group along with Singapore-based Tanker Pacific, an, affiliate, were sanctioned by the US State Department for their involvement in the sale of an oil tanker to Iran. In September, the State Department clarified that the sanctions applied to three entities affiliated with the Ofer brothers, but not to the group itself, which has been disbanded.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tsai Eng-Meng built a fortune in the snack business on the mainland, using experience gained with the same products back home in Taiwan. In addition to its rice crackers and nuts,Tsai's Want Want China is also turning itself into a beverage company. Sales in the first six months of 2011 were up 28% to $1.3 billion; net profit edged up to $167 million. Tsai listed Want Want Holdings in Singapore in 1996, only to delist in 2007 and transfer its food and beverage business to a new Hong Kong listing, Want Want China, in 2008. Tsai is also in the media, hotel and insurance industries.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kjeld Kirk Kristiansen is the grandson of the founder of LEGO, the third-largest toy manufacturer in the world in terms of sales ($3 billion). Kristiansen served as LEGO's chief executive for 25 years before stepping down in 2004; he remains the company's majority owner and vice chairman of the board. During his tenure he introduced a number of new ideas to modernize the firm, including Star Wars and Lord of the Rings-themed LEGOs and the popular mini-figures (4 billion produced). After restructuring and selling off some assets, including the Legoland amusement parks, the company has been profitable since 2006. Kristiansen also started the Next Generation Foundation which is focused on children's development through creativity and play.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers Paolo & Gianfelice Rocca, both Italian citizens, inherited 10% stakes in Italian holding company Techint Financial Corporation from their late father, Roberto Rocca, who apparently left equal parts to his three children. The oldest son Agostino died in a plane crash. The remaining brothers share through Techint a 20% stake in both Ternium and Tenaris, Argentina's largest firms in the fields of seamless and welded steel pipe products and flat and long steel. Paolo, 58, is president of both companies. He lives in San Isidro, a suburb of Buenos Aires, and owns a vacation home in Uruguay. Older brother Gianfelice, 61, is president of Humanitas, a health care company based in Italy, where he resides.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vladimir Yevtushenkov added to his oil empire in January 2010, picking up a 49% stake in Russneft from the company's founder Mikhail Gutseriev for $100 million; now the oil magnate is angling to merge oil producer Bashneft, in which his AFK Sistema conglomerate has a controlling stake, with Russneft. Yevtushenkov's London-listed AFK Sistema is a sprawling operation with interests in some 200 companies ranging from microchips to toy stores.  Since 2008 Sistema has controlled the Indian Sistema Shyam Teleservices Ltd.  Yevtushenkov, a former plastics engineer, co-founded Sistema in 1993. Early on, Sistema created a joint venture with Moscow's municipal telephone network (MTS) and later received a controlling stake in the network, along with its main assets, which included MTS (now the largest cellular operator in Russia, traded on the NYSE).  Yevtushenkov took Sistema public on the London Stock Exchange in 2005.

name: Billionaires
bio: In front of an audience of businessmen, Sulaiman Al Rajhi announced plans in May 2011 to donate the bulk of his fortune to charity. "How can you satisfy your hunger while your neighbor is spending the night hungry?" he asked. His drop in net worth from $7.7 billion in 2011 reflects an estimated donation of part of his fortune. Al Rajhi, one of Saudi Arabia's richest men, became wealthy by founding with his brothers one of the world's largest Islamic banks, Al Rajhi Bank. He's also in the process of transferring his fortune to his heirs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Silvio Berlusconi is out of office and out of jail, at least for now. The former Italian Prime Minister resigned in November amid scandals, gaffes and a crumbling economy. This past February, the media and banking maven had corruption charges thrown out of Italian court thanks to a statute of limitations, but he still faces separate charges for sex with a minor and tax fraud. He denies all allegations. Berlusconi started his career as a singer on cruise ships, and later built his fortune through Fininvest, which now has interests in media, life insurance, movie production and soccer team A.C. Milan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kunio Busujima is the founder of Sankyo, the pachinko gambling-machine maker, now run by his son Hideyuki. The company's sales have been declining steadily during past five years due to the game's declining popularity. For the first half of 2012 fiscal year, the company expects turnover to decline by nearly 40%; the company' stock price has suffered as a result, down 20% over the past year. Sankyo is looking for a boost from new games like Fever X Japan, a collaboration with a popular rock band, introduced in September 2010 to attract younger players.

name: Billionaires
bio: Last year Beny Steinmetz poured $100 million into his real estate company, Scorpio, in exchange for rescheduling debt payments until 2018. That followed a $130 million loan from Steinmetz to fuel ­operations. However, his fortune was buoyed by selling 51% of his iron ore company in Guinea to Brazil's Vale for $2.5 billion. His group ­recently announced that ­­spinoff diamond mine company Octea plans to list its shares on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. With his wife, Steinmetz oversees the Beny & Agnes Steinmetz Foundation, which donates to schools, hospitals, army units and the arts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Andrew Forrest tried in the 1990s, unsuccessfully, to make his name as a pioneer of a technology to produce the steel hardening metal nickel, but he enjoyed much greater success in the simpler business of digging up and delivering iron ore to China. Descendant of a pioneering Australian family of explorers and farmers, he has challenged, and beaten, some of the world's biggest mining companies, building his own railway and port systems when they refused to carry his ore. He has been a strong advocate of job creation for Australia's under-privileged Aboriginal people. Twiggy, as his is widely known, has appealed to Australia's highest court in a bid to overturn a ruling that he should be banned as a director for making misleading comments to investors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hui Ka Yan has overcome a tough year for the China property market by moving units in a hurry. Sales in the first half of last year at Evergrande, the Guangzhou developer he founded in 1997, rose 60% to $5 billion. The company's Hong Kong-traded shares edged up in the past year, helping to bump up Hui's wealth from $5.1 billion in 2011. Evergrande currently has 181  large-scale projects under way in 101 cities. It has a soccer team and is also investing in movie production. Hui is a member of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, and vice chairman of the China Enterprise Federation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Johnson passed the chairmanship of Fidelity's flagship mutual fund business to his daughter Abigail in 2011, fueling rumors that he may soon retire. "Ned" joined his father's company, Fidelity Investments, as an analyst in 1957. In 1965 Johnson took the reins of Fidelity's storied Magellan Fund and seven years later was named president of the firm. Johnson rapidly expanded Fidelity's market share by pioneering funds for virtually every investment strategy. Though he reduced his personal stake for estate planning purposes in 1995, the Johnson family still holds 49% of the company. Today the firm has over $1.5 trillion under management and also runs a sizable brokerage business, an insurance outfit, and a private equity shop. Fidelity's Magellan Fund, however, currently manages just $17 billion, dramatically less than the more than $100 billion the fund had under management at its peak in the 1990s. The Johnsons continue to enjoy summers at Ned's seaside estate on Mount Desert Island in Maine.

name: Billionaires
bio: Liu Yongxing first made money with his brothers in the quail-breeding business and later sold animal feed in western China. Each brother went his own way in the 1990s. Yongxing's East Hope Group has emerged as one of China's largest non-government companies, having expanded in recent years in aluminum products, plastics and cement. East Hope is still one of China's largest animal-feed producers, with operations in Vietnam, Indonesia. Only son Shawn, a graduate of the University of Southern California, is heir apparent. Liu's brother Liu Yonghao is also a billionaire.

name: Billionaires
bio: Eyal and his younger brother Idan  inherited a fortune from their father, shipping magnate and formerly Israel's richest man, Sammy Ofer, who died in June 2011. He has since taken on the family's stake in Royal Caribbean Cruise Lines, Mizrahi Tefahot bank, and the family's international real estate, including the Altria Building and 15 Central Park West in New York. He shares his father's shipping empire and vast art collection, said to be one of the most magnificent in the world, with Idan. Eyal Ofer and younger brother Idan inherited the fortune of their father, shipping magnate and formerly Israel's richest man, Sammy Ofer, after he passed away last year. The brothers' fortunes were equal upon their father's passing, and their spokesmen claim that their fortunes are still virtually equal. While we can accurately confirm Idan's public stakes in Israel Corp and Pacific Drilling, we apply more conservative valuations to Eyal's less transparent private holdings. In May 2011, The Ofer Brothers Group along with Singapore-based Tanker Pacific, an, affiliate, were sanctioned by the US State Department for their involvement in the sale of an oil tanker to Iran. In September, the State Department clarified that the sanctions applied to three entities affiliated with the Ofer brothers, but not to the group itself, which has been disbanded.

name: Billionaires
bio: New Zealand's richest person continues to build his packaging empire. His Rank Group bought Graham Packaging, which makes plastic bottles for customers such as Pepsico and Heinz, for an estimated $1.7 billion in the summer. Rank also bought America's Pactiv, maker of Hefty garbage bags for around $4.4 billion in 2010. Rank's past acquisitions have included Australasian forest products group Carter Holt Harvey, Swiss packager SIG, Alcoa's former packaging unit, Reynolds Consumer Products and Closure Systems International. Hart drew up the idea for Rank as an M.B.A. student at University of Otago in New Zealand. A boating enthusiast, Hart owns 190-foot yacht Ulysses, which is reportedly on sale, and is working on his new prize, the superyacht Weta.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shares of his casino outfit Galaxy Entertainment were up three-fourths last year as mainland visitors continued to pour into Macau, the only place in China where gambling is legal. Galaxy now has the second-largest market share among the enclave's six casino operators, which is particularly noteworthy as it had no previous experience in the gambling industry when licenses were awarded a decade ago. The only major casino to open in the former Portuguese colony last year was its new $2 billion resort on the Cotai Strip. Eldest son Francis Lui, 55, manages the gambling business as Galaxy's vice-chairman. Lui's four other children also work in the family's business empire that includes the Hong Kong-listed property firm K. Wah International and San Francisco-based Stanford Hotels.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sergei Popov reduced his share in SUEK to less than 25% as he and long-time business partner and fellow billionaire Andrey Melnichenko continued to divide their assets. Popov graduated from Ural Polytechnic Institute in 1993. He partnered with Melnichenko to found Industrial group MDM; the pair began to buy assets, creating TMK, Russia's largest pipe exporter; Eurochem, the country's largest mineral-fertilizer producer; and SUEK, Russia's largest independent coal produce. In 2006 the partners started splitting their assets; in 2011 they divided SUEK. Popov merged his MDM Bank with Igor Kim's Siberian Ursa Bank in 2008. Last year Kim sold his 11% stake to Popov's MDM Bank, which distributed the shares in a still-undisclosed manner among the remaining shareholders; official documents say Popov owns a 56.3% stake.

name: Billionaires
bio: Marcel Telles shares control of Anheuser-Busch InBev, the world's largest beer company, with longtime billionaire partners Jorge Paulo Lemann and Carlos Alberto Sicupira. Their investment firm 3G Capital bought hamburger chain Burger King in 2010 and is working to turn it around. The trio also control Brazilian retailer Lojas Americanas.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of China's richest women, Wu Yajun chairs Beijing-based property developer Longfor Properties. Company weathered China's tight-credit policies in the past year with multiple new projects. Improved sales helped to keep its Hong Kong-listed shares on even keel at a time when the broader market was down. Company was cited in a Moody's report this summer that expressed concerns about accounting and governance issues at 160 Chinese companies. It decided to cancel a planned share sale in July.  Longfor said in August that Wu would step down as CEO but stay on as chairman. A former journalist, Wu is influential in government as a member of the National People's Congress.

name: Billionaires
bio: Viktor Rashnikov resigned from his post of CEO of MMK after 14 years in 2011, though he remains chairman of the company's board. Rashnikov began his career at Magnitogorsk Iron & Steel mill (MMK) in 1967 as a mechanic, but eventually became its general director. He built his stake to nearly 100% by buying shares on the market; Rashnikov also fought takeover attempts by companies associated with fellow billionaire Iskander Makhmudov. When he faced problems with iron ore supply, he bought the shares (with partners) of one of the biggest iron ore deposits in Russia. In 2007, Rashnikov took MMK public on the London Stock Exchange and pocketed around $1 billion; however the vast majority of his wealth remains tied up in the stock. Outside of MMK, Rashnikov invests in real estate, including the construction of the Rossiya Hotel and a wedding palace in Moscow.

name: Billionaires
bio: A 2010 inductee to the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame, Geffen bought the 377-foot "Pelorus" yacht from Russian billionaire Roman Abramovitch last year for a reported $300 million. Geffen's fortune continues to rise thanks to the increasing value of his massive contemporary art collection. He owns a stake in DreamWorks Studio, although he is no longer involved in that business (he departed in 2008). He founded Asylum Records and Geffen Records, launching the careers of the Eagles, Aerosmith and Guns N' Roses. In 1990 he sold out to MCA for $550 million. Geffen got his start sorting mail at the William Morris talent agency. With partners Jeffrey Katzenberg and Steven Spielberg he launched DreamWorks SKG in 1995.

name: Billionaires
bio: It's been a year of mixed fortunes for Taiwan's Terry Gou and his electronics contract manufacturer Hon Hai Precision. Known in the industry by its trade name, Foxconn, and with a client list that includes Apple, Sony and HP, it has been battling slower growth, rising wages, tough competition and increased scrutiny. In February, the company said it would raise base pay for mainland factory workers by up to 25%. After a big drop in its shares for much of last year, Hon Hai has rallied since August on hopes of a global uptick in growth

name: Billionaires
bio: Dietmar Hopp cofounded German software firm SAP with four former IBM colleagues. He served as co-CEO of SAP from 1988 until 1998 and chairman of the company's supervisory board from 1998 until 2003. He stepped down from his place on the board in 2005, but kept 10% of the company's shares after leaving. After Hopp left in 2005, the street on which SAP is headquartered was renamed to Dietmar-Hopp-Allee. In 2006, Hopp transferred 70% of his wealth to a charitable foundation, Dietmar Hopp Stiftung, which supports sports, medicine, education and social programs. Hopp is the chief financial backer of the German football club TSG 1899 Hoffenheim, where he played in the club's youth setup as a boy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Blackstone's chairman, CEO and co-founder has seen his wealth fluctuate along with his company's stock. The investment firm's shares are almost back to where they were at this time last year, after plunging in the third quarter of 2011 and then rebounding nearly 40%. While at Yale (former President George W. Bush was a classmate), Schwarzman founded a ballet society to meet girls. In 2008 he donated $100 million to the New York Public Library and had the main Fifth Avenue branch named after him. Schwarzman has made news recently because of his support for Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Blackstone Group', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Bangkok street vendor, Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi made his fortune selling inexpensive beer and whiskey. He's been lately increasing his stake in Thai Bev, Thailand's largest brewer and maker of Chang Beer, which he took public in Singapore in 2006. He owns Bangkok's famous tech-mall Pantip Plaza, Hotel Plaza Athenee in Manhattan, plus hotels in Asia, the United States and Australia, residential, commercial and retail buildings in Singapore and Thailand. Berli Jucker, listed conglomerate he controls, saw stock price more than triple in past year. Last September, he took over PepsiCo's local bottler.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alexander Abramov and his partners exchanged shares with Luxembourg's Evraz Group S.A. last October, gaining shares in steel outfit Evraz Plc, a new company that debuted on the London Stock Exchange in November. It's been a long road to get there: Abramov got his start as the head of a research lab before the Soviet Union collapsed. In 1992, he established a precursor to Evraz Holding and made a fortune exporting metals and coal from the Urals and Siberia. After the 1998 Russian financial crisis, Abramov bought up hobbled steel companies and coal mines on the cheap. In 2006, he partnered with fellow billionaire Roman Abramovich in Evraz. In 2007, they made a number of acquisitions, including U.S. firms Claymont Steel Holdings of Delaware and Oregon Steel Mills. Abramov was elected chairman of Evraz in December 2008, replacing fellow billionaire Alexander Frolov with whom he cofounded the group.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Adani Enterprises and India's largest private sector port operator faced setbacks; was denied security clearance by the government while bidding for several port projects. Facing no such problem overseas, he bought Australia's Abbott Point coal terminal for $1.8 billion in May. Shares, down by 40% in past year, took hit over allegations that group was involved in illegal mining of iron ore in Karnataka state; it denied any wrongdoing. Power generation unit Adani Power, which plans to produce 20,000 megawatts by 2020, expanded into solar energy. He's planning to spinoff real estate arm and take it private. Group recently unveiled a new corporate logo.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Budapest in 1944 during a Russian bombing raid, Peterffy emigrated to the United States in 1965. When he arrived in New York he spoke no English. In 1977 Peterffy left his job designing commodities trading software and purchased his own seat on the American Stock Exchange where he began trading options. In 1993 he launched the electronic brokerage firm Interactive Brokers. The firm paid its first dividend to investors in December 2010, dolling out a whopping $1 billion. Interactive Brokers was in talks to acquire the majority of MF Global's operating assets as that firm imploded in October 2011. Interactive's due diligence uncovered information that immediately killed the deal: hundreds of millions of missing customer dollars. An avid equestrian, Peterffy keeps horses at his Greenwich estate.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brooklyn native and former credit analyst Rennert made the first chunk of his fortune in the 1980s junk bond market. Today his Renco Group is one of the largest holding companies in the U.S. In 1992, Rennert paid $133 million for military contractor AM General, which started selling consumer Hummers. In 2004, Rennert sold a majority stake to billionaire Ronald Perelman's MacAndrews & Forbes for $930 million. Renco's current holdings include RG Steel, US Magnesium and the Doe Run Company. The Doe Run mining facility in Peru is the subject of an environmental pollution suit. Rennert's 43,000-square-foot home in Sagaponack, N.Y. is one of the largest dwellings in the nation, with 29 bedrooms and 39 baths. Rennert gives regularly to Jewish causes, recently donating a Torah to New York City's trendy SoHo Synagogue.

name: Billionaires
bio: Johann Graf is the founder and sole owner of Novomatic Group of companies, an international gambling group with businesses in more than 31 countries.  A butcher by profession, Graf started his gaming career in 1974  importing American pinball machines to Austria. Now the company is one of the world's largest manufacturers of electronic betting machines. It operates over 160,000 gaming machines in some 1,000 traditional and electronic casinos in Germany, Croatia, Switzerland, the Czech Republic and Slovenia; also present in Latin America where it runs Chile's Casino Resort Monticello. In September 2011 the company mentioned the possibility of an initial public offering. The Novomatic Group consists of Novomatic AG and two Swiss entities, ACE Casino Holding AG and Gryphon Invest AG, and had turnover in 2010 of nearly $3.6 billion.  Eldest son Thomas heads one subsidiary, Austrian Gaming Industries. A car buff, Johann owns some 120 vintage Jaguar models.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jeffrey Hildebrand is coming off a big year, having turned a $100 million investment in the Eagle Ford shale of Texas into a multi-billion-dollar payday, with a $3.5 billion sale to Marathon Oil. Hildebrand has already reinvested in Cook Inlet, Alaska. In 1989, he left a safe career at Exxon and founded Hilcorp Energy. The company started small, just three guys and a telephone. It bought proven fields that were too small for the supermajors, and then used advanced technology to boost efficiency. By 2003, Hildebrand was able to buy out partner Thomas Hook for $500 million.
