Hilcorp did well enough last year that every employee got $50,000 to buy a new car. Hildebrand is ultra private, but a fixture of Houston's social scene. He donates to Texas Childrens' Hospital, Star of Hope Missions, Boys & Girls Clubs, Houston Livestock Show & Rodeo.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dietrich Mateschitz, a former marketing executive, created the Red Bull energy drink with Thai business partner Chaleo Yoovidhya. He markets the drink to young people using cheeky advertising and extreme-sports sponsorships. A Taurus (the zodiac sign of the bull), Mateschitz owns 49% of the $5 billion (sales) company, which still plans to expand to China. Now also present in France, Denmark and Norway, where it had been banned because of its contents; it is still banned in Iceland and Uruguay. Thanks to higher sales figures, Mateschitz's net worth rose $300 million since last year. The company has stakes in two soccer teams: Red Bull Salzburg and New York Red Bulls; also a Formula One team, Red Bull Racing. Mateschitz's other interests include Seitenblicke magazine; Servus TV; a luxury resort on the island of Laucala in Fiji; and Hangar-7, the event center on the grounds of Salzburg airport that houses his historical aircraft collection, the Flying Bulls.

name: Billionaires
bio: Built IOI Group into one of the world's biggest palm oil producers and one of the country's biggest property developers. Group employs 30,000 worldwide. Grew up on a rubber plantation where his father ran a Chinese food shop. Left school at 11 to help support his family, selling ice cream on a bicycle for 4 years before returning to finish high school. All of his children now work for his companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Carlos Alberto Sicupira shares control of Anheuser-Busch InBev, the world's largest beer company, with longtime billionaire partners Jorge Paulo Lemann and Marcel Telles. Their investment firm 3G Capital bought hamburger chain Burger King in 2010 and is working to turn it around. The trio also control listed Brazilian retailer Lojas Americanas.

name: Billionaires
bio: Reinhold Wurth took over his father's tiny screw business at 19 and turned it into the $11.4 billion (FY 2010 sales) Wurth Group. A maker of fasteners, the company also has interests in a bank and a solar energy firm. Now retired, Wurth rides a Harley-Davidson and has a professional pilot's license. A holder of an honorary doctorate in art history from the University of Palermo, Wurth maintains a vast art collection that includes works by Emil Nolde, Alfred Hrdilicka and Pablo Picasso. Last year, Wurth acquired "Schutzmantelmadonna," one of the most famous paintings from Hans Holbein the Younger. The purchase price was kept secret, but some media outlets have speculated that it is the highest price ever paid for a work of art in Germany.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Bulgheroni brothers turned Bridas, an oil services company founded by their father, into Argentina's second largest oil and gas company. In March 2010, China's National Overseas Oil Co. (CNOOC) paid $3.1 billion for a 50% stake in privately held Bridas. Through Bridas, the brothers hold a 20% stake in oil and gas producer PanAmerican Energy (PAE). Last year, Bridas agreed to buy an additional 60% of PAE from troubled British oil giant BP for $7.1 billion, but it terminated the deal in November. In a separate deal, PAE bought the local operations of ExxonMobile for $800 million. Alejandro, 68, lives in Argentina; Carlos, 66, lives in Rome.

name: Billionaires
bio: Media magnate Malone's stocks in Liberty Media, Liberty Global, and Discovery Communications have all risen in the last year, driving his net worth higher. The former partner of TCI Cable founder Bob Magness (d. 1996), sold what was then the nation's largest cable company to AT&T in 1999 for $54 billion. Today his Liberty Media owns stakes in cell phones (Sprint Nextel), Internet (Expedia), pro baseball's Atlanta Braves. In 2009, Malone paid $530 million for a 40% stake in Sirius XM, saving the satellite radio operator from bankruptcy and beating out rival Charles Ergen's Dish Network. In 2010, Malone stepped down as interim chairman of the board at concert and ticket company Live Nation and unwound his 17-year partnership at InterActiveCorp with Barry Diller. Malone recently gave $7 million to the Denver School of Science and Technology and $50 million to Yale, his alma mater. Last year, he surpassed Ted Turner as the U.S.'s largest individual landowner, with nearly 2.2 million acres.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ludwig Merckle is the son and sole heir of Adolf Merckle (d. 2009). He studied business informatics at the University of Mannheim and headed the Merckle Group from 1997 until 2008, when Oliver Windholz took over. In May 2009 after his father died, he inherited the group and began restructuring it. He sold the pharmaceutical company Ratiopharm and a large stake of HeidelbergCement. In three years he has managed to turn around a floundering fortune.

name: Billionaires
bio: Johann Rupert is South Africa's luxury goods billionaire. He serves as chairman and chief executive officer of Richemont, a publicly traded Swiss holding company that controls brands such as Vacheron Constantin, Cartier, Alfred Dunhill, Montblanc and Chloé. In 2010 Richemont acquired online fashion portal Net-a-Porter for $343 million. Sales at the Richemont group were up 24% in the third quarter ended December 2011 over the year prior, driven largely by demand for luxury goods in Asia where revenues rose 36% in the same period. Rupert also chairs South Africa-based Remgro Ltd and Reinet Investments Manager. The latter was created in 2009 as a home for Remgro's stake in British American Tobacco after that firm was taken public. While British American Tobacco still accounts for over 80% of Reinet's net asset value, the firm is taking steps to diversify by investing British American dividend payments across several industries. An avid golfer, Rupert had only played 21 times in 2011 through October due to his busy work schedule. He recently made headlines for his opposition to Royal Dutch Shell's planned hydraulic fracturing operations in the Karoo region of South Africa, where he owns extensive conservation land.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nassef Sawiris runs Orascom Construction Industries, Egypt's most valuable publicly-traded company, which was founded by father Onsi. This past December, the company announced plans to split its construction and fertilizer businesses into two publicly traded companies in the first quarter of 2012. In the U.S., Sawiris increased his stake in struggling cement producer Texas Industries last December, after the company ended an agreement that prevented Sawiris from acquiring more than 20% of TI. In October, Sawiris hooked up with Brazilian billionaire Eike Batista's EBX Group to develop a nitrogen fertilizer plant in Brazil.

name: Billionaires
bio: David Tepper's Appaloosa Management was down in 2011, a year in which the entire hedge fund industry struggled. The average fund lost 5% last year while Appaloosa's Palomino Fund returned -5.09% after fees, though Tepper is reportedly up through mid-February of 2012. Tepper divested his stakes in Bank of America, Yahoo, HP, and Pfizer in 2011. He also reportedly dumped Wells Fargo, and bought shares in GM and oil refiners. Tepper is currently a minority owner of the Pittsburgh Steelers. He razed the Sagaponack beach house he had bought from Jon Corzine's ex-wife for $43 million. He gave $55 million to Carnegie Mellon's business school in 2004; it was renamed Tepper School of Business. He has also donated $7 million to food banks. Tepper was formerly the head trader on a high yield desk at Goldman Sachs; he failed to make partner and left to start Appaloosa in 1993.
title: President and Founder
employment: {'name': 'Appaloosa Management', 'title': 'President and Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Amway co-founder Richard DeVos's fortune has risen even during tough economic times as his private company (reorganized as Alticor in 2000) recently notched its 11th sales increase in the last 12 years. He met Amway partner Jay Van Andel (d. 2004) in high school when DeVos offered Van Andel 25 cents a week for a ride to school. The entrepreneurial pair opened a drive-in diner after DeVos's two-year stint in the Air Force. They began selling all-purpose cleaner to friends, family, and door-to-door in 1959. Today, 3 million salespeople peddle Amway's personal care and home products in more than 80 countries. DeVos retired in 1993; his son Doug is president. DeVos owns the NBA's Orlando Magic. In 2010 he opened the $480 million Amway Center for the team.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ray L. Hunt, the son of legendary wildcatter H.L. Hunt, has been building on his inheritance for nearly 40 years. Hunt Consolidated owns hotels and office parks around Dallas, and oil and gas worldwide. Bold moves include liquefied natural gas projects in Peru and Yemen and drilling for oil in northern Iraq. This year Hunt sold a one-third stake in Eagle Ford shale fields to Japan's Marubeni for $1.3 billion. Last year the company sold Canadian oil fields to the Korean government for $520 million, and raised $600 million to build a high-voltage power line in Texas. Torch passing underway: last year Ray Hunt relinquished the chief executive role to son Hunter Hunt.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers James and Arthur Irving head of the family's New Brunswick business conglomerate. Dominating the local economy, Irving Group of Companies interests include oil, natural gas, gas stations, timber, paper products, shipbuilding, construction, agriculture, building supplies, newspapers, radio stations, and even a Canadian Hockey League team. In October 2011 Irving Shipbuilding's Halifax Yard won a monstrous federal contract to build $25 billion worth of frigates, destroyers and patrol ships for the Canadian military. The Irving empire was founded in 1881 by the brothers' grandfather, J.D. Irving. James and Arthur's brother and business partner, John, died at age 78 in 2010.

name: Billionaires
bio: Karl-Heinz Kipp is one of Germany's post-World War II retail pioneers. He began his career in 1948 selling clothes and opened the first Massa department store in 1965. He sold the chain in 1986, but smartly held on to the underlying real estate, which he now rents to retailer Metro. Kipp has divested his real estate in the U.S., notably 950 Third Avenue and several other high-end properties in Manhattan. He owns four Swiss luxury hotels and resorts including the Hotel Eden Roc in Ascona; the Carlton Hotel in St. Moritz and the Tschuggen Grand Hotel in Arosa, where he lives with his wife, Hannelore.

name: Billionaires
bio: LeFrak and his family saw their enormous real estate portfolio increase in value in 2011 along with the rest of the New York City market. LeFrak's grandfather, Harry, began developing properties in 1901 and his father, Sam, expanded the family's operations in New York City and New Jersey.  Richard joined the business in the 1970s and became chairman after Sam died in 2003.  The family owns 5,000 apartments in LeFrak City, Queens, and 16 million square feet of commercial, residential, and retail properties in Newport, N.J. LeFrak Energy owns interests in 851 onshore producing oil and gas wells and opened an office in Houston in August 2010. In February, the family firm, together with two partners, bought the luxury Gansevoort hotel, private beach and retail venues in Miami's South Beach.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shiv Nadar cofounded $6 billion (revenues) HCL Group 36 years ago in a garage. His biggest asset today is a 64% stake in flagship HCL Technologies, among India's top 5 software firms. He no longer runs operations, saying he spends bulk of time on philanthropy. His Shiv Nadar Foundation, which is run by daughter Roshni, has set up the Shiv Nadar University in Delhi. Wife Kiran, an art collector, has an art museum in Delhi

name: Billionaires
bio: Cell phone tycoon Denis O'Brien received the National Order of Honour and Merit form the Haitian president for his work helping Haiti recover from the 2010 earthquake. He funded the restoration of Haiti's century-old Iron Market with his own money, and has built 50 primary and secondary schools in the last 18 months. In 2010, Digicel bought out sister company Digicel Pacific for $825 million. O'Brien's other holdings include radio stations, online recruiting sites in China, and a Portuguese resort. The son of a human rights activist created the nonprofit organization Front Line to fly activists out of harm's way.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Public Bank, now Malaysia's third-largest banking group. Group also owns one of the largest private mutual fund management companies in the country, is reportedly bidding for an Islamic insurance license and has gotten a brokerage license in Cambodia. He is also a big shareholder of LPI Capital, a general insurance company in Malaysia and Singapore.

name: Billionaires
bio: Norwegian real estate magnate Olav Thon's fortune jumped in the last year, as his private hotel and property company has seen solid gains. He bought his first building in 1951 and opened his first restaurant in 1966. Now his Olav Thon Gruppen, the country's largest private real estate company, owns 425 properties in Norway and 25 abroad. The portfolio includes 61 shopping malls as well as office buildings, retail stores, hotels (7,000 rooms) and several Oslo restaurants and pubs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dennis Washington completed a nearly four year, estimated $200 million renovation on his latest yacht, the breathtaking 332-foot Attessa IV;  it was awarded the World Retrofit Yacht of the year in 2011. It's the 10th yacht he's fixed up over the years. Another recently finished project is the $30 million construction of a middle school campus at the Washington Family Ranch, the Oregon camp he donated to Young Life, a Christian youth organization. Altogether he's spent $60 million on the camp. Washington made his luck and fortune "the old fashioned way," in businesses like construction, railways and mining. His Washington Co. controls a copper mine in Butte, a tugboat and barge business in Vancouver, and Montana Rail Link. The child of divorced parents, he had a tough start, "I went to seven grade schools. I was a god damn cripple," he says, referring to his childhood bout with polio, from which he fully recovered. He eventually settled down in Montana with his grandparents. After working for his uncle's construction company he went out on his own and got a $30,000 loan from a local Caterpillar dealer to start his own highway construction firm. Though he doesn't spend much time in the office these days, Washington still gets updates at least every other day and signs off on any transaction. "I know what's going on, so I can stop and raise hell," he says. He will be receiving the Norman Vincent Peale Award from the Horatio Alger organization in April in Washington, DC.

name: Billionaires
bio: Energy drink pioneer Chaleo Yoovidhya died on March 17 of natural causes. He was age 89. The Thai tycoon was the low key partner behind iconic energy drink Red Bull. He devloped the drink formula while Austrian partner, Dietrich Mateschitz, with whom he partnered in 1984, created the marketing buzz. Yoovidhya  owned 49% of the privately held company. His son Chalerm holds 2%.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jean-Claude Decaux founded JCDecaux, an outdoor advertising company, in 1964; its first contract was to install ads on bus shelters in Lyon. In 2010, it overtook its rivals to become the largest outdoor advertising company in the world. On any given day, more than 300 million people in 3,600 of the world's largest cities might see its ads on bus shelters, public toilets or billboards, in malls, subways and airports. The firm is also a leading provider of eco-friendly transportation in big cities, including bicycles for hire. Decaux is chairman of the supervisory board; he handed the reins to his  sons Jean-Francois and Jean-Charles, who are co-chief executives of the board, in 2000.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sergei Galitsky's Magnit supermarket and cosmetics shop chain made a secondary public offering in December, and the founder and CEO reduced his stake from 46% to about 38% while preserving his ability to control corporate decisions. Galitsky started out as a perfume and beauty supplies wholesaler in 1994. Four years later, the Wal-Mart admirer established Magnit, a chain of grocery stores with the slogan "Always Low Prices." (Wal-Mart's slogan has long been "Everyday Low Prices."). He took the company public in April 2006. Galitsky also has investments in agriculture, development, tourism and advertising. He has bought a business jet and a yacht.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers Hank and Doug Meijer are co-chairmen of Grand Rapids, Michigan-based Meijer grocery chain. Hank is also CEO. The company was founded in 1934 by their grandfather Hendrik, who hired son Frederik to stock shelves. Father and son launched Meijer Thrifty Acres in 1962 and pioneered one-stop shopping, now the staple of competitors like Wal-Mart. Frederik led the company from 1964 until he passed the reigns to his sons in 1990. He remained active in the business until his death in November 2011. The company has recently moved away from its superstore roots, investing in a handful of smaller, more upscale grocery stores called Meijer Marketplace. The 78-year-old company still derives the bulk of its revenues, estimated at $14.6 billion for 2010, from its big-box stores across five states.

name: Billionaires
bio: Intel co-founder and chairman emeritus Gordon Moore now focuses on philanthropy. His Gordon & Betty Moore Foundation awards approximately $200 million annually to support environmental conservation and fundamental science, plus science and technology museums and nursing care in the San Francisco Bay area. Recent donations include a collaboration with the Howard Hughes Medical Institute on plant science research. The foundation is also the largest donor toward the construction of the world's biggest telescope, known as the Thirty Meter Telescope, in Moore's part-time resident state of Hawaii. The foundation donated $50 million for its design and pledged $200 million for the telescope's construction. Moore studied chemistry at U.C. Berkeley and earned a Ph.D. in chemistry and physics from Caltech. He co-founded Intel in 1968 and was chief executive until 1987. Four decades ago he came up with Moore's Law, which posits that computing power will double every 18 months (later updated to 2 years).
title: Cofounder and Chairman Emeritus
employment: {'name': 'Intel', 'uri': 'companies/intel', 'title': 'Cofounder and Chairman Emeritus', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Property baron Sam Zell is bullish on developing markets. His private investment firm, Equity International, has $2 billion invested overseas, including $1 billion in Brazil and investments in Mexico, Colombia, Peru, Chile, China and Egypt. Zell is also still betting on U.S. real estate. Last summer he bought a controlling stake in a 40-story Chicago tower, valuing the property at $106 million. Zell began dabbling in real estate while in college. He made his first fortune buying and selling properties from distressed owners. In 2007, he sold Equity Office Properties to Blackstone for $39 billion. Also in 2007, Zell bought the Tribune Co. in a deal saddled with $13 billion in debt. Declines in ad revenue forced it into bankruptcy less than a year later and employees sued, claiming Zell, Tribune Co. and GreatBanc Trust had violated federal pension laws when they created an employee stock ownership plan to finance the deal. Though Zell and Tribune were dismissed from the suit, employees settled with GreatBanc Trust for $32 million in August.

name: Billionaires
bio: Isak Andic opened his first apparel store in Barcelona in 1984. Today his $1.6 billion (sales) retailer Mango gets more than 80% of sales outside of Spain and operates more than 2060 stores in 104 countries, from the Dutch Antilles to China. The group, known for producing reasonably priced, trendy women's apparel, has opened 800 "corner" stores within other retailers in the past two years, 500 of which are in JC Penneys. Sales in these shops have apparently been disappointing but execs predict the gambit will pay off in 2012. Last year, Kate Moss starred in a Mango commercial in which she robbed one of the stores; this January, the company announced that Moss is the new face of its spring ad campaign. Andic also has shares in Banco Sabadell, one of Spain's largest banking groups. The media-shy entrepreneur's family came to Spain from Turkey in 1960s; he is apparently an enthusiastic sailor.

name: Billionaires
bio: Robert Rowling took over TRT Holdings from his father Reese (d. 2001), an oil and gas wildcatter. He owns the Omni hotel chain, which now has 15,000 rooms in nearly 50 locations, including newly acquired Amelia Island resort in Florida. Rowling is investing $75 million rehabbing Amelia and another $250 million on a new hotel in Nashville. He is also rebuilding oil company Tana Exploration with the $220 million acquisition last year of offshore explorer Meritech. Rowling owns the Golds Gym chain; he faced criticism this year from some Golds franchisees in the San Francisco Bay area over millions in donations to Karl Rove's American Crossroads "superPAC."

name: Billionaires
bio: It was a turbulent year for Miami Heat owner and Carnival Cruises CEO Micky Arison. When the Costa Concordia, a ship owned by Carnival Cruises, sunk off the coast of Italy, shares in the company plunged and Arison was criticized for failing to step forward and make public statements about the disaster. Dwayne Wade's seemingly perma-injured ankle has slowed what many were hoping would be a blockbuster season for the Heat, the team's second with a power trio composed of Wade, LeBron James and Chris Bosh. Late last year, Arison sold the remainder of his shares in Arison Holdings to his sister, Israeli billionaire Shari Arison, effectively ending the financial relationship set up for the siblings by their father Ted Arison, who founded Carnival in 1972 and passed away in 1999.
title: Chairman and CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Ma Huateng's Shenzhen-based Tencent, is one of the  world's 10 most popular websites and also one of China's largest by market capitalization (about $47 billion). Its  stock has edged down amid global declines in equities, trimming Ma's wealth.  Tencent's overall business has been growing steadily on the back of games such as League of Legends and its popular QQ messaging service  It holds minority stakes in movie and television producer Huayi Brothers Media Group of Beijing, online travel service provider eLong and security software company Kingsoft.

name: Billionaires
bio: When James Packer inherited a $5 billion empire from his father Kerry Packer in late 2005, his fortune was built on media assets. Today, it is centered on the casino and gaming business Crown Limited, which owns two casinos in Australia and also has a joint venture in the booming gaming centre of Macau. Packer still owns some media assets, including a large stake in Consolidated Media, which has interests in Australian pay TV. In the last 12 months, Packer sold interests in a financial services business, a tourism group and a cosmetics company, but he acquired stakes in two online retailers through his private equity business. Pack operates a charitable foundation named in honor of late father Kerry Packer. This foundation was seeded with $10 million in 2006. Packer has been a strong supporter of a program to help indigenous Australians into corporate jobs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Juan Roig, president of the supervisory board of Mercadona, the largest chain of supermarkets in Spain, now holds 55% of the $22 billion (revenue), 1,356-store food empire that his parents founded. As the Spanish economy nosedived in recent years, Mercadona cut prices in stores by 14 percent--an effort Roig felt necessary to help Spanish families get through the crisis. Mercadona's A.L.P. (always low prices) marketing strategy has helped it take first place in the market, with a 22 percent market share. The company prides itself on long tenure of its 63,500 employees, who have regular schedules, enjoy company profit-sharing, and are two-thirds female. Daughters Hortensia, Amparo, Juana and Carolina all sit on the supervisory board with their dad.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dieter Schnabel became the sole owner of Helm AG when his father Hermann, the company's founder, died in June 2010. The $10.3 billion (sales) company is one of the world's leading independent chemicals marketing enterprises with interests in trading, chemicals and pharmaceuticals. He has been chairman of the executive board since 1984, when his father retired. Thanks to a surge in production, the yearly sales figures for Helm surged more than 60%. Schnabel reportedly enjoys golf and kayaking.

name: Billionaires
bio: Karl Wlaschek is the founder of the Austrian retail chain Billa. In 1996 he sold it to the German REWE Group for about $1 billion. Since then he has invested heavily in prime Austrian real estate and is now one of the largest private real estate owners in the country. In September  2011 his real estate company Amisola bought one of the best known hotels in Austria, the Schlosshotel Velden at the Worther See in Carinthia. Because of mismanagement the hotel has suffered significant losses in recent years. Wlaschek had an emotional connection to the place: When he was a poor musician back in the early 1950s he and his band played at the hotel for two seasons. Wlaschek turned 94 on August 4, 2011.

name: Billionaires
bio: Her low-key dad, Yeung Kwok Keung, transferred his holding of the family's main fortune, shares in family-controlled real estate developer Country Garden Holdings to her ahead of the company's Hong Kong IPO in 2007. Yang, China's richest person in 2007 (net worth then: $16.2 billion), has seen her fortune drop dramatically since, though she's wealthier than last year. Shares are up 11% from a year ago. Rarely seen in public, Yang is said to be in charge of Country Garden's development strategies. Her cousins Yang Zhicheng and Yang Yongchao sit on the board.

name: Billionaires
bio: The 8th Earl Cadogan -- or Charles, to his friends -- saw his family's 300-year-old fortune rise again this year with London's economy-proof prime real estate market. His family's 90-acre estate stretches across the capital's most desirable postcodes in the posh neighborhoods of Chelsea and Knightsbridge. In 2011, Cadogan Estates was granted permission to redevelop a section of Sloane Street, a popular shopping destination named after an ancestor, with a new piazza of high-end shops. Charles Cadogan himself began his career at merchant banker Schroder Wagg, and took on the management of his family's property portfolio in 1974.

name: Billionaires
bio: Singapore resident since 2008, Richard Chandler got his start in 1986, when he and brother Christopher, also a billionaire, sold their parents' retailing business to invest in Hong Kong real estate. They cofounded investment firm Sovereign Global, focusing on emerging economies. After they split in 2006, he started a Singapore-based fund now called Richard Chandler Corporation. It is embattled Chinese timber company Sino-Forest's biggest shareholder; called for chief executive and board members to step down in December in light of claims the company had fraudulently overstated timber holdings. In February, it agreed to invest $160 million in Australian forestry company Gunns. He has a $100 million fund aimed at improving education in the developing world.

name: Billionaires
bio: Michael Herz, his brother Wolfgang and his mother Ingeburg own Maxingvest AG (formerly Tchibo Holding). Maxingvest AG holds 50.47% of the outstanding shares in Beiersdorf AG and all of Tchibo GmbH, makers of Germany's best-known coffee brand, Tchibo. Herz helped push out his brother Gunter and his sister Daniela from the company in 2003 after a drawn-out family feud. His brother Joachim died in 2008 after being hit by a boat while swimming in a Georgia lake.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wolfgang Herz, his brother Michael and his mother Ingeburg own Maxingvest AG (formerly Tchibo Holding). Maxingvest AG holds 50.47% of the outstanding shares in Beiersdorf AG and all of Tchibo GmbH, makers of Germany's best-known coffee brand, Tchibo. Herz was involved in an effort to push out his brother Gunter and his sister Daniela from the company in 2003 in a drawn-out family feud. His brother Joachim died in 2008 after being hit by a boat while swimming in a Georgia lake.

name: Billionaires
bio: Charles Johnson's investment and mutual fund giant Franklin Resources Inc. acquired Balanced Equity Management of Australia, with more than $10 billion in assets under management, in July, following decades of similar strategic acquisitions, including Fiduciary Trust in 2001 and Templeton Funds in 1992. Johnson's father, Rupert Sr., founded a mutual fund shop in 1947, then called Franklin Distributors. Charles took over as chief executive in 1957. His half-brother, Rupert Jr., joined eight years later. The pair expanded into Franklin Resources in 1969. The firm manages more than $659 billion in assets. Charles is the company's chairman, while Rupert Jr. is vice chairman. Charles' son Gregory is Franklin's chief executive. By recently upping his stake, Charles reportedly became the largest shareholder. He is also chairman of the San Francisco Giants baseball team.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: After generating more than $12 billion in net gains for investors since he founded Caxton Associates in 1983, hedge fund legend Kovner called it a career in September 2011. The reins to his $10 billion firm were officially handed to former chief investment officer Andrew Law on January 1, 2012. Under Law's management Caxton Global Investment returned 0.7% net of fees in 2011. Kovner addressed the transition in a letter to investors saying he will miss the adrenalin rush of confronting markets every day. The son of a trade unionist, Kovner abandoned his Harvard PhD in economics after a fit of writer's block. He moved on to driving taxis, writing and studying harpsichord at Julliard. At 31, he turned $3,000 he borrowed on his credit card into $45,000 trading soybeans and watched as that value halved. It was a seminal lesson in risk management. Kovner is the Chairman of Julliard, and has donated 140 scores and sketches by Bach, Beethoven and Brahms to the school. Kovner gave $20 million to Julliard in January to endow a graduate-level program in historical performance.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Hardware mogul Menard owns the nation's third largest home improvement retailer by sales, Menards, with $7 billion in estimated revenue. The University of Wisconsin-Eau Claire graduate financed his education constructing post-frame homes. In the 1970s, he began selling tools from a single store, which grew into a giant Midwestern chain. After fielding race cars in the IndyCar series for years, he finally broke through in 2011 when his son Paul won his first NASCAR race at the Brickyard 500. Menard serves on the board of Polaris Industries, a maker of ATV and snowmobiles, a position that has earned him more than $2 billion in stock options, exercisable when he retires from the board.
title: president and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Menard, Inc.', 'title': 'president and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Rosalia Mera, co-founder of Inditex with ex-husband Amanacio Ortega, remains Spain's richest woman. Mera dropped out of school at 11 to work as a seamstress, then helped then husband make dressing gowns and lingerie in their home. Today, the company Ortega and Mera founded is one of the globe's most successful retailers: Inditex, parent company of Zara retail stores. Mera and Ortega are long-divorced, but she still holds a 5.8% stake in now $16.1 billion (sales) Inditex, plus a pile of cash from its 2001 IPO, which netted her $600 million at the time. Mera has invested money in causes dear to her heart: a marine farm fishing group, a company that looks for cancer treatments in products from the ocean, and a maker of a fingerprinting system for newborns. Her Paideia Foundation works to integrate people with physical and mental disabilities, like son Marcos, into larger society.
title: Investor, Philanthropist

name: Billionaires
bio: France's richest web entrepreneur saw his fortune grow in his second year on the list along with stock in Iliad SA, his telecoms company. Xavier Niel owns two thirds of Iliad, parent company of Free, with 23% of France's broadband market share and a growing slice of mobile. The 44-year-old, from a working class Paris suburb, has come a long way since he built an erotic chat service for French internet forerunner Minitel as a teenager. After foregoing college, Niel launched his country's first ISP in 1993, making his first fortune when it sold for $50 million at the height of the internet boom. He was a shareholder in sex shops and peep shows until a prostitution scandal landed him in jail for a month. He was cleared of pimping charges but convicted of failing to disclose income. Current investments include a stake in Le Monde, the bestselling French language newspaper in the world and the rights to 'My Way', made famous by Frank Sinatra.

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow Dorothea Steinbruch and her children control one of Brazil's largest steelmakers, Companhia Siderurgica Nacional (CSN), with $9 billion in revenues and a $15 billion market capitalization. Their net worth has dropped by $1.3 billion since 2011 due to a fall in the price of CSN shares. The Steinbruch and Rabinovitch families, through their Vicunha Textile, paid a reported $800 million in 1993 for control of CSN, a formerly state-owned steel company. In 2005 the Steinbruch family bought out the Rabinovitch stake for a reported $590 million. Dorothea's brother-in-law, Eliezer Steinbruch, who shared control of CSN, died in 2008. She is not involved in running the business; her son Benjamin serves as chairman and chief executive of CSN. The family also owns Banco Fibra; Dorothea's son Ricardo is chairman of the board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Peter Woo's main holding company, Wheelock,  controls Hong Kong landmarks such as Times Square and Harbour City. Woo won the bid for the site that's expected to overlook the future Kai Tak Cruise Terminal at the former Kai Tak Airport in Kowloon. Investors whacked 30% off Wheelock's share price last year, nervous about the industry. Woo is a member of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference. Daughter Jennifer Woo runs privately held mall chain Lane Crawford. Douglas, a Princeton grad with an architecture degree, focuses on Wheelock's property investments in China.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhang Jindong is chairman of Suning Appliance, dubbed the "Best Buy" of China because Suning is number one in its home market in electronics retailing. Yet Sunning in some respects is surpassing Best Buy. The market capitalization for Suning's China-traded shares, for instance, was recently $10 billion, compared with $9 billion for Best Buy. Suning has been growing faster, too, amid double-digit increases in Chinese consumer spending. Sales climbed 25% in the first nine months of 2011 to $10.7 billion, boosting its profit 21% to $540 million. Not content with Suning's present success, Zhang has been adding even more stores -- a net 226 of them in the first nine months of 2011, to a total of 1,575.  Zhang-led Suning Real Estate, a separate business, has been expanding, too, building commercial real estate in major cities across China. Suning Appliance is working to expand its Suning-controlled Laox of Japan as a second brand in China. Suning Appliance last year also unveiled plans to become a major China e-commerce player. Investors, for their part, have been worried profit may suffer from all of that new e-investment and slower economic growth in China, and pushed shares Suning Appliance's shares down in the past year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cork king Americo Amorim turned a small cork factory started by his grandfather in 1870 into the world's largest producer, Corticeira Amorim. His group has now added real estate and tourism interests. No longer involved in daily operations, Amorim still owns 50% of the group. Most of his fortune now comes from his extensive investments in stocks, particularly in finance and energy industries; holdings include various banks, a large stake in Galp, Portugal's former state energy company, and 25% of Tom Ford, a luxury fashion designer. In 2009 Amorim was awarded an honorary doctor of commercial science from St. John's University in New York.

name: Billionaires
bio: Filaret Galchev's Eurocement Group is Russia's largest cement producer.  In the 1990s, Galchev created Russia's largest coal-trading company, Rosuglesbyt. He later invested in cement, purchasing the Stern Cement plants as well as the cement arm of Inteko, owned by fellow billionaire Elena Baturina. Galchev bought out partner Georgy Kransyansky to become the company's sole owner.  Last year he boosted his stake in Swiss billionaire Thomas Schmidheiny's cement maker Holcim to 10%. Now he invests in fertilizers and owns a 10.3% stake in Uralkali-Silvinit.

name: Billionaires
bio: With his brother Charles and nephew Gregory Franklin, Rupert Johnson, Jr. runs Franklin Resources Inc., which has $659 billion under management. The firm acquired Australia's Balanced Equity Management in July, following decades of similar strategic acquisitions, including Fiduciary Trust in 2001 and Templeton Funds in 1992. Rupert Sr. founded a mutual fund shop in 1947, then called Franklin Distributors. Rupert Jr.'s brother Charles took over as chief executive in 1957. Rupert Jr. joined him eight years later. The pair expanded into Franklin Resources in 1969. Today, Charles is the company's chairman and Rupert Jr. serves as vice chairman. Charles' son Gregory is the company's chief executive.
title: Vice Chairman and Director
employment: {'name': 'Franklin Resources', 'uri': 'companies/franklin-resources', 'title': 'Vice Chairman and Director', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Frank Lowy is founder of one of the world's biggest listed retail property groups, Westfield, which owns 124 shopping malls in Australia, New Zealand, England and the US. Last year Lowy relinquished the reins after 50 years, but remains chairman. His sons Steven and Peter became joint CEOs. The group, in which family has an estimated 8% stake, is now expanding into Italy and Brazil and recently opened Europe's largest mall near the London Olympics site. Eldest son, David, runs the family's private global hedge fund. Czech-born Lowy fled post-war Europe to set up a sandwich shop in Sydney in 1952, then expanded into property development in Sydney's western suburbs, then malls. Passionate soccer supporter, he was reappointed chairman of the Football Federation of Australia for four years. He is also a major donor to many causes including the Lowy Institute think tank, the Lowy Medical Research Institute and an aviation museum.

name: Billionaires
bio: In December, media mogul Sumner Redstone's brother Edward passed away. The pair were partners in family company National Amusements, founded by their father Mickey in 1936. The partnership ended in a lawsuit in 1972, in which Edward sued both Sumner and Mickey for mismanagement. Now, the bulk of Sumner Redstone's fortune comes from his controlling stakes in CBS and Viacom. In September of last year, the Sumner M. Redstone Foundation donated $1.5 million to eradicate extreme poverty. The foundation also funded The End of Polio Concert, drawing more than $100 million in donations from around the world, including $40 million in funds from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation. Redstone is a World War II vet and Harvard Law grad.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Heinz Hermann Thiele and his family acquired Knorr-Bremse AG in the late 1980s and transformed it into world's leading manufacturer of braking systems for rail and commercial vehicles. In early 2011, Thiele withdrew from his position on the operational side of the business. He still sits on the company's advisory board. Thiele gave a portion of the company to his two children, Henrik and Julia. He is said to enjoy hiking, skiing and animal photography. Thiele has received various awards for his philanthropic contributions, including his support of children's cancer research and aid to developing countries.

name: Billionaires
bio: Reclusive tycoon Mike Adenuga runs Conoil Producing, the first Nigerian company to strike oil in commercial quantities in the early 1990s. Today it is Nigeria's largest oil exploration company. He also owns Globacom, Nigeria's second-largest mobile telecom operator. He made his first million at age 26 selling lace and distributing soft drinks, but hit it big through the bene­faction of Nigeria's former military ­president, Ibrahim Babangida.

name: Billionaires
bio: Pyotr Aven heads Russia's largest private bank, Alfa Bank, part of the Alfa Group conglomerate controlled by fellow billionaires Mikhail Fridman, German Khan and Alexei Kuzmichev. In June 2011, Alfa Group sold its 25% stake in CTC Media to billionaire Yury Kovalchuk and his partners for $1 billion. Aven remains co-head of the board of CTC; he also owns about 0.2% of the company as a private investor. Aven grew up in Moscow and attended a well-regarded high school for the city's elite and prestigious Moscow State University. Later he worked at the Institute for Systems Studies at the Soviet Academy of Sciences. In 1989, Aven went to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs; he was tapped to be minister of foreign economic relations two years later. In 1994 Aven met Alfa Group's Mikhail Fridman and soon becuame a shareholder of Alfa-Bank. Aven owns the largest private collection of Russian art in the country, but keeps the most valuable pieces in the UK.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 60 years, Paul Desmarais has transformed his father's one-route Ontario bus company into Power Corp., a $10.3 billion (market cap) behemoth with interests including La Presse, a Montreal daily newspaper and life insurer Great-West Lifeco. Now age 85, Desmarais leaves the daily operations of Power Corp. to his sons Andre and Paul, Jr., who serve as co-CEOs. The company continues its strong investment in China, buying a 10 percent stake in China Asset Management Co. in August 2011 for about $270 million. Power Corp., which is a key shareholder Chinese conglomerate CITIC Pacific, began its foray into Chinese ventures in 1986, when the company partnered with a CITIC subsidiary to buy a pulp mill in British Columbia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Walter Haefner passed away in June 2012. At the time, he was the oldest billionaire in the world, at 101 years old. Haefner was the largest individual shareholder of IT software maker CA (formerly Computer Associates). He sold the data processing firm in 1968 to University Computing which was bought by Computer Associates in 1987. Haefner still holds a 24% stake in his own name, and has benefitted from a rising stock price, as well as handsome dividend payouts. The family owns Automobil-und Motoren AG, Switzerland's main importer of Volkswagen, Seat, Skoda and Audi. In 2011, Haefner transferred ownership of his Moyglare Stud Farm in Ireland to his daughter.

name: Billionaires
bio: Marking his 50th year with the Vancouver-based Jim Pattison Group, Jim Pattison says he's been very grateful for his company, which began its first year with sales of about $2 million. The Jim Pattison Group, with more than 455 locations worldwide and 33,000 employees, has interests in the automotive, media, packaging, food sales, magazine distribution, entertainment and financial industries. It's the third largest private company in Canada. Group sales in 2010 were $7.2 billion, though Pattison maintains that the company remains the same as when it was first founded and that he still goes to work every day at the age of 83. He owns a Palm Springs home that once belonged to Frank Sinatra and maintains a vintage car collection.
title: Founder, Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Jim Pattison Group', 'title': 'Founder, Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Yoshikazu Tanaka is the founder and CEO of Gree, a mobile gaming service that is Japan's biggest online social network, with some 29 million users in Japan. Gree aims to outpace Japanese rivals abroad: it acquired U.S. mobile gaming company OpenFeint last year, and works with China's largest net portal, Tencent; now reaches over 190 million users globally. Tanaka first worked at So-net Entertainment Corporation, then at online shopping site Rakuten under billionaire Hiroshi Mikitani prior to launching Gree in 2004. Company moniker refers to "six degrees of separation." The company's stock price is up nearly 100% over the past year on rising sales and profits; company rumored to be seeking overseas listing. Tanaka earned a bachelor's degree in Law from Nihon University in 1999.

name: Billionaires
bio: Leslie Wexner has seen his fortune grow by $1.1 billion this year thanks to a 70% boost in the stock price of his Limited Brands chain of mall staples. His retail empire continues its spread overseas: Lingerie giant Victoria's Secret is opening outlets in Bahrain and Saudi Arabia this year, and upscale sister brand La Senza just launched a Sydney, Australia flagship. Ohio State law school dropout Wexner founded The Limited with a $5,000 loan from his aunt in 1963, and took it public six years later. He sold a majority stake in The Limited clothing chain in 2007 and gave up the remaining stake last year. A passionate contemporary art collector, Wexner has pieces by Picasso, Matisse, Degas and DeKooning. He previously funded Ohio State University's Wexner Center for the Arts and in February, he and wife Abigail pledged another $100 million to the college to be doled out over nine years. He owns a 315-foot yacht, called Limitless.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Limited Brands', 'uri': 'companies/limited-brands', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: True to form, Britain's most outrageous billionaire Richard Branson has had a year of huge public ups and downs. In August, the main villa on his private Necker Island burned to the ground after being struck by lightning during Hurricane Irene. In October, Branson opened the world's first commercial spaceport in the New Mexico desert (he rappelled down the side of the huge glass SpacePort America building while popping champagne, of course). In November, his Virgin Money teamed with US billionaire investor Wilbur Ross in a deal worth $1.2 billion to bail out the UK's nationalized Northern Rock, which collapsed in 2007 after a run on the bank.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gustavo Cisneros, one of South America's most prominent businessmen, oversees a diversified empire with interests in Venezuelan television stations, telecom, a regional brewery and a baseball team. With U.S. billionaire Jerry Perenchio and Mexican billionaire Emilio Azcarraga Jean, Cisneros sold U.S. Spanish-language TV network Univision to a private equity consortium led by U.S. billionaire Haim Saban for $13.7 billion in 2007. After Cisneros' Venezuelan broadcaster Venevision locked horns with President Hugo Chavez, it is avoiding politics these days, preferring to concentrate on entertainment content, including hugely popular Latin American soap operas. In October 2011, Carlos Slim's America Movil announced a deal to purchase Cisneros' digital content business, DLA Inc.; purchase price was not disclosed. Cisneros and his wife Patricia are familiar figures in high society, hobnobbing with former presidents like George H. W. Bush, designers and fellow billionaires. The couple boasts an extensive collection of Latin American art: one favorite is an Amazonian landscape by German artist Frank W. Post. His daughter, Adriana, directs company strategy and is overseeing the development of Tropicalia, a luxury eco-resort in the Dominican Republic, from her home in New York. The family foundation promotes education and protection of indigenous people in the Amazon basin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Revenues at Sir James Dyson's eponymous appliance company rose  in 2011 as the company continues to expand into new product categories on a wave of fresh engineering hires. Dyson is best known for inventing the bag-less vacuum. He debuted his latest invention in 2010, a futuristic bladeless fan called the "Air Multiplier," and has since been battling to take down Chinese rip-offs of the product. The company is hush hush about the new products to come, but digital motors are in the mix. Dyson has also invested in Ingenious Media, the investment company behind Avatar and Live Free or Die Hard.  Dyson ran through 5,127 prototypes until he perfected G-Force, an upright vacuum using spinning technology to maintain constant suction. He introduced product in U.K. in 1993; it was an immediate hit.

name: Billionaires
bio: Aloysio de Andrade Faria, now 91, sold most of his Banco Real to Dutch bank ABN Amro in 1998 for $2.1 billion. With the remaining assets he built Banco Alfa, now Brazil's 22nd largest bank. He also owns Agropalma, Latin America's biggest palm oil producer, which also makes biodiesel, and C&C, a chain of home improvement stores. Today he is mostly retired, and reportedly owns 150 pure-bred horses. Faria trained as a doctor and practiced medicine for two years. When his father died suddenly, Faria took his place running Banco Real.

name: Billionaires
bio: A sluggish economy has dented the Greens' fortune, as profits at Arcadia Group--holding for clothing stores Top Shop and BHS, slipped 40% in 2011. There are plans to open two stores in the U.S. this year, but 260 will close in the U.K. over the next few years once leases end. Green closed 66 stores last year as Brits tightened their wallets. A high-school drop-out, Green bought his first store in London at 27, and sold discounted designer brands. He bought retail group Arcadia in 2002 for $1.2 billion; sales now top $4 billion. After buying rundown retail chain BHS, he raised profits by 500% in two years. Green served as an advisor to the British government in 2010, and complained of "staggering waste." He shares his fortune with South African wife Cristina through offshore investment vehicle Taveta Investments. A lavish party-giver, he counts Simon Cowell and Kate Moss as friends.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bruce Halle opened his first tire store more than 50 years ago in Ann Arbor, Michigan. Today his Discount Tire is the world's largest independent tire and wheel retailer with 804 locations in 23 states. The company's "Thank You" commercial holds the Guinness World Record for the longest-running TV commercial; the twelve-second spot has been on the air since 1975. The No. 22 Discount Tire car, driven by Brad Keselowski, won the 2010 NASCAR Nationwide Series championship in November 2010. Halle maintains what is most likely the world's largest collection of vintage tire advertisements; his collection contains nearly 400 unique lithographs from the earliest days of the industry. His Bruce T. Halle Family Foundation supports many causes, from the Diane Halle Center for Family Justice at Arizona State University to Children First Academy, the nation's largest school for homeless children.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Kiev-born Victor Pinchuk was a big hit at the Swiss schmooze-fest that is the annual World Economic Forum in Davos. At the January summit, his Pinchuk Foundation played host to a panel on internet philanthropy featuring fellow Forbes billionaires Sean Parker, Eric Schmidt and Yuri Milner. The Ukrainian mogul is still investing the $2.2 billion he made in the sale of his Ukrotsbank in 2008, most recently acquiring a stake in Russian mobile provider Vimpelcom and Groupon-alike Pokupon.  He's said to be readying his oil and gas exploration company, Geo Alliance, for a possible IPO. Pinchuk made his first fortune with Interpipe, supplying pipes for huge energy customers including Gazprom and Rosneft. He's the son-in-law of Ukrainian ex-president Leonid Kuchma and, as well as being a prominent business figure, owns TV stations and a tabloid and has served as a Member of Parliament.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads conglomerate Hong Leong Group Malaysia and owes the biggest part of his fortune to its Hong Kong-listed investment holding company Guoco Group. Also has interests in financial services, property development and hotels across Southeast Asia. His Hong Leong Bank still stalking Malaysian bank Eon Capital (see No. 10).

name: Billionaires
bio: Thomas Schmidheiny's great-grandfather owned a brick factory, and his grandfather worked in cement. When Thomas' father Max carved up his estate in 1984, his brother Stephan, also a billionaire, got construction company Eternit, and Thomas got Holcim, the world's second-largest supplier of cement and concrete. Schmidheiny ran Holcim for two decades, stepping down as chairman in 2003. This past fall, he increased his stake in Holcim to 20% as the company's stock price fell. His Cuvaison and Chapel Hill wine labels are suffering from a global slump, but new Mendoza vineyards in Argentina are faring slightly better.

name: Billionaires
bio: Andrei Skoch has been a Russian parliamentary deputy since 1999; his wealth comes from a 30% stake in iron ore and steel company Metalloinvest, which technically is owned in the name of his father Vladimir, a former factory worker. Skoch was born in a small settlement near Moscow and studied at the Institute of Physical Culture. Skoch later worked for Moscow's MontazhSpetsBank. He and Lev Kvetnoi, who grew up in the same settlement, joined billionaire Alisher Usmanov's metallurgical business; Kvetnoi was sent to Oskol Metal Works, while Skoch went to Lebedinsky Mining. Later Usmanov merged the two firms with a third to create the Metalloinvest conglomerate. Kvetnoi sold out, but Skoch remains a partner. He sponsors a literary competition for young authors called Debut.

name: Billionaires
bio: Real estate mogul Stern expanded his New York and New Jersey empire to Chicago last year. He bought downtown retail and apartment tower One Superior Place for a reported $320 million, in what was the second largest apartment transaction in the history of the Chicago market. Stern sold his family business Hartz Mountain Pet Products for $350 million in 2000. He now owns more than 38 million square feet of commercial, residential, and retail property. Son Emanuel oversees the real estate holdings. Hartz also invests in oil and gas exploration. An art collector, Stern bought three 16th century suits of armor to decorate his firm's Manhattan lobby in 2010. He also founded Homes for the Homeless, which provides housing and employment training for the disadvantaged in New York City.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Hartz Mountain Industries, Inc.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Stef Wertheimer first garnered attention in 2006, when the carbide industrial cutting tool manufacturer company he founded out of a garage in his backyard became the first big international target of Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway. Wertheimer sold 80% of Iscar to Buffett that year and maintains a 20% stake in the company, which his son currently runs. Wertheimer's latest endeavors involve building industrial parks in Israel's economically depressed and predominantly Arab regions. Wertheimer believes that industry and jobs can solve the war-torn country's conflicts. He was honored with Oslo Business for Peace Award in 2010 for these efforts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daniel Ziff is the youngest son of publishing magnate William Ziff Jr. (d. 2006), the man behind the Ziff-Davis empire that included titles such as Popular Aviation, PC Magazine, and Car and Driver. Daniel and his billionaire brothers Dirk and Robert inherited the family fortune in 1994 after their father sold 95% of the business to Forstmann Little for $1.4 billion and retired. Through their New York City-based Ziff Brothers Investments, the brothers reinvested the proceeds across equities, debt, real estate, commodities, private equity and hedge funds, providing seed money to fund manager Daniel Och in exchange for a 10% stake in Och-Ziff Capital Management, which went public in 2007.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dirk Ziff is the eldest son of publishing magnate William Ziff Jr. (d. 2006), the man behind the Ziff-Davis empire that included titles such as Popular Aviation, PC Magazine, and Car and Driver. Dirk and his billionaire brothers Daniel and Robert inherited the family fortune in 1994 after their father sold 95% of the business to Forstmann Little for $1.4 billion and retired. Through their New York City-based Ziff Brothers Investments the brothers reinvested the proceeds across equities, debt, real estate, commodities, private equity and hedge funds, providing seed money to fund manager Daniel Och in exchange for a 10% stake in Och-Ziff Capital Management, which went public in 2007. Dirk is married to a former Forbes Reporter. The couple reportedly lives in Palm Beach, Fla., and vacations at their Martha's Vineyard home.

name: Billionaires
bio: Robert Ziff is the middle son of publishing magnate William Ziff Jr. (d. 2006), the man behind the Ziff-Davis empire that included titles such as Popular Aviation, PC Magazine, and Car and Driver. Robert and his brothers Dirk and Daniel inherited the family fortune in 1994 after their father sold 95% of the business to Forstmann Little for $1.4 billion and retired. Through their New York City-based Ziff Brothers Investments the brothers reinvested the proceeds across equities, debt, real estate, commodities, private equity and hedge funds, providing seed money to fund manager Daniel Och in exchange for a 10% stake in Och-Ziff Capital Management, which went public in 2007. Robert made headlines in 2011 for his financial contributions to Republican legislators supportive of gay marriage.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dannine Avara is one of four children of the late energy pipeline entrepreneur Dan Duncan, founder of Enterprise Products. Avara added $1 billion to her fortune in the last year as the company's share price climbed 24%. Duncan, the former richest man in Houston, died in 2010 at age 77. He grew up poor and formed Enterprise Products with two trucks in 1968, selling door to door. Today Enterprise owns more than 50,000 miles of natural gas, oil, and petrochemical pipelines.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heinz-Horst Deichmann owns the family-run company Deichmann-Schuhe GmbH, Europe's largest shoe retailer and the owner of the Rack Room Shoes and Off Broadway chains in the U.S. Despite the economic downturn, sales increased in 2008, 2009 and 2010 (by 12.5%). The 85-year-old Deichmann insists on expanding the company without the help of the stock market or bank loans. His son Heinrich runs daily operations. Deichmann is a committed philanthropist, and regularly donates large sums to missionary and humanitarian organizations, including a program to help leprosy victims in India.

name: Billionaires
bio: Scott Duncan is one of four children of the late energy pipeline entrepreneur Dan Duncan, founder of Enterprise Products. Scott Duncan added $1 billion to his fortune in the last year as the company's share price climbed 24%. His father, the former richest man in Houston, died in 2010 at age 77. He grew up poor and formed Enterprise Products with two trucks in 1968, selling door to door. Today Enterprise owns more than 50,000 miles of natural gas, oil, and petrochemical pipelines.

name: Billionaires
bio: Milane Frantz is one of four children of the late energy pipeline entrepreneur Dan Duncan, founder of Enterprise Products. Frantz added $1 billion to her fortune in the last year as the company's share price climbed 24%. Duncan, the former richest man in Houston, died in 2010 at age 77. He grew up poor and formed Enterprise Products with two trucks in 1968, selling door to door. Today Enterprise owns more than 50,000 miles of natural gas, oil, and petrochemical pipelines.

name: Billionaires
bio: India's first billionaire banker, Uday Kotak started out with small finance firm in 1985. Scaled it up to full-fledged bank after snagging banking license in 2003. Today he owns 46% of Kotak Mahindra Bank, so named because of early backing from industrialist Anand Mahindra. It has over 335 branches and 2.7 million customers. Sumitomo Mitsui Banking holds a minority stake.

name: Billionaires
bio: Randa Williams is one of four children of the late energy pipeline entrepreneur Dan Duncan, founder of Enterprise Products. Williams added $1 billion to her fortune in the last year as the company's share price climbed 24%. Duncan, the former richest man in Houston, died in 2010 at age 77. He grew up poor and formed Enterprise Products with two trucks in 1968, selling door to door. Today Enterprise owns more than 50,000 miles of natural gas, oil, and petrochemical pipelines.
title: Director

name: Billionaires
bio: Jeronimo Arango, with brothers Manuel and Placido, shares a fortune gained from selling their stake in retailer Cifra to Wal-Mart's Mexican arm in 1997. Jeronimo is said to live a quiet life in Los Angeles. Manuel, a real estate developer, also founded the Mexican Center for Philanthropy and, in 2011, called on businesses to donate at least one percent of their profits to charity. Placido collects art and has owned a chain of restaurants.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founders of fast fashion retailer Forever 21, Do Won (Don) Chang and his wife Jin Sook immigrated to America from Korea in 1981. Chang initially held three jobs at once, doing janitorial work, pumping gas and working in a coffee shop. He and his wife opened their first clothing store in 1984; today $2.6 billion (sales) Forever 21 operates more than 480 stores. The firm has been criticized for copying designer clothes and sued more than 50 times by other retailers such as Anthropologie for copyright infringement. Born-again Christians, the two apparently attend church at 5:20 a.m. on weekdays, keep bibles in the office, and print John 3:16 on the bottom of each bag.  Don is chief executive, Jin Sook is the head buyer, daughter Linda runs marketing, while daughter Esther heads the visual display team.

name: Billionaires
bio: Navy vet DeJoria was living in his car when he teamed up with Paul Mitchell to launch the shampoo company with a $700 investment. Sales now come to nearly $1 billion. DeJoria earned his second fortune with tequila maker Patron Spirits, which he founded in 1989 with Martin Crowley. Friends like Clint Eastwood and Wolfgang puck introduced the drink to the Hollywood crowd. DeJoria's philanthropic efforts include Grow Appalachia (in partnership with Berea College), which helps families fight obesity and poverty by creating gardens. The Austin resident also gives to Mineseekers, Food4Africa and Blazer House.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hobby Lobby founder David Green signed onto the Warren Buffett-Bill Gates Giving Pledge, to donate more than half his fortune, in December 2010. Green is a big contributor to evangelical education, having given to Jerry Falwell's Liberty University and Oral Roberts University. He has also acquired Christian artifacts (medieval manuscripts, Hebrew scrolls and Codex Climaci Rescriptus: a rare sixth century Bible written partly in Palestinian Aramaic) for the National Bible Museum. In August 2011, Green announced that he is donating a 170-acre ranch in San Juan Capistrano, Calif., to Saddleback Church. A preacher's son from a poor background, Green started Greco Products in 1970 with $600, which he spun into his first Hobby Lobby arts and crafts stores in Oklahoma City in 1972. The family-friendly chain now has 490 locations in 40 states. Green strives to grow the company according to biblical principles; stores are closed on Sundays. The company has also delivered 508 million copies of a gospel booklet to children in more than 100 countries. It raised its minimum wage for the third consecutive year to $12 an hour.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Erivan Haub owns the Tengelmann Group, one of Germany's largest food retailers. Operational management of the group, which was established as a family business more than 140 years ago, is now in the hands of Erivan's sons, Karl-Erivan and Christian. Haub also owned 41% of U.S. grocery chain A&P, which filed for bankruptcy in December 2010; Haub has fully written off the value of that stake. A big fan of the U.S., Haub owns extensive land in Washington state, a buffalo ranch in Wyoming and a ski resort in the Cascades called Sun Mountain Lodge. He is a small town celebrity in Tacoma, Wash., thanks to his contribution to the town's revitalization.

name: Billionaires
bio: He and brother Fred sold out to brothers Charles and David for $1.3 billion in 1983 but later sued for more; the case settled in 2001. Now less than one sixth as rich as his siblings, he still has plenty to spend. Koch used some of his cash to pay $2.3 million in June for the world's only known photograph of Billy the Kid. Earlier, he reportedly paid $3.1 million for the faux Colorado ghost town of Buckskin Joe, dismantled it and moved the buildings to his 5,000-acre Bear Ranch in Gunnison. Koch bet on Mitt Romney in the presidential election by sending a $1 million check to a pro-Romney Super PAC. In February he unveiled his collection of Wild West paintings, sculptures and memorabilia at the Society of Four Arts in Palm Beach. Congress is mulling a land swap that would allow him to build a reproduction ghost town in Colorado to house the collection.

name: Billionaires
bio: Legendary buyout pioneer Kravis founded KKR with cousin George Roberts and Bear Stearns mentor Jerome Kohlberg in 1976. KKR's recent notable deals include a May 2010 investment in Dalmia Cement, forming the largest private cement company in India. KKR also led a 2010 deal to buy Del Monte Foods for $4 billion. The firm was one of the first to use leverage in acquisitions. In 1989, KKR orchestrated the $25 billion buyout of RJR Nabisco; the deal became the basis of the bestselling book Barbarians at the Gate. In July 2010, KKR went public. Kravis is a patron of the Metropolitan Museum of Art where he has a wing named after him. His economist wife Marie-Josée is president of the Museum of Modern Art's board of trustees. Kravis will have a new building at Columbia's business school named after him following a $100 million pledge.
title: Co-Chair and Co-CEO
employment: {'name': 'KKR and Co', 'title': 'Co-Chair and Co-CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Business is booming at his Belle Holdings, the Hong Kong fashion giant Tang Yiu founded that's China's biggest women's footwear retailer. As a reward its shares changed little during a year when Hong Kong's main stock index suffered a double-digit fall. He has stayed on as chairman after a stroke last year. Son Tang King Loy is executive director.

name: Billionaires
bio: Harry Triguboff was one of the first property developers to see the potential of apartment living, at a time when most Australians were assumed to aspire to a suburban block.  These days he is one of the country's largest apartment developers, earning him the nickname "High Rise Harry." Triguboff was born in China to Russian parents and moved to Australia as a teenager.  He began his working life in the textile business, making his move into property in the 1960s.  These days Chinese are among the most enthusiastic buyers of his developments in Sydney and Brisbane.  In 2011 he won the Gold Harold Humanitarian Award for supporting work to educate youth about drugs and well-being. He established a center in Israel that examines issues around immigrants and Judaism.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wang Jianlin is the chairman of unlisted real estate developer Wanda Group of Beijing, one of China's -- and the world's -- largest real estate developers and retailers. Sales at the privately held group last year climbed by 43% to $16.7 billion, according to company figures.  Wanda says last year it opened 12 new luxury hotels and 14 stores for its retail chain, Van's Department Store, which had a total of $1.1 billion in sales. Wang's Wanda Cinemas movie theater chain boasts the biggest cinema chain in Asia. With 730 screens, it has a 14% market share in mainland China, based on company figures.  Wanda in November inked a $397 million contract with theatre producer Franco Dragone Entertainment of Belgium to put on stage shows in China. Wanda employs 50,000 people. Wang topped the 2011 Forbes China Philanthropy List for his nearly $200 million in donations.  Wang disagreed with our wealth estimate.

name: Billionaires
bio: Roger Wang's Hong Kong-listed Golden Eagle Retail Group, is one of China's largest mall chains with 21 stores in 14 cities as of mid-2011. Sales in the first half of 2011 rose by 35% to $238 million, as the company expanded into central and western China from its base in Jiangsu Province.   Born in China, Wang moved to Taiwan as a child after the Communist revolution. He graduated from Southern Louisiana University, and made money in real estate and insurance in the U.S. before he returned to China and founded Golden Eagle.  Golden Eagle is 68% owned by GEICO Holdings, which in turn is held by Wang's family trust.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cher Wang's wealth declined to $4 billion this year from $6.8 billion a year ago amid a drop in the share price of HTC, the handset manufacturer she chairs, on worries about tougher competition. Wang who runs HTC with husband Wenchi Chen, made headlines in Taiwan's presidential election in January by wading into politics and coming out in favor of the China policy of the ruling political party, the Kuomintang. She is one of 9 children of deceased Taiwan management icon Y.C. Wang. Her uncle Wang Yung-tsai is also a billionaire.

name: Billionaires
bio: The richest woman in Israel is a big shareholder in Carnival Cruises, owner of Costa Concordia, the ship that crashed off the coast of Italy. She inherited her shares in Carnival, Israel's Bank Hapoalim, and infrastructure behemoth Shikun u'Binui Holdings Ltd from her late father Ted Arison. Last year she bought up her brother's shares in Arison Holdings, the investment company her father left to them. The Tel Aviv-based billionaire controls her investments and philanthropy through the Arison Group and Ted Arison Family Foundation, which each year contributes to hundreds of nonprofits involved in health, education, disabilities and research. Arison has tried to position herself as a force for good in business. She has invested in a number of green projects, including a massive desalination plant and a green shopping mall in Israel, and started Miya in 2006, a $100 million venture dedicated to maximizing the efficiency of large urban water systems. She also launched International Good Deeds Day to advocate community service, and in 2009 published the book Birth: When the Spiritual and the Material Come Together.
title: Investor, Philanthropist

name: Billionaires
bio: Ann Walton Kroenke inherited a chunk of Wal-Mart stock after father James "Bud" Walton -- brother of famous founder Sam -- died in 1995. Ann is married to Stanley Kroenke, a Forbes billionaire in his own right as owner of pro basketball's Denver Nuggets, the Colorado Avalanche hockey team, plus stakes in the St. Louis Rams football team and English soccer titan Arsenal. They met while skiing in Colorado in 1971. Her fortune is up this year along with the retail giant's stock, which saw a 14% year on year increase.

name: Billionaires
bio: Francisco Ivens de Sa Dias Branco joins the ranks of the Forbes World's Billionaires for the first time on the basis of his stake in cookie and pasta maker M. Dias Branco S.A., founded as a bakery by his father Manuel in the 1940s. Francisco, now 77, became the controlling shareholder in 1953; the company began milling its own wheat in the 1990s. The company holds a near 50% market share for its products in Brazil's northeast, where M. Dias Branco is based, and a 25% market share across Brazil.  Francisco is chairman and chief executive and owns 63% of the company, worth $2 billion at press time. His five children work in various roles at the company. He also owns $1 billion worth of real estate in the northeastern Brazilian state of Ceara, where he lives.
person: {'name': 'Francisco Ivens de Sa Dias Branco', 'uri': 'francisco-ivens-de-sa-dias-branco', 'imageExists': False}
personName: Francisco Ivens de Sa Dias Branco

name: Billionaires
bio: Li & Fung Chairman Victor will pass the helm to brother William, who is currently deputy chairman, at annual shareholders meeting in May. The Fung family bought 80% of French fashion house Sonia Rykiel in February, offered to buy apparel maker Hang Ten Group Holdings for $340 million in December, and invested $9 million in e-commerce firm Onestop Internet a month earlier. Shares of the outsourcing firm were down more than a third in 2011 thanks to rising manufacturing costs in China and weakness in its two largest markets, the U.S. and Europe. One of the largest suppliers to Wal-Mart, the Li & Fung Group also includes high-end menswear retailer Trinity and Convenience Retail Asia, which operates Circle K convenience stores. Victor's son Spencer, an executive director who oversees the European operation, is seen as the likely successor. Grandfather Fung Pakliu started the company a century ago with partner Li To-ming; duo sold porcelain, antiques. Father Fung Hon-chu ran it while brothers studied business in U.S.; they returned to take the helm in the 1970s.

name: Billionaires
bio: College dropout Micky Jagtiani started with $6,000 and a kids store in Bahrain in 1973. Today he controls $4.7 billion (sales) Landmark Group, a Middle East retailing empire, headquartered in Dubai. It has over 1,000 stores in 15 countries, including India, selling everything from home furnishings and baby products to shoes and electronics. It recently expanded into Kenya and opened candy-store chain Candlelite. It has the regional franchise for Steve Madden and health club group Fitness First. Group is reportedly mulling partnering French retailer Auchan for a venture in India.

name: Billionaires
bio: Joe Lewis' dream of opening a medical city in Lake Nona, near Orlando, is finally coming together. Three large medical institutions are slated to open in 2012, including an academic center and a children's hospital. The visionary behind the development, he owns 7,000 acres in the Lake Nona area. Born above a pub in London's East End, he helped his family build a catering business. He sold it and became a currency trader.  Some reports claim he made more on collapse of sterling on Black Wednesday in 1992 than George Soros. He is still an active trader but also the main investor in Tavistock Group, which has interests in more than 150 companies. He owns soccer team Tottenham Hotspur (Spurs), which is apparently working on plans for a new stadium and redevelopment initiative in London's East End; has a stake in UK's largest pub operator, Mitchell's & Butlers plc, and owns many US restaurants including Abe & Louie's, Freebirds. Lewis has homes in Argentina, France, Albany, Lyford Cay and Isleworth near Orlando, Florida. He spends a couple of months a year working from his yacht. His vast art collection includes works by Picasso, Matisse, Lucian Freud and Francis Bacon.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hollywood producer Arnon Milchan, made bold moves early this fall when he stripped down and rebuilt his executive team at New Regency films,  the company he founded, which had been suffering anemic box office returns. New Regency released seven major films this past year, including Big Momma's Like Father Like Son, In Time and Alvin and the Chipmunks: Chipwrecked. A book released last July, "Confidential: The Life of Secret Agent Turned Hollywood Tycoon Arnon Milchan," delves into the his former life as what some call an "arms dealer." He prefers "consultant." The billionaire housed actor Brad Pitt during his messy break-up with Jennifer Aniston. Pitt later married Angelina Jolie, whom he shared the screen with in New Regency's 2005 film Mr. and Mrs. Smith. In more modest beginnings, Milchan, a business student and professional soccer player, successfully transformed his family's bankrupt fertilizer company into a $125 million business with interests in agriculture, aerospace, animal health products, plastic, fiber optics and pharmaceuticals. He has recently taken to painting -- around three hours every day.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wee Cho Yaw is chairman of United Overseas Bank, Singapore's largest bank, which his father founded in 1935. He ran it for 33 years until 2007 when son Wee Ee Chong became chief executive. He also has land holdings in Singapore through privately held Kheng Leong. Singapore listed Haw Par, which his family owns nearly one quarter of, makes iconic Chinese ointment Tiger Balm. He shares his fortune with five children. Plays tennis.

name: Billionaires
bio: Patrizio Bertelli is chief executive officer of fashion retailer Prada and husband of the brand's lead designer and head matriarch, Miuccia Prada. Born in Arezzo in 1946, son of two prominent Tuscan lawyers, Bertelli studied engineering at the University of Bologna but dropped out after starting a leather accessories company called Mr. Robert. He met Miuccia in 1977 at a trade fair in Milan. The two were married in 1978. He pushed Prada to open its first store in New York in 1986 and urged the brand to acquire smaller labels during the 1990's. He and Miuccia took Prada public in June 2011 on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. An avid sailor, Bertelli's boat the Luna Rossa finished runner up at the 2000 America's Cup.

name: Billionaires
bio: The chairman of outsourcing giant Li & Fung will pass his job to brother, William, who is currently deputy chairman, at the company's annual shareholder meeting in May, 2012. Victor's son Spencer, an executive director who oversees the European operation, is seen as a likely eventual successor. Shares in the company were down more than a third in 2011 thanks to rising manufacturing costs in China and weakness in its two largest markets, the U.S. and Europe. One of the biggest suppliers to Wal-Mart, the Li & Fung Group also includes high-end menswear retailer Trinity and Convenience Retail Asia, which operates Circle K convenience stores.
