Grandfather Fung Pakliu started the company a century ago with partner Li To-ming. The duo sold porcelain and antiques. Father Fung Hon-chu ran the company while the brothers studied business in the U.S. Victor and William took the helm in the 1970s. The Fung family bought 80% of French fashion house Sonia Rykiel in February, offered to buy apparel maker Hang Ten Group Holdings for $340 million in December, and invested $9 million in e-commerce firm Onestop Internet a month earlier.

name: Billionaires
bio: Taiwan electronics industry pioneer Barry Lam runs Quanta Computer, one of the world's largest manufacturers of notebook computers and a supplier to HP and Apple. Amid tough competition from smart phones and notepads, Quanta was able to hold its own; its shares gained by one fourth in past year. Lam is a director of Hong Kong-listed semiconductor supplier Soloman Systech International and Taiwan's Fubon Financial. He's also a patron of the arts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alain Merieux is the chairman of Institut Merieux. The institute's numerous subsidiaries specialize in public health and medicine, specifically diagnostics, immunotherapy and nutrition. Alain's father Marcel Merieux was a laboratory aide to Louis Pasteur; Marcel founded the Institut Merieux in 1897. In 1963, Alain founded  BioMerieux, a $1.9 billion (sales) subsidiary which specializes in infectious disease diagnostics that test for diseases such as HIV and tuberculosis. After becoming an industry leader in human and veterinary vaccines, Institut Merieux made a series of strategic acquisitions and has since formed Merieux Nutrisciences to address issues of food supply. It has also launched Merieux Developpement as a healthcare investment vehicle. Rodolphe Merieux, Alain's oldest son, was killed in 1996 at age 27 when TWA Flight 800 crashed in Long Island. His second son, Christophe, who was expected to take over the family business, died of cardiac failure in 2006 at age 39. His third son Alexandre is a member of the board. The family supports the Meriuex Foundation, which helps developing countries combat infectious diseases.

name: Billionaires
bio: The co-founder of manufacturing and technology company Danaher, Mitchell Rales, along with brother Steven, left his father's real estate firm in 1979 and started buying small manufacturing companies during the junk bond frenzy of the 1980s. The result was Equity Group Holdings, co-founded with his billionaire brother. The brothers acquired a crippled REIT, and fused it with other industrial companies to form Danaher, named after the Montana stream where they once fished for trout. They took the industrial pump maker Colfax public in 2008. In January, Colfax finalized a $2.4 billion deal to buy British welding, cutting and automation company Charter International. A trustee of the National Gallery of Art, Mitchell has amassed a valuable collection of post-WWII art that includes works by Jeff Koons, Alexander Calder, and Jackson Pollock, housed at Glenstone, a private museum in Potomac, Md.

name: Billionaires
bio: Statistics wizard John Sall met partner James Goodnight at North Carolina State. They co-founded SAS in 1976; now it's the world's largest privately held software company. Sall runs the dynamic data visualization software division. The company saw a 12% increase in revenues to $2.72 billion in 2011 as clients looked to business intelligence to sort out where to make money. The company kept its 2009 promise of no layoffs; it reinvested 24% of 2011 revenue in research and development. The Cary, N.C.-based firm is known for worker-friendly policies, including wellness programs, on-site child care centers and free snacks. With Goodnight, Sall owns the tony Prestonwood Country Club, the Umstead Hotel & Spa and local private school Cary Academy. He is a trustee at N.C. State University.
title: Co-Founder, Executive Vice President
employment: {'name': 'SAS Institute', 'title': 'Co-Founder, Executive Vice President', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Canada's cheese king, Emanuele "Lino" Saputo, began his fortune by acquiring U.S. and Canadian dairies in the 1980s. As pizza consumption boomed, so did Saputo's wealth, leading the Sicilian emigre to corner a hunk of the market and eventually establish publicly traded cheese maker Saputo Inc. Now semi-retired, Saputo, a former mozzarella delivery boy, remains chairman of the board but has handed most day-to-day operational control of the company to his son Lino, Jr.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: After earning a doctorate in rocket science at MIT, Barry Sherman took his mother's life savings to buy his uncle's drug company. In 1974, that company became the foundation for Apotex, a Canadian generic drug company . Today, Apotex has sales over $1 billion, employs over 6,000 people in 21 facilities and produces 300 pharmaceuticals that are exported to 115 countries. Despite their manpower, a great deal of Apotex's work is done in courtrooms where the company is engaged in legal battles for their efforts to market cheaper, generic versions of brand name drugs. In October, a U.S. district court ruled that Apotex had to pay more than $400 million to Sanofi-Aventis for selling a generic version of the blood-thinning, Plavix, the world's second-largest selling drug.
title: Chairman and CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: With his brothers, Robert Bass controls one of the country's largest privately held oil outfits, Bass Enterprises Production. Sid Richardson, his father Perry's uncle, was an oil baron who left a piece of his fortune to the Basses in 1959. They made the most of it, in part by putting capital in the hands of legendary investor Richard Rainwater. The brothers sold one division to Southern Union for $1.6 billion in 2005. Robert co-founded private equity firm Oak Hill Capital Partners, which has $13 billion under management. Robert also invested in companies like Aerion, which is developing supersonic business jets. He recently paid $34 million for an apartment at 834 5th Avenue in Manhattan. Rupert Murdoch is his new neighbor, two floors up.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ana Lucia de Mattos Barretto Villela is a low-profile member of one of Brazil's oldest and most distinguished banking families. In 2008 her family's Banco Itau merged with Unibanco. Now she is one of the largest individual shareholders of Itau Unibanco Holding SA, Brazil's second biggest bank. Her brother, Alfredo, is the bank's vice chairman. She serves as president of the Alana Institute, a non-profit organization created in 1994 with the mission of promoting social work, education and culture.
person: {'name': 'Ana Lucia de Mattos Barretto Villela', 'uri': 'ana-lucia-de-mattos-barretto-villela', 'imageExists': False, 'squareImage': '//specials-images.forbesimg.com/imageserve/5e7422c310380d0006bdac2a/416x416.jpg?background=000000&cropX1=176&cropX2=2832&cropY1=268&cropY2=2925'}
personName: Ana Lucia de Mattos Barretto Villela

name: Billionaires
bio: It's been an active year for Abilio Diniz, chairman of Brazil's largest retailer by revenue, Companhia Brasileira de Distribuicao (CBD)-which runs supermarket chain Pao de Acucar.  In 2005 Diniz sold a stake in the company to French retailer Casino; the agreement stated that in June 2012, Casino has the option to obtain a share from Diniz that gives Casino control of the company. In July 2011, Diniz held talks with Casino rival Carrefour about buying in, but Casino's board rejected any such move. Per the shareholders' agreement, Diniz can (and likely will) remain chairman of CBD after Casino takes control in late June.

name: Billionaires
bio: Now 86, Albert Frere built the family's scrap-metal business into a media, utilities and oil empire, Compagnie Nationale a Portefeuille. In May 2011 he and French bank BNP Paribas took CNP private; the two parties paid more than $1.9 billion for 28% of the company they didn't own. In July 2008 Frere completed what some say is the greatest coup of his career by playing a key role in pushing through the stalled mega-merger of CNP's subsidiary Suez with French utility Gaz de France. The merged company, European energy giant GDF Suez, with $119 billion in sales, is now one of the largest independent electricity suppliers in the world.

name: Billionaires
bio: Danish furniture tycoon Lars Larsen's fortune is flat year on year; his IKEA-alike chain JYSK saw its revenues up about $180 million, not enough to change his net worth overall. "Duvet Larsen", as he's known in Denmark, was brought up on a potato farm and apprenticed in a bedding store. He opened his first bedding warehouse in 1979, and will open his 2,000th jysk store this year. His cut-price furnishings chain is in the middle of a big international push, targeting China among other markets. Larsen is a consummate self-promoter: in 2004, he sent copies of his autobiography to every household in Denmark. Those 2.4 million copies make him the country's most widely-read author.

name: Billionaires
bio: The only son of Samsung Group chairman Lee Kun-Hee, Jay Y. Lee became president and Chief Operating Officer (2009) of Samsung Electronics in December 2010. He began his career at Samsung Electronics in 1991 and had recently served as president for one year. Samsung Group, which accounts for almost 20 percent of South Korea's gross domestic product, is the world's top memory chip maker. Lee is known for keeping a low profile like his father, but attended the memorial service for Steve Jobs at Stanford University in October.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stock price of his Borneo-based coal mining outfit Bayan Resources has tripled since its 2008 listing in Indonesia. Company recently announced a $270 million deal to acquire a controlling stake in an Australian mining company. Born in Singapore, Low worked for his father's construction company there in his 20s. He moved to Indonesia in 1972 in search of better opportunities. He thrived as a building contractor but hit the jackpot after moving into coal mining. He bought his first mine in 1997, five years after becoming an Indonesian citizen. After a failed effort to sell out, Low took his coal company, Bayan Resources, public in 2008. He also has stakes in Singapore-listed Manhattan Resources and Singapore HealthPartners, which plans to open an integrated hospital, medical center and hotel there in 2013. Animal lover has a zoo in Borneo with dozens of animals including gibbons, sun bears, peacocks; rehabilitates orangutans for reintroduction into the wild.

name: Billionaires
bio: Low profile billionaire, Lotti, as she is known to her friends, is second largest shareholder of trendy apparel retailer Hennes & Mauritz, founded by her father Erling Persson in 1947. The biggest shareholder is her brother Stefan, who has run the company since 1982. Nephew Karl-Johan Persson became its chief executive in 2009

name: Billionaires
bio: Trevor Rees-Jones started as a bankruptcy lawyer, then switched to oil and gas. He was an early investor and early seller in the Barnett shale gas play in Texas, netting more than $1.5 billion. He also plowed cash into the Marcellus shale and has made another $2 billion selling acreage there to the likes of Chevron and Enerplus. Rees-Jones is now reinvesting in the Mississippian Lime play in Kansas and drilling in Utah with partner Occidental Petroleum. He is generous to Dallas charities, giving $25 million each to the new Museum of Nature & Science and the Boy Scouts. He is also a big backer of Karl Rove's American Crossroads SuperPAC.

name: Billionaires
bio: Roberts is one of the three original partners at the legendary private equity firm KKR and still active there. Among KKR's recent notable deals was an investment in Dalmia Cement in May 2010, to form the largest private cement company in India. Roberts made partner at Bear Stearns at age 29. He co-founded KKR with cousin Henry Kravis and Bear Stearns mentor Jerome Kohlberg in 1976. The firm was one of the first to use leverage in acquisitions. Kohlberg retired in 1987. Two years later, KKR orchestrated the $25 billion buyout of RJR Nabisco; the deal became the basis of the bestselling book Barbarians at the Gate. Roberts is a founder of REDF, a San Francisco non-profit that uses venture philanthropy to create job opportunities.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former trader of scrap metals Anil Agarwal runs London-listed, $11.4 billion (revenues) Vedanta Resources whose stock nearly halved in past year. He bought its shares in bid to boost investor confidence after government stopped company from mining bauxite in eastern India following protests over its mining practices. Expanded into oil: his deal to buy a 59% stake in Cairn India, which owns country's biggest onshore oilfield, finally secured crucial approval from government after objections from state-owned oil explorer ONGC caused delay. Brother Navin is now chairman of oil outfit and daughter Priya sits on its board.  Recently announced plan to merge Indian units Sesa Goa and Sterlite Industries. His much-touted Vedanta University, to which he pledged $1 billion, is stalled owing to problems related to land acquisition.

name: Billionaires
bio: Andrei Guriev, a Senator from Murmansk Oblast who controls the world's second-largest producer of phosphorous fertilizer concentrate, continues to benefit from a fertilizer boom. Last summer he sold a 10.8% stake in his Fosagro for $535 million; he still controls more than 70% of the company's stock. Guriev, a former Moscow communist committee leader, became an avid capitalist in the 1990s working with Mikhail Khodorkovsky's Menatep Group.He eventually chaired its subsidiary Apatit. During the prosecution of former billionaire Khodorkovsky, who has been in jail for years, Guriev led a management buyout of Apatit and acquired control.

name: Billionaires
bio: Macau mogul Stanley Ho, 90, has 17 children from four women, but only Pansy is now a billionaire, thanks to the successful June 2011 listing of MGM China, a JV with the U.S. gambling firm that she helped start in 2004 and now runs. She also got stakes in her father's SJM and Shun Tak Holdings after the family settled a feud over those assets in March 2011. Pansy also has Canadian citizenship.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of copper miner Kazakhmys and former member of Kazakh President Nazarbayev's political council, Vladimir Kim oversaw secondary listing of Kazakhmys in Hong Kong in June 2011. A couple of months later, Kazakhmys initiated a share buyback with hopes of boosting the miner's shares, down over 30% in the past year. Kim himself has sold more than $1 billion worth of shares since 2010. A descendent of Koreans forced by Stalin to move to Kazakhstan, Kim joined Kazakhmys during Khazakstan's early 1990s privatization wave.

name: Billionaires
bio: Starting out as flour trader, Kuok Khoon Hong runs world's largest palm oil firm, Wilmar International, in which his uncle Malaysian billionaire Robert Kuok has nearly one-third stake. It has expanded into sugar and real estate. In November, it reported a 25% jump in quarterly net profits to $321 million. Together with Indonesian billionaire and Wilmar shareholder Martua Sitorus, he bought London's Aviva Tower once owned by former billionaire Simon Halabi for $473 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: An unbeatable tic-tac-toe algorithm won Patrick McGovern a full ride to MIT. He was made associate publisher at his first computer magazine, Computers and Automation, while studying neurobiology. He sold his car for $5,000 and used the cash to found IDG. Today the media company has 200 magazines (PC World, CIO), 460 websites (CFOworld.com) and produces 700 events (Macworld, DEMO). All told,the group generated $3.24 billion in sales last year. McGovern dresses up as a national icon at IDG manager meetings: in China as Confucius, in Austria as Kaiser Franz Joseph, in Boston as Ben Franklin. He founded McGovern Institute for brain research at his alma mater.
title: Founder and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'International Data Group', 'title': 'Founder and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Elisabeth (Liz) Mohn is the widow of Reinhard Mohn and the owner of the media conglomerate Bertelsmann. Bertelsmann owns assets including European broadcaster RTL Group; Random House, the world's largest book-publishing group and Gruner + Jahr, Europe's biggest magazine publisher. Mohn serves on the supervisory board of Bertelsmann and on the board of the Bertelsmann Foundation. She and her family own 23% of Bertelsmann, while the remaining shares are controlled by the Bertelsmann Foundation. Liz and Reinhard Mohn had three children, two of whom are on the company's supervisory board. In the early 1990s, she founded the German Stroke Foundation and still serves as its president.

name: Billionaires
bio: Akira Mori's Mori Trust is taking a hit from the aftereffects of Japan's earthquake on his real estate holding company. Mori Trust is spending millions to create an emergency information-sharing network between main office buildings and other properties it manages and operates in Tokyo. Last year, immediately after the quake, operations in Sendai were affected; an in-house disaster response headquarters was set up collaborating with the Tokyo head office to help residents unable to return home. The company's subsidiary also has stake in Mori Trust Sogo REIT; the REIT's share price is down 20% this year. Akira, with brother Minoru, who is also a billionaire, inherited his initial fortune from his father. The brothers parted ways, with Akira focusing on office buildings, apartment blocks and hotels in high-rent districts of Tokyo.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dustin Moskovitz was Mark Zuckerberg's Harvard roommate and Facebook's third employee. The two dropped out of Harvard and moved to California to work for the social-networking firm full-time; he was its first chief technology officer and then vice president of engineering. He left in 2008 to start Asana, a collaboration and messaging software company that is aiming at tracking "the collective memory of organizations." Moskovitz sold a 1% stake in Facebook, but vows not to change his life much. He bikes to work and flies commercial. He is newly-engaged to former journalist Cari Tuna. The two met on a blind date. Tuna is overseeing his philanthropic outfit, Good Ventures. Both are hoping to use the transparency and community of the Web to guide giving. So far they've pledged to anti-malaria, education, and poverty-fighting charities.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Henry Ross Perot Sr. sold his data-processing firm Perot Systems to Dell in 2009 for $3.9 billion, pocketing some $400 million. His fortune is now concentrated in Hillwood, a massive nationwide real estate firm run by son H. Ross Perot, Jr. Hillwood's biggest project is the 18,000-acre AllianceTexas industrial park near Dallas, which includes homes, offices, a giant rail yard and its own airport. Hillwood also drills for oil and gas in Texas, Alabama and Iraq. With Marathon Oil and Maersk Oil it is developing the Sarsang field in the Kurdish region of Iraq. A cotton broker's son and former IBM salesman, Perot made his fortune selling his first data-processing firm EDS to GM for $2.5 billion in 1984. Perot Sr. was honored at the Army Heritage Center Foundation in July 2011 for donating to POWs' families, children of deceased soldiers and for supporting entertainment efforts for active troops through USO events.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lynn Schusterman is the widow of Oklahoma wildcatter Charles Schusterman (d. 2000) who built Samson Resources from nothing. Last November the Schustermans decided to sell most of Samson to a group led by KKR for $7.2 billion. Much of the windfall goes to the Charles & Lynn Schusterman Foundation. This is not the end of the family oil company though; the deal excluded deepwater Gulf of Mexico prospects like Buckskin and Moccasin that are in development now with Chevron. Lynn and daughter Stacy are dedicated givers to Jewish charities including Birthright Israel, as well as early-childhood education projects in Tulsa. Lynn splits her time between homes in Tulsa, New York and Jerusalem.

name: Billionaires
bio: Schwab founded his eponymous firm in a two-room office in 1971. Deregulation of brokerage commissions and the birth of online investing propelled the company to immensity. The company now manages $1.65 trillion in client assets. Charles left the chief executive post in 2008, but still sits as chairman. In January 2011, the firm fended off a drawn-out lawsuit over its mortgage-bond mutual fund YieldPlus, with a $119 million settlement, which Schwab called a "pimple" on the firm's record. Last March, the firm announced it was buying online brokerage services provider optionsXpress for $1 billion to capitalize on options trading. A dyslexic, Schwab has given to the Yale Center for Dyslexia and Creativity, the Hawaii Meth Project and young adult mental health programs at the University of California, San Francisco through his Charles and Helen Schwab Foundation.
title: Chairman and Founder
employment: {'name': 'Charles Schwab', 'uri': 'companies/charles-schwab', 'title': 'Chairman and Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers Malvinder and Shivinder Singh have been busy remaking their holdings ever since they sold their family's stake in pharma outfit Ranbaxy Laboratories, founded by their grandfather, to Daiichi Sankyo for $2 billion in 2008. They sold their privately owned outfits Super Religare Labs for $167 million and Fortis Healthcare International for $665 million, to Fortis Healthcare, creating $1 billion (revenues) healthcare giant. With a prsence in over 10 countries, it is among Asia's largest. Malvinder is executive chairman; Shivinder is vice chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Takemitsu Takizaki is the founder of Keyence, a leading supplier of sensors like photo-electric eyes and other electronic devices for factory automation systems. At a shareholder meeting last year, he won only 80% of votes for reappointment as chairman, despite holding 25% of shares himself. Media reports blamed this shareholder rebuff -- rare in Japan -- to dissatisfaction with balance sheet issues; despite steady, high profits, current dividend yield is below 1%. The company's stock price down 15% over the past year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tobacco king Lucio Tan holds over a third in Philip Morris-Fortune Tobacco, a joint venture between his privately held Fortune Tobacco and Philip Morris. Combined entity has an estimated 80% share of the Philippines cigarette market. His Asia Brewery is the country's second largest beer maker. A big chunk of fortune comes from Hong Kong-based Eton Properties. In December, he sought an investment from San Miguel Corp. to help refurbish the aging fleet of Philippine Airlines, which he controls. Three of his companies, Eton Properties Philippines, Tanduay Holdings and PAL Holdings, face delisting by the Philippine Stock Exchange for failing to maintain a 10% public float. He got his start as a chemical engineer and mopped floors to pay for school. Tan enjoys flying helicopters.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhang is the chairman of aluminum alloy producer China Hongqiao, the country's fifth-largest aluminum-products maker. It's been a rocky past year: the group canceled a planned IPO in January 2011 due to poor market conditions, and then got it off the ground in March, raising  $817 million. But then it tanked, causing investors that bought at the peak to lose more than half of their money. The underlying business was good in the first half of last year: Sales rose by 61% to 11.3 billion yuan, boosting profit by 44%, to 2.9 billion yuan. Zhang's family is also involved in cotton and yarn fabric maker Weiqiao Textile, where he and daughter Zhang Yanhong sit on the board; another daughter, Zhang Hongxia, is chair.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vasily Anisimov sold off of his stake in Metalloinvest-previously the majority of his fortune--to state-controlled bank VTB; a major chunk of the proceeds was used to repay a bank loan he'd taken out for his development company, Coalco. Boris Berezovsky claimed part of Metalloinvest and sued Anisimov for $600 million. The trial is ongoing. In the 1990s, Anisimov was one of the best-known Russian businessmen, and co-owner of aluminum plants and the bank Rossiyskiy Kredit. In 2000, he sold all his holdings in Russia and laid low for four years. In 2004, he made a comeback as co-owner of Metalloinvest with fellow billionaires Alisher Usmanov and Andrei Skoch.

name: Billionaires
bio: Pierre Bellon founded Sodexo as a catering and river cruise company in 1966 in a warehouse in Marseilles. Today the $21 billion (2011 sales) company supplies food to the U.S. Marine Corps; operates prisons; organizes major sports events such as the Ryder Cup, the Dakar Road Rally, and the World Scout Jamboree. BELLON OR SODEXO? also has majority stake in the Lido, the Parisian topless cabaret that features ice dancers and trapeze artists and a 90% stake in Yachts de Paris, one of the best-known cruise companies operating on the Seine. Sodexo became one of the leading food and facilities management services companies in India with its acquisition in 2011CK of Radhakrishna Hospitality Services Group for $90 million. Bellon stepped down as chief executive in 2005 but remains chairman. He penned his autobiography, "I've Had a Great Time".

name: Billionaires
bio: Leon Black is the lead partner of buyout shop Apollo Global Management. The firm, which has $75 billion in assets under management, went public in March 2011. He and the other partners didn't sell shares at the time of the IPO but did cash out some of their stake back in 2007, when CALPERS and Abu Dhabi Investment Authority invested. A former M&A boss at Drexel Burnham Lambert, Black and his two younger colleagues, Marc Rowan and Joshua Harris, also billionaires, formed Apollo in 1990 after Drexel collapsed. A prodigious art collector, Black owns works by old masters and impressionists, serves on the board of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and MoMA and also helped fund a biography of Pablo Picasso. He founded the stem cell initiative at Mount Sinai Hospital, and he and his wife founded the Melanoma Research Alliance, apparently the largest private foundation engaged in providing research to prevent and also find a cure for the disease.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gayle Cook, the wife of William Cook, inherited her husband's stake in the medical device company after he died in April, 2011. The couple created Cook Incorporated from humble beginnings in 1963 using a spare bedroom in their Bloomington, Indiana apartment as its first "factory." Now with offices stretching from the U.S. to Ireland to the far reaches of the Pacific Rim, the company specializes in stents and antibiotic-impregnated catheters. Next move: expanding throughout Asia (Hong Kong, Malaysia, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand, and China) via its Asia-Pacific Distribution Centre arm that has recently doubled in size. The couple spent $500 million to restore the luxury French Lick Resort and West Baden Springs Hotel in Indiana, adding a casino and a Pete Dye-designed PGA golf course. Due to their active philanthropy in hometown Bloomington, the mayor proclaimed June 20th Bill and Gayle Cook Day.
title: co-founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Alfredo Egydio Villela Filho is a member of one of Brazil's oldest banking families. He was chosen to lead the family business after the death of his great-uncle Olavo Setubal in 2008. That same year the family's Banco Itau merged with Unibanco. He is vice chairman of the board of Itau Unibanco Holding SA, Brazil's second biggest bank. Alfredo is among the largest individual shareholders of the bank. With his sister, Ana Lucia, he supports the Alana Institute, a non-profit organization created in 1994 with the mission of fostering and promoting social work, education and culture.

name: Billionaires
bio: Paul Tudor Jones' $8 billion flagship hedge fund, BVI Global Fund, produced a 2.12% net return last year--which was a pretty respectable result in 2011. Though his big hedge fund firm, Tudor Investment Company, did have one fund that returned a dismal -10.29% net of fees. Tudor is offering a new class of shares in his fund that will allow investors to choose between fees of 2.75% and 27% and the traditional 4% and 23% currently charged. Updated tax rolls in Greenwich, Ct., revealed 16 cars registered in Jones' name in February, and local legend has it that his Greenwich home features an underground garage. Jones made his first fortune trading cotton on Wall Street before going on to launch Tudor Investment Corp in 1980. Anticipating the 1987 market crash, Jones was able to triple his capital. An avid pheasant hunter and bass fisherman, the UVA grad owns property in the Florida Keys and in Zimbabwe. He is the founder of New York City's poverty-fighting Robin Hood Foundation, a favorite of many of Wall Street's elite.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Estée Lauder (d. 2004), Ronald Lauder serves as Chairman of Clinique Laboratories. Estée Lauder shares have risen 18% in the past year, boosting his net worth. His daughter Jane was elected to the Estée Lauder board in 2010; daughter Aerin is a senior vice president. He served as U.S. Ambassador to Austria from 1986 to '87 and Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for European & NATO Affairs from 1983 to '86. He has been president of the World Jewish Congress since June 2007. In 1987, Lauder established The Ronald S. Lauder Foundation, dedicated to rebuilding Jewish communities in Central and Eastern Europe. Like his older brother, Leonard, he owns a vast art collection. In 2006, he paid $135 million for a 1907 Klimt portrait, the largest sum ever spent on a single painting at the time.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wal-Mart heiress Nancy Walton Laurie received a large amount of the retailer's stock after her father, James "Bud" Walton -- brother of the retail giant's famous founder Sam -- died in 1995. Today, those shares are worth $3.4 billion, with a $600 million boost this year thanks to a 14% uptick in Wal-Mart's share price. In 1999, Laurie bought hockey's St. Louis Blues with her husband Bill, only to sell it six years later. She also founded Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet in New York in 2003, and owns Providence Bank, commercial real estate, and shopping centers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Liu Yonghao is chairman of the New Hope Group, one of China's largest agribusiness companies.  New Hope also has interests in finance, chemicals and real estate. In the past year Liu changed the name of his main listed company into New Hope Liuhe after it purchased some of his privately held businesses, including Liuhe Group. Liu was a teacher before he started his first business in a village in Chengdu with his brothers Liu Yongyan, Liu Yongxing and Chen Yuxin in 1982; they invested their first income from selling watches and bicycles in agribusiness. Today, Liu also sits on the board of China Minsheng Banking, one of China's largest non-government controlled banks. Liu's daughter Liu Chang is a director of New Hope Group and was named as one of 15 women to watch in connection with Forbes Asia's "50 Power Businessmen" list published in March. It has been reported that her father hopes she will succeed him.  Liu Yonghao's elder brother Liu Yongxing is also a member of the 2012 Forbes World's Billionaires list.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lorenzo Mendoza continues to head Empresas Polar, one of Venezuela's largest private companies. The firm produces Polar beer and staples like flour, condiments, tuna fish and wine. Mendoza is the grandson of Empresas Polar's founder. Leftist President Hugo Chavez regularly attacks Mendoza in the press, and this year Mendoza has fired back with criticisms of the country's strict price controls. Despite Chavez's continued public threats to nationalize Polar if it is caught hoarding food (Polar said it has no role in the country's food shortages), the company remains private. In 2010, Mendoza received the Americas Business Council's award in recognition of his contributions to creating positive change in Latin America. The Mendoza family operates and finances one of Venezuela's biggest charities.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bruno Schroder is the fourth generation in his banking family to operate their eponymous financial-services company, Schroders; he is a non-executive director. Shares of the company are down from their all time high in February of last year, decreasing the fortune he shares with his sister Charmaine. His nephew, Philip Mallinckrodt, sits on the company board. In his spare time, Schroder flies his private plane and breeds Middle White pigs at his estate in Islay, Scotland.

name: Billionaires
bio: Silicon Valley real estate magnate John A. Sobrato began his career selling residential real estate after graduating from Santa Clara University. The Sobrato Organization now owns and manages 8 million square feet of commercial office space and 30 apartment facilities with nearly 7,300 units. Commercial tenants include Yahoo and Nvidia. His son John M. Sobrato is the CEO. The company has donated more than $300 million in office space in the past five years, including a $135 million building in San Jose to the Sobrato Family Foundation. In January, Sobrato and his wife made a $5 million donation to the Santa Clara Valley Medical Center for a new hospital wing, which will be called the John A. and Susan Sobrato Pavilion. He has also pledged $20 million for a new hospital wing--to be called the Sobratto Pavilion--under construction at Lucile Packard Children's Hospital at Stanford.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Shipping rates have fallen because of overcapacity in the industry, holding down the value of his family's flagship, Oriental Overseas (Intl.). Chairman C.C. runs the company, which has offices in 55 countries. In January 2011  it sold its real estate development arm, Orient Overseas Developments. Brother C.H. Tung, a former chairman and a former Hong Kong chief executive who shares the fortune, is active in U.S.-China diplomacy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Certified jet pilot Steven Udvar-Hazy heads Air Lease Corp, which he took public last year, raising more than $900 million. The company has 105 jets in its fleet and 260 new Boeing and Airbus jets on order for delivery between 2012 and 2016. Udvar-Hazy moved to New York from Budapest as a child. He entered the aircraft business while still an undergraduate at UCLA, putting together a $1 million deal for Air New Zealand during his senior year. With fellow Hungarians Louis and Leslie Gonda, he used $150,000 in savings and a $1.7 million bank loan to start International Lease Finance Corp. In 1990, he sold the company to American International Group for $1.3 billion in stock. Though Udvar-Hazy says he sold his AIG stock long before the financial crisis, he stuck around as chief of the International Lease Finance unit until early 2010. He donated $65 million to the Smithsonian's National Air and Space Museum, to build the Steven F. Udvar-Hazy Center near Dulles airport, which displays planes and other artifacts that don't fit into the space on the National Mall. He has also given $100 million to Stanford University.
title: Director

name: Billionaires
bio: His Malaysia Mining Corp. runs Johor Port and the state's airport. Won a big contract with Gamuda (see Nos. 33 and 38) to oversee construction of the mass-transit rail system in Kuala Lumpur. Set up Albukhary International University, and his Albukhary Foundation funds remedial classes for thousands of underachieving students from poor rural families each year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Otto Beisheim cofounded retailer Metro AG in 1964 with the Schmidt-Ruthenbeck and Haniel families. Beisheim owns some 10% of the publicly traded $89 billion (sales) company. In the last 12 months, shares have fallen nearly 50 percent due to a company-issued profit warning and the surprising departure of CEO Eckhard Cordes at the end of 2011. Beisheim manages Beisheim Holding Schweiz AG, which invests in Internet and technology companies. He also owns Beisheim Center, a high-end complex in Berlin with apartments, office buildings, two five-star hotels, shops and cafes. Beisheim maintains homes in Switzerland, Paris and Germany's Rottach-Egern. A former widower with no children, he remarried in 2008 to new wife, Lise Evers. During the winter, he resides in Miami.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cargill heir Pauline MacMillan Keinath is one of seven billionaire relatives who hold a majority of Cargill, the largest private company in the U.S. Cargill makes money in all areas of food production from animal feed, meat, and crops to commodity trading and risk management. The company divested itself of its stake in fertilizer maker Mosaic in 2011. William Cargill, the son of a Scottish sea captain, founded the Iowa grain storage business after the Civil War. Will's son-in-law John MacMillan took control in 1909, and no family member has run the company since Whitney MacMillan stepped down as chief executive in 1995.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Casino magnate Kirk Kerkorian stepped down from the board of MGM Resorts International in June to become a senior adviser and the first director emeritus. The move accompanied his sale of 20 million shares in the company. In February 2011 he pledged $200 million from his Lincy Foundation to UCLA. In December, his energy company Delta Petroleum Corp filed for bankruptcy, and in the fallout, Kerkorian sued a former friend, Edward Michael Davis of Las Vegas, for fraud. 
His $8.5 billion gamble, City Center, opened in Las Vegas in December 2009. The casino was the most expensive privately funded real estate deal in U.S. history. His stake in MGM was worth $11 billion during 2007; however today it's down to roughly $1.2 billion. In 1966, he launched Trans International Airlines and sold it for a $104 million profit. He has bought and sold MGM Studios three times and is rumored to be looking to buy his way back into the film industry. An eighth-grade dropout, he trained World War II fighter pilots. His Lincy Foundation, which was founded to aid victims of the 1989 Armenian earthquake, and Tracinda Corporation are named after his two daughters, Tracy and Linda.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kim Jung-Ju is the founder of Nexon, Korea's largest online gaming company that created popular games "Kart Rider" and "Maple Story." In 2010, he expanded by acquiring rivals Ndoors and Gamehi. Nexon has 350 million users all over the world in more than 72 countries; 64% of its revenues come from outside South Korea. His wife Yoo Jung-Hyun is also a major shareholder.  The company was listed on Tokyo's stock exchange in December 2011.

name: Billionaires
bio: Real estate developer Ted Lerner made his fortune building massive shopping malls in the suburbs of Washington, D.C. A former lawyer, he borrowed $300 from his wife to start his development company, Lerner Enterprises, in 1952. Today Lerner owns 20 million square feet of commercial and retail space, as well as 7,000 apartments and 750 private home lots. He's currently building new projects in Tyson's Corner and Dulles Town Center. Lerner is also the majority owner of baseball's Washington Nationals and owns a smaller stake in regional broadcast network, Mid-Atlantic Sports Network (MASN).

name: Billionaires
bio: Donna MacMillan is the widow of Cargill heir Cargill MacMillan, who died in November 2011. She is one of seven billionaire relatives who hold a majority of Cargill, the largest private company in the U.S. Based in Minneapolis, Cargill makes money in all areas of food production from animal feed, meat, and crops to commodity trading and risk management. The company divested itself of its stake in fertilizer maker Mosaic in 2011. William Cargill, the son of a Scottish sea captain, founded the Iowa grain storage business after the Civil War. Will's son-in-law John MacMillan took control in 1909, and no family member has run the company since Whitney MacMillan stepped down as chief executive in 1995.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cargill heir Whitney MacMillan is one of seven billionaire relatives who hold a majority of Cargill, the largest private company in the U.S. Based in Minneapolis, Cargill makes money in all areas of food production from animal feed, meat, and crops to commodity trading and risk management. The company divested itself of its stake in fertilizer maker Mosaic in 2011. William Cargill, the son of a Scottish sea captain, founded the Iowa grain storage business after the Civil War. Will's son-in-law John MacMillan took control in 1909, and no family member has run the company since Whitney stepped down as chief executive in 1995.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cargill heir Gwendolyn Meyer, the daughter of the late Marion MacMillan Pictet, is one of seven billionaire relatives who hold a majority of Cargill, the largest private company in the U.S. Cargill, based in Minneapolis, makes money in all areas of food production, from animal feed, meat, and crops to commodity trading and risk management.The company divested itself of its stake in fertilizer maker Mosaic in 2011. William Cargill, the son of a Scottish sea captain, founded the company, then an Iowa grain storage business, after the Civil War. Will's son-in-law John MacMillan took control in 1909, and no family member has run the company since Whitney MacMillan stepped down as chief executive in 1995.

name: Billionaires
bio: Qiu Guanghe is chairman of Zhejiang Semir Garment, one of China's largest apparel chains and a rival to fellow Chinese billionaire Zhou Chengjian's Metersbonwe.  Investors who bought into Semir's IPO on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange got burned last year: It ended the year down by more than a third. Qiu focuses on two brands: casual "Semir," aimed at consumers aged 16-25; and a kid's brand, "Balabala," targeted at 3 -12 year olds.  Sales in the nine months to September gained 30% from a year earlier to 5.2 billion yuan or $830 million, helping to boost net profit 26% to 808 million yuan, or $128 million. Qiu's son-in-law Zhou Pingfan is vice chairman of the listed company. His son Qiu Jianqiang is a director and the general manager. The company is reportedly aiming to launch a new brand this year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Co-founder of manufacturing and technology company Danaher, Steven Rales, along with brother Mitchell, left his father's real estate firm in 1979 and started buying small manufacturing companies during the junk bond frenzy of the 1980s. The result was Equity Group Holdings, co-founded with his billionaire brother. The brothers acquired a crippled REIT, and fused it with other industrial companies to form Danaher, named after the Montana stream where they once fished for trout. They took the industrial pump maker Colfax public in 2008. In January, Colfax finalized a $2.4 billion deal to buy British welding, cutting and automation company Charter International.  Steven is now chairman of the board of Danaher. He is reportedly a dedicated supporter of the Washington Ballet and DePauw University. He also founded a film production company in Santa Monica, Calif., Indian Paintbrush, which produced Wes Anderson's "The Darjeeling Limited", "Fantastic Mr. Fox" and the upcoming "Moonrise Kingdom."
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Andreas Strungmann left his medical practice in South Africa to join his identical twin brother Thomas and found generic drug maker Hexal AG in 1986. The pair eventually built it into Germany's second-largest generic drug maker. In 2005, they sold the business and their 68% stake in U.S.-based Eon Labs to Novartis for $7.5 billion. The brothers now manage their Santo Holding, which invests primarily in the German biotech sector, with a focus on cancer research.  They established a neuroscience research center in Frankfurt named after their father, Ernst Strungmann. Andreas is known to love sailing, golf and skiing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Thomas Strungmann, with his identical twin, Andreas, founded generic drug maker Hexal AG in 1986. They eventually built it into Germany's second-largest generic drug maker. In 2005, they sold the business and their 68% stake in U.S.-based Eon Labs to Novartis for $7.5 billion. The brothers now manage their Santo Holding, which invests primarily in the German biotech sector, with a focus on cancer research. They established a neuroscience research center in Frankfurt named after their father, Ernst Strungmann. Thomas is said to be the more extroverted of the twins. He reportedly collects modern art and Swiss watches.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhou Chengjian chairs Shanghai Metersbonwe Fashion & Accessories, one of China's largest apparel retailers. The former tailor owns 90% of the Shanghai-listed company with his daughter Hu Jiajia. Business has thrived amid China's double-digit annual growth in consumer spending. Sales grew 40% in the first nine months of 2011 from a year earlier to  $1.1 billion; net profit soared 132% to $118 million. The company has two main retail brands -- Metersbonwe and Me & City. Metersbonwe's MTEE shirts were worn in the summer Hollywood hit, "Transformers: Dark of the Moon," and the company launched an MTEE campaign around popular Taiwan singer Jay Chou.

name: Billionaires
bio: David and Frederick Barclay have been engaged in a very public battle with Irish property developer Paddy McKillen for the past few months as the identical twins look to take 100% control of London's luxury Maybourne hotel empire, including Claridges, the Berkeley and the Connaught. The two already own the capital's exclusive Ritz and Cavendish hotels as well as a handful of casinos. The Barclays started together in the accounts department at General Electric and then flipped houses before buying their first hotel in 1975. Their business umbrella now includes the Telegraph Newspaper Group and U.K.'s largest online retailer, Shop Direct Group. The media-shy duo live together in a mansion on the isle of Brecqhou in the English Channel and have significant investments on neighboring Sark.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ron Burkle made his first fortune in grocery stores and continues to invest in private companies that support the food trade in areas like logistics, cold storage and food safety. He's also dipped his toe into technology and social media, co-investing with actor Ashton Kutcher in companies like Airbnb, Foursquare and Flipboard. He lost a proxy fight with bookseller Barnes & Noble in 2010 but added more to his position last year and now owns just under 20%. The son of a grocer, Burkle joined a union local as a box boy at age 13. In 1986 he formed investment firm Yucaipa, and bought and sold supermarket chains Fred Meyer, Jurgensen's, Ralphs and others. Most recently, he has taken a stake in movie studio, Relatively Media. He also controls Soho House. The high-end, members-only club chain with locations in New York City, Los Angeles and London, plans to expand into India and China.
title: Founder
employment: {'name': 'The Yucaipa Companies, LLC', 'title': 'Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Dr. Thomas Frist's hospital giant HCA went public for the third time in 2010. The company, in which he is still the biggest shareholder, is now worth less than $13 billion, well below the $40 billion estimated before the offering. The former Air Force flight surgeon started HCA with his father in 1968; it went public a year later. He led a management buyout of the firm in 1989 only to take it public again three years later. He then took the company private in 2006 in a $33 billion buyout with help from KKR, Bain and Bank of America. Next he restructured the board to include his two sons, and when the company issued a $2.2 billion cash dividend in 2010, he pocketed $400 million. HCA is expanding in China, building a hospital with the Chinese government, 100 miles south of Shanghai.

name: Billionaires
bio: Usually cautious, John Gandel is poised to expand his retail empire aggressively. His half-owned $3.4 billion shopping center Chadstone is adding a $525 million hotel and office tower, and he has $475 million to play with after selling a stake in another center. The son of Polish immigrants, John Gandel took the fortune his parents made in the women's clothing business and crafted a retail empire. He gave $7.5 million to the National Gallery of Australia in 2010. He supports The Gandel Institute for Adult Jewish Learning.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heidi Horten is the widow of Helmut Horten, founder of eponymous German department store chain. He died in 1987 and left her an estimated $1 billion fortune. She divides her time between a penthouse in Vienna, a residence in Tessin, Switzerland, and a home in Lyford Cay in the Bahamas. She owns one of the world's largest yachts, the 315-foot Carinthia VII. In 2008 she sold a 35.5 carat diamond, once part of the crown jewels of Bavaria, for $24 million at Christie's. Horten is said to enjoy hunting and collecting art. She met Helmut in a hotel bar in 1959 when she was 19; he was 30 years older.

name: Billionaires
bio: After studying art history at Wroclaw University, "Basia" left Poland for the United States in 1968, landing a job as the chambermaid of Johnson & Johnson heir John Seward Johnson and his wife Esther. By 1971 Johnson had divorced his wife and married Piasecka. Upon Johnson's death in 1983 Piasecka inherited the bulk of his fortune, including 18 million shares of Johnson & Johnson, now worth more than $2 billion. She also got the couple's Princeton, New Jersey estate, Jasna Polana, which she later transformed into a country club with the manor house serving as club house. Piasecka is an art and antiques collector, with a particular interest in Baroque and Old Masters. In 2004 she sold the world's most expensive piece of furniture, Badminton Cabinet, to Prince Hans-Adam II of Liechtenstein for a record $36.7 million, and in December 2009 sold a Rembrandt to Steve Wynn for $33 million. Piasecka is an supporter of Art for Autism and funds philanthropic initiatives in her native Poland.

name: Billionaires
bio: Real estate mogul Stanley Kroenke has been rumored to be in the running to buy the Los Angeles Dodgers. Already the owner of the basketball franchise, the Denver Nuggets, and the Colorado Avalanche hockey team, Kroenke upped his stakes in the St. Louis Rams football team and the English soccer club Arsenal in the last year. To comply with NFL ownership rules, he will have to relinquish ownership of the Nuggets and Avalanche before 2015. He made his first fortune developing commercial and retail properties. Today his THF Realty operates shopping centers in nearly half the U.S., many anchored by Wal-Mart. Kroenke owns Canada's largest cattle ranch and two wineries. He is married to Ann Walton Kroenke, daughter of James (Bud) Walton and niece of Wal-Mart founder Sam Walton.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lucas made the best deal of all time back in the '70s when he insured himself a cut of all 'Stars Wars'- related toys. He continues to rake in money from the franchise which is now getting a new life with 3-D re-releases of the last three movies. 'Red Tails,' the first movie Lucas has produced since 2008, was a box office dud. No matter. The mogul still earns big from Industrial Light and Magic, his special effects house that is now moving into animation.
title: Director/Producer

name: Billionaires
bio: With his now-deceased brother Y.C. Wang, Wang Yung-tsai helped to build Taiwan's Formosa Plastics Group into one of the world's largest petrochemical companies. Though he no longer sits on the board or has management role, he continues to hold stake.

name: Billionaires
bio: Han Chang-Woo immigrated from Korea and made a fortune in Japan and now plans to donate most of his wealth to solidify relations between the two nations, primarily via scholarships. He expects his son will succeed him at the helm of Maruhan, Japan's largest operator of pachinko parlors, as well as bowling alleys, golf driving ranges and movie theaters. The company's subsidiaries operate in the food industry, building maintenance and banking. After Japan's earthquake, Maruhan donated nearly $8.5 million collectively as disaster relief.

name: Billionaires
bio: As he attempts to turn around his largest investment, Sears Holdings Corporation, Lampert is committing ever more of his personal capital to the struggling venture. In January he bought more than $130 million worth of Sears stock from his ESL Investments, reportedly because the Ziff family, ESL investors, wanted to cash out. Lampert's personal share purchases came after Sears announced in late December 2011 that as many as 120 locations would be shuttered. Lampert is a lawyer's son who read corporate reports and financial textbooks in high school before heading to Yale where he was a member of Skull & Bones. After graduating, he learned alongside billionaire investor Daniel Och in the risk arbitrage department at Goldman Sachs. In 1988, Lampert went solo and later acquired Kmart in bankruptcy by buying its bonds. He then merged Kmart with Sears Roebuck and Co. and has served as chairman of the combined company since 2005.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alexander Nesis and fellow billionaires Suleiman Kerimov and Filaret Galchev, who together controlled Russian fertilizers producer Uralkali, completed a merger deal with Silvinit in 2011; Nesis's stake in the combined company is now 8.5%. Nesis started out in the 1990s reinvesting profits from Central Asian uranium mining into other metals and shipbuilding. He created miner Polymetal, then sold the company to Kerimov in 2005. Three years later, Nesis bought back a stake at a rock-bottom price in the heat of the financial crisis; Nesis now owns 19%. His ICT Group also controls Nomos Bank, a railroad-car repair factory, a chemicals factory and land for housing developments.

name: Billionaires
bio: Terence (Terry) Pegula has shifted his focus from natural gas to ice hockey rinks and sports management. He sold his oil and gas company, East Resources, to Royal Dutch Shell for $4.7 billion in May 2010 and bought his hometown team, the NHL's Buffalo Sabres, for $189 million from billionaire Tom Golisano in February 2011. He also donated $88 million to his alma mater, Penn State, to build a hockey arena and field a division one team. In December he purchased the NFL player-agent firm France Allpro Sports Management and brought longtime friend and agent Brian Ayrault to the company. So far the venture into sports is a work in progress. The Sabres are struggling near the bottom of the NHL's Eastern Conference. A former Penn State math major, Pegula switched to petroleum engineering for a scholarship and joined Getty Oil after graduation. He founded East Resources with a $7,500 loan from friends and family in 1983 to drill sand wells. He later expanded his business, buying Pennzoil Assets from Devon Energy for $31 million in 2000.
title: Owner

name: Billionaires
bio: Karen Pritzker is now the wealthiest of the 11 members of the extended, Chicago-based Pritzker family on the billionaires list. She is a granddaughter of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who built industrial conglomerate Marmon and hotel chain Hyatt with his sons Jay (d. 1999), Donald (d. 1972) and Robert (d. 2011), Karen's father. While other family members have been selling their stakes in Hyatt, Karen and husband Michael Vlock, an investor, have held onto their shares. They invest in buy-and-hold stocks; their biggest holding other than Hyatt is in Apple. Michael's physician brother partnered with an inventor and developed a drug to prevent and treat infections; Karen and her husband invested $3 million and later licensed the drug to SanofiAventis for $375 million plus royalties; Pritzker and Vlock have a majority stake. The couple also has a venture fund, LaunchCapital LLC, and stakes in a chain of grilled cheese restaurants and a battery-operated surfboard/paddleboard-maker. The couple is a major donor to Yale, and gave $1.5 million over three years to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research, in honor of Karen's father, who had Parkinson's.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tax lawyer-turned-real estate developer Stephen Ross has been on the prowl for distressed property since the downturn via his Related Cos., recently closing on an $825 million fund to purchase more. He has begun work on New York City's Hudson Yards, with a plan to create a new neighborhood. The massive complex will host Coach's headquarters and Danny Meyer restaurants; Ross acquired a stake in the celebrity chef's company. He's also investing in affordable housing in major metro areas like Hunter's Point South, the biggest affordable housing complex in New York since the 1970s. His luxe developments continue to perform well: He sold out three high-end condo buildings in New York, including a $31.5 million record-breaking penthouse sale. His 1.2 million square foot Manhattan development MiMA is more than 90% leased. New high-end residential buildings are underway in Chicago and Santa Monica, Calif. Ross has offices in Shanghai and Abu Dhabi, where the company has partnered with Mubadala Development Co. to develop a project called Sowwah Square. In 2009 he completed a $1 billion purchase of pro football's Miami Dolphins, maintaining a 95% ownership stake. Ross was awarded an honorary doctorate from his undergraduate alma mater University of Michigan, where his donations have resulted in a business school with his name on it.

name: Billionaires
bio: Naguib Sawiris, the eldest son of Egyptian billionaire Onsi Sawiris, built Orascom Telecom, then sold the family's stake to Russian and emerging market telecom giant VimpelCom in April for $6.5 billion in shares and cash, becoming one of VimpelCom's largest shareholders in the process. He's still looking to reinvest in telecom. In January, he reportedly bought 21% of Telekom Austria with Austrian investor Ronny Pecik. Sawiris plunged into politics when he formed last year the Free Egyptians party to promote free markets and a secular government. Although he apologized, hard-line Islamists wanted him tried on charges of insulting Islam for tweeting a bearded Mickey Mouse and a veiled Minnie.

name: Billionaires
bio: Keichiro Takahara is the chairman and founder of Unicharm, maker of diapers, sanitary napkins and other personal-care goods; company's stock price rose nearly 40% over the past year as it launched in Vietnam and China and margins expanded. It also has a successful joint venture with Sumitomo's US based pet business, Hartz. His son, Takahisa, the group's chief executive, has focused the company on overseas expansion since taking the helm in 2001.

name: Billionaires
bio: South Africa's Christoffel Wiese, known as Christo, is the chairman and the largest single shareholder of the African continent's biggest retailer, low-price supermarket chain Shoprite. The company's shares climbed 50% since last year, boosting Wiese's fortune. He also owns a large stake in discount clothes, shoes and textiles chain Pepkor (slogan: "Making the desirable affordable"), where he is executive chairman. Last March, he bought several hundred million dollars of shares in private equity investor Brait, which also has a large stake in Pepkor. Wiese also has investments in gold and diamond mining concerns, real estate holding companies and in Pallinghurst, a private equity firm with investments in mining and in storied jeweler Fabergé. Other interests: Wiese restored a South African farm estate and remodeled it into a five-star hotel, Lanzerac Manor & Winery. He replanted the vineyards around it, created a modern cellar and has been making wine. He also owns wine producer Lourensford Estate and a private game reserve in the Kalahari.

name: Billionaires
bio: Igor Zyuzin's Mechel Group announced last year its second attempt to take its subsidiary Mechel-Mining, the group's consolidated mining assets, public, selling up to 25% of the company; however, the IPO was postponed again. Zyuzin started out with partner Vladimir Iorich in 1995, forming Uglemetkooperatsiya, a coal-trading company, which was among the first to buy up shares in coal mines and pits in the Kuzbass region. In 2001 the partners bought a controlling stake in Chelyabinsk Metals Factory, which formed the basis of the Mechel Group, now consisting of more than 20 plants and coals mines around the world. Three years later, its shares began trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The firm bought a US coal miner, Bluestone Coal, for $425 million plus shares in 2009.

name: Billionaires
bio: After returning capital to investors in 2011, the former star Enron trader's Centaurus Advisors now manages $3.5 billion, with Arnold's personal capital accounting for well over half of the total assets. Coming off of what was rumored to be his first down year in 2010, this hedge fund manager introduced a new, leaner management fee of just 1.5% in 2011 and produced net returns of 9%. Arnold began trading oil at Enron in 1995 and is said to have earned $750 million for company in 2001. When the energy outfit famously collapsed a year later, he went into business for himself founding Centaurus, a hedge fund focusing mostly on natural gas and energy trading. He bought up hedge fund Amaranth Advisors' losing positions in natural gas in 2006 in the trade that propelled him to billionaire status. Arnold has signed onto the Warren Buffett-Bill Gates Giving Pledge, to donate more than half his net worth. His Laura and John Arnold Foundation has more than $700 million in assets according to the organization's most recent tax filing. The foundation focuses on criminal justice, improving K-12 education and public accountability.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers Martin and Olivier Bouygues hold 19% of the Bouygues Group, a diversified industrial conglomerate founded by their father in 1952. Martin serves as chairman and CEO, a post he has held for 22 years, while Olivier serves as the deputy chief executive. The company initially specialized in industrial works and construction but has expanded into other industries, mainly telecom and media. Notable projects include the Hassan II Mosque in Casablanca, Morocco; the University of Riyadh in Saudi Arabia; the English Channel Tunnel; the Kwun Tong viaduct in Hong Kong; numerous motorways in Hungary; and the Sydney CityRail airport link. The brothers purchased a famous vineyard, the Chateau Montrose, in 2006 and have been selling wine for the past few years. Martin is a close friend of French President Nicolas Sarkozy as well as the godfather of the president's son. Martin  was also awarded the Legion d'honneur in July 2010.

name: Billionaires
bio: Andre Esteves, the hard working chief executive of Brazilian investment bank BTG Pactual, took a step to enlarge the bank with a deal announced in February in which BTG will buy Chile's Celfin Capital for $245 million plus shares equivalent to 2.4% of BTG's total capital. The takeover makes BTG Pactual the largest independent investment bank in Latin America. In December 2010 Esteves sold 18% of the bank to a consortium of foreign institutional investors for $1.8 billion, valuing the bank at $10 billion. In 2011 Esteves vowed to take BTG public in 2012; that may be delayed given the recent acquisition news. Working up from the IT department, Esteves made his mark in the 1990s as an ace trader at Brazilian investment bank Pactual, which was later bought by Swiss bank UBS. In 2009 he engineered the repurchase of Pactual from UBS.

name: Billionaires
bio: After taking a historic beating in 2008, Griffin's flagship hedge funds, Kensington and Wellington, funds each produced net returns north of 20% in 2011. Their performance brought to an end what has been a three year battle for this hedge fund manager, as his funds clawed their way back to their pre-recession high-water marks. In his year end letter to investors Griffin specifically credited his investment team and "valuable lessons we have learned during prior periods of market turmoil" for the firm's success. 2011 wasn't all good news, however: Griffin's firm, Citadel, sold its investment banking unit to Wells Fargo, effectively extinguishing his dream of building a full-service financial institution. A noted art collector, Griffin dropped $80 million on Jasper Johns' "False Start" in 2006 and sits on the boards of the Museum of Contemporary Art and the Art Institute of Chicago. Griffin began investing as a Harvard undergrad when he read a Forbes article about the Home Shopping Network. Citadel currently manages approximately $11 billion.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Swedish billionaire Bertil Hult got rich helping others learn. He dropped out of college after a year to start a business in his dormitory's basement, helping set up students with host families. The company, EF Education First, focuses on cultural exchanges, educational travel, language training and degree programs. Its programs are now available in over 50 countries. It was the official supplier of language training for the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games. Hult, who has passed the reins of EF to his sons, donates money to a Swedish school annually, based on innovative support for dyslexia education. He made headlines when he lent his yacht, the Erica XII, and his private jet to Swedish royals Crown Princess Victoria and Prince Daniel for their 2010 honeymoon.  He is a trustee and former chairman of the Mentor Foundation. He is an avid sailor.

name: Billionaires
bio: Before founding Southern California sunglasses juggernaut Oakley, Jannard sold rubber grips for motorcycles and BMX bikes out of the trunk of his car. Oakley rose to prominence in the cycling, skateboarding and motocross scenes after Jannard persuaded star athletes to wear his high-tech lenses. The company went public in 1995. By the time he sold Oakley to Leonardo Del Vecchio's optics giant Luxottica in 2007 for $2.1 billion, Oakley's product line included goggles, apparel, bags and footwear. In 2005 Jannard founded RED Digital cinema cameras. RED cameras have been used to shoot "The Social Network," "The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo," and "The Artist," among other films.

name: Billionaires
bio: After his lawyers produced documents last year proving that Kamprad had irrevocably transferred the majority of his economic stake in global furniture retailer Ikea to his philanthropic foundations, later selling them the balance, his net worth took a drastic slide. But with the exception of his winery in Provence, Kamprad has historically shown little interest in the trappings of wealth anyway. He reportedly drives a Volvo 240 GL he has owned for two decades. At age 85 his great love remains Ikea and the culture he built that made Ikea one of the world's most successful brands and retailers. Known for his relentless pursuit of efficiency, Kamprad introduced the flat-pack in 1953, moved production to Soviet Poland in 1961 to minimize labor costs and publishes the Furniture Dealer's Testament or the "Ikea Bible," which includes maxims such as "wasting resources is a mortal sin at Ikea." Through his Ikano Group, Kamprad currently has interests in banking, real estate, asset management and insurance; Ikea is one of the firm's biggest customers.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner and fellow billionaire Henadiy Boholyubov,  Ihor Kolomoyskyy controls Privat group, a banking and industrial conglomerate. Began with Privatbank, which was founded with $1 million of capital in early 1990s; now the partners plan to take Privatbank public on the London stock exchange this year. Oil producer Ukrnafta, in which Kolomoyskyy holds 10% stake, is also preparing to IPO; there are plans to integrate other group oil refineries and terminals and grow Ukrnafta. Outside of Privat, Kolomoyskyy has a 4.5% stake in Roman Abramovich's Evraz as well as energy interests. With his partner Bogolyubov, Kolomoyskyy is building the world's biggest multifunctional Jewish center, the Menorah Centre in Dnepropetrovsk; it is set to open this fall.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lin Yu-lin is one of Taiwan's largest landlords and developers, owning prominent properties in Taipei's top business districts, including near skyscraper Taipei 101. An avid golfer, Lin has also profited from ties to the island's financial services industry, with interests in banking and insurance. Brother Lin Rong San, who appears on this year's billionaires' list, has a separate real estate empire.

name: Billionaires
bio: Richard Livingstone, a chartered surveyor, and his older brother Ian, a former optometrist, kicked off their business career together by opening optical stores and acquiring the David Clulow optical chain in 1992 (which they sold in 2011). Their main business these days is real estate, which they first entered in the late 1980s when they founded a property trading company. They now operate multiple property investment vehicles under the umbrella firm Loopsign Limited, with interests in various countries, including the UK, Germany, Russia, and Panama. Last year the brothers purchased the Cliveden House Hotel, an iconic 5-star hotel near London. In 2011, they sold the company's interests in Scandinavia and South Africa, most notably the V&A Waterfront in Cape Town.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lu Zhiqiang is chairman of the China Oceanwide Group, which like many pioneering Chinese private-sector businesses has diversified over the years.  Lu made money in real estate in Shandong Province in the 1980s when that industry was opening up to reform after years of Mao-era slumber. Today he controls Shenzhen-listed Oceanwide Real Estate Group, one of the largest sources of his wealth.  In the 1990s, he co-founded China Minsheng Banking when the government opened the door to private-sector investors in the banking industry. In Sept. 2009, Lu invested in Legend Holdings of Beijing at a time when one of its main investments-- computer maker Lenovo -- was struggling. Lenovo has bounced back, and Legend itself is eyeing a possible IPO in 2014. Of late, Lu has also been putting money into resource industries. Lu is also a vice chairman of All-China Federation of Industry & Commerce

name: Billionaires
bio: Luo is chairman of Cheng Shin Rubber, a bicycle tire maker founded in 1967 that has since become one of the world's largest automobile tire producers.  From the company's base in Taiwan's Changhua county, Cheng Shin has successfully targeted the mainland, selling its products under the Maxxis brand. The company's marketing tie-up with the NBA's New York Knicks couldn't come at a better time: Its Taiwan-linked star Jeremy Lin is boosting viewership of games and benefitting Cheng Shin.    The company's shares have gained 45% in the past year, helping to fuel an increase in Luo's wealth.   Luo's son-in-law Chen Rong-hua leads the day-to-day business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Najib Mikati became prime minister of Lebanon in January 2011 and immediately faced a series of threats to the country's stability--not least the violence in neighboring Syria. Mikati, who's a moderate in a divided nation, keeps in touch with a growing following on Twitter to explain his policies. Mikati and his brother Taha made their fortune in telecom by selling their stake in Investcom to South Africa's MTN Group. With the proceeds from the sale, they established the M1 Group, which has investments in real estate, jet leasing, and apparel company Façonnable. Mikati relinquished his post in the group when he became prime minister. His son Maher oversees the retail and travel divisions.

name: Billionaires
bio: Taha Mikati founded Investcom with his brother Lebanese Prime Minister Najib Mikati during Lebanon's civil war, and later expanded into Africa. In 2006, they sold their stake to South Africa's telecom powerhouse MTN Group, and remain the company's largest single shareholder through their holding company M1 Group. Taha Mikati is responsible for strategic decisions, while his son Azmi, a Columbia University engineering grad, runs the day-to-day business. M1 Group has investments in real estate, jet leasing, and apparel company Façonnable.

name: Billionaires
bio: David Nahmad and his two brothers have become influential megadealers of modern and impressionist art by the most well-known names, from Monet and Matisse to Renoir and Rothko. They own a vast inventory of between 4,000 and 4,500 works in a duty-free warehouse next to the airport in Geneva, Switzerland. Among those holdings: 300 Picassos, worth some $900 million. The family buys and sells most of their works at auction. It also trades millions of dollars in currencies and commodities. A skilled backgammon player who bets hundreds of thousands on the game in Monte Carlo, David holds the 1996 world title.

name: Billionaires
bio: Husnu Ozyegin's investments are grouped in Fiba and Fina Holding and include financial services, tourism, retail and real estate development companies. He announced plans to expand his holdings into energy by investing over $500 million in wind power projects over the next two years. His Credit Europe Bank and Fibabanka have been opening  in new markets and growing deposits. Last October, his Ozyegin University which was founded in 2008, moved to a new campus to better cater to the 1,500 strong student body.

name: Billionaires
bio: Starting from near-barren natural gas wells, Clayton Riddell has built up a dominant position in the Canadian oil and natural resource realm over five decades. While he maintains stakes in more than five Canadian energy companies, Riddell's primary investment remains Paramount Resources, which assumed total control of ProspEx Resources in April 2011. The purchase of ProspEx gave Riddell greater access to the liquid-rich assets of the Motney oil region. Riddell also owns a partial stake in the Calgary Flames.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Paramount Resources Ltd.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Melker Schorling is the chairman and owner of investment firm Melker Schorling AB. He founded MSAB in 1999 and took it public in 2006, attracting such investors as fellow billionaire Stefan Persson of H&M, who sits on the board of the company. He has also partnered with another Swedish billionaire, Gustav Douglas.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shaw is no longer actively involved in the day-to-day operations of his $23 billion hedge fund firm, D.E. Shaw & Co., but he remains involved in certain higher-level strategic decisions affecting the investment management businesses. D.E. Shaw's Oculus fund produced an impressive 19.9% net return in 2011 and the firm's Composite fund returned 6.2% net of fees. 2011 was also a good year at D. E. Shaw Research, where Shaw serves as Chief Scientist. The independent research laboratory focuses on computational biochemistry and won a patent in September for "approaches and architectures for computation of particle interactions." Shaw, a Columbia University computer science professor, launched D.E. Shaw & Co. in 1980. The firm, which leans heavily on mathematical computer-driven models, currently manages approximately $23 billion and is known for being incredibly selective in its hires: only one in 500 applicants make the cut (Amazon founder Jeff Bezos is a former employee). Shaw was appointed to the President's Council of Advisers on Science and Technology by President Clinton in 1994, and again by President Obama in 2009. He has been a senior research fellow at Columbia since 2005.
title: Founder
employment: {'name': 'D. E. Shaw & Co., L.P.', 'title': 'Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Chief operating officer of Wilmar International, one of world's largest palm oil producers; firm announced last year plans to build a natural alcohol plant in Netherlands with Texas' chemicals maker Huntsman Corp. It is also investing in property in China.  Onetime economics student started out trading shrimp as a teenager, then switched to palm oil. He co-founded Wilmar International with Kuok Khoon Hong, who is the nephew of Malaysia's richest man, Robert Kuok. They merged Wilmar with the senior Kuok's plantation and agribusiness group in June 2007. Last year Sitorus and Kuok personally paid $473 million for London's Aviva Tower.

name: Billionaires
bio: This is the director's tenth year with an Oscar nomination, this time for his film version of "War Horse." It was one of two movies he directed that were in theaters at the same time last Christmas; the other was "The Adventures of Tintin," a 3-D animated movie. Neither film set the box office on fire. Spielberg continues to be a prolific producer, making money off films like "Real Steel," "Super 8" and the latest "Transformers" film. Spielberg is moving into television in a big way. He's the force behind four shows currently airing, including the NBC Broadway musical show "Smash."
title: Director/Producer

name: Billionaires
bio: Friede Springer is the fifth wife and widow of Axel Springer, the founder of $3.9 billion (sales) Axel Springer Verlag, one of Germany's leading publishing groups. She owns 52% of the company, which publishes 240 newspapers in 35 countries, including leading German conservative daily Die Welt and Germany's largest tabloid, Bild Zeitung. Axel Springer publishes foreign language editions of Forbes magazine in Poland and Russia. She is active in various philanthropic organizations and has received numerous awards for her efforts to rebuild German-Jewish relations. Springer also holds the Federal Cross of Merit for her efforts to promote social, cultural and scientific dialogue worldwide. She is a member of the German's conservative party, the Christian Democratic Union, and is a personal friend of chancellor Angela Merkel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tsvetkov Nikolai sold his Kopeyka supermarket chain to X5 Group for $1.1 billion in cash in 2010. He's created a network of companies producing organic food; he also chairs financial services firm Ursalib, which includes banking, insurance, investment, leasing companies and asset management. The former air force lieutenant colonel met Leonid Fedun, also a former military officer, who was a privatization consultant for Lukoil. After setting up Nikoil (later renamed Uralsib) in partnership with other top Lukoil managers such as Vagit Alekperov, Tsvetkov helped them gain a controlling stake in the oil company; for his services was rewarded with a sizable Lukoil stake. He left the oil firm's board of directors in 2010 but still has about 1% of its shares. He also owns legendary Lomonosov Porcelain, to which he returned its original name, Imperial Porcelain Manufacture. Tsvetkov is passionate about Eastern philosophy and yoga.

name: Billionaires
bio: Press-shy brothers Sol and Eddie Zakay captain real estate investment company Topland Group. Sol, the firm's original founder, heads up the company's international arm, while Eddie acts as managing director of the UK sector.
