In 2004, Topland acquired 33 stores and two distribution units from Tesco for $1.2 billion. In 2007, the company sold its 50/50 joint-venture interest for $1.9 billion. Topland acquired 78 Marks & Spencer stores in a leaseback deal for $505 million in 2001; a decade later the properties were valued at $1.2 billion. In January 2011, Topland and Barclays agreed to co-invest close to $1 billion in the natural resources sector. Sol left the UK after a 50% tax rate on high earners was enacted and is now living in Gibraltar; Eddie runs the business in the UK.

name: Billionaires
bio: Abdul Aziz Al Ghurair presides over Mashreq, a leading bank in the United Arab Emirates. The bank is on the path to recovery after taking a hit for its exposure to bad real estate loans. Assets are still declining, but in a turnaround, Mashreq's net earnings were up almost 17% in the first nine months of 2011. Al Ghurair has served as head of UAE's national assembly, but will reportedly not seek another term this year. The Al Ghurair conglomerate, which has interests in food, construction, and retail is looking to invest in Libya, where it already owns reportedly half of the country's largest oil refinery.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fresh off of leading the largest private IPO in Israel's history, David Azrieli continues to develop his North American and Israeli real estate empire, which he started years ago by building four homes in a Montreal suburb. The Azrieli Group, which went public in June 2010 and is controlled by Azrieli and his family, continues to snap up or construct large Israeli office buildings and shopping malls. The family patriarch is also expanding his North American real estate holdings, purchasing a Houston office building leased to Dow Chemical Co. for $107 million in early 2012. Azrieli, an avid art collector, maintains a large Jewish art collection, some of which has been displayed at the Tel Aviv Museum of Art and the Haifa Museum of Art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vladimir Bogdanov is often called the Siberian hermit because he rarely leaves the remote town of Surgut; he avoids public attention and the trappings of wealth entirely. A professional oil driller, Bogdanov was appointed chief executive of Surgutneftegas at age 33. In the early 1990s he and fellow managers privatized the company. In 2009 the firm bought a 21.2% stake in Hungarian group MOL. But local regulators considered the buy an attempted hostile takeover and in 2011 Surgutneftegas had to sell its entire MOL stake to the Hungarian government for $2.5 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Miloud Chaabi made his debut on our inaugural Africa's 40 Richest. He got his start in 1948 developing housing, then expanded through Ynna Holding into hotels, supermarkets, and renewable energy. Chaabi was a member of Parliament, where he was dubbed the "red capitalist," when he allied himself with the socialist party. He doesn't shy away from lashing out in the press at competitors and corrupt practices. In the wake of the Tunisian uprising, Chaabi said that Morocco had its own Trabelsis (the deposed Tunisian dictator's in-laws who allegedly enriched themselves). He railed at billionaires "born overnight...who treat themselves with land they obtain at symbolic prices." In February 2011, he marched to Parliament with protesters demanding an end to political and business corruption--and distributed his own bottled water at the demonstration.

name: Billionaires
bio: Otto Happel turned his father's dust removal business into thermal engineering firm GEA. In 1999, he sold his stake in GEA to MG Technologies for $1 billion in cash and a 21% interest in the combined group. He cashed out the rest in 2006, selling his stake to various institutional investors for approximately $630 million. Happel lives in Switzerland with his wife and six children. An enthusiastic sailor, he has a yacht named Hetairos. Happel owns a luxury resort, Fregate Island, in the Seychelles. He has a foundation in his name that supports development projects in third world countries.

name: Billionaires
bio: Onetime lawmaker Eitaro Itoyama derives bulk of fortune from 9 counry clubs and 1 golf driving range but Japan's sluggish economy, coupled with the nation's earthquake, has made it difficult to attract golfers. Meanwhile there has been plenty of industry upheaval as rival Taiheiyo Club went bankrupt and another, PGM Holdings, was taken over by pachinko operator Heiwa. Itoyama also holds 5% stake in TV Tokyo. Itoyama is chairman of the Shonan Institute of Technology; he writes monthly missives on macroeconomics and politics.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mehmet Emin Karamehmet has been struggling to regain control over his holdings after last year's jail sentence and $300 million fine for embezzlement related to use of loans at Pamubank AS, a lender he owned until regulators seized it in 2002. Over the past year, he failed to pay for the electricity distribution tenders that he won for $4.9 billion with his former partner Mehmet Kazanci;  the tenders were cancelled. He also failed to pay up for the Baskent natural gas tender which he won; the tender was also cancelled and he lost his $92 million down-payment. Karamehmet's Cukurova Group faced tax penalties last April. Meanwhile his shares in Turkcell are being contested in a lawsuit by partner, Altimo; though in March a British appeals court ruled in his favor over a $1.45 billion deposit. And he continues to negotiate with fellow billionaire Mehmet Sepil, his partner in Genel Energy, which listed in Lodon in November, to sell him part of the media group he owns. Karamehmet founded his first trading firm at age 22, has grown into one of Turkey's largest diversified conglomerates.

name: Billionaires
bio: It's been six months of growing pains for Eric Lefkofsky's Groupon. His net worth has almost doubled since FORBES' last valuation in September after Groupon went public in November. But it hasn't been all smooth sailing for Lefkofsky and the Chicago-based online coupon machine he helped fund. Analysts have heavily scrutinized the company's revenue streams after Groupon announced in February losses of $43 million for its fourth quarter, its first as a public company. Groupon is also facing stiff competition from a host of online deal companies and even Google, which is ramping up its Google Offers operation. Lefkofsky once employed Groupon chief, Andrew Mason, at another company called InnerWorkings. Mason called Lefkofksy in December 2006 with an idea to launch a company that "used the power of tipping points and the Internet to solve collective action problems." Lefkofsky offered $1 million if Mason would drop out of school and start that business, which eventually became Groupon. While Mason runs day-to-day operations, Lefkofsky operates a venture fund, Light Bank, from an office in the same building; it has stakes in nearly a dozen companies. Lefkofsky, who grew up in the Detroit suburbs, got his start selling carpets during his freshman year at University of Michigan, after being dumped by a girl.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turning point for Brijmohan Lall Munjal, patriarch of 65-year-old Hero Group, India's largest motorcycle maker. After breaking off longstanding partnership with Honda Motors in December 2010, he bought out Japanese firm's stake last year at a 50% discount to market price for $785 million. Renamed the company, run by son Pawan, as Hero MotoCorp. While it has a technology-licensing agreement with Honda until 2014, it now competes with the Japanese firm in the Indian market. It bought minority stake in US motorcycle maker Erik Buell Racing and is reportedly eyeing Ducati. Bain Capital and Singapore's GIC invested $900 million in the group.

name: Billionaires
bio: Horse breeder Cyrus Poonawalla founded and runs Serum Institute of India, one of world's leading vaccine producers. Its affordable vaccines, approved by the World Health Organization, cost "not more than a cup of tea."  Serum's portfolio includes a meningitis vaccine sold in Africa for 50 cents a dose, the world's cheapest 5-in-1 vaccine, costing $1.75 a dose, and a nasal vaccine for swine flu. Serum had a bumper year thanks to soaring demand, especially for its pentavalent vaccine. It is now partnering Merck to jointly develop a vaccine for pneumonia aimed at emerging markets. Son, Adar, oversees Serum's operations. He collects custom-built limousines and still maintains ties to the horse racing circuit.

name: Billionaires
bio: Israeli tycoon Haim Saban chairs Spanish language broadcaster Univision, which he bought in conjunction with private equity firms in 2007, for $13.7 billion. In October 2010 Saban settled a dispute with Mexican broadcaster Televisa and negotiated a deal in which Televisa bought a stake in Univision for $1.2 billion and agreed to provide the U.S. network with its popular programming. He's tripled the number of employees at Saban Brands, which owns and manages the Power Rangers brand, the initial source of Saban's fortune. Saban Brands also owns Paul Frank, known for its iconic monkey, Julius. Saban invests in real estate and is a longtime Democratic donor. Lifetime charitable giving to various causes by Saban and his wife Cheryl exceeds $200 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Onsi Sawiris is the patriarch of Egypt's wealthiest family. The Egyptian government nationalized his first construction business in 1971. Undeterred, he rebuilt what became Orascom Construction Industries. His son Nassef took over in 1995. In January, Orascom Construction announced it plans to split its construction and fertilizer divisions into two publicly-traded companies during the first quarter of 2012. Onsi Sawiris also owns shares in Russian mobile operator VimpelCom, following son Naguib's sale of the family stake in Orascom Telecom in April 2011.

name: Billionaires
bio: Antonio Luiz Seabra co-chairs Natura Cosmeticos, a Brazilian version of Avon. Shares are nearly flat with March 2011.The company, which he founded in 1969, has "consultants" sell Natura's cosmetics across Brazil and seven other Latin American countries. Media-shy Seabra is reported to live in London. In October 2011, with business partner and fellow Natura billionaire Guilherme Peirao Leal, Seabra reportedly formed Bresco, a new Brazilian property-rental operation focused on industrial property, warehouses, offices and hotels.
title: Entrepreneur

name: Billionaires
bio: As eBay's first employee and President, Jeffrey Skoll oversaw the company's meteoric rise from Internet start-up to multi-billion-dollar company. While he no longer works for eBay, Skoll maintains a roughly 4% stake. These days he funnels much of his money and energy into his production company, Participant Media, which makes films intended to inspire social change, such as Al Gore's Oscar-winning documentary on climate change, "An Inconvenient Truth." Participant's most recent release, "The Help," grossed more than $200 million in theaters worldwide. Skoll has already given away more than $1 billion, primarily through his Skoll Foundation and Skoll Global Threats Fund, supporting causes from environmental sustainability to human rights. Recent beneficiaries include the Global Viral Forecasting Initiative and the Peace Works Network Foundation. Skoll's venture capital firm, Capricorn Investments, has stakes in TrueCar, Nanosolar, and Tesla Motors. He was named an Officer of the Order of Canada in December. Skoll was previously listed as a Canadian on Forbes World's Billionaires list; because he has obtained U.S. citizenship, we are now listing him as an American.

name: Billionaires
bio: It's no surprise that The Donald is on Forbes' Celebrity 100 list (#17, at that) as well as our rich lists. The New York-born mogul isn't one to shy away from the spotlight. He recently made headlines for endorsing Mitt Romney as his 2012 presidential candidate of choice, after leading the press on for a year, hinting that he'd like to run himself. As ever, Trump's had a big year. His controversial golf course in Aberdeen, Scotland is completed and just about ready for play; in February, he bought Miami's Doral Hotel and Country Club. He also won a bid to turn D.C's iconic Old Post Office building into a Trump International hotel. His NBC show Celebrity Apprentice continues to kill it in the 18-49 category, boasting 5 million viewers over two hours the same night as this year's Oscars ceremony. He celebrated a very modern milestone in February, passing 1 million followers on Twitter.
title: Entrepreneur, Personality

name: Billionaires
bio: Klaus Tschira us one of four former IBM colleagues who cofounded German software company SAP in 1972. It has grown to be one of the world's largest software firms with $16.2 billion revenue in 2010. He retired from the company in 1998 and stepped down from its supervisory board in 2007 but still owns plenty of stock in the company. Now, he devotes time to his Klaus Tschira Foundation, one of Germany's largest philanthropic organizations, with assets of $2.4 billion.  The foundation supports scientific research and cultural projects such as a youth software prize given to students who explain math or science matters through the clever use of software. In 2010, the foundation spent $23 million on various projects. Tschira has taken up astronomy as a hobby, and has an asteroid between Mars and Jupiter named after him.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chip Wilson made a bundle selling luxury workout wear at Lululemon, the company he founded, and he debuted on the billionaires list in 2011. Wilson stepped down as Chief Innovation and Brand Officer in early 2012, ceding that role to CEO Christine Day. Wilson will remain Chairman of the Board. He started his career with outerwear company Westbeach Snowboard  in 1979. He opened the first Lululemon store in 2000 in Vancouver and took the firm public in 2007. Lululemon boasts a cult following and revenue of $700 million from 137 stores and catalog sales. Wilson concocted the company's manifesto, including slogans like "The pursuit of happiness is the source of all unhappiness" and "What we do to the earth we do to ourselves."
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Riley Bechtel is the fourth-generation CEO and chairman of engineering giant ($27.9 billion sales) Bechtel Corp., the firm that built the Hoover Dam, the Chunnel and more recently, the Tacoma Narrows Bridge. He and his father Stephen are each believed to own 20% of the firm, which builds roads and rail systems, airport and ports, liquefied natural gas processing plants and copper smelters. Ongoing projects: construction of a 440-megawatt solar thermal power complex in California's Mojave Desert and a 21 km tunnel in London, part of a new commuter railway. One of the top service providers to the U.S. government, it treats hazardous liquid waste at a former nuclear production site and eliminates unused chemical weapons. He is reportedly a member of San Francisco's exclusive all-male Bohemian Club, whose fellows are thought to include every Republican President since Herbert Hoover. He sits on the board of the Indian School of Business and is a member of JPMorgan Chase's International Council along with Henry Kissinger and George Schultz.
title: Chairman and CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Stephen Bechtel is an heir to engineering giant Bechtel Corp. ($27.9 billion sales), the firm that built the Hoover Dam, the Chunnel and, more recently, the Tacoma Narrows Bridge. Stephen became Bechtel president at age 35, chairman 13 years later. Son Riley now runs the show. Believed to own 20% of the company. Bechtel builds roads and rail systems, airport and ports, liquefied natural gas processing plants and copper smelters. Ongoing projects: construction of a 440-megawatt solar thermal power complex in California's Mojave Desert and a 21 km tunnel in London, part of a new commuter railway. Stephen's foundation gave $50 million to the Boy Scouts of America in 2009 to help create a 10,600-acre reserve in West Virginia. He is reportedly a member of San Francisco's exclusive all-male Bohemian Club, whose fellows are thought to include every Republican President since Herbert Hoover.
title: Former Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner and fellow billionaire Ihor Kolomoyskyy, Henadiy Bogolyubov controls Privat group, a banking and industrial conglomerate. Began with Privatbank, which was founded with $1 million of capital in early 1990s; now the partners plan to take Privatbank public on the London stock exchange this year. Oil producer Ukrnafta, in which Bogolyubov holds 10% stake, is also preparing to IPO; there are plans to integrate other group oil refineries and terminals and grow Ukrnafta. Outside of Privat, he is pursuing mining interests via his Consolidated Minerals. His Bogolyubov Foundation focuses on promoting Jewish education and religion. With his partner Kolomoyskyy, Bogolyubov is building the world's biggest multifunctional Jewish center, the Menorah Centre in Dnepropetrovsk; it is set to open this fall.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partners and longtime friends Alexander Machkevich and Alijan Ibragimov (both billionaires), Patokh Chodiev built Eurasian Natural Resources Co., a metals and mining empire in Kazakhstan. The company finished a three-month corporate governance review last September after a board tussle and CEO Felix Vulis' resignation earlier in the year; Vulis returned and the board was reconstituted. ENRC continues to expand: settled a case in March to acquire First Quantum Minerals assets in the Democratric Republic of Congo for $1.25 billion ending a legal dispute between the companies over the Kolwezi copper project. Chodiev, an Uzbekistan native, lived in Japan before teaming up with his pals in Kazakhstan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chung Eui-Sun is the eldest son of Chung Mong-Koo, and the vice president of Hyundai Motors. After completing his education, he worked at Itochu's New York office before joining Hyundai Motors. He rapidly moved up the ranks, becoming president of KIA Motors in 2005. He is credited with the successful launch of small family car Kia Cee'd in Europe, as well as the Soul and Forte. In 2009, he was promoted vice president of Hyundai Motors. Last year, he hired BMW design director Christopher Chapman as chief designer for Hyundai Motors. Chung Eui-Sun heads the Asian Archery Federation.

name: Billionaires
bio: In September, Conway's renowned private equity firm, the Carlyle Group, made headlines after filing for its long-awaited initial public offering, which it expects to complete in 2012. Conway founded the firm in 1987 with Daniel D'Aniello and David Rubenstein. In the early years, Carlyle garnered success by using politically connected advisers, including former President George H.W. Bush and former British prime minister John Major, to buy defense-oriented businesses. It then turned around operations and flipped the companies for large profits. Today the firm has $148 billion under management. Carlyle has been in the news recently after filing an amended registration statement with the SEC detailing the founders' compensation packages of around $138 million each in the last year.
title: Co-Chief Executive Officer and Co-founder
employment: {'name': 'Carlyle Group', 'title': 'Co-Chief Executive Officer and Co-founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: In September, D'Aniello's renowned private equity firm, the Carlyle Group, made headlines after filing for its long-awaited initial public offering, which it expects to complete in 2012. D'Aniello founded the firm in 1987 with William Conway and David Rubenstein. In the early years, Carlyle garnered success by using politically connected advisers, including former President George H.W. Bush and former British prime minister John Major, to buy defense-oriented businesses. It then turned around operations and flipped the companies for large profits. Today the firm has $148 billion under management. Carlyle has been in the news recently after filing an amended registration statement with the SEC detailing the founders' compensation packages of around $138 million each in the last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: William Ding, also known as Ding Lei, has led the evolution of his one-time portal Netease into one of China's largest online game businesses.  Sales in the three months ending September 2011 rose by 28% from a year earlier to $341 million, helping profit to gain 9% to $143 million.  Business at the 45% Ding-owned company has been growing on the success introduction of Tianxia III and Ghost. This year, it may benefit from the start of World of Warcraft: Mists of Pandaria and Diablo III via a partnership with Blizzard Entertainment of Irvine, California.  Besides his stock in Netease, Ding also owns a pig farm.

name: Billionaires
bio: A Swedish count who made his fortune in the security business, last year Gustaf Douglas merged his personal holdings in Sakl AB with the largest source of his wealth, AB Latour, which has stakes in Assa Abloy, the world's largest producer of locks; Securitas AB, one of largest publicly traded security companies; and Fagerhult AB, a Swedish maker of light fixtures.  Formerly on the board of Sweden's Moderate party, Douglas has now taken an interest in education policy. He is a member of the Royal Swedish Academy of Engineering Sciences. His wife Elisabeth née von Essen is also of noble descent.

name: Billionaires
bio: A diminutive former car salesman, Bernie Ecclestone raced into the billionaire ranks in 2005 after selling stakes in Formula One Group for $2.5 billion. After failing to qualify as a Formula One race driver, he bought a team and brokered a complex series of contracts and TV deals for other F1 teams, taking over most rights in 1997, and turning F1 into a lucrative global franchise. He then began selling the sport's commercial rights to TV broadcasters, which eventually brought him billions. CVC Capital Partners owns Formula One, but Ecclestone still runs the show at 81. He's dealing with an investigation in Germany over allegations that he bribed an investment banker to undervalue shares in F1 when it was sold to CVC. He recently sold his majority stake in Queens Park Rangers soccer club. Divorce from his ex-model Croatian wife netted her a reported $1.2 billion. Socialite daughters Tamara and Petra buy mansions, while dad prefers the penthouse above his office.

name: Billionaires
bio: Temp agency entrepreneur Frits Goldschmeding stepped down as Vice Chairman in April 2011 from the temporary employment company Randstad Holding he founded back in 1960. Goldschmeding took the company public in 1990, then merged Randstad with Dutch group Vedior in 2008 to form the world's second-largest temp agency in the world. Now truly retired, he still owns 35 percent of the company. Goldschmeding is also a professor at the Centre for Entrepreneurship of the Nyenrode Business University, and enjoys sailing in his free time.

name: Billionaires
bio: Diane Hendricks took over roofing empire ABC Supply after her husband and business partner, Kenneth Hendricks, died in 2007. Today she controls the nation's largest roofing, window and siding wholesale distributor. After ABC acquired competitor Bradco Supply Co. in 2010, sales grew to $4.6 billion in 2011, up from $4.1 billion the previous year. Hendricks met her late husband at age 21. Together they launched ABC in 1982. In addition to ABC, Hendricks also presides over 25 million square feet of commercial property, 25 smaller companies via  Hendricks Holding Co., and a growing family (seven children, 17 grandchildren). She rides horses and Harley-Davidsons, fishes, and hunts wild birds with a shotgun on her 200-acre estate. For her next adventure, she's considering hunting black bears in the wilds of Canada.
title: Cofounder and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'ABC Supply', 'title': 'Cofounder and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: With partners and longtime friends Alexander Machkevich and Patokh Chodiev (both billionaires), Alijan Ibragimov built Eurasian Natural Resources Co., a metals and mining empire in Kazakhstan. The company finished a three-month corporate governance review last September after a board tussle and CEO Felix Vulis' resignation earlier in the year; Vulis returned and the board was reconstituted. ENRC settled a case in March to acquire First Quantum Minerals assets in the Democratic Republic of Congo for $1.25 billion ending a legal dispute between the companies over the Kolwezi copper project. Ibragimov, a native of Kyrgyzstan, moved to Kazakhstan when the group decided to pursue business interests there. He is a devout Muslim with 6 sons.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ingram family matriarch Martha took over as chairman of the family's distribution conglomerate, $1.9 billion (estimated sales) Ingram Industries in 1995, after her husband's death. The group transports commodities on barges and distributes books. In 2009, it merged its book, print-on-demand and digital divisions into Ingram Content group, overseen by Martha's son John, who replaced her as chairman in 2008. The company provides print on demand services. It also provides publisher content to Apple's iBookstore for the iPad. Ingram Entertainment, run by son David, is a distributor of DVDs and video games. Son Orrin runs the industrial businesses. The marine division operates nearly 4,000 barges and more than 100 towboats, hauling coal, grain and fertilizer on America's inland waterways. A Vassar grad, Ingram is prominent in Nashville society; she sits on boards of four cultural institutions that support theater, opera and the symphony in Tennessee.
title: Former Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Ingram Industries, Inc.', 'title': 'Former Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: San Antonio-based Rodney Lewis has been drilling for gas in south Texas for three decades, with lots of acreage in and around a hotspot, the Eagle Ford shale. Experience in the region helped him win a contract to drill just over the border for Mexico's Pemex. Lewis Energy is also producing oil in Colombia. Lewis battled and beat esophageal cancer a few years ago. His passion is World War II-era planes, known as warbirds. He now owns 30, perhaps the best collection in the world, topped off by Glacier Girl, a P-38 bomber dug out of Greenland ice and restored to mint condition. His latest acquisition: an 820 Havoc single-pilot bomber.

name: Billionaires
bio: A farmer's son, Lin Rong San is one of Taiwan's biggest landlords. A thorn in the side of China-friendly Taiwan President Ma Ying-jeou, Lin publishes the Liberty Times, a  popular daily that's skeptical about China. He also controls Taipei-listed Union Bank. Lin's three sons work with him. His brother Lin Yu-lin, also a billionaire, is listed separately

name: Billionaires
bio: With partners and longtime friends Patokh Chodiev and Alijan Ibragimov (both billionaires), Alexander Machkevich built Eurasian Natural Resources Co., a metals and mining empire in Kazakhstan. The company finished a three-month corporate governance review last September after a board tussle and CEO Felix Vulis' resignation earlier in the year; Vulis returned and the board was reconstituted. ENRC continues to expand: settled a case to acquire First Quantum Minerals assets in March in the Democratic Republic of Congo for $1.25 billion ending a legal dispute between the companies over the Kolwezi copper project. Machkevich resigned as the head of Euro-Asian Jewish Congress to focus on creating a Jewish version of Al-Jazeera that will "represent Israel on an international level, with real information"; to start broadcasting mid-2012. The "returning citizen" of Israel bought a $100 million apartment on the Tel Aviv waterfront this year.

name: Billionaires
bio: A Glencore lifer, Daniel Mate joined Marc Rich & Co. in 1988 in Switzerland, six years before the firm was bought out by management and rebranded. Mate joined the zinc, copper and lead commodity department in 1991, rising to co-director of the division in 2000. Mate broke into the ranks of the world's billionaires when the commodities giant went public in May 2011. Despite its shares losing nearly 20% of their value since their debut, the future is bright for Glencore. The firm announced plans to merge with mining outfit Xstrata in February 2012. The proposed all-stock "merger of equals" would spawn a $90 billion mining and marketing behemoth.

name: Billionaires
bio: After graduating from the London School of Economics, Mistakidis took a position at private commodities giant Cargill where he worked in non-ferrous metals for six years. Mistakidis then joined Marc Rich & Co. in 1993 just before the firm was bought out by management and renamed Glencore. Mistakidis worked in what would become the zinc, copper, and lead department, rising to the rank of co-director in 2000. A citizen of both the United Kingdom and his native Greece, Mistakidis attained billionaire status in May 2011 with the IPO of Glencore. Despite its shares losing nearly 20% of their value since their public debut, the future is bright for Glencore. The firm announced plans to merge with mining outfit Xstrata in February 2012. The proposed all-stock "merger of equals" would spawn a $90 billion mining and marketing behemoth.

name: Billionaires
bio: In September, Rubenstein's renowned private equity firm, the Carlyle Group, made headlines after filing for its long-awaited initial public offering, which it expects to complete in 2012.  Rubenstein founded the firm in 1987 with William Conway and Daniel D'Aniello. In the early years, Carlyle garnered success by using politically connected advisers, including former President George H.W. Bush and former British prime minister John Major, to buy defense-oriented businesses. It then turned around operations and flipped the companies for large profits. Today, the firm has $148 billion under management. Rubenstein sits on the boards of numerous nonprofits, including Lincoln Center and the Kennedy Center. He also collects historical artifacts, including original copies of the Magna Carta, the Emancipation Proclamation, and the Declaration of Independence, all of which he has loaned to various government offices. Last year he donated $13.5 million to the Foundation for the National Archives, the largest single contribution ever received by the foundation. Carlyle has been in the press recently after filing an amended registration statement with the SEC detailing the founders' compensation packages of around $138 million each in the last year.
title: Co-Chief Executive Officer and Co-founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Memory-module entrepreneur David Sun founded Camintonn with partner and fellow billionaire John Tu in 1982. They sold the company four years later for $6 million and founded Kingston Technology. Sun and Tu then sold 80% of the company to Softbank for $1.5 billion in 1996, before buying it back three years later for $450 million. Today Kingston is the nation's largest privately held computer memory outfit; it reported record revenues of $6.5 billion in 2010. The company beats competitors on price by using pared-down packaging and closely monitoring supply shipments to avoid holding onto excess inventory. Both billionaires continue to work in cubicles at the center of the sales floor.
title: COO

name: Billionaires
bio: Sukanto Tanoto's conglomerate RGE (Royal Golden Eagle) has $12 billion in assets; it owns papermaker April and palm oil firm Asian Agri, and has operations in China and Brazil. His Pacific Oil & Gas announced the launch of its LNG project, a joint venture with 2 Chinese partners, in Jiangsu Province, China. Tanoto is a member of the Asia executive advisory board of Wharton and a member of the Insead International Council.  The eldest of 7 boys, he dropped out of school at age 17 to help support his family. He says he taught himself English by translating Readers' Digest, Life and Newsweek.

name: Billionaires
bio: Memory-chip entrepreneur John Tu founded Camintonn with partner and fellow billionaire David Sun in 1982. They sold the company four years later for $6 million and founded Kingston Technology. Tu and Sun then sold 80% of the company to Softbank for $1.5 billion in 1996, before buying it back three years later for $450 million. Today Kingston is the nation's largest privately held computer memory outfit; it reported record revenues of $6.5 billion in 2010. The company beats competitors on price by using pared-down packaging and closely monitoring supply shipments to avoid holding onto excess inventory. Both billionaires continue to work in cubicles at the center of the sales floor. In 2011, Tu donated $1.2 million to give every first year medical student at U.C. Irvine an iPad. He plays drums with his band, JT and California Dreamin'.
title: President

name: Billionaires
bio: Murat Ulker heads Turkey's largest food producer Yildiz Holding which he shares with sister, Ahsen Ozokur, who is also a billionaire. Yildiz makes everything from biscuits to milk products and baby food. In 2007, the conglomerate bought Godiva Chocolatier for $850 million and has been expanding production. Last year also purchased Nuroll, Italy's largest polyester food packaging film producer. Separately, Ulker purchased margarine and oil producer Marsan Foods last year. He is also one of Turkey's foremost contemporary art collectors; his collection includes such Turkish artists as Burhan Dogancay as well as Yucel Donmez,Omer Uluç (Mavi Kus- Blue Bird), Devrim Erbil, Onay Akbas, Gulay Semercioglu (Kirmizi- Red) , Mubin Orhon, Haluk Akakce, Peyami Gurel, Ferruh Basaga and Erol Akyavas.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chen Fashu is chairman of the New Huadu Group, a diversified investment conglomerate whose interests span mining, retailing, real estate, technology, spirits and tourism. Though he is one of China's most powerful entrepreneurs, Chen has been enduring a high-profile setback:  He paid Yunnan Hongta Group $349 million in 2009 for a 13.6% stake in Yunnan Baiyao Group, one of China's biggest pharmaceutical companies, but Yunnan Hongta Group didn't deliver the shares, and the matter is in court.  Brother Chen Zhicheng is chairman of Fujian New Hua Du Supercenter, whose biggest shareholder is New Huadu. Among Chen's toys: a private jet.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sports mogul Malcolm Glazer owns two major sports franchises, the NFL's Tampa Bay Buccaneers and English soccer's Manchester United. Combined, they are worth more than $2.5 billion, although Manchester is burdened by a large debt load. He snagged Rutgers University's Greg Schiano for the head coaching job with the Bucs, hoping to end a trend of nine seasons without a playoff win. Glazer inherited his father's watch business at age 15. He later formed real estate company First Allied, which today owns more than 6.7 million square feet of retail space in the United States. His Glazer Children's Museum opened in Tampa in September 2010 after he donated $5 million. Glazer's six children now manage the family assets.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tamara Gustavson debuted on the Forbes World's Billionaires list last year as her father, Public Storage founder B. Wayne Hughes, started passing his assets to Gustavson and her children. She owns more shares in the storage giant, about 10%, than the rest of the Hughes family combined. But if Public Storage continues to perform well - its stock is up 25% year on year - her brother B. Wayne Hughes Jr. may soon join the list. Gustavson also owns a commercial real estate company, American Commercial Equities Management LLC in Malibu, Calif., with property in Hawaii and California. She gives to Republican candidates and causes and donates money to the HollyRod Foundation for autism.

name: Billionaires
bio: Retail entrepreneur Stein Erik Hagen opened the Rimi discount supermarket with his father in the late 1970s, eventually partnering with Swedish retailer ICA Group and supermarket Giant Royal Ahold. Hagen sold his remaining 20 percent stake in the company in 2004. He bought into department store chain Steen & Strom, then took the company private in 2007. Through his Canica group, Hagen also owns a handful of other Scandinavian companies, including hardware store chain Jernia, e-commerce site Komplett, and consumer goods manufacturer Orkla.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inspired by his geologist father, Tim Headington founded Headington Oil in 1978. He stayed under the radar until 2008 when he sold acreage in North Dakota's Bakken oil play to XTO Energy for $1.85 billion. Now Headington is funding another passion, moviemaking. Through GK Films, a production company he owns with Graham King, he has bankrolled more than a dozen films. The producers have a special relationship with Martin Scorsese, having worked with him on "The Departed," "The Aviator," and most recently "Hugo," which was nominated for 11 Academy Awards, winning five. Other recent flicks include "Rango" (which won the Oscar for best animated film), "The Tourist" and "The Rum Diaries" (all starring Johnny Depp). The pipeline is thick and includes a biopic of Queen frontman Freddie Mercury starring Sacha Baron Cohen, a redo of the "Lara Croft: Tomb Raider" franchise, and an adaptation of Broadway hit "Jersey Boys." Headington owns two ultra-chic hotels in Dallas, Lumen and Joule. His oil company is still pumping, with a pending acquisition of 120,000 acres in South Texas.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hui Wing Mau's Hong Kong-listed Shimao Property Holdings is one of China's largest real estate developers. Its shares have dropped 20% during the past year amid government moves to rein in the property market. It also has eight hotels in different cities as well as a 64%-owned Shanghai-traded  real estate subsidiary. Hui holds an MBA from the University of South Australia and is a member of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Congress. Son Jason is Shimao's vice chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Poland's richest person Jan Kulczyk saw his fortune rise this year thanks to a variety of investments across multiple continents. He owns shares in UK brewer SABMiller, parent of Grolsch and Peroni beers, as well as a stake in LSE-listed oil and gas exploration company Ophir Energy, with a predominantly African portfolio. In 2010 he listed Kulczyk Oil Ventures, with oil and gas assets with Brunei, Syria and Ukraine. In 2011 he bought power plant Elektrocieplownia Nowa Sarzyna. He enjoys the high life, with a yacht, plane and homes in Florida, France and on a Mediterranean island.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dairy king James Leprino's Leprino Foods supplies cheese for brands including Domino's, Papa John's, Pizza Hut and Hot Pockets. Leprino's father, Mike Sr., came to America in 1914 and started the company in Colorado, making homemade mozzarella and ricotta cheese for locals in the 1950s. James joined the firm at age 18 and turned the family business into the world's largest mozzarella producer. Based in Denver, the company now has 12 production plants across the U.S. and Europe. The firm's by-products include whey protein, lactose, and sweet whey powder used in infant formula and yogurt. Leprino's goal is to expand operations in Colorado, boosting dairy production and fueling the local economy.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: In 1981, Fredrik Lundberg took over L.E. Lundbergforetagen AB, founded by his father Lars in 1944 as a construction company. It is now a diversified holding company with interests in property management and investments totaling nearly $4.9 billion. He enjoys hunting and was once a junior curling world champion.

name: Billionaires
bio: China's e-commerce pioneer Jack Ma's Alibaba Group, China's top e-commerce company, owns two of the world's most popular sites, Taobao and Alibaba.com. The past year has been tumultuous and hasn't resolved Ma's wish to find buyers of Yahoo's current 40%  stake in Alibaba Group. In February, he moved to privatize Hong Kong-listed e-commerce unit, Alibaba.com, in a $2.5 billion transaction. Ma is a former English teacher from Hangzhou, where Alibaba is headquartered.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fernando Roberto Moreira Salles is a member of one of Brazil's oldest banking families. In 2008 his family's Unibanco merged with Banco Itau. Now he is a board member and one of the largest individual shareholders of Itau Unibanco Holding SA, Brazil's second biggest bank.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brazilian documentary filmmaker Joao Moreira Salles is a member of one of Brazil's most distinguished banking families. In 2008 his family's Unibanco merged with Banco Itau, making him one of the largest individual shareholders of Itau Unibanco Holding SA, Brazil's second biggest bank. He is also president of Instituto Moreira Salles, a non-profit foundation started in 1990 to promote cultural development in Brazil. His brothers Walther, Pedro and Fernando Roberto are all billionaires as well.

name: Billionaires
bio: Pedro Moreira Salles chairs the board of Itau Unibanco, Brazil's second largest bank, with some $450 billion in assets. His father Walther ran Unibanco for several decades; Pedro joined Unibanco in 1989 and was largely responsible for orchestrating the bank's 2008 merger with Banco Itau. He is reportedly a member of the Group of Fifty, a non-profit initiative made up of Latin American executives and sponsored by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace and the Inter-American Dialogue in Washington D.C.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brazilian filmmaker Walther Moreira Salles (also known as Walter Salles) is a member of one of Brazil's oldest banking families. He is named after his father, Walther Moreira Salles, who founded Unibanco. In 2008 his family's Unibanco merged with Banco Itau and he became one of largest individual shareholders of Itau Unibanco Holding SA, now Brazil's second biggest bank. Walther has directed some 22 films, including The Motorcycle Diaries in 2004 and the Academy Award-nominated 1998 Brazilian film Central do Brasil ("Central Station"). His film "On The Road," based on the book by Jack Kerouac, is due out later in 2012.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mining magnate Patrice Motsepe is South Africa's first and only black billionaire. He built a $1.9 billion (sales) publicly traded mining conglomerate, African Rainbow Minerals (ARM), with interests in platinum, nickel, chrome, iron, manganese, coal, copper and gold. The share price of ARM has dropped 10% in the last year, shaving $500 million off Motsepe's net worth. Born in the sprawling black township of Soweto and then trained as a lawyer, he became the first black partner at Bowman Gilfillan law firm in Johannesburg, and then started a contracting business doing mine scut work. He bought low-producing gold mine shafts in 1994 and turned them profitable using a lean management style. Motsepe benefited from South Africa's Black Economic Empowerment (BEE) laws, which mandate that companies be at least 26% black-owned in order to get a government mining license. He also holds a stake in Sanlam, a publicly traded financial services company outside Cape Town; he sits on its board.

name: Billionaires
bio: David Murdock wants to live to be 125. That's what he told the New York Times in a rare profile interview this year, on the eve of his 88th birthday. The Dole Foods founder pins his longevity hopes on a strict diet, daily exercise and a lifestyle free of any pills or supplements. Murdock's lived quite the life already: He left high school in the 9th grade and worked at a gas station before being drafted into the Army in 1943. After WWII, he made a small profit buying and selling a diner before developing property in Arizona. In 1985, he bought out failing Hawaiian real estate outfit Castle & Cooke, which owned fruit company Dole. He spun off the real estate holdings, but still owns assets including the Hawaiian island of Lana'i. He took Dole, now the world's largest fruit and vegetable producer, public in 2009, the same year he received his high school diploma. His other investments include cargo equipment firm Flexi-Van and cancer drug developer NovaRx, where his son Justin is CEO.

name: Billionaires
bio: Rubens Ometto is the world's first ethanol billionaire. His net worth is $200 million higher this year thanks to an 18% increase in the share price of his ethanol producer Cosan S.A., which he controls. In 2011 he announced a joint venture with Shell that was hailed as an important collaboration between a global oil giant and a Brazilian renewable energy company. Cosan is one of the world's largest growers and processors of sugarcane and one of the largest producers of ethanol. Cosan listed its shares on the Brazilian stock exchange in 2005 and the New York Stock Exchange in 2007. The company's origins date from 1936, when Ometto's grandparents established a sugarcane mill in Piracicaba, northwest of Sao Paulo. Cosan has grown into an integrated sugar and ethanol producer and distributor through acquisitions and new partnerships. In 2008 Cosan paid a reported $1 billion to buy fuel retailer and distributor Esso's assets from ExxonMobil.

name: Billionaires
bio: In February, an Italian criminal court sentenced the former owner of construction materials manufacturer Swiss Eternit Group, Stephan Schmidheiny to 16 years in prison after a lengthy trial on charges of asbestos-related illnesses at Eternit Italia in which the Swiss group had a stake. The judge ordered Schmidheiny to pay compensation to former workers and residents who lived near the plants. Schmidheiny plans to appeal; his lawyers called the verdict "totally incomprehensible." When Schmidheiny took over the Swiss company from his father in 1976, he began moving away from asbestos long before it was a banned substance. He diversified over the next ten years, investing in forestry firm Grupo Nueva, among others. In 2003, Schmidheiny donated all his shares in Grupo Nueva, worth $1 billion, to his Viva Trust, which funds environmental causes and education. The global economic slump has hurt his diversified portfolio of stocks, bonds and private equity investments. Schmidheiny is an art collector who favors contemporary painters Richter and Warhol.

name: Billionaires
bio: An outspoken critic of what he claims are the Obama administration's anti-business policies, Warren Stephens thinks the path to economic health lies in part with forcing government agencies to own up to and limit the costs that regulations like Sarbanes/Oxley foist on businesses. Stephens owns the Little Rock, Ark. investment bank Stephens, Inc. It was founded with $15,000 in 1933 by uncle W.R. (Witt), who started underwriting and dealing muni bonds. Warren's father Jackson (d. 2005) joined in 1946. The brothers paid $5.4 million for Arkansas-Oklahoma Gas in 1954. They plowed the earnings into private equity, hewing to the investment criteria, "whim and caprice." They famously underwrote Wal-Mart's public offering in 1970. Warren grew up in the business, becoming chief executive in 1986. Witt died in 1991. Warren bought out his cousins' stake in 2006. Since then he's expanded the company's asset management and insurance arms and added to private equity stakes like Stephens Media, which owns 30 newspapers including the Las Vegas Review-Journal. He recently bought 16 regional papers from the New York Times.  A golf nut, he built the ultra-private Alotian Club on 1,000 acres outside of Little Rock. Stephens is also a wine aficionado; he sold 5,000 bottles in a 2007 Sotheby's auction. His favorite quaff: 1959 Chateau Latour.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sun Guangxin is chairman of the Xinjiang Guanghui Industry Investment Group, which has interests in real estate, energy and auto distribution. The company's Shanghai-listed coal mining arm, Xinjiang Guanghui Industry, this year expanded beyond China by paying $180 million for a 51% stake in an oil and gas project in Kazakhstan. Sun's auto distributor China Grand Auto, which is partly owned U.S. investment house TPG, had 400 stores in near 20 provinces in China at the end of 2011 and is said to be on the prowl for acquisitions.  Sun, who was born in Shandong Province, joined the army in 1980 and left in 1989 to enter the catering business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oprah Winfrey is now well into her next chapter. Her OWN cable network, a joint venture between Winfrey's company Harpo and Discovery Communications, completed its first full year, marked by ratings disappointments and turnover at the top. In mid-2011, Winfrey named herself CEO and chief creative officer, in addition to her previous role as chairman. A new programming line-up, including a nightly talk show with performer Rosie O'Donnell and an interview show featuring Winfrey with high-profile guests, has given the channel a recent boost, but its future remains uncertain.The Mississippi native moved to Chicago after news stints in Nashville and Baltimore. She spent 25 years hosting an eponymous daytime talk show, which ended last year.
title: Entrepreneur, Personality

name: Billionaires
bio: With her husband, Pan Shiyi, Zhang Xin forms a China power couple in the real estate industry. Their flagship Soho China, founded in Beijing in 1995 and known for its stylish architecture, bought seven sites in some of Shanghai's pricey districts last year. One, along the Bund, has drawn criticism for supposedly not fitting in with the historic skyline. Its latest purchase of a 50% stake in a site near the Bund for $634 million, sparked controversy when a Shanghai company controlled by fellow billionaire Guo Guangchang claimed it had the first right to buy the land. Pan is said to be eyeing U.S. real estate. Both Pan and Zhang are active bloggers. She recently featured in Forbes Asia's inaugural list of Asia's Power Business Women.
title: Cofounder, CEO
employment: {'name': 'Soho China Ltd.', 'uri': 'companies/soho-china', 'title': 'Cofounder, CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Semahat Arsel is a member of the Board of Directors of Koc Holding, the family company, which she shares with fellow billionaires, her brother, Mustafa Rahmi Koc, sister, Suna Kirac, and nephew, Mustafa Vehbi Koc. Arsel runs the group's investments in the tourism sector, Setur Tourism and Divan Hotels. She is also president of SANERC (Semahat Arsel Nursing Education & Research Center) which she founded in 1992 after battling an illness. She is fluent in English and German.

name: Billionaires
bio: John Caudwell's prescient belief in mobile phones led him to create retail and distribution giant Phones4U, before cashing out in 2006 for $2.8 billion. He sold his remaining stake in the retail chain last year for $272 million. This past spring, he formed new investment fund JDC Investments, dropping $233 million on a car park in swanky Mayfair, where he plans to develop luxury apartments overlooking neighboring embassies. He also recently put $93 million in distressed assets fund Better Capital. Caudwell, who comes from a poor family in Stoke-on-Trent, bought 26 mobile phones from the U.S. in the 1980s, and sold them for thousands of pounds each to British plumbers and repairmen. An avid sportsman, he also chairs his charity, Caudwell Children. A burglar recently wacked him on the head with a crowbar in a scrap at his Jacobean mansion in Staffordshire. Caudwell also keeps homes in London and France.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chen Din Hwa came to Hong Kong from the mainland, started textile company in 1954 and transformed the privately held Nan Fung Group into a major property developer and shipping company. Diagnosed with Alzheimer's in 2009, a Hong Kong court declared him incapable of "managing and administering his properties." A court-appointed committee tapped daughter Vivien to head Nan Fung, passing over her older sister Angela, a longtime U.S. resident. Chen's wife, Yang Foo Oi, is suing Vivien, accusing her daughter of exercising undue influence. Inspired by the teachings of Buddhism, the family's D.H. Chen Foundation has made substantial donations to help the needy through education, welfare and medicine.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cable television mogul Charles Dolan, whose Cablevision serves customers in greater New York City as well as New Jersey and Connecticut, is a polarizing figure in the cable television industry, due to the numerous carriage battles the company has fought with networks and other providers. In 2010 Cablevision fought with Fox over carriage fees, and millions of cable subscribers in the Northeast missed two weeks of programming. MSG Network recently ended a 48-day standoff with Time Warner Cable that deprived 2 million TWC customers from watching the rise of Knicks sensation Jeremy Lin and the success of the New York Rangers. In June Cablevision spun off its Rainbow Media unit, which led to a slight decline of share prices in 2011. Rainbow Media, now known as AMC Networks, got a major boost in value with the success of "Mad Men." The Dolans own just under 20% of the network. Shares of Dolan's Madison Square Garden Sports and Entertainment conglomerate are up, boosted by a nearly $1 billion arena renovation project and the continued success of the Knicks and Rangers. Dolan got his start editing sports reels and sending them out to TV stations. He started the network that would become HBO in 1965, and traded it to Time Inc. in 1973 for the Long Island cable company that became Cablevision.
title: Chairman and Founder
employment: {'name': 'Cablevision Systems Corp.', 'title': 'Chairman and Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Audio tech titan Ray Dolby retired from the board of his company, Dolby Laboratories, in December 2010, but retains the titles of Founder and Director Emeritus. Dolby played clarinet as a child and became fascinated with reed vibrations. Audio and video company Ampex hired him at age 16 to develop electrical components of its tape recording system. Dolby earned a Ph.D. in physics at England's University of Cambridge. He founded Dolby Laboratories in 1965, and made his fortune with audio-processing systems that eliminate background noise. The first inception of the system was used on the soundtrack of the 1971 hit "A Clockwork Orange." He took Dolby public in 2005. Dolby personally holds 50 patents. He enjoys skiing, sailing, and flying airplanes and helicopters. At the 2012 Berlin international film festival, he was honored for his contributions to movie-making.
title: Founder and director emeritus
employment: {'name': 'Dolby Laboratories', 'uri': 'companies/dolby-laboratories', 'title': 'Founder and director emeritus', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Timberland tycoon Archie Aldis Emmerson took Sierra Pacific Industries public in 1969, and private again four years later. He bought 522,000 acres from Santa Fe Southern Pacific Railroad with a $460 million loan in 1988. Today Sierra Pacific owns nearly 2 million acres in California and Washington. China's increased demand for timber has pushed up log prices this year, giving Emmerson's net worth a $100 million boost.

name: Billionaires
bio: Guenther Fielmann opened his first optician shop in Cuxhaven, Germany in 1972. Today, Fielmann AG sells one in two pairs of glasses in Germany. It is estimated that 23 million people wear Fielmann glasses. He took the company public in 1994. Fielmann is reported to want his son Marc, 22, to take over the company someday. He is a committed environmentalist and grows a tree for every company employee each year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jewelry business insiders call British diamond merchant Graff the new Harry Winston. Specializing in the highest end of jewelry retailing, Graff has more than 20 stores worldwide, including new outposts in San Francisco, Gstaad and Taipei. Clients include the Sultan and Queen of Brunei, Oprah Winfrey and Donald Trump. Prices for top-quality diamonds were up for the year, boosting Graff's net worth. In November, news broke that Graff is preparing an initial public offering in Hong Kong of his main asset, Graff Diamonds International. The plan: to raise $1 billion by mid-2012, to fuel expansion in Asia. Graff will open stores in Hangzhou and Macau next year. "Unless you are a certain size you haven't got a chance," Graff said in November. A self-made tycoon, Graff spent childhood in London's gritty East End, dropping out of school at age 14 to become a jeweler's apprentice. In 2008 he achieved full vertical integration when he bought a stake in publicly traded diamond miner Gem Diamonds. Other assets include a polished diamond trading venture in Antwerp, a real estate company in Luxembourg that holds properties in London's tony Mayfair district, and a stake in a South African diamond wholesaler. Graff splits his time between homes in Gstaad, London, Cap Ferrat, New York City and his 150-foot Feadship yacht. Also owns Delaire Graff Estate, a vineyard and winery with a boutique hotel and restaurant in Stellenbosch, the Napa Valley of South Africa, and an extensive modern and contemporary art collection. On a personal note, Graff, 73, has acknowledged that he fathered a baby girl out of wedlock three years ago. He and French wife Anne-Marie have been married 49 years, and remain together.

name: Billionaires
bio: Known by his middle name, Earl, Robert Holding parlayed a stake in the Little America motel in Wyoming into a hospitality empire including ski resorts Sun Valley and Snowbasin and the Grand America hotel in Salt Lake City. He bought Sinclair Oil in the 1970s, which still operates refineries and pipelines. Holding is said to be among the largest landowners in America, with some 400,000 acres across the west. He grew up with the current president of the Mormon church, Thomas Monson. Holding's family is preparing for a changing of the guard; his son Stephen is the heir apparent.

name: Billionaires
bio: Huang Rulun is chairman of the privately held Century Golden Resources Group, whose business spans real estate, hotels, mining, agribusiness and finance. The company was founded in 1991 by Huang in Fuzhou with eight people; today, it has 20,000 employees, 16 five-star hotels with 7,000 rooms and six shopping malls. Huang has also been expanding his wealth through investments in the financial industry. New China Life Insurance, in which he owns a 2.5% stake, went public in both Hong Kong and Shanghai last year. Other financial companies in which he holds stakes include unlisted China Securities and Shanghai-listed Bank of Beijing.  Huang's son Huang Tao is managing director of the group.  Huang disagreed with our estimate of his wealth.

name: Billionaires
bio: Manuel Jove, a carpenter by trade, opened his own business in 1980 and developed it into one of Spain's leading property companies, Fadesa Inmobiliaria. In 2004 he took the company public; he sold his 55% stake to real estate group Martinsa for $3 billion in September 2006, just before the collapse of the Spanish real estate bubble. Martinsa filed for bankruptcy two years later; last March, Martinsa sued Jove for $2 billion, claiming that the purchase price of Fadesa was inflated. As of press time, the judge rejected the case but Martinsa had the option to appeal. Jove holds a 5.1 % stake in Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria, one of Spain's largest banks. He collects art from the Spanish province of Galicia, and enjoys woodworking.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cirque du Soleil founder Guy Laliberte became the first fire-breather in space when he blasted into orbit in 2009, following six months of training in Russia. Back on Earth, Cirque's revenues have crossed the $1 billion threshold on the strength of shows throughout the U.S., Europe, Asia and Africa, including the popular Michael Jackson Immortal World Tour. Laliberte founded the Montreal-based circus in 1984 with a gang of street performers, receiving early funding from the Canadian government. The outfit became a for-profit group in 1985; Laliberte bought out the majority partner in 2000. He hit the jackpot when fellow billionaire Steve Wynn brought Cirque to Las Vegas in 1991, and again in 2008 when he sold 20% of Cirque to two Dubai firms for $600 million.
title: Cofounder and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Cirque du Soleil', 'title': 'Cofounder and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Shipping tycoon Spiro Latsis took a big hit amid Greece's economic woes. Stocks of his EFG International, EFG Eurobank, Lamda Development, and Hellenic Petroleum, all fell significantly in 2011. Latsis also owns jet operator PrivatAir, as well as PrivatSea, an exclusive yacht club that promises members an exceptional experience onboard some of the world's most spectacular yachts. He has a Ph.D. from the London School of Economics and sits on the board of Institute of Advanced Studies in Princeton.

name: Billionaires
bio: At 28, Friedhelm Loh took over the Loh Group after his father's death in 1974. He is still the sole owner of the company, which is now known as the Friedhelm Loh Group. The company makes switch boxes for control circuits, high grade steel cabinets, enclosures for electronic components, postboxes, intercom systems and steel sheeting.  He is currently president of ZVEI, a German electronics and electric manufacturer association. He's known for his religious beliefs and has established the Christian Media Foundation, which publishes Christian literature. Loh is an avid collector of antique cars.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lu  Guanqiu is chairman of Hangzhou-based Wanxiang Group, one of China's largest non-government-owned conglomerates.  He traveled to the U.S. with China's Communist Party Vice Chairman Xi Jinping in February, following a similar mission in America with President Hu Jintao in 2011. Storied entrepreneur fixed machinery and bicycles early in his career. Today, Lu's 80%-owned Wanxiang Group employs 30,000 in industries spanning  auto parts, real estate, metals and finance, among other industries.  Heir apparent is son Lu Weiding, who  has personal investments in Hong Kong-listed Amber Energy and film maker Huayi Brothers Media. Wanxiang America Corporation, based in Chicago, is run by Lu's son-in-law Ni Pin.   Net profit at Lu-backed Waixiang Qianchao, one of China's largest auto parts maker, in first six months up 17.5% to $40 million; sales edged up 3.5% to $670 million. The company last August formed a joint venture with Italian auto parts maker Magneti Marelli to produce auto parts in Hangzhou. Lu holds an honorary doctorate from Hong Kong Polytechnic University.

name: Billionaires
bio: Media baron Kalanithi Maran's fortune is down $900 million as shares of his Sun TV Network, whose 32 channels reach more than 95 million households, tumbled on spate of bad news. His politician brother Dayanidhi had to resign as textiles minister in July for, among other things, allegedly favoring Sun's business partner Malaysian billionaire Ananda Krishnan in acquiring telecom company Aircel when he was telecom minister. The Marans deny any wrongdoing. His powerful granduncle M. Karunanidhi was voted out as chief minister of Tamil Nadu state. New government revived state-owned cable company to compete with his and imposed a tax on direct-to-home services, where his Sun DTH is big player. He's pumping money into his lossmaking low-cost airline SpiceJet, which he bought from American billionaire Wilbur Ross.

name: Billionaires
bio: Masahiro Miki is the founder of ABC Mart, Japan's fast-growing discount shoe retailer which operates some 650 stores in Japan, and smaller chains in Korea, Hong Kong and Taiwan, selling brand-name and private label footwear. Though sales are increasing, profits are down; company stock price is down 13% over the past year. ABC Mart sold official "Save Japan" tee-shirts to raise money for disaster relief last year. Miki himself is a former amateur boxer.

name: Billionaires
bio: The founder of hedge fund firm Och-Ziff Capital Management, Och had a tough 2011. The performance of Och-Ziff's Master Fund was flat, but the firm's stock price took a disproportionate beating, tumbling by 37%. It wasn't all bad for the company's namesake however, who earned $1.07 in cumulative dividends per share in 2011, much of which was the bounty of a good 2010. Och's firm manages $29 billion and its founder is cautiously optimistic heading into 2012, seeing opportunity in Asian equities where macroeconomic conditions have depressed market prices below fundamental values. Och, who got his start at Goldman Sachs with other big time investors such as Eddie Lampert and Thomas Steyer, struck out on his own in 1994 with a reported $100 million in seed money from the Ziff brothers. On December 6, 2010 Solomon Schechter Day School of Essex and Union in West Orange, N.J., became Golda Och Academy after receiving a $15 million donation from The Jane and Daniel Och Family Foundation. The school was renamed for Och's mother, a former history teacher and administrator at the school. Och sits on the board of the Robin Hood Foundation, a charitable organization dedicated to fighting poverty in New York City.
title: Chairman and CEO
