name: Billionaires
bio: In 2007, Igor Olenicoff plead guilty to tax felony charges for stashing more than $350 million in Europe. He paid $52 million in fines, and was sentenced to two years of probation and 120 hours of community service. He now cooperates with the U.S. government on  investigations of foreign financial institutions. Through Olen Properties, Olenicoff owns more than 6.4 million square feet of office space and nearly 12,000 residential units in Las Vegas, Arizona and Florida.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stefano Pessina, a former nuclear engineer, turned his family's ailing Naples pharmaceutical wholesaler into Alliance UniChem Group, which merged with U.K. pharmacy chain Boots Group in 2006 to form Alliance Boots. It went private in a $22 billion deal in 2007 with financing from private equity firm KKR, still Europe's largest leveraged buyout. Pessina owns an estimated 32% of the company, as does KKR. His net worth is $1.2 billion higher than in 2011 based on improved performance at Alliance Boots and better information about how KKR values its stake in the company. Alliance Boots has some 115,000 employees in more than 20 countries, and Pessina is the company's executive chairman. In 2011 it partnered with Chinese Guangzhou Pharmaceutical Ltd to form the third-largest drug company in China, GP Corp. Pessina officially separated from his estranged wife, Barbara, in 2011.

name: Billionaires
bio: Anthony Pritzker is a Los Angeles-based member of the extended Chicago Pritzker family. With his brother J.B., Tony runs the Pritzker Group, a private equity firm. Tony is a grandson of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who built industrial conglomerate Marmon and hotel chain Hyatt with his sons Jay (d. 1999), Donald (d. 1972) and Robert (d. 2011). Tony is in the process of building a 49,300-square-foot home that includes a bowling alley, hairdressing area and gym in the hills above Los Angeles. Before going into private equity, Tony's career included stints running businesses inside of Marmon. An ironman triathlete, he sits on the board of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art and the UCLA Institute of the Environment and Sustainability.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jay Pritzker, known as J.B., is one of 11 members of the Chicago-based Pritzker family on the Forbes World's Billlionaires list. With his brother Tony, J.B. runs the Pritzker Group, a private equity firm. Recent acquisitions include a facilities maintenance company, a shipping equipment rental firm and a medical device manufacturer. J.B.'s net worth is up this year due to the success of his private equity investments. J.B. is a grandson of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who built industrial conglomerate Marmon and hotel chain Hyatt with his sons Jay (d. 1999), Donald (d. 1972) and Robert (d. 2011). J.B. started venture capital firm New World Ventures in 1995. He is a supporter of early childhood education, a regular donor to Democratic candidates and a member of Chicago Mayor Rahm Emanuel's "World Business Chicago" council of 50 businessmen.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ferit Faik Sahenk heads the the family conglomerate, Dogus Holding, founded by his father who died in 2001. He shares fortune with his sister, Filiz Sahenk, and mother, Deniz Sahenk. The holding includes finance, media, tourism and construction assets. In May, he completed the sale of a 6.3% stake in Garanti Bank to Spain's Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argenteria for $2 billion; remaining shares have remained flat over the past year. In October, Dogus bought Turkey's first private TV channel STAR from the Dogan Group for $327 million. Now looking to expand internet operations. He is married to Diana Sahenk, an American.

name: Billionaires
bio: Indonesia's Midas, Peter Sondakh, seems to have success in nearly all businesses he touches. Head of Rajawali Group, he has over the years cashed out stakes in cementmaker Semen Gresik, tobacco firm Bentoel International and cellphone firm Excelcomindo Pratama. His group currently has interests in mining, plantations, Indonesia's second-largest taxi operator. a toll road operator, and hotels: it owns St. Regis Bali, Surfers Paradise in Queensland. He is chairman of Rajawali. He owns a vacation home in Beverly Hills.

name: Billionaires
bio: With sister-in-law Wilma Tisch, Joan Tisch controls a family fortune built by their late husbands, investors Preston and Laurence Tisch. The duo started with a small New Jersey hotel in 1946. They acquired Loews Theatres in 1959. Today publicly traded Loews Corp. holding company includes oil drilling (Diamond Offshore), natural gas pipelines (Boardwalk) and insurance (CNA). Loews stock has held steady over the past year. Joan's son, Jonathan, heads Loews Hotels and serves as co-chairman. Wilma's son, James, is CEO of Loews. Her other son, Andrew, is co-chairman with Jonathan. Joan inherited 50% ownership of the New York Giants football team, which her late husband bought in 1991.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded conglomerate YTL Corp. in 1955, using the first letters of his name. Children all work in the company; 56-year-old son, Francis, has run it for 23 years. Its secondary listing on the Tokyo Stock Exchange in 1996 was the first non-Japanese company from Asia to start trading there. Communications unit has pumped $2.5 billion into a 4G network and Internet technology in Malaysia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhang Zhirong lost more than half his wealth as shares of his Hong Kong-listed China Rongsheng Heavy Industries tumbled; the stock is down nearly two thirds since its November 2010 IPO. One of country's largest non-government-controlled shipbuilders, it is facing a global glut of ship-producing capacity that is hurting profits.  His listed real estate developer Glorious Property also declined amid government measures aimed at curbing property prices. The company responded by launching projects in cities where government measures aren't so stringent. Zhang was a trader of construction materials and construction subcontractor before he started his first real estate project in 1996.

name: Billionaires
bio: Michael Ashley is a reclusive tycoon who does not shy away from bold business moves. He recently upset the British soccer establishment by renaming Newcastle United's sports stadium the Sports Direct Arena, after his company. A shrewd negotiator who prefers casual dress, he turned his retail chain into a sports clothing empire, netting $1.8 billion in a 2007 IPO. He still owns a 71% stake and remains executive director. Sports Direct's stock price rose in 2011 on strong earnings despite a difficult U.K. economy. Ashley pocketed $140 million last year, when Sports Direct bought 32 stores he was leasing. Right after becoming a billionaire, he bought Newcastle United, then tried to sell it twice. He still owns the Premier League soccer club to the chagrin of some fans.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nuclear physicist Peter Buck loaned family friend Fred DeLuca $1,000 in 1965 to open a sandwich shop in Bridgeport, Ct. From that first location sprang the Subway restaurants empire, offering DeLuca's famous "submarines" around the globe. In recent years, Subway's wildly successful marketing campaigns, starring the formerly obese Jared Fogle and featuring the $5 footlong sandwich, have fueled unprecedented franchise growth. Subway added more than 24,000 jobs in 2011. With more than 36,000 locations from Afghanistan to Zambia, Subway overtook McDonalds last spring to become the largest restaurant chain in the world. Of these locations, Subway operates more than 8,000 "non-traditional" stores, including a car showroom, a Detroit school, and even a Baptist Church. In 2004, Buck donated a massive 23.1-carat ruby to the Smithsonian, naming the stone for his late wife, Carmen Lucia.
title: Co-Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Chung Mong-Joon is South Korea's richest politician, but last year his shares in Hyundai Heavy Industries lost half of their value. The assemblyman, who's a former ruling party leader, is the biggest individual shareholder in the company, which he ran until 1988 when he entered politics. Chung Mong-Joon is said to have close ties to South Korea's president, a former Hyundai executive. His brother Chung Mong-Koo is also a billionaire.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 1965 a young Fred DeLuca borrowed $1,000 from family friend Peter Buck to start a "submarine" sandwich shop in Bridgeport, Ct. DeLuca's original plan was to offset the cost of his college education with the profits from his restaurant. Subway now has locations the world over, from Afghanistan to Zambia, and recently overtook McDonalds as the world's largest restaurant chain with more than 36,000 locations. Of these, Subway operates more than 8,000 "non-traditional" stores, including a car showroom, a Detroit school, and even a Baptist Church. The chain is known for its popular ads featuring formerly obese student Jared Fogle and the ever-popular $5 footlong. While his partner and fellow billionaire Peter Buck's role has become less active over the years, DeLuca continues to oversee the day-to-day operations of the company. Subway generated revenue of $16.6 billion and added 24,000 jobs in 2011.
title: President and Co-Founder
employment: {'name': "Doctor's Associates (Subway)", 'title': 'President and Co-Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Stanley Druckenmiller closed down his $12 billion (assets) hedge fund, Duquesne Capital Management, in August 2010 and returned investors' money citing frustration with his inability to deliver high returns. He'd started Duquesne Capital Management 30 years ago with $1 million. In 1988 Druckenmiller was hired by George Soros and the duo was reported to have made $1 billion in a day with a timely short position on the British Pound in 1992. Druckenmiller struck out on his own in 2000 and reportedly made money in 2008 when most other firms tanked. In December 2009 he announced a $705 million commitment to "medical research, education and the fight against poverty," including $100 million for a new neuroscience institute at NYU Langone Medical Center. He chairs Harlem Children's Zone, which helps 17,000-plus children and adults.

name: Billionaires
bio: Barbara Carlson Gage jointly owns Carlson Inc. with her sister, Marilyn Carlson Neslon. Carlson Inc. owns restaurants (T.G.I. Friday's) and travel agencies, and the company is focused on growing its hotel division (Radisson, Country Inns & Suites). It announced an internal restructuring of properties with franchisee Rezidor Hotel Group and a plan to bring its upscale brand, Blu, stateside, while continuing to pursue its goal of increasing the hotel portfolio 50% to 1,500 hotels by 2015. Her father, Curt (d. 1999), began selling Gold Bond trading stamps in the 1930s and later expanded into dining and hospitality. Barbara runs the family foundation and is active in children's charities.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bahaa Hariri who's the eldest son of slain Lebanese Prime Minister Rafik Hariri has invested heavily in Jordan. In partnership with the Jordanian government, his real estate development holding Horizon Group is building a new urban area in downtown Amman. This past May he inaugurated the Rafik Hariri Center for the Middle East at the Atlantic Council, which he hopes will focus on governance in Egypt. His dream job: CEO of Apple.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gunter Herz inherited a fortune from his father, coffee magnate Max Herz, along with his mother Ingeburg; his brothers Joachim, Michael and Wolfgang and his sister Daniela. He headed the family's Tchibo Holding, now called Maxingvest AG, for almost 35 years. A nasty family feud led Herz and his sister Daniela to sell their combined 40% stake in the German consumer goods group to their mother and three brothers for an estimated $5 billion in 2003. Now, he and his sister own private equity firm Mayfair GmbH, which in 2011, acquired 40% of the Vapiano Group, a restaurant chain with operations in more than 70 locations in Europe, the US and the Middle East. Gunter raises horses at his stud farm and races his yacht, All Smoke.

name: Billionaires
bio: Masatoshi Ito is honorary chairman of the biggest Japanese retailer, Seven & I, which operates some 42,000 shops, mostly 7-Eleven convenience stores as well as superstores and department stores. The company expects record net income of $1.6 billion for this fiscal year, thanks in part to rising sales and new 7-Eleven store openings in Japan. Expanding in Beijing and Chengdu. After Japan's earthquake, the company's logistics were disrupted, about 350 of 13,219 7-Eleven stores closed and customers emptied storeshelves. Some Ito Yokado Supermarkets sheltered victims inside, moving goods for sale outdoors. A company spokesperson said Seven & I considered it a "mission" to keep stores open to help daily life return to normal. The company also donated emergency supplies of bottled water and food.

name: Billionaires
bio: H. Fisk Johnson is chairman and CEO of $9 billion (sales) household products company S.C. Johnson and a son of Samuel Curtis Johnson (d. 2004), who ran the firm for 46 years. H. Fisk's great great grandfather started a parquet flooring company in 1886. S.C. Johnson is best known for brands like Windex, Pledge and Ziploc. The company settled two class action suits that challenged the company's Greenlist logo on its products. Nevertheless, S.C. Johnson has reduced greenhouse gas emissions with efforts like a factory powered by methane gas from a nearby dump in the Johnsons' hometown of Racine, Wisc.; a wind turbine helps run a plant in the Netherlands. H. Fisk Johnson sits on the board of Conservation International. The family is a big backer of the Smithsonian and the Mayo Clinic. The Johnsons left an indelible stamp on Racine, commissioning Frank Lloyd Wright to design the company's corporate headquarters in the late 1930s.

name: Billionaires
bio: Imogene Powers Johnson is the widow of Samuel Curtis Johnson (d. 2004), who ran household products company S.C. Johnson. Sam joined the S.C. Johnson company in 1954, expanding it into industrial cleaning, banking and camping supplies; he passed the company on to the fifth generation in 2000. Their four children attended Sam's alma mater, Cornell University, before entering the family business. Her children all work at the company and are billionaires. Imogene is the founding director and chairman of the Prairie School, a college preparatory day school; she is also a director at Cornell University's Laboratory of Ornithology. The family is a big backer of the Smithsonian and the Mayo Clinic. The Johnsons left a stamp on their hometown of Racine, Wisc., commissioning Frank Lloyd Wright to design the corporate headquarters in the late 1930s.

name: Billionaires
bio: S. Curtis "Curt" Johnson, fifth-generation heir to the SC Johnson cleaning product fortune, is currently awaiting trial a year after being charged for the repeated sexual assault of a minor. Until February 2011, Curt chaired family-owned industrial cleaning outfit Diversey Inc., formerly JohnsonDiversey. He stood down citing personal reason before is March arrest.The trial is scheduled for this April; Curt has pleaded not guilty. Diversey has since been sold to Sealed Air, the maker of Bubble Wrap, for $4.3 billion. Curt still lives in his hometown of Racine, Wisconsin, S.C. Johnson's base, and is out on $500,000 bond. He's one of four children of Samuel Curtis Johnson (d. 2004), great-grandson of the former salesman who started a flooring company in 1886, the moved into the wax business. Johnson Wax expanded to cleaning products, many of which are now household names, including Windex, Pledge and Drano. Curt's brother Fisk heads up S.C Johnson, while sister Helen Johnson-Leipold runs the businesses under the Johnson Financial Group umbrella.

name: Billionaires
bio: Helen Johnson-Leipold is one of two daughters of Samuel Curtis Johnson (d. 2004), the great-grandson of the salesman who started parquet flooring company S.C. Johnson in 1886. The company later diversified into household and industrial cleaning, banking and camping supplies. Helen runs financial services company Johnson Financial as well as Johnson Outdoors, a publicly traded camping and military supplies company; she also chairs the Johnson Foundation at Wingspread. Helen is the founder and chairman of Next Generation Now, a child development and family resource center in central Racine, Wisc. She and her husband have five boys and five dogs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Winifred Johnson Marquart is a daughter of Samuel Curtis Johnson (d. 2004) and one of five members of the Johnson family on the Forbes World's Billionaires list. Samuel Curtis was a great-grandson of the salesman who started parquet flooring company S.C. Johnson in 1886. The company has since diversified into household and industrial cleaning, banking and camping supplies. Winifred is president of the Johnson Family Foundation and formerly worked in corporate public affairs at S.C. Johnson. The family is a backer of the Smithsonian and the Mayo Clinic. The Johnsons left their stamp on their hometown of Racine, Wisc. by commissioning Frank Lloyd Wright to design the company's headquarters there in the late 1930s.

name: Billionaires
bio: New Jacksonville Jaguars owner Shahid Khan tried to buy a majority stake in the St. Louis Rams football team in 2010, but was beat out by fellow billionaire Stan Kroenke. Instead, Khan purchased the Jaguars from Wayne Weaver for $770 million, with the sale finalized in January 2012. Khan is a naturalized U.S. citizen who emigrated from Pakistan for college at age 16. He got his start working at auto parts manufacturer Flex-N-Gate while earning his engineering degree. He left in 1978 to found his own company, Bumper Works, and created a new one-piece car bumper design that would become the industry standard. Two years later, Khan bought his former employer and merged operations. Flex-N-Gate, still privately-held, now takes in more than $3 billion in revenue a year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Honorary president of the family holding company, Koc Holding, Mustafa Rahmi Koc handed over his duties to his eldest son Mustafa in 2003 after nearly two decades at the helm. The industrial group plans $3.4 billion in new investments in 2012 from cars to refining. He founded the Rahmi Koc Museum which is dedicated to the history of transportation, industry and communication and houses thousands of objects ranging from gramophone needles to ships and planes. Known for his love of the sea and luxury yachts, he is a member of both the Istanbul Ocean Racing Club and the New York Yacht Club. His sisters Semahat Arsel and Suna Kirac and his son Mustafa Vehbi Koc are also billionaires.

name: Billionaires
bio: An elusive Canadian billionaire who rarely gives interviews, Robert Miller founded Future Electronics in 1968. Today the private Quebec-based company is one of the world's largest electronics distributors, with products including semiconductors and electro-mechanical components, and operations in 42 countries. As a believer in cryonics, the science of freezing bodies to possibly restore life later on, Miller is a supporter of Alcor Life Extension Foundation. He is also an avid real estate investor.

name: Billionaires
bio: Marilyn Carlson Nelson jointly owns Carlson Inc. with her sister, Barbara. An industry-wide recovery benefited its restaurants (T.G.I. Friday's) and travel agencies, and Carlson is now focused on growing its hotel division (Radisson, Country Inns & Suites). The company announced an internal restructuring of properties with franchisee Rezidor Hotel Group and a plan to bring its upscale brand, Blu, stateside, while continuing to pursue its goal to increase the hotel portfolio 50% to 1,500 hotels by 2015. Her father, Curt (d. 1999), began selling Gold Bond trading stamps in the 1930s and later expanded into dining and hospitality. Marilyn stepped down as CEO of Carlson Inc. in 2008.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Greek shipping heir Philip Niarchos inherited his father's art collection of such masterpieces as Vincent van Gogh's "Self-Portrait with a Bandaged Ear" and Pablo Picasso's self-portrait "Yo, Picasso." Philip, who is a board member of the Museum of Modern Art in New York City, has added such contemporary works as Jean-Michel Basquiat's "Self-Portrait" and Andy Warhol's "Shot Red Marilyn." Commissioned to do Philip's portrait, Warhol created a series based on CAT-scans of Philip's skull. While Philip is intensely private, art experts pin his collection as world's most valuable in private hands.

name: Billionaires
bio: After his father's death in 2005, Axel Oberwelland became sole owner of candy company Storck, makers of Werther's Original, Riesen, and Toffifee. He is the fourth generation of his family to run the company. The company established the Stork Foundation in 1992 to preserve Germany's endangered stork population.

name: Billionaires
bio: For the first time in more than a decade, the legendary Tiger Management founder is opening a fund to outside investors. The Tiger Accelerator Fund, which will invest exclusively in a group of six Tiger-seeded hedge funds, has raised $450 million from investors, with Robertson personally committing a further $250 million. The six seeds are Tiger Eye Partners, Long Oar Global Partners, Tiger Ratan Capital, Cascabel Management, Tiger Veda Management, and Teewinot Fund. After originally closing his fund in 2000, Robertson became a pioneer in seeding and mentoring handpicked hedge funds, known as Tiger Cubs. He now seeds over 40 funds, the majority of which operate out of 101 Park Avenue where Robertson himself operates his family office, Tiger Management L.L.C. Robertson founded Tiger Management (his son, who is now a partner, suggested the name) in 1980. It became one of the world's biggest hedge funds, peaking at $22 billion in assets under management in 1998. A fan of New Zealand, Robertson owns two wineries and three golf resorts there. He signed onto Bill Gates-Warren Buffett Giving Pledge. In his letter to Buffett,  Robertson says: "One very fortunate thing is that I did not get nearly as enthusiastic about philanthropy early on as I am now; if I had there would be very little to give away." Robertson has thrown his support behind Mitt Romney's 2012 presidential campaign.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nevaldo Rocha debuts on the Forbes World's Billionaires list after finding success running  Brazil's version of fast-fashion king Zara. Rocha co-founded apparel maker Guararapes Confeccoes with his brother more than half a century ago. In 1979 the company acquired the Riachuelo department stores; it has been making low-priced clothes at its own plants and selling them to Brazil's emerging middle class at its 145 shops. Analysts expect revenues for 2011 to reach $3.4 billion, up nearly 18% from 2010 in local currency terms. Its stores are located throughout Brazil  -- including in its home territory, the fast-growing northeastern region, where GDP growth of 8% in some states matches that of China. Rocha, who didn't even attend high school, is the chairman and chief executive officer. His son Flavio is vice president of the company and CEO of Riachuelo, the retail division. Rocha's two other children, daughter Lisiane and son Elsio, are board members. Nevaldo holds about $1 billion of the stock in his name; another $1 billion or so of stock is owned by his three children.
title: Entrepreneur

name: Billionaires
bio: David Rockefeller is the grandson of oil baron John D. Rockefeller. He is now working to give away his fortune. Among the beneficiaries of his wealth: New York's Museum of Modern Art, Rockefeller University, Harvard University, the Americas Society and the Council on Foreign Relations. His grandfather turned $4,000 in oil refining into Standard Oil, the energy giant that fueled America's industrial revolution. The company was broken up in 1911 in a landmark antitrust case. His father then began investing in real estate, which David continues to do. His parents also helped establish the MoMA. David has a vast trove of contemporary and modern art which he has been collecting for more than 70 years. He is also an insect enthusiast, with one of the largest beetle collections in the world. David is the oldest living member of the Rockefeller clan and the only one to make it on the billionaires list.

name: Billionaires
bio: Retail king Eliseo Alexandre Soares dos Santos owns more than 20 percent of one of Portugal's largest retailers, Jeronimo Martins. The company, which traces its beginnings to a tiny store opened in Lisbon in 1792, operates super and hypermarkets in Portugal, and retail stores and pharmacies in Poland. It's value grew more than 200 percent from 2009 to 2012. Soares dos Santos became CEO in 1968, and is now the Chairman of the Board. Four of his seven children work in the company, including his son Pedro, who is the current CEO.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zygmunt Solorz-Zak founded TV network Polsat in 1992; today the Polsat Group is listed on the Warsaw Stock Exchange and includes a digital platform as well as sports, news and film channels. He also owns shares in Poland's InvestBank, pension fund PTE Polsat, pharmaceutical company Bioton and TV producer ATM Group. In 2011 Solorz-Zak he bought Polish telecoms outfit Polkomtel in a deal worth $5.3 billion. He's the majority shareholder in soccer team Śląsk Wrocław.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ronda Stryker has used her wealth from Stryker Corp., a medical device company founded by her grandfather, to fund education causes, especially those that empower girls and young women. She's been gradually selling shares, but still owns 8.5% of the company directly and through two trusts. Stryker makes hospital beds, joint replacements, medical software and surgical cameras. The stock tumbled last summer, but has been recovering lately. It's up 22% since mid-December. She is the only family member on Stryker's board of directors. Her surgeon grandfather Homer Stryker (d. 1980) founded the company in 1941 after inventing a mobile hospital bed. Her father, Lee, succeeded Homer as president, but died in a plane crash in 1976. John Brown became chief executive and took the company public in 1979. A former teacher, she's suspected of being one of the donors of a $100 million anonymous gift to Western Michigan University for a new medical school.

name: Billionaires
bio: In April the mall mogul pledged $56 million to the University of Michigan and is now the largest donor in the school's history, having given $142 million. The school's college of Architecture and Urban Planning bears his name as does a research institute at the medical school. Taubman is a strong supporter of stem cell research and hopes to make his home state a stem cell mecca. The University of Michigan dropout started mall empire,Taubman Centers, in 1950. He later took auction house Sotheby's private in 1983, although he brought it public again in 1988. Formerly Sotheby's chairman, Taubman sold his controlling interest in 2005. He wrote his memoir, Threshold Resistance, about his career and a 9-month prison sentence he served in 2004 on art auction price-fixing charges.

name: Billionaires
bio: Steve Wynn spent much of 2011 battling with his partner, Japanese billionaire slot machine tycoon Kazuo Okada, who was the largest shareholder and director of Wynn Resorts Ltd. In February, Wynn dismissed Okada from the board of directors and forcibly bought out his 20% stake, filing suit against Okada in Nevada. Wynn had hired former FBI director Louis Freeh to investigate Okada. Freeh's report claims that Okada violated the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act when he gave gifts and payments worth more than $100,000 to gaming officials in the Philippines, where Okada is building a casino. Okada disputes Wynn's charges. Besides the feud, Wynn had a busy 2011. He and NFL Patriots owner Robert Kraft lobbied for support of a possible Wynn-owned casino to be located across from the football stadium in Foxboro, Mass. In December, local politicians voted down the plan. In November, a Nevada judge ruled that Wynn's policy of pooling tips for dealers in his Nevada casinos violates state law, sending the fight to the state supreme court. Shares of Wynn's casino empire peaked in July but then dropped significantly toward the end of the year. In 2010 he partnered with online poker site, PokerStars, but severed ties in April after the U.S. government clamped down on Internet gambling. In January of 2010 he had his (second) divorce from his wife, Elaine, making her a billionaire.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Wynn Resorts', 'uri': 'companies/wynn-resorts', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Largest individual shareholder of Nintendo, Hiroshi Yamauchi has seen his wealth halved by the company's falling stock price. Over the past year, Nintendo's share price plummetted 55% on disappointing year-end sales of its video game software, handhelds and consoles, widely blamed on an aging product lineup. The rising yen has also hit profits abroad. The company is trying to regroup with sales of its 3DS handheld and a new console, Wii U, offered this year. Yamauchi ran Nintendo for 55 years before retiring in 2005. He bought the baseball team, the Seattle Mariners, in 1992, and later transferred ownership to Nintendo's U.S. unit.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former head of Esprit sold his remaining stake in February 2010, before the company's profit fell 98% in the year ended June 30. Ying's history with Esprit began in 1971, when the company's American founders hired him as their primary sourcing agent. By 2002, he had bought them out to become the fashion retailer's sole owner. Wife, Brigitte Lin, published a book about her career as a movie star, and the couple bought a colonial-style home on the lower slopes of Kowloon Peak for $32 million. He is said to be an amateur paleontologist and an enthusiastic golfer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Thomas Bruch is the fifth generation of his family to run the $8 billion (revenues) Globus & Co., one of Germany's largest food retailers. The company also operates 83 hardware stores and nine electrical appliance stores. His great-great-grandfather Franz Bruch opened the first store in 1828. Thomas Bruch took over from his father in 1979. With his three sons working at the firm, a continued family stewardship seems assured.

name: Billionaires
bio: Clive Calder, whose wealth comes from selling his Zomba Group for $2.7 billion, started out playing in a band at age 18 to support his mother and sister after his father's death. He moved to London in 1975 and founded Zomba, whose crown jewel was Jive Records. Calder's firm ventured stateside in 1978, signing acts like Billy Ocean and the Cars, Backstreet Boys, Britney Spears, and 'N Sync. In 2002, Calder sold Zomba to BMG. He now lives in the Cayman Islands, spending part of his time on charitable foundation Elma Philanthropies, which works in twelve African countries to improve children's education and health.

name: Billionaires
bio: Financier Mark Coombs benefited from investor interest in Latin America and Asia in 2011; earnings at fund manager Ashmore Group are up 13%. Taking advantage of cheap equities, he bought money manager Emerging Market Management for $246 million in February 2011, and nearly doubled assets under management to $60.4 billion. Coombs started Ashmore as a new division of Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, then led a buyout in 1999. He took the firm public in 2006, raising $2 billion, and keeping a 42% stake. Ashmore is now in London's FTSE index of 100 leading companies. A Cambridge law graduate, Coombs lives in Wimbledon, close to the tennis club.

name: Billionaires
bio: John Doerr of Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers earned the bulk of his wealth from timely investments in Web 1.0 companies Amazon, Netscape, Sun Microsystems and Google, where he remains on the board. Now he's making up for a sharp left turn into green-tech--with notably few exits with later stage investments in hot social media startups. KPCB invested early in online game phenoms Zynga and Ngmoco (sold to DeNa for $400 million), but had to pay top dollar to get into Facebook at a $52 billion valuation, Groupon at a $4.75 billion valuation and Twitter at a $3.7 billion valuation. Doerr sits on the board of non-profit venture firm NewSchools Venture fund which backs entrepreneurs working to transform public education. He hosted President Obama and a who's who of technology at his Woodside, California home last year.
title: Partner
employment: {'name': 'Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers', 'title': 'Partner', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of the Campbell's soup founder, John Dorrance III cashed out of the family business when he sold his 10.5% stake in 1995-1996. He timed the move well, getting out before the stock plunged. Dorrance renounced his U.S. citizenship and moved to Ireland prior to the sale, presumably to avoid paying capital gains taxes. Since then, he's lived quietly in South Dublin, while frequenting the Bahamas with his Finnish wife. In the past, Dorrance joined movements to legalize game ranching in Wyoming and fox hunting in Great Britain.

name: Billionaires
bio: Philippe Foriel-Destezet merged his French staffing firm Ecco with Klaus Jacobs's Swiss firm Adia to create Adecco in 1996. Foriel-Destezet stepped down as co-chairman of Adecco in 2005 and is now honorary president. He founded his staffing company in 1964; by the 1980s the firm was France's largest supplier of temporary personnel. He currently serves as the chairman of Akila Finance, a holding company based in Luxembourg. Though a native of France (was awarded the French Legion of Honor), Foriel-Destezet resides in London, where taxes are lower. His business partner, Klaus Jacobs, passed away in 2008.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alexander Frolov is chief executive of Evraz Group; partner and fellow billionaire Alexander Abramov is chairman. Frolov has managed the company's debt burden since the beginning of the economic crisis; at its peak in 2008, Evraz's debt was $9.1 billion, by the end of 2011 the debt had been reduced to $7.2 billion. In 2011 the company paid its first dividends in three years. Frolov has investments in Highlands Gold Mining and Russia's electricity infrastructure. He got his start working as a research fellow at the I.V. Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy; he holds a doctorate in physics and mathematics.

name: Billionaires
bio: Third generation to head 115-year-old Godrej Group, a $3.3 billion (revenues) consumer goods conglomerate. Its Godrej Consumer Products bought a 51% stake in Africa's Darling Group, its fourth acquisition in that region.  Group denied rumor that it was ending its partnership with chocolate maker Hershey's. Son Pirojsha, a Columbia University grad, was appointed chief executive of fast-expanding property arm, which listed in 2010. Family's biggest asset is its 3,500 acre estate in suburban Mumbai. His fortune is down this year on new information about ownership of family assets which he shares with cousins Jamshyd Godrej and Rishad Naoroji who debut on list this year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mechanical engineer Jamshyd Godrej, the third generation of the Godrej clan and a cousin of Adi Godrej, debuts on list. He runs Godrej & Boyce, group's privately-held consumer durables arm that makes, among much else, home appliances and office furniture. He also chairs the Indian arm of the Aspen Institute. Likes to go sailing. Wife Pheroza owns an art gallery in Mumbai.

name: Billionaires
bio: In February Tom Gores' sale of $350 million (sales) fiberglass company 3B capped off an active year for the Michigan native's buyout firm Platinum Equity. He sold the San Diego Union Tribune in December, after owning the newspaper for two years, and bought a shipping company and a digital imaging firm. Gores' highest profile acquisition was in April 2011 when he became the new owner of the NBA's Detroit Pistons after buying Palace Sports & Entertainment from the Davidson family for $325 million. The Michigan State alum started in the buyout business with brother Alec who's now a billionaire too. Platinum Equity has made more than 100 acquisitions since its founding in 1995.

name: Billionaires
bio: Guo Guangchang is the chairman and cofounder of Fosun International, one of China's largest conglomerates, with interests in pharmaceuticals, real estate, steel, mining, retail and publishing. His net worth is down several hundred million dollars compared to March 2011 due to a drop in Fosun's stock price. Fosun, which is listed on the Hong Kong stock exchange, bought a 9.5% stake in Greek luxury retailer Folli Follie for about 85 million euros ($110 million) in May 2011, highlighting the firm's strategy of partnering with overseas companies that cater to China's rising consumer demand. A joint venture with U.S. insurer Prudential is expected to begin operating later this year. Fosun also holds a 9.5% stake in Club Mediterranee SA (Club Med), acquired in June 2010. Fosun Media is a licensing partner of Forbes Media in China. Guo earned a bachelor's degree in philosophy and master's degree in business administration, both from Fudan University.

name: Billionaires
bio: The son of a prominent stockbroker, Hostetter graduated from Harvard Business School in 1961 and then convinced his employer, Boston-based Cambridge Capital, to finance a small cable television system in rural New Jersey. Alongside his college roommate, Hostetter then spread the business to the rest of the country under the name Continental Cablevision. The company eventually became the largest privately held cable company in the country, before being sold to US West for $11 billion in 1996. Later Hostetter bought the company back, renamed it MediaOne, and sold it to AT&T for $58 billion three years later. Today he owns Boston's Lewis Wharf, which serves as the base for his privately held Pilot House entities. He is now an investor in cable companies, broadband start-ups and the odd piece of Nantucket real estate. His billion-dollar-endowed Barr Foundation focuses on environmental issues and public education in and around Boston and has given large gifts to area museums.
title: Chair

name: Billionaires
bio: Zarakh Iliev and his partner God Nisanov own the Radisson Royal Ukraine Hotel, European Shopping Center and Radisson SAS Slavyanskaya Hotel in Moscow. The partners also own several big shopping centers in Moscow's outskirts, where wholesalers from all over Russia come to buy goods. Born in Azerbaijan, Iliev moved to Moscow and began selling alcohol before partnering with Nisanov and creating shopping markets near metro stations. The partners turned these into shopping complexes. Now they have a growing pipeline of hotel projects in Moscow and other regions of Russia.

name: Billionaires
bio: This last year brought good news for the Ilitchs' Little Caesar's chain: Pizza sales have been rising and cheese prices, dropping. Revenues at Marian's Motor City Casino improved, too. The Ilitch clan smartly passed on the chance to buy the Detroit Pistons basketball team, but Mike hopes a $214 million deal to bring slugger Prince Fielder to the Detroit Tigers will finally get him a World Series championship.

name: Billionaires
bio: Pharmaceutical entrepreneur Randal Kirk's net worth jumped in the last year after he sold his drug company, Clinical Data, to Forest Laboratories for $1.2 billion. Kirk had previously sold New River Pharmaceutical to Shire in 2007 for $2.6 billion. He currently invests in medical and biotech start-ups like Intrexon, which uses genetic engineering to achieve "synthetic biology." Son of a drill sergeant, Kirk graduated from Radford University in 1976 and the University of Virginia School of Law in 1979. He serves on the University of Virginia Board of Visitors and is an avid falconer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Adi Godrej's cousin, Rishad Naoroji debuts on list due to his one third share of the Godrej family fortune that he inherited from his mother. He plays no active role in running the business. Avid photographer and birdwatcher, main interest is studying raptors. He spent three years in Africa photographing predators. Has authored Birds of Prey of the Indian Subcontinent.

name: Billionaires
bio: God Nisanov and his partner Zarakh Iliev own the Radisson Royal Ukraine Hotel, European Shopping Center and Radisson SAS Slavyanskaya Hotel in Moscow. The partners also own several big shopping centers in Moscow's outskirts, where wholesalers from all over Russia come to buy goods. Born in Azerbaijan, Nisanov moved to Moscow. Wiith Iliev he began creating shopping markets near metro stations. The partners turned these into shopping complexes. Now they have a growing pipeline of hotel projects in Moscow and other regions of Russia; their real estate projects total nearly 10.8 million square feet.

name: Billionaires
bio: Viktor Nusenkis gained the bulk of his fortune in his native Ukraine, where he owns two coal mines, a coke-chemical plant, and metallurgy works. During the Soviet era, Nusenkis became director of a Ukrainian coal mine and was among the first to begin exporting coal independently, despite communist rules. In 1993, Nusenkis founded Energo Concern, which helped state-owned factories organize trade deals. Energo quickly became one of the biggest coal traders in Ukraine. Nusenkis's business was done under the protection of Gennady Vasilyev, the former attorney general of Ukraine, who is currently trying to prove in Cyprus court that he owned half of Energo. Nusenkis is now a Russian citizen and owns coal mines in Siberia. Since the 1990s, Nusenkis has been very active in the Russian Orthodox Church, and is one of its most influential patrons in both Ukraine and Russia.

name: Billionaires
bio: The lone American among the billionaires at commodities trading giant Glencore, Peterson joined the firm in 1992 following a six year stint at Phibro-Salomon in New York as a commodities marketer. In 2002 Peterson succeeded current Glencore CEO Ivan Glasenberg as director of the coal and coke commodity department. After boarding school in Switzerland, Peterson attended Duke University, where he got his B.A. in political science and French in 1986. Peterson officially became a billionaire thanks to Glencore's May 2011 IPO. Despite its shares losing nearly 20% of their value since their public debut, the future is bright for Glencore. The firm announced plans to merge with mining colossus Xstrata in February 2012. The proposed all-stock merger would spawn a $90 billion mining and marketing behemoth.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sebastian Pinera, a Chilean Renaissance man, serves as his country's first conservative president in decades. He has a Ph.D. in economics from Harvard, founded credit card giant Bancard and owned several other businesses. After he was elected president in January 2010, Pinera kept his campaign promise to sell his holdings, a popular move. He unloaded his 26% stake in Chilean airline LAN for $1.5 billion, sold the TV channel Chilevision to Time Warner for a reported $150 million, and sold his share of popular soccer team Blanco & Negro. But last year after student protests, worker strikes, and raging wildfires in Torres del Paine National Forest, Pinera's approval ratings dropped to a reported 23%, the lowest of any Chilean president since Pinochet.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former engineer James Ratcliffe's $40 billion (sales) Ineos is the world's third-largest chemicals company. In 2011, Petrochina agreed to pay $1 billion for a 50% stake in Ineos's European refinery operations. Over the years, Ineos has largely grown through a series of acquisitions, and continued the pattern in 2011: in May, the firm acquired polyvinyl chrloride and chlor-alkali businesses from Belgium-based Tessenderlo, for $110 million. In August, Ineos combined certain assets with Germany's BASF to become the global leader in styrene monomer and polystyrene production. But the biggest acquisition came in 2005: an $8.7 billion deal to buy BP Group's Innovene business. Ineos moved its headquarters moved from the U.K. to Switzerland, apparently to save on taxes. The firm has expressed interest in pursuing joint ventures in the Middle East.

name: Billionaires
bio: Phil Ruffin's Treasure Island Casino has seen revenues climb as his relaxed resort draws droves of blue collar gamers. Ruffin quit his job at a mass-merchandise store after his boss asked him to repossess a live monkey; he's been self-employed since. In 1959 he bought a convenience store, which grew to 65 locations. He later bought gas stations, oil wells, manufacturing concerns and casinos. Ruffin purchased New Frontier Hotel & Casino for $165 million in 1998; he sold it to El-Ad Group for $1.24 billion in 2007. In March 2009, Ruffin paid $755 million to buy Treasure Island from MGM Mirage. Ruffin has committed to playing in Cirque du Soleil founder Guy Laliberte's July 2012 high-stakes charity poker tournament; the entrance price was a cool $1 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Moise Safra is the older of two living billionaire brothers descended from a Middle Eastern banking family. In 2006 Moise sold to his brother Joseph his holding in Banco Safra, now Brazil's 9th-largest bank, plus stakes in Safra-owned banks in New York, Luxembourg and other locations, for an undisclosed sum estimated at $2 billion. In 2010 Joseph and Moise sold their stakes in pulp and paper maker Aracruz to the Votorantim Group (owned by billionaire Antonio Ermirio de Moraes). Joseph and Moise's deceased brother Edmond had a separate multibillion-dollar banking fortune, part of which he left to his wife Lily, who is also a member of the Forbes billionaires' list. Moise occasionally shows up in Brazil's society pages and has an auditorium named after him at the Albert Einstein Israelite Hospital in Sao Paulo.

name: Billionaires
bio: Filiz Sahenk is the sister of fellow billionaire Ferit Faik Sahenk, who runs the family's Dogus Holding; their mother Deniz Sahek is also a billionaire. The holding includes finance, media, tourism and construction assets. Filiz handles the group's retail partnerships with luxury brands Tod's (owned by  Italian billionaires Diego and Andrea Della Valle) and Armani (Georgio Armani is also a billionaire). An advocate of women's leadership she is also the  president of the Ayhan Sahenk Foundation. She is also active in the International Myeloma Foundation. Filiz has a large antique collection.

name: Billionaires
bio: Although the Beanie Babies fad that made him a billionaire in the 1990s has waned, Warner's Ty Inc. continues to produce the stuffed creatures and pen the whimsical quatrains that accompany each toy. Beanie Babies 2.0 now include codes that allow kids to interact with their Beanies and others online. These days the majority of Warner's wealth is held in his Ty Warner Hotels and Resorts, a portfolio that includes the New York and Santa Barbara Four Seasons hotels. A night in the New York Four Seasons' Ty Warner Penthouse Suite will cost you $35,000; the package includes a personal butler and unlimited travel in either a Rolls Royce or a Maybach. In the wake of Japan's devastating tsunami in March 2011, Warner created a limited edition Hello Kitty Beanie Baby to benefit relief efforts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Othman Benjelloun made his debut on Africa's 40 Richest list. His father was a large shareholder in a small Moroccan insurance company. Benjelloun took over in 1988, and built it into RMA Watanya, a leading insurance company. He then used it to expand into banking. His publicly traded BMCE Bank is present in more than a dozen African countries (due to an acquisition of Bank of Africa), and has a market capitalization of $4 billion. His holding company Groupe FinanceCom has also interests in telecom, airlines, and information technology. Son Kamal, a clean tech enthusiast, is heir apparent.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heirs to a half-share in the same Rio Tinto royalty stream that has enriched Gina Rinehart, brother and sister keep very low profiles. Among there few notable interests is a world-class vineyard, Voyager Estates. They also own property in Australia and allegedly in the U.S. Both are said to be in extremely ill-health.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dubbed the "homeless billionaire" for his penchant for living out of hotels, Berggruen is pouring money into real estate developments in Newark, Los Angeles, and Tel Aviv. In 2011, he announced the formation of a new cash shell called Justice. His reputation as a savvy investor reportedly helped him quickly raise $1.1 billion, without naming investment targets. Berggruen's disparate holdings include hydroelectric power plants in Turkey, residential real estate in Tel Aviv and a Spanish media conglomerate. In 2010, he brought German retailer Karstadt out of bankruptcy for the symbolic price of one euro. He claims to have improved the department store chain's revenues since, and is attempting to buy competitor Kaufhof. Berggruen has given more than $20 million to support efforts to restructure California's state government. He collects Picasso, Warhol, Basquiat and Koons, and claims he likes to hold on to art more than hoarding cash. His father, Heinz, amassed a world-famous collection of works by Picasso. Berggruen grew up in France and Switzerland.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chan Laiwa chairs the Fu Wah International Group, whose operations are headquartered in Beijing.  Her wealth has increased from a year ago on a recovery in Beijing's property market. The Chan clan owns the high-profile Jinbao Street development project in Beijing's busy Chaoyang district, located about a mile away from the Forbidden City. Denizens include the Hong Kong Jockey and luxury hotel Beijing Regent. Fu Wah resigned a licensing partner with Regent in September, after the brand was purchased by Taiwan's Formosa International in 2010 from Carlson.  The family also runs the prestigious Chang An Club, Lee Garden serviced apartment complex, among other businesses in Beijing.  Chan is a member of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference.
title: Philanthropist

name: Billionaires
bio: Francis Choi made his first fortune churning out toys for the likes of Mattel through his Early Light International. He is now one of Hong Kong's most successful real estate investors. He turned his passion for collecting watches (he has more than 200) into yet another source of profits; he now owns  Halewinner watch-retailing chain, which he is expanding. This year he plans to introduce a new line of timepieces at his Macau stores, the "Francis C." Choi also collects cars and has minority stakes in Hong Kong-listed Regal Hotels and Town Health.

name: Billionaires
bio: Serial entrepreneur Mark Cuban started audio and video portal Broadcast.com with college pal Todd Wagner and sold to it Yahoo for $5.7 billion in 1999. Outside of the Dallas Mavericks basketball team, which he bought in 2000 for $280 million, Cuban's entertainment vehicles include cable channel HDNet, Landmark Theatres and filmmaker Magnolia Pictures. In late 2011, Cuban flirted with the idea of buying the Los Angeles Dodgers baseball team, but pulled away after bankrupt owner Frank McCourt asked for $1.2 billion.
title: Owner

name: Billionaires
bio: Shopping mall mogul Ed DeBartolo Jr. took over most of the family business from his father, leading DeBartolo Realty Corp.'s merger with Simon Property Group in 1996 to create the largest public REIT in North America. DeBartolo owned the San Francisco 49ers for 23 years, during which time the team won an NFL-record five Super Bowl championships. In 2000 he swapped his 49ers ownership with sister Denise York for a large stake in SPG. In 1998, DeBartolo had pled guilty to a felony, admitting he failed to report a bribe request from then-Louisiana Gov. Edwin Edwards that came when DeBartolo was trying to get a riverboat casino license. The NFL fined him $1 million for his involvement in the scandal and suspended him from running the 49ers for one year. Today, "Mr. D" owns a stake in the Famous Famiglia pizza chain and DeBartolo Sports & Entertainment. He also co-founded a charter school in Tampa Bay with former Buccaneers linebacker Derrick Brooks.

name: Billionaires
bio: A hedge fund purist, "Izzy" doesn't charge a management fee. Because his funds are legally structured as true partnerships, Englander only earns fees in years in which he produces positive returns. 2011 was one of those years. Millennium International and Millennium USA returned 8.45% and 8.67% respectively net of fees. The $14.75 billion firm has produced annualized net returns of 15% since 1990, suffering its sole down year in 2008. Millennium is said to be preparing to enter the South Korean market by way of establishing an office in the country. A Brooklyn native, Englander founded Millennium Partners in 1990. He has a B.S. in finance from NYU. His sister was married to famed investor Jack Nash (d. 2008).
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: These days, about as much of Gap co-founder Doris Fisher's wealth is held in shares in the clothing company as it is in her vast contemporary art collection. The 80-year-old widow owns some 1,100 works by 185 artists including Andy Warhol and Claes Oldenburg. A Stanford graduate, Fisher and her late husband Don, who died in 2009, founded the Gap in 1969 when he couldn't find jeans that fit. Now the chain operates more than 3,200 stores, including Old Navy, Banana Republic and newer brands Piperlime and Athleta. Two of Doris' sons, Robert and William, sit on Gap's board of directors; the youngest, John, is not as involved.
title: Cofounder

name: Billionaires
bio: Mining mogul Robert Friedland finally lost control of his company Ivanhoe Mines to mining group Rio Tinto, which achieved 51% ownership after a long battle. Reports say Friedland's other mining company, Ivanplats Ltd., may seek as much as $1 billion in an initial public offering in 2012. The Chicago native attended Reed College in Oregon and studied Sanskrit and Buddhism in India after graduating. Friedland made his first fortune stumbling on large nickel deposit at Voisey's Bay in Canada. He sold the nickel-rich property to Inco for $3.1 billion in 1996. He sold Ivanhoe Energy's U.S. oil and gas operations to Seneca Resources Corporation for $40 million in July 2009.
title: Founder and Executive Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Ivanhoe Mines', 'uri': 'companies/ivanhoe-mines', 'title': 'Founder and Executive Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Phillip Frost made his fortune selling drug manufacturer Ivax to Israel-based Teva Pharmaceuticals for $7.6 billion in 2005. He was elected chairman of Teva in 2010, and it remains his most valuable holding, despite a stock drop over the past year. The company paid $1 billion in July for Japanese generic drug outfit Taiyo. A former dermatalogy professor, he got his start in pharma in 1972, when he took over Key Pharmaceuticals with partner Michael Jaharis, to develop generic pharmaceuticals and veterinary products. They sold out to Schering-Plough in 1986 and founded Ivax. Today he has stakes in more than a half dozen firms, including medical device company SafeStitch. Frost pocketed more than $160 million this year when one of his investments, medical services outfit Continucare, was sold to competitor Metropolitan Health Networks. Frost signed the Gates-Buffett Giving Pledge in April, agreeing to give away at least half his fortune.

name: Billionaires
bio: The grandson of publishing magnate William Randolph Hearst has seen his fortune increase by $500 million since the 2011 Billionaire's list, thanks both to the ad industry's continued rebound and the success of cable networks his family part-owns. The Hearsts have stakes in Lifetime, A&E and ESPN, the latter being the most lucrative: the family's share in the sports channel and all its offshoots is worth over $6 billion. The Hearst empire includes newspapers, magazines, TV, radio and internet holdings. Last May, the company's publishing arm signed a deal with Apple so readers can now buy iPad magazine subscriptions through iTunes. The Hearst brand continues to expand internationally. It launched Esquire in the Philippines and Harper's Bazaar in Brazil in the fall of 2011 and expanded ELLE China to semi-monthly in February. The family owns significant real estate, much of it in California, including Hearst Castle in San Simeon. Harvard grad William Randolph Hearst III is an affiliated partner in Silicon Valley venture firm Kleiner, Perkins Caufield & Byers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daniela Herz inherited a fortune from his father, coffee magnate Max Herz, along with his mother Ingeburg and her brothers Gunter, Joachim, Michael and Wolfgang. A nasty family feud led Herz and her brother Gunter to sell their combined 40% stake in the German consumer goods group to their mother and three brothers for an estimated $5 billion in 2003. Now, she and her brother own private equity firm Mayfair GmbH, which in 2011 acquired 40% of the Vapiano Group, a restaurant chain with operations in more than 70 locations in Europe, the US and the Middle East.

name: Billionaires
bio: It's been just over a year since serial entrepreneur Wayne Huizenga listed his latest venture, industrial cleaning firm Swisher Hygiene, on NASDAQ after a reverse merger. He and longtime business partner Steve Berrard continue to acquire other companies aggressively as they look to build Swisher into a dominant force in the industry. Recent buys include chemical firm Specialty Products and laundry outfit Country Linens. This isn't Huizenga's first stint in sanitation. He started out with one trash truck, and built haulage giant Waste Management. After retiring from WMX in 1984, he switched industries, investing in Blockbuster Video. He sold the movie rental outfit to Viacom for $8.4 billion in 1994. Huizenga owned the Miami Dolphins for 15 years before selling the team to real estate billionaire Stephen Ross for $1.1 billion in 2009; he still owns a 5% stake in the team and has a Dolphins helmet painted on the tail of his Boeing 737 business jet. His other investments include a golf course and vineyard property in Tennessee.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vyacheslav Kantor heads Acron, the country's third-largest fertilizer producer. Last year Acron, a minor shareholder of Silvinit, attempted unsuccessfully to block the biggest fertilizer deal of the year--Silvinit's merger with Uralkali. Kantor, son of a Moscow department store director, graduated from the Moscow Aviation Institute and set up a computer trading firm in late 1980s. Later he became friendly with the governor of Novgorod, Mikhail Prusak, and through privatization bought local fertilizer producer Azot. He renamed it Acron and made it the basis for his chemicals empire, which is now publicly traded. Kantor is a passionate collector of paintings by Russian artists of Jewish origin; he also chairs the European Jewish Congress. He spends most of his time at his mansion in Geneva.

name: Billionaires
bio: Along with business partner Gary Burrell, Min Kao founded Garmin in 1989 to produce navigational tools for pilots and sailors. In 1998 the company branched out into consumer devices for directionally challenged drivers; it went public two years later. Min Kao is now chairman and CEO. Born in Taiwan, he earned a Ph.D. in electrical engineering from the University of Tennessee. He donated $12.5 million to the school for the $37.5 million Min H. Kao Electrical Engineering and Computer Science building, which opened in January. Also in January, he paid $40 million for a 41st-floor condo at 15 Central Park West.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Garmin Corporation', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Kellogg's father, James Kellogg, founded the specialist brokerage firm that became Spear, Leeds & Kellogg in 1931. A native of New Jersey, Peter Kellogg took over the firm in 1973, turning it into a dominant market maker. The firm was the first specialist to control more than 10% of stocks trading on the Big Board. Kellogg engineered a sale to Goldman Sachs for $6.5 billion in 2000. He plowed the proceeds into reinsurance company IAT, whose subsidiaries focus on contractors, truckers and commercial property. A supporter of the U.S. Ski Team, he funds a school in Vail for aspiring ski racers, and also gave $3.8 million to his alma mater the Berkshire School in Sheffield, Mass. last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Li Shuirong chairs Rongsheng Petro Chemical, one of the largest non-government controlled petrochemical companies on the mainland. The company, based in a mecca of entrepreneurism in China's Zhejiang Province, has profited from growing demand for consumer goods in China, as well as the country's rise as an industrial powerhouse. The company said in January it expected net profit for 2011 to grow a slower-than-expected 5%-10% from $244 million in 2010, owing to slower global economic growth and falling commodity prices.  Li's main holding company, Zhejiang Rongsheng Holding Group, also owns 30% of the Shanghai-listed diversified firm Ningbo United Group and 16% of Shenzhen-listed chemicals maker Yibin Tianyuan Group. It also indirectly owns 1.1% of Zhejiang Daoming Optics & Chemical, which went public on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange last November. The company produces reflective film, fabric, vests and other reflective products. Li is vice chairman of the China Chemical Fibers Association

name: Billionaires
bio: Granddaughter of Campbell Soup founder and condensed soup inventor John T. Dorrance, Mary Alice Dorrance Malone sits on the company's board with her billionaire brother Bennett Dorrance. Campbell, the world's largest soup company, with $7.7 billion in revenues, owns other familiar brands such as Pace (salsa), V8 (vegetable juice), Pepperidge Farm (cookies, Goldfish), and Swanson (broth). Malone breeds horses on her Iron Spring Farm in Pennsylvania. A former employee plead guilty to extortion charges in Philadelphia federal court in May 2011 after demanding $250,000 a year to keep quiet about the heiress' life.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sergio Mantegazza's father Antonio founded tour outfit Globus in 1928 with a single boat that ferried tourists around Lake Lugano in Switzerland. Mantegazza now controls the family's tour and travel empire. The bulk of his wealth is tied up in low-risk bonds. His Monarch Airlines is suffering from a downturn in travel and high oil prices. After the airline reported another loss last year, Mantegazza had to inject $115 million. The airline is not expected to regain profitability until 2013.

name: Billionaires
bio: Home Depot co-founder Bernie Marcus has been actively denouncing what he calls "imbecile" Occupy Wall Street protesters. He recently helped launch the Job Creators Alliance, a Dallas-based nonprofit of CEOs and entrepreneurs with the mission to "defend and preserve the system of free enterprise in the United States." Back in 1978, Marcus started the world's largest home improvement retailer with Arthur Blank (now a fellow billionaire), then took it public in 1981. Marcus had worked as a cabinet-maker at his father's shop. He retired in 2001 to focus on philanthropy. Marcus donated $250 million to open the Georgia Aquarium, the world's largest, with more than 8 million gallons of water in its exhibits. He also started the Marcus Autism Center in Atlanta in 2008.
title: Co-founder, ex chairman of the board
employment: {'name': 'Home Depot', 'uri': 'companies/home-depot', 'title': 'Co-founder, ex chairman of the board', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Still best known as the 'Junk Bond King' Milken made his billions in leveraged buyouts in the 1980's, only to be sent to prison in 1989. He pleaded guilty to securities fraud after the government agreed to drop criminal charges against his younger brother, Lowell, and then served 22 months. The one-time Drexel Burnham Lambert executive has charted an entirely different course ever since. He invests in education companies, including interactive toy firm LeapFrog and school software outfit K12. He's an avid philanthropist, with a particular interest in cancer charities; he survived prostate cancer and is in remission. He and wife Lori joined the Gates-Buffett Giving Pledge in December 2010, writing in their accompanying letter: "Philanthropy is far more than just writing checks. It takes an entrepreneurial approach that seeks out best practices and empowers people to change the world."

name: Billionaires
bio: Television tycoon A. Jerrold Perenchio, known as Jerry, made the bulk of his fortune selling Spanish-language broadcaster Univision for $13.7 billion in 2007 to a group of investors led by fellow Los Angeles billionaire Haim Saban. Perenchio is one of the largest private landowners in Malibu. A onetime talent agent, he represented Marlon Brando and Elizabeth Taylor. Perenchio formed Embassy Communications with "All in the Family" producer Norman Lear, then sold it to Coca-Cola for $485 million in 1985. He plowed the proceeds into TV; with partners, he bought Univision from Hallmark for $550 million in 1992. Perenchio is a longtime Republican donor. Through the Chartwell Charitable Foundation, he and his wife, Margie, support education and the arts in Perenchio's hometown of Fresno, California. The foundation has made grants of $100 million since 2005. Most recently, he contributed $2 million to American Crossroads, a super PAC advised by Karl Rove.
title: Founder & Owner

name: Billionaires
bio: Rainwater, the legendary Fort Worth dealmaker, a friend and mentor to tycoons like Eddie Lampert, David Bonderman, Ken Hersh and the Bass brothers, is now mentally incapacitated, struggling with progressive supranuclear palsy. Often mistaken for Parkinson's disease, it strikes just six people in 100,000. Seeking a cure, Rainwater's family has organized a genius-filled group of researchers dubbed the Tau Consortium, to share ideas on cures. Any advance is unlikely to help Rainwater, but could lead to future breakthroughs in treating dementia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Candy maker Hans Riegel is credited with inventing more than 200 sweets, including Gummi Bears, Vademecum sugar-free gum and Maoam fruit chewies. He has said he gets his inspiration from reading comic books and watching movies for children. Makes these candies for the ultra tight-lipped, family-owned Haribo candy company, which does not even disclose its revenues --  estimated at $2.5 billion in 2010. He and his brother Paul rebuilt the company after World War II and ran it together until Paul's death in 2009. Hans, who is single and has no children, owns 50% of the company, still runs it and is in charge of marketing; nephew Hans Guido Riegel heads production and technical questions. Two other nephews, Hans Juergen Riegel and Hans Arndt Riegel, also sit on the supervisory board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Secretive brothers Michael and Rainer Schmidt-Ruthenbeck together own nearly 16% of retailer Metro, which was co-founded in 1964 by a partnership between the Schmidt-Ruthenbeck family, the Haniel family and billionaire Otto Beisheim. Shares have fallen nearly 50% within the last 12 months due to a company-issued profit warning and the surprising departure of CEO Eckhard Cordes at the end of 2011. As a result, the brothers' fortune is $2 billion lower than Forbes? valuation last year. The Schmidt-Ruthenbeck brothers also own Travel Charm, a chain of luxury hotels and spas in Germany, Austria and Italy. Together they fund the Mercator Foundation, which supports projects in three different thematic clusters: integration, climate change and arts education. The foundation has a current endowment of $145 million. Since its formation in 1996, the foundation has financed nearly 600 projects with more than $200 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sarik Tara is the founder of Turkey's largest construction company, ENKA; his son Mehmet Tara, also a billionaire, runs the company. ENKA is active in Turkey and Russia where it owns 10 shopping centers, 9 in Moscow and 1 in St. Petersburg. The holding is also Turkey's largest private electricity producer. Sarik emigrated from Macedonia to Turkey in 1942 during the Second World War when he was only 13. After graduating as a civil engineer he founded ENKA in 1957.

name: Billionaires
bio: Andreas (Andy) von Bechtolsheim is a tech visionary and early backer of Google: His initial $100,000 investment is now worth nearly $2 billion. A co-founder of Sun Microsystems, he left in 1995 to found a network switching startup, Granite Systems. That company was bought by Cisco. After leaving Cisco and founding another startup, Kealia, he returned to Sun in 2004 after it bought Kealia in 2004. Most recently, he founded Arista Networks, another switching company, with Canadian billionaire and friend David Cheriton. Bechtolsheim is Arista's chairman and chief development officer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oil pipeline magnate Kelcy Warren and his Energy Transfer Equity beat out the Williams Companies for a merger with George Lindemann's Southern Union pipeline company in December 2011, after months of bidding. When he's not building his natural gas empire, the music fan prints albums for singer-songwriters at his Austin-based studio, Music Road Records. Warren built up his pipeline network in the wake of Enron's collapse; it is currently the largest in Texas. He bought a 3,500-acre Colorado ranch for $46.5 million in April 2010, and donated $250,000 to support Texas Governor Rick Perry's failed presidential bid.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wei Jianjun is chairman of Great Wall Auto, one of China's largest non-government-controlled automobile makers. Even as growth in China's domestic auto industry slowed last year, Great Wall's sales increased by 49% in the first half of 2011 from a year earlier to $2.2 billion, helped by exports, which accounted for 13% of its business. The company, whose primary stock listing is at the Hong Kong Stock Exchange, issued A-shares and obtained a secondary listing in China last year. In February 2012, Great Wall forged a "strategic cooperation agreement" with South Korea's Pohang Iron and Steel that includes research work. Wei graduated from the Committee College of Hebei Province branch of the Communist Party, specializing in corporate management. He worked in carpet and a water-pump factories before joining Great Wall.

name: Billionaires
bio: Aloys Wobben founded wind turbine manufacturer Enercon in 1983 and reportedly built its first wind turbine in his backyard. A trained engineer, he probably got his inspiration close to home?he grew up in windy northern Germany. In 1992, Enercon began producing non-polluting models without gears or hydraulics. The company has over 18,000 wind turbines installed in more than 30 countries. Analysts say that the wind turbine sector is stagnating and that growth is in the single digit range. Turbine makers led by Vestas and competitor General Electric Co. are suffering from slower demand growth and narrowing margins as Chinese companies including Xinjiang Goldwind Science & Technology Co. grab market share.

name: Billionaires
bio: Despite weak advertising and tepid circulation for Zuckerman's U.S. News and World Report and New York Daily News, the owner remains optimistic about media. U.S. News and World Report moved to a web-only publication in January 2011. The New York Daily News scooped up Colin Myler, former editor of Rupert Murdoch's shuttered News of the World, in early 2012. The son of a Montreal tobacco and candy seller, Zuckerman co-founded Boston Properties and took it public in 1997. He has donated hundreds of millions of dollars to cancer research, and his charitable foundation was ripped off by Bernie Madoff. Zuckerman has filed a suit against money manager J. Ezra Merkin over his Madoff losses.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Boston Properties', 'uri': 'companies/boston-properties', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Mohammed Al Issa is one of the largest individual investors in the Saudi stock market. His holdings include major stakes in Savola Group, one the Kingdom's largest food processors; Saudi Hotels & Resort Areas, and Banque Saudi Fransi. The bank announced last November that it will sell its stake in a Syria-based bank, because of instability in the country.

name: Billionaires
bio: Abdullah Al Rajhi, with his brothers Sulaiman, Mohammed, and the late Saleh, formed Al Rajhi Bank, one of the largest Islamic banks in the world with $49 billion in assets. He also holds a stake in Islamic bank powerhouse Al Baraka Banking Group, founded by fellow billionaire Saleh Kamel. Other investments include stakes in cement and agriculture companies. Brothers Sulaiman and Mohammed are also billionaires.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sir Anthony Bamford is chairman of J.C. Bamford Excavators (JCB), maker of construction, agricultural and demolition equipment. JCB is rebounding nicely from the recession, helping push Bamford and his family back into the ranks for the first time since 2002.  Founded by Sir Anthony's father in 1945, JCB is now owned by him and his brother Mark. The brothers have been fighting in court over ownership of JCB research, a company within the larger JCB. Sir Anthony's wife Carole started Daylesford Organics to sell organic food from the family's estate in Gloucestershire. She has expanded to include shops in London, a cookery school, a clothing line and a spa. He owns two U.K. estates as well as a home in Barbados, a vineyard in France and a vintage car collection.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chen Jianhua is the chairman of Hengli Group, one of China's largest chemical fiber manufacturers. Its end customers include Nike, Adidas and Toyota.  Sales last year rose to $8.2 billion from $5 billion a year earlier. Chen was born in 1971 in the Jiangsu Province city of Wujiang known as the "capital of silk," and his business is headquartered there today. Wife Fan Hongwei is a cofounder and general manager of its main subsidiary, Jiangsu Hengli Fiber, and director of Hengli Group. Hengli also owns the Tongli Lake Resort, located in Jiangsu.

name: Billionaires
bio: Originally a landscape architect, Jack Dangermond founded Environmental Systems Research Institute in 1969 with $1,100 of family savings. Today, ESRI is the world's largest mapping software company, providing software to 350,000 customers, including federal agencies and health departments across the country. Dangermond studied environmental science at Cal Poly Pomona, urban planning at the University of Minnesota, and landscape architecture at the Harvard Laboratory for Computer Graphics and Spatial Analysis. In February 2011, the Secretary of the Interior appointed him to the National Geospatial Advisory Committee (NGAC), which provides recommendations on federal geospatial policy. Dangermond and his wife also recently endowed geography chair at the University of California at Santa Barbara.

name: Billionaires
bio: Edson de Godoy Bueno, a doctor-turned-billionaire entrepreneur, presides over publicly-traded Amil Participacoes S.A., the largest health care company in Brazil. It provides health insurance and medical care to more than 5 million people. His net worth is $200 million higher than in March 2011 due in part to a rise in the value of Amil Participacoes' stock. He decided to become a doctor at age 14, studied for a medical degree at Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro while working at a struggling clinic, which he bought before graduating in 1971. He acquired other clinics soon after, and co-founded Amil Assistencia Medica in 1978. In August 2010 he negotiated the merger of MD1, his diagnostic company, with Dasa, the largest chain of laboratories in Latin America. His ex-wife, Dulce Pugliese de Godoy Bueno, is also a billionaire due to her stakes in Amil and Dasa.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brazilian philanthropist and socialite Maria de Lourdes Egydio Villela, known as Milu, is a member of one of Brazil's oldest banking families. In 2008 her family's Banco Itau merged with Unibanco to form Itau Unibanco, Brazil's second biggest bank. She is the vice chairwoman of the board of Itausa Investments, a unit of the giant bank, and is one of the bank's largest individual shareholders. She is also president of Sao Paulo's Museum of Modern Art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bond investor Bill Gross controls the world's largest mutual fund, Pimco's Total Return. After a bad bet against US Treasuries last year, Gross is backtracking. 2011 was reportedly the first calendar year of net outflow from the Total Return fund since its inception in 1987. January marked the fourth month in a row that Gross has continued to pick up Treasury securities. The Bond King got his start when he spent four months in Las Vegas playing blackjack after college and turned $200 into $10,000. He became an investment superstar after discovering that the key to profits was to trade bonds, not buy and hold. He managed a $10 million portfolio for Pacific Life in the 1970s, then spun off its fixed-income division and took it public in 1994. In 1999 he sold 70% to Allianz AG for $3.3 billion. An active philatelist, Gross has donated much of his stamp collection to Doctors Without Borders. He recently gave $10 million to establish a 12,000-square-foot gallery at the Smithsonian's National Postal Museum in Washington, D.C., which will be called the William H. Gross Stamp Gallery. It is expected to open in 2013.
title: Cofounder and Co-Chief Investment Officer
employment: {'name': 'Pacific Investment Management Company LLC', 'title': 'Cofounder and Co-Chief Investment Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: A former elite jet pilot in the navy?an Indonesian "top gun," which included training in the Royal Netherlands Air Force pilot program in Europe, he rose to become the youngest colonel in the Indonesian military. He later took early retirement. With little savings, he started a tutoring business, giving private math lessons to students at home. "Met", as he is known, won the Caterpillar dealership in Indonesia and started trading the construction equipment in 1971. He handed reins over to his son after he lost his sight to a glaucoma attack in 1999.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of steel tycoon J.H. Hillman, Jr., owner of Pittsburgh Coke & Chemical, Henry Hillman diversified the family fortune via The Hillman Co., investing in real estate, private equity and venture capital. He was an early backer of influential Silicon Valley venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers and LBO titans Kohlberg Kravis Roberts. He's the co-owner of downtown Pittsburgh's PPG Place.
