Hilllman is a philanthropist dedicated to the Pittsburgh region, with gifts to Carnegie Mellon University and the Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh. Late last year, Hillman's foundation donated $3 million to Rider University's Westminster Choir to build a new performance hall.

name: Billionaires
bio: Eduardo Hochschild leads the mining and cement-focused Hochschild Group, which was founded by his great uncle in 1911. He chairs both Hochschild Mining and Cementos Pacasmayo, which together comprise the Hochschild Group. During World War II, the Hochshild Group was a key supplier of tin and other metals to the Allied forces. Hochschild Mining is based in Lima, trades on the London Stock Exchange and operates gold and silver mines in Peru, Argentina and Mexico. Cementos Pacasmayo, one of Peru's largest publicly traded cement companies, listed its shares on the New York Stock Exchange in February. In 1998 during a period of political unrest in Peru, Hochschild survived an attack by gunman that claimed the life of his father. Hochschild was kidnapped by the attackers, but was released six days later.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Matriach Indu Jain chairs privately held media group Bennett, Coleman & Co., which her sons, Samir and Vineet, run. Portfolio includes daily newspaper The Times of India and business daily The Economic Times, which turned 50 last year. Among other interests are online arm Times Internet, TV channels Times Now, Zoom and ET Now; FM radio network Radio Mirchi. Group is reportedly mulling an IPO of flagship Bennett, Coleman.
title: Artist

name: Billionaires
bio: Suna Kirac holds a stake in the family industrial holding, Koc Holding, which she shares with fellow billionaires, her brother, Mustafa Rahmi Koc, sister, Arsel Semahat Sevim, and nephew, Mustafa Vehbi Koc. Since contracting ALS (Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis) also known as Lou Gehrig's disease in 2000, she can communicate only with her eyes. With her husband Inan Kirac she cofounded the Pera Museum in 2005 which focuses on Turkey's cultural history. The Istanbul Research Institute, supported by her Suna-Inan Kirac Foundation, also promotes these cultural studies. She is an Honorary Fellow of the London Business School.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kohler's grandfather founded the iconic toilet and faucet making firm in 1873, originally producing hitching posts, farm tools, and cemetery ornaments for Midwestern farmers. Today Kohler specializes in fashionable bathroom and kitchen fixtures, offering more than 150 different toilet designs. Herb controls the $4.6 billion (sales) empire with his sister, Ruth, after buying out 300 shareholders in 1998. Kohler's Whistling Straits golf course on Lake Michigan played host to the 2010 PGA championship and is slotted to hold the prestigious event again in 2015. Blackwolf Run, the company's other golf course, will host the U.S. Women's Open in 2012. The Yale graduate's real estate portfolio also includes the Old Course Hotel at St. Andrews in Scotland. Kohler breeds Morgan show horses.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Kohler Co.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: George Lindemann successfully navigated a bidding war in 2011 between Kelcy Warren's Energy Transfer Equity and Williams Companies. He eventually agreed to sell his gas pipeline company, Southern Union, to ETE in December, after its stock went up 75%. The native New Yorker sold his family eye care company, Permalens, in 1971, and founded Vision Cable in 1972, which he sold to the Newhouse brothers for $220 million a decade later. Next he started cell phone firm Metro Mobile, flipping it to Bell Atlantic for $2.5 billion in 1991 before getting into the energy game.

name: Billionaires
bio: The father of natural gas shale drilling, George Mitchell was the first to use horizontal drilling and hydraulic fracking to crack open the Barnett shale field in Texas. He opened the door to development of shales worldwide. Mitchell sold his company to Devon Energy, where he remains the biggest shareholder. He has completed renovations of his beloved hotel, Galvez, damaged when Hurricane Ike slammed Galveston in 2008. Mitchell's son Todd is carrying the flame; he is a big shareholder in private Alta Resources, which has sold $800 million in shale acreage in recent years and now has a $1 billion drilling venture with Blackrock.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of pharmacy professor, Pankaj Patel owns 75% of generics maker Cadila Healthcare co-founded by his late father in 1952. He took charge after pharma empire split in 1995 and built Cadila into $1 billion (revenues) firm. Company forged marketing joint venture with Bayer Healthcare for the Indian market. In bid to expand overseas, it bought a German animal health care unit and a generics business in the U.S. Portfolio includes vaccines, including India's first for H1N1 and Sugar Free, country's largest selling sweetener.

name: Billionaires
bio: Thomas Pritzker, chairman of Hyatt Hotels, is one of 11 members of the extended Pritzker family on the Billionaires' list. Along with his sister Jean (Gigi) Pritzker, he has picked up more stock in Hyatt from cousins Linda and James, who sold shares last year. For the past decade, Tom and his cousin Penny Pritzker have been in charge of selling assets the family owns jointly. Back in 2007, the family sold control of industrial conglomerate Marmon Holdings to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway for $4.7 billion. Tom's grandfather A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), with his sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert (d. 2011), created Marmon and the Hyatt hotel chain. Tom remains chairman of Marmon Holdings and sits on the board at Royal Caribbean Cruises. He's a trustee at the University of Chicago and chairman of the Art Institute of Chicago.
title: Executive Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: In 2011, vulture investor Wilbur Ross made big bets on the Diamond S Shipping company and the faltering Bank of Ireland. He also added to his holdings in oil and gas company Exco Resources Inc. In 2010 he paid $154 million for a substantial minority stake in Richard Branson's consumer-credit business Virgin Money, then helped fund a Virgin Money acquisition of British bank Northern Rock. After Yale undergrad and Harvard Business School, Ross joined Rothschild in 1976. He made his initial fortune buying and restructuring failed companies in steel, coal, textiles and car parts. Head of the prestigious Japan Society on Manhattan's Upper East Side.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alexandra Schorghuber (also spelled Schoerghuber) is the widow of Stefan Schorghuber, who died unexpectedly in November 2008 at age 47.  She has taken her husband's position at Schoerghuber Unternehmensgruppe, which oversees breweries, real estate, construction, and a host of tourist amenities. The group owns one of Germany's largest real estate companies, Bayerische Bau und Immobilien GmbH. The family is well-known in Munich for its support of modern art and subsidized holidays for underprivileged children and their families.

name: Billionaires
bio: T.Y. Tsai's sale of his stake in Cathay Financial Holding to his brothers Hong-tu and Cheng-da  in 2010, though it was never officially confirmed, split what was one of the country's most successful families. T.Y. has benefitted from the move, isolating himself from a quarter drop in the company's shares in the past year amid slowing economic growth in Taiwan.  Hong-tu, the company's chairman, and brother Cheng-da meanwhile have dropped from the billionaire ranks this year.  T.Y. collects cars and art, including at least one Monet. He's developing luxury property in Taipei with fellow tycoon Lin Ming Hsiung.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wang Yusuo is chairman of the ENN Group, which has interests in energy.  Wang's wealth has increased in the past year amid an overall rise in global energy demand despite relatively tepid economic growth. His Hong Kong-listed flagship gas distributor ENN Energy Holdings, in which Wang and his wife Zhao Baoju own a 31% stake, reported a 43% jump in sales during the first half of 2011. In the first six months of the year, the company launched new piped gas projects in Hunan, Jiangsu, Fujian, Hebei, Yunnan, Liaoning, Jiangsu and Guangxi Provinces. To fund expansion, it raised $750 million through a bond sale last May. In a statement in February, Shanghai-listed Hebei Veyong Bio-Chemical said it planned to buy majority Wang-owned Xinneng Kuangye in a stock deal. Veyong valued Xinneng Kuanye at 7.2 billion yuan, or $1.1 billion. Wang's wife is a non-executive director at ENN Energy, and holds a degree from the Hebei Medical College Professional Nursing School.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heir to bubble gum maker Wrigley, he finalized the $23 billion sale of his family's gum operation to privately held candy giant Mars in 2008, making the combined company the largest confectioner in the world. In September, Wrigley sold its iconic headquarters in downtown Chicago to a consortium that includes the owners of Groupon. Wrigley Jr. stayed on after the acquisition by Mars, but left in January 2011 to pursue philanthropic interests. Wrigley Co. was founded in 1891 by his great-grandfather (d. 1932), who moved from Philadelphia to Chicago to sell soap, and then baking powder. The company introduced the first spearmint chewables in 1893; in 1915 it sent four sticks of gum to every person in the U.S. with a listed phone number. The fourth-generation Wrigley took over in 1999.
title: Director

name: Billionaires
bio: Ali Ibrahim Agaoglu is the president of the Agaoglu Group which is involved in real estate and tourism construction projects. Currently, the group is building 10,000 housing units in Istanbul; plans underway to expand to London's Canary Wharf with a hotel and two residential towers.The luxury car afficianado owns 3 Bentleys, 2 Lamborghinis, 2 Rolls-Royce, a Ferrari, Porsche, Maserati and an electrical Tesla.

name: Billionaires
bio: With his brothers, Lee Bass controls one of the country's largest privately held oil outfits, Bass Enterprises Production. Father Perry's uncle Sid Richardson was an oil baron who left a piece of his fortune to the Basses in 1959. They made the most of it, in part by putting capital in the hands of legendary investor Richard Rainwater. The brothers sold one division to Southern Union for $1.6 billion in 2005. Lee and brother Sid continue their legal fight with Credit Suisse over $500 million the bank lent them in 2004 against their real estate development, Lake Las Vegas. The brothers and another owner distributed the cash to themselves. Then, pushed over the brink by the housing bust, Lake Las Vegas went bust and defaulted. The bank wants its money back. In their countersuit, the Basses accuse Credit Suisse of predatory lending.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sid Bass and wife Mercedes shocked New York society last October with the revelation that after 25 years of marriage they were getting divorced. Sid reportedly didn't want to go to the opera anymore, preferring to spend his time back in Fort Worth, painting pictures. There is no word yet on how much Mercedes will get in the split (and no evidence we can find that divorce papers have even been filed in New York or Texas). Sid and brother Lee continue their legal fight with Credit Suisse over $500 million the bank lent them in 2004 against their real estate development, Lake Las Vegas. The brothers and another owner distributed the cash to themselves. Then, pushed over the brink by the housing bust, Lake Las Vegas went bust and defaulted. The bank wants its money back. In their countersuit, the Basses accuse Credit Suisse of predatory lending.

name: Billionaires
bio: After stints at BP and Trafigura, Alex Beard joined mining and commodities trading giant Glencore in 1995, where he was named director of the oil commodity department in 2007. Based in London, Beard is the highest-ranking Glencore executive in the U.K., responsible for the company's worldwide oil operations. A graduate of Oxford University with a degree in Biochemistry, Beard joined the billionaires club when Glencore listed on the London exchange in May 2011. Despite its shares losing nearly 20% of their value since their public debut, the future is bright for Glencore. The firm announced plans to merge with mining outfit Xstrata in February 2012. The proposed all-stock "merger of equals" would spawn a $90 billion mining and marketing behemoth.

name: Billionaires
bio: The deputy chair of Edizione SRL founded the Benetton Group with his siblings Luciano, Giuliana and Gilberto in 1965. Today Benetton is a $2.9 billion (sales) clothing company, which sells brands like United Colors of Benetton and Sisley. Carlo holds the title of Deputy Chairman with the group and deals with the company's production projects analysis and technological processes, as well as new industrial developments in the textile and clothing sectors.The family also owns a big stake in Atlantia, one of the world's largest toll-road companies; this asset is now worth more than the clothing company. In early February the Benettons announced plans to take the company private via their Edizione SA holding company, offering $363 million to purchase the 33% of the company they do not currently own.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gilberto Benetton has been the chairman of the popular Autogrill restaurants, which serve customers on highways and in airports, since 1995. He is also chairman of Benetton family investment company Edizione Holding and a director of Mediobanca, Atlantia and Pirelli. Together with his siblings Carlo, Giuliana and Luciano, Gilberto formed the Benetton Group clothing company in 1965. In 2010 the company did $2.9 billion in sales of brands like the United Colors of Benetton and Sisley. The clothing maker's stock is is down as retail sales suffered in Italy's weak economy.  In early February the Benettons announced plans to take the clothing company private via their Edizione SA holding company, offering $363 million to purchase the 33% of the company they do not currently own. The family's most valuable asset is a big chunk of Atlantia, one of the world's largest toll-road companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Giuliana Benetton originally knitted sweaters that her brother Luciano would peddle by bicycle; they were sold under a variety of labels before becoming United Colors of Benetton. She founded the Benetton Group with siblings Luciano, Carlo and Gilberto in 1965. In 2010 the Benetton company did $2.9 billion in sales, with brands like United Colors of Benetton and Sisley. The clothing maker's stock is is down as retail sales suffered in Italy's weak economy. The cost of commodities and small exposure to the red hot Asian markets also hurt Benetton's growth forecasts. Giuliana is a regular on lists of the wealthiest self-made women. In early February the Benettons announced plans to take the company private via their Edizione SA holding company, offering $363 million to purchase the 33% they do not currently own.

name: Billionaires
bio: Together with his siblings Carlo, Giuliana and Gilberto, Luciano Benetton formed Benetton Group in 1965. After running it for 40 years, he is now chairman of the $2.9 billion (revenues) clothing company, which sells brands including United Colors of Benetton and Sisley. The stock is down since last year as retail sales suffered in a weak economy. In early February the Benettons announced plans to take the company private via their Edizione SA holding company, offering $363 million to purchase the 33% they do not currently own. At press time there was no definitive decision about what would happen with the company. The family's most valuable asset is a large chunk of Atlantia, one of the world's largest toll-road companies. It also owns a share of Autogrill restaurants, which serve customers on highways and in airports around the world; those stocks are up since February 2011.
title: Entrepreneur

name: Billionaires
bio: Bernard Broermann founded his first hospital in 1984 and named it Asklepios after the Greek God of medicine. Through the Asklepios Group, he now owns about 100 hospitals worldwide with 42,000 employees and locations in Germany, Greece, Portugal, the U.S., China and Saudi Arabia. Broermann practiced as an accountant and lawyer before founding the hospital chain and has an M.B.A. from Harvard University. He owns the Kempinski Hotel Falkenstein in Koenigstein, a five-star luxury spa and hotel in the Taunus mountains near Frankfurt.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chey Tae-Won is the chairman of SK Group, South Korea's third-largest conglomerate by assets with 90 affiliates in energy, telecom, and chemicals, among others. His wife is the daughter of South Korea's former president, Roh Tae Woo. In January, he was reportedly indicted on charges of embezzling more than $40 million from SK companies to cover trading losses; Chey Tae-Won denies any wrongdoing. In February, subsidiary SK Telecom acquired a 21% stake in Hynix, a memory chip manufacturer. A sports enthusiast, Chey heads the Korea Handball Federation, and owns the SK Wyverns baseball team.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chu Lam Yiu is chairman of Hong Kong-listed Huabao International, a flavoring and fragrance producer. Once-routine double-digit sales and profit growth at the company has moderated, leaving its share price little changed.  China's tobacco industry -- a big Huabao consumer ? enjoyed production growth of only 3.9% in the first half of 2011, limited Huabao's prospects.   Growth has come in part from last April's acquisition of Yongzhou Shanxiang, a supplier of litsea cubeba, a natural aromatic raw material. Overall, Huabao's sales increased by 6.4% in the first six months of 2011 to $171 million. Chu is one of the youngest self-made female billionaires in the world.

name: Billionaires
bio: The global economic undertow snared Richard Elman's Singapore-listed Noble Group, one of the world's largest trading companies. Shares fell more than 30% over the past year in part due to a cut in its credit rating by Moody's, which was concerned by Noble's debt level. That sliced $700 million off Elman's net worth since March 2011. The U.K.-born Elman came back from retirement to take over as acting CEO in November. He had stepped down in September 2010. Prior to setting up Noble in 1986, Elman spent 10 years with commodities trading firm Phibro as regional director of its Asia business.

name: Billionaires
bio: A onetime Democratic candidate in Florida for the U.S. Senate, Jeff Greene was the only member of our list of wealthiest Americans willing to visit Occupy Wall Street with us last year, riding his bike downtown to listen to protesters. Greene became a billionaire by buying credit default swaps on subprime mortgage-backed bonds as housing crashed. He now has about half his fortune in investments and the rest in real estate, including 3,500 Los Angeles apartments. He has settled in Palm Beach with his wife and two young children, having paid $24 million for a historic mansion dubbed La Bellucia in late 2009 and more recently paying $42 million for the Omphoy Hotel in Palm Beach. He also paid $26 million for a building in New York City's Soho neighborhood and $37 million for a house in the Hamptons where he plans to spend summers. Greene put himself through Johns Hopkins U. working as a busboy at the Breakers Hotel in Palm Beach, teaching Hebrew School part-time and checking IDs outside a gym. He also traveled the country selling circus tickets in later years; he put himself through Harvard business school.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former chemistry professor Deshbandhu Gupta controls pharma outfit, Lupin which he founded in 1968. It derives over two-thirds of its $1.3 billion sales from international markets, the biggest of which is the U.S., where it claims to be among the top 5 generic firms in terms of prescriptions. Drugmaker is  targeting Japan where it has acquired two pharma firms. Last year, It forged an alliance with Eli Lilly to sell its insulin in India and Nepal.

name: Billionaires
bio: With fellow billionaire Sze man Bok, Hui Lin Chit cofounded Hengan International in 1985. The company is one of China's largest makers of sanitary napkins and also makes tissues, diapers, bandages and snack products. Hui serves as CEO. Sales rose by 24% to over $1 billion in the first half of 2011 amid buoyant Chinese consumer spending; but higher prices for raw materials hurt profits, which declined by 2% to $155 million. Eyeing the company's strong brand and market share, investors have pushed Hengan's shares up by about a quarter in the past year.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Chief executive of Indus Gas, Ajay Kalsi has more than two-thirds stake in the London-listed oil-and-gas outfit. Also chairs Focus Energy, the Indian operating arm of Indus Gas that owns a hydrocarbon block in the western state of Rajasthan. Got his start in family's shoe business making sneakers for Reebok. Also founded iEnergizer, a business-process outsourcer. He's built an Olympic size wave pool at his farmhouse near Delhi for his daughter who is an avid swimmer. Splits his time between London and Delhi.

.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alicia Koplowitz and her older sister Esther inherited construction firm Fomento de Construcciones y Contratas from their late father. Their husbands ran the company from the early 1970s until 1989, when both marriages ended. The sisters took over and jointly ran the business until 1997, when Alicia sold her share to Esther, also a billionaire, for $800 million. Over the years, Alicia has invested the proceeds in such companies as steelmaker Acerinox, electric utility Iberdrola and Banco Sabadell; she also owns hotels in Spain, Italy, Portugal, and Miami. She has assets under management in Spain and England that total over $700 million; the value of a hedge fund in Ireland is not disclosed. Through her charitable foundation, she sends Spanish fellows to study child psychiatry in England and the U.S. at places like Columbia University's Medical Center. In 2009 she was named an honorary member of the Spanish Society of Psychiatrists for her efforts in promoting the study and development of child and juvenile psychology. She has been linked romantically with the Duque de Huescar, heir to the Spanish aristocratic house of Alba.

name: Billionaires
bio: Patrick Lee is the founder and chairman of Lee & Man Paper, one of Asia's largest paper producers. His company has been battling rising costs and weak demand. His fortune is down $300 million year on year but higher than just a couple of months ago. Sons Raymond and Man Bun run the business. Lee is the honorary principal of the Qionghai Jiaji Secondary School and Hainan Guoxing Secondary School in the mainland. He is an honorary citizen of Dongguan in Guangdong Province. Enjoys horse racing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alexander Mamut was trained as a lawyer but made his fortune in banking. Last spring he bought $50 million worth of shares of Russian Nomos bank when it debuted on the London market; he purchased a 3.5% stake in Uralkali from fellow billionaire Dmitry Rybolovlev. Also in 2011, Mamut purchased British bookshop chain Waterstone's (296 stores in Britain and Ireland), which was founded by his friend Tim Waterstone. In 2010 Mamut considered selling a portion of his 51% stake in mobile phone retail chain Evroset by taking the company public on the London stock exchange, but due to lack of investor interest an IPO was postponed. Mamut is still seeking a buyer. The Moscow State University graduate gained notoriety in the late 1990s during the Bank of New York money-laundering scandal, when he became known as "the Yeltsin family banker." (No charges were filed against him in connection with the case.) One of the founders of Imperial Bank, Mamut at one point ran MDM-Bank and was a major investor in Troika-Dialog investment bank and Ingosstrakh insurance company. In recent years he has preferred the role of portfolio investor, putting money into real estate, retail, telecom, construction and oil fields. Last year he increased his stake in home entertainment retailer HMV Group to 6%. In 2007 he bought U.S.-based blogging site LiveJournal.com, extremely popular among Russian users. Pet projects: the Strelka Institute for Media, a cultural and educational center, architecture and design, and art-house cinemas in central Moscow and Gorky Park.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ziyad Mansir's Stroygazconsulting has close ties with Russia's state-owned gas producer, Gazprom. He is building a compressed air plant, Portovaya, near the Baltic Sea for the Nord Stream pipeline; once complete it will be the biggest in Russia. The Jordanian-born businessman came to Russia as an exchange student and attended the Azerbaijan Oil and Chemistry Institute. While he was in school he began trading computers and cars, and later moved on to trading yellow phosphorus, timber and oil products. In the mid-1990s Manasir bought a construction factory in Tyumen and started building residences for Gazprom workers. Orders from the gas monopoly grew each year, and Manasir's Stroygazconsulting expanded into pipeline, road, and field facilities construction.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kerr Neilson founded boutique international equities firm Platinum Asset Management in 1993, with George Soros as a founding stakeholder. Neilson cashed out part of his stake in a well-timed 2007 IPO, but still owns 57% of Platinum and manages its flagship fund. Born in Johannesburg, he bought his first stock at age 13 and moved to Australia in 1983, where he earned guru status as a value-focused contrarian at BT Australia during the 1980s. Great calls included short-selling shares just before the 1987 global stock market crash and picking the top of the late 1980s Japanese bull market. His White Rabbit Gallery in Sydney, open to the public, displays his wife Judith's extensive collection of post-2000 Chinese art. He has set up the Neilson Foundation, which gifted the White Rabbit Gallery building to the nation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lirio Parisotto makes his debut on the Forbes billionaires' list after years of careful investing in a limited number of Brazilian stocks. The entrepreneur-turned-investor began putting profits from his video and audiotape production company Videolar into the market in 1988. Today his Geracao Futuro L Par fund, of which he owns 86%, is worth close to $1.4 billion. He buys and holds Brazilian stocks primarily in the banking, electricity, mining and steel sectors that pay good dividends and are well managed. His other assets include Brazilian bonds, the majority of Videolar (now a petrochemical company) and land in Sao Paulo state. He was born in southern Brazil but now makes his home in the city of Manaus in the Amazon. A firm believer in protecting the Amazon rain forest, he serves as vice president of the Foundation for a Sustainable Amazon.

name: Billionaires
bio: Facebook's first president is looking to disrupt the Web once again with Airtime, the social video site he plans to launch with his Napster co-founder, Shawn Fanning, by the end of 2012. He's also looking to fix the very music industry he helped break with Napster in 1999 as investor and board member of Swedish music platform, Spotify. The former hacker will likely see his fortune surge even higher after Facebook goes public this spring.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hailing from Mumbai real estate clan, Rajan Raheja gets more than half his fortune from Exide Industries, maker of auto and industrial batteries. It recently forged a technical collaboration with American battery maker East Penn Manufacturing.  In 2010, he took cable distribution arm Hathway Cable & Datacom public  Other assets include an insurance partnership with Australia's QBE and stake in Trident, part of Oberoi hotel chain. Reportedly, he's looking to sell tech outfit Sonata Software. His son Akshay works with him.

name: Billionaires
bio: With his brother Jude, Christopher Reyes sits atop Reyes Holdings, a $15 billion (sales) food and beer distribution conglomerate. The family purchased a small South Carolina beer distributor for $740,000 in 1976; they bought Chicago Beverage Systems three years later. The company is now the largest beer distributor in the U.S., delivering 95 million-plus cases a year. It acquired McDonald's' largest U.S. distributor, Martin-Brower, in 1998; today that outfit delivers burgers and fries to all the McDonald's in Canada, Latin America and Ireland as well as thousands of locations in the U.S. The company also owns Reinhart FoodService, one of the largest food service distributors in the US. Chris and Jude are co-chairmen of Reyes Holdings; brother David runs the beer outfit. Chris is on the board of the Ronald McDonald House Charities, chairman of the board of Chicago's Children's Memorial Hospital and a trustee of the Chicago Museum of Science and Industry.
title: Co-Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: With his brother (and fellow billionaire) Christopher, M. Jude Reyes oversees Reyes Holdings, a $15 billion (sales) food and beer distribution conglomerate. The family purchased a small South Carolina beer distributor for $740,000 in 1976; it bought Chicago Beverage Systems three years later. The company is now the largest beer distributor in the U.S., delivering 95 million-plus cases a year. It owns McDonald's' largest U.S. distributor, Martin-Brower, acquired in 1998; today the outfit delivers burgers and fries to all the McDonald's in Canada, Latin America and Ireland as well as thousands of locations in the U.S.  The company also owns Reinhart FoodService, one of the largest food service distributors in the U.S. Chris and Jude are co-chairmen; brother David runs the beer outfit. A trustee of Northwestern University, he sits on various boards, including NorthShore University HealthSystem, and the Rehabilitation Institute of Chicago. He reportedly purchased an oceanfront Kiawah Island, S.C. home for $14 million in 2010.
title: Co-Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: The boss of food giant Rich Products is also a sportsman and author. Rich as penned four books, his latest "The Right Angle" covers tales of fishing, hockey and life as a minor league baseball owner. Last year Rich donated small English soccer club, the Bedlington Terriers, a shirt sponsorship and new scoreboard--the gift turned into an international feel-good story. Hollywood is turning his sport fishing book "Fish Fights," into the film "Islamorada."

name: Billionaires
bio: Maritime magnate Kjell Inge Rokke's main holding is a conglomerate that operates shipyards, offshore drilling, seafood, and shipping. Rokke, who is dyslexic, was reportedly told by a schoolteacher that he'd never amount to anything. He started selling fish off a single boat in Seattle, before returning to Norway and building up a fleet and reputation as a ruthless corporate raider. Nearly drove his shipping empire into the ground by 2003, had to sell off his yacht to pay his debts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Majestic Realty founder Ed Roski Jr., who built the Staples Center arena in Los Angeles with billionaire Philip Anschutz, is now competing with Anschutz to build a 75,000-seat football stadium outside the city in hopes of luring an NFL team back to the City of Angels. In his day job, Roski runs one of the country's largest commercial builders, with 70 million square feet in L.A., Denver, Las Vegas and Dallas. A University of Southern California alumnus, he donated $23 million to his alma mater's fine arts school in 2006 and currently serves as chairman of the USC board of trustees.
title: President and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Majestic Realty, Co.', 'title': 'President and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Though FedEx shares hit a two-year low in October 2011, they have surged more than 20% since, breaking even year over year. Smith got the idea for FedEx when he wrote a term paper at Yale about automation and logistics. He launched the company in 1971, putting every dollar he had into the venture. When the young company was short on cash to make a jet fuel payment, Smith reportedly headed to Las Vegas for the weekend and returned to New York on Monday with more than $20,000 in winnings, just enough to keep the company afloat. Today FedEx is active in more than 220 countries and territories and maintains a fleet of 654 aircraft and 43,000 vehicles. Smith is a founding member of the Electrification Coalition, an organization committed to ending the United States' dependence on oil. His solution: Replace vehicles powered by internal combustion engines with electric ones, a move Smith is currently making at his own company. Smith owns 10% of the NFL's Washington Redskins
title: Chairman and CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: With fellow billionaire Hui Lin Chit, Sze cofounded Hengan International, one of China's largest makers of sanitary napkins, tissues, diapers, bandages and snack products. Sze serves as chairman. Sales rose by 24% to $1.06 billion in the first half of 2011 amid buoyant Chinese consumer spending, but higher prices for raw materials hurt profits, which declined by 2% to $155 million. Eyeing the company's strong brand and market share, investors have pushed Hengan's shares up by about a quarter in the past year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of factory worker, Andrew Tan did odd jobs to put himself through college. Saved money he earned as a kitchen appliance salesman to buy a distillery and made his first fortune in brandy. His holding company, Alliance Global, has interests in food and beverage, real estate, gaming. With partner Genting Malaysia, he plans to build a second casino in Pasay City this year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhu Gongshan founded GCL-Poly Energy Holdings, one of the world's largest producers of polysilicon and wafers used in solar panels. In the first six months of 2011, sales climbed 162% from a year earlier to $2.4 billion. In February, Bank of America Merrill Lynch agreed to finance GCL-developed solar power systems at 15 locations in the Palmdale School District in southern California. The Chinese company has U.S. offices in San Francisco and Richland, Wash. Zhu's son Yufeng sits on the board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Juan Abello, a onetime pharmacist, sold his family's pharmaceutical business in 1985 and invested the proceeds in several industries, from banking to textiles. He accumulated a 9.6% stake of construction giant Sacyr Vallehermoso, of which he is a vice president. Abello often appears in tabloids alongside well-known politicians and members of Spanish artistic and cultural circles. He is also known for his valuable art collection which includes works by Edgar Degas, Toulouse-Lautrec, Salvador Dali and Van Gogh, among others. He's an enthusiastic hunter who enjoys bullfights and soccer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Saif Al Ghurair is the chairman of Al Ghurair Group. He hails from one of Dubai's oldest merchant families, with interests in banking, malls and manufacturing. Six sons hold various positions within the group's subsidiaries; son Majid is chief executive. Al Ghurair is a major shareholder in Mashreq, a leading Emirati bank helmed by his nephew Abdul Aziz Al Ghurair, also a billionaire. The bank is on the path to recovery after taking a hit for its exposure to bad real estate loans. Assets are still declining, but in a turnaround, Mashreq's net earnings were up almost 17% in the first nine months of 2011.

name: Billionaires
bio: Emilio Azcarraga is the chief executive of powerhouse Mexican TV broadcaster Televisa, which has recently begun producing English-language programming. Azcarraga and his would-be business partner Ricardo Salinas Pliego, of TV Azteca, continue an ongoing Mexican media battle with Carlos Slim Helu, Mexico's richest man. Last year Azcarraga's Televisa struck a deal to buy a 50% stake in Salinas' mobile phone company, Iusacell, for $1.6 billion. In early February Mexico's Federal Competition Commission vetoed the deal, a move widely viewed as stinking of politics; Televisa and Iusacell are appealing. Slim's phone companies Telmex and Telcel as well as retailers belonging to Grupo Carso pulled their advertising from Televisa in 2011 after Televisa increased ad rates by 20%. Televisa said the increase came because the Slim companies did not participate in "upfront" ad buying for the year. Meanwhile, Azcarraga is nudging into Slim's hold on telephony in Mexico by offering bundled Internet, phone and cable TV through Televisa's cable TV unit.

name: Billionaires
bio: In December 2010, publisher Heinz Bauer, 72, transferred an 85% of the family-run business to his daughter Yvonne Bauer. Yvonne is now chief executive of Bauer Media Group. The $1.7 billion (sales) group publishes everything from television guides to car and cooking magazines. The company sells its publications in 15 countries worldwide including Mexico, Russia and China. Its U.S. titles include First for Women, Woman's World and In Touch. Heinz' other three daughters Mirja, Nicola and Saskia each hold a 5% limited partnership share in the company. Heinz Bauer remains a general partner. Yvonne Bauer is the fifth generation of the family to run the group, which was founded in 1875.

name: Billionaires
bio: Evangelical tech entrepreneur Marc Benioff believes companies and products are naturally and now digitally "social." His Salesforce.com was dubbed "most innovative company in the world" by Clayton M. Christensen's new ranking in Forbes. Yet investor enthusiasm for the stock has waned: it has traded down 10% over the past year, behind the general tech index, as annual revenues approach $3 billion. Benioff founded his first company at age 15 to write Atari videogames. He started Salesforce after stints at Apple and Oracle; he championed "the end of software" and declared the company's mission to take traditional software online. The industry has followed. In June 2010 he pledged $100 million to University of California, San Francisco, toward construction of a new children's hospital, and plans to give more. This December Benioff and his wife, Lynne, donated $1.5 million to move homeless children in San Francisco into housing. The Hawaii fan signs emails "Aloha."
title: Chairman and CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Casino magnate Neil Bluhm opened his sixth gaming property in Des Plaines, Ill,, making it the first new casino in the state in 18 years. During Obama's 2008 charge to the White House, Bluhm was a major fundraiser, hosting a birthday party for the President when he turned 49 (price of admission: a $30,000 contribution to the DNC). This election cycle, he is co-chairing the president's finance committee. Bluhm's other interests include a stake in real-estate-focused private equity firm Walton Street Capital and a piece of JMB Realty, which owns, manages and develops commercial property throughout North America. An arts patron and board member of Chicago's Art Institute and New York City's Whitney Art Museum, he has a collection worth $100 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Charles Bronfman and his brother, Edgar Sr., inherited the Seagram spirits empire, which was built by their father, Sam. Since selling off his stake in Seagram in 2000, Charles has occupied himself with philanthropic giving, mainly through a foundation he founded with his former wife Andrea. The Andrea & Charles Bronfman Philanthropies give millions annually to promote, among other things, an appreciation for Canadian culture and the development of Israeli pride. The foundation's Taglit-Birthright Israel sends Jewish youth from North America on educational tours of Israel. In July 2011 Bronfman announced that his foundation would close in 2016. After Bronfman's wife Andrea was killed in an accident involving a taxi in 2006, he married Bonnie Roche. Last year the couple decided to divorce, amicably, and hosted a lavish pre-divorce party in the spring of 2011.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Greek immigrants, John Catsimatidis owns the Red Apple Group, Gristedes Foods supermarkets and the United Refining Company, which has a refinery in Pennsylvania that, at an estimated $900 million, is his most valuable asset. He opened his first grocery store at 100th St. and Broadway in New York City in 1969. By age 24 he owned 10 stores and made $25 million a year in revenue. He spent $5 million on Manhattan real estate in 1977, and the property was worth $100 million 5 years later. He bought United Refining Company in 1986. In March 2012, he announced his United Refining Company would try to buy Sunoco's 355,000-barrel-a-day refinery in Philadelphia. He credits his success to "Stubbornness, perseverance and a little bit of fearlessness."

name: Billionaires
bio: Michael Kors? financial backer sewed up his spot in the ranks after taking the fashion house public in November. Its shares are up more than 75% since the IPO. Silas Chou and his partner, new Candian billionaire Lawrence Stroll, were the same team that helped build Tommy Hilfiger into a 1990s worldwide retail phenomenon. Through their Hong Kong company, Sportswear Holdings, the 2 now have interests in Tom­my Hilfiger Asia, Karl Lagerfeld and Pepe Jeans. Chou comes from money; his father was on the billionaires list in the early 1990s.

name: Billionaires
bio: While the average hedge fund returned a dismal -5% last year, Cooperman's Omega Advisors broke even net of fees in 2011. Omega was up approximately 8% through mid-February 2012. Cooperman grew up in the South Bronx and started his career as a Xerox quality control engineer in 1965. After earning his MBA at Columbia University, Cooperman joined Goldman Sachs, where he rose to the head of the bank's asset management business. He then departed in 1991 to found his own fund management company. Today Omega manages approximately $6 billion. His Leon and Toby Cooperman Family Foundation currently has approximately $150 million in assets. Cooperman recently gifted a $20 million life insurance policy to the Jewish Community Foundation, the largest gift ever given to that organization. His other major philanthropic involvements include Columbia Business School, the United Jewish Appeal, the NJ Performing Arts Center, Barnabas Medical Center and Paul Tudor Jones' Robin Hood Foundation. Cooperman also serves as Treasurer of Damon Runyon Cancer Research, where he oversees the foundation's $60 million endowment. Cooperman made headlines with an open letter to Obama in November 2011.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Dulce Pugliese de Godoy Bueno is vice chairwoman of publicly-traded Amil Participacoes S.A., the largest healthcare company in Brazil. It provides health insurance and delivers health care via hospitals and clinics to 5 million people. Her net worth is $100 million higher than in March 2011 due to an increase in Amil's share price. She met her ex-husband, Amil founder Edson de Godoy Bueno, in medical school and helped him build Amil, starting with the acquisition of a few medical clinics. She was assistant professor in the pediatrics department at Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, where she also served as academic dean of the undergraduate program and founded the Pediatric Rheumatology Service of the Martagao Gesteira Pediatric Institute. Received a PhD in management from McCombs School of Business at the University of Texas at Austin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Reality TV pioneer John de Mol's latest hit, singing competition The Voice, is now in 45 countries. De Mol made his fortune a a founding investor in production company Endemol, which was behind other hits, including Deal or No Deal, Fear Factor, and Big Brother. He sold Endemol to Spanish telecom giant Telefonica in 2000, but he's bought back into a small stake in the company since then. De Mol now works through his new production company Talpa Media, and is busy acquiring radio and television stations throughout the Netherlands.

name: Billionaires
bio: Back in 1948 Carlo Fidani's grandfather and namesake founded Fidani and Sons, a Toronto area construction company. After his father Orey passed away in 2000, Fidani assumed full ownership and control as the third generation to run the family construction, development and management business, now branded as Orlando Corp. Today the firm owns, leases and manages more than 40 million square feet of industrial, office and commercial real estate in the Toronto area. Of this total, the vast majority (33 million square feet) is comprised of industrial distribution centers, Orlando's core product. Fidani has been a significant supporter of health services in the Toronto area, namely the Carlo Fidani Peel Regional Cancer Centre in Mississauga, the Princess Margaret Hospital Foundation, and the University of Toronto Mississauga.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: The youngest son of Gap founders Doris and the late Donald Fisher (d. 2009), John followed older brothers William and Robert to Princeton and Stanford, but isn't as involved in the family retail empire as his siblings. While he owns more shares in the $12 billion (market cap) company than any other Fisher, he isn't on the board. He is an active sports investor, owning 90% of the Oakland A's baseball team. In recent years he and fellow investor Lew Wolff have come under fire for attempts to move the franchise to San Jose. Fisher owns a smaller stake in a San Jose team already, major league soccer's Earthquakes. He is also an investor in Scotland's Glasgow Celtic football club.
title: President

name: Billionaires
bio: Jean-Claude Gandur netted $1.5 billion when he sold Addax Petroleum to China's Sinopec Group in 2009. He returned to oil exploration with Oryx Petroleum in 2010. He has stakes in two fields in Iraq's Kurdish region, and is vying for more in Africa. His Addax & Oryx Group is expected to glean $400 million from the pending sale of African oil storage terminals. Last year Addax Bioenergy broke ground on a $350 million project to grow sugarcane for ethanol in Sierra Leone. He formed the Fondation Gandur pour l'Art, and pledged to house its collections in Geneva's Musée d'Art et d'Histoire. His 101 European post-war abstract paintings are now on show in Montpellier, France, and 100 Egyptian pieces are on display in St. Petersburg, Florida.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of renowned oil baron J. Paul Getty Sr. (d. 1976), Gordon sold Getty Oil to Texaco in 1986 for $10 billion and plowed the proceeds into investments and wine. He seeded mutual fund servicing outfit ReFlow Management in 2002 and bought a stake in investment firm Forward Management. A trained musician, he composes operas. His works were performed in his hometown of San Francisco in 2010 by the Russian National Orchestra. Getty is also an investor in former San Francisco Mayor Gavin Newsom's PlumpJack Group hospitality business. Getty and his wife Ann fund an invite-only preschool called Playgroup for children of high-profile people in Silicon Valley. He is a big donor to Democrats, including President Obama and Nancy Pelosi.
title: President and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Ann & Gordon Getty Foundation', 'title': 'President and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Esther Grether inherited a beauty and health care products company from her late husband in 1975, and continues to run it with her daughter's involvement. Grether also has a 7.2% stake in watchmaker Swatch. However, a large part of her fortune comes from her collection of 20th century art, which reportedly includes over 600 pieces by artists such as Pablo Picasso, Paul Cezanne, Salvador Dali, Francis Bacon and Alberto Giacometti. She reportedly keeps the works in a converted printing factory. Grether sits on the committee which selects resident artists at the new Swatch Art Peace Hotel in Shanghai.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vladimir Gridin is the largest shareholder in Siberian Business Unit (SDS-holding), a coal mining, railway transportation and machine building concern. In the 1980s Gridin worked as the head of Novokuznetsk railways division responsible for civil facilities; he forged ties with head of Novokuznetsk railways division Aman Tuleev, who is now governor of Kemerovo region where SDS-holding is based. In 2007, Gridin was appointed State Duma deputy from the Yedinaya Rossiya party; he was just elected for a second term as deputy chairman of the transport committee.

name: Billionaires
bio: Reclusive investor David Hains keeps a low profile, but his private investment vehicle Portland House Group continues to perform well, investing around the world across equities, fixed interest, property and managed funds. The former engineer - who took seven years out of his early career to play golf - spent time working as a corporate restructuring expert. He came to prominence in 1993 when he sold an investment in the U.S. steelmaker Wheeling-Pittsburgh for $107 million. He is also an active horse breeder and racer though his Kingston Park Stud.

name: Billionaires
bio: Antti Herlin, Finland's only billionaire, amassed his fortune via the $6.8 billion (sales) KONE Corporation, a Finnish elevator and escalator manufacturer and installation and maintenance firm. Herlin's grandfather founded KONE in 1924. After being appointed deputy chairman and CEO in 1996, Antti Herlin expanded operations through a series of acquisitions, alliances, and technological advancements. He stepped down as CEO in 2006; he's been chairman since 2003, the year his father Pekka died. Antti is also the chairman of Security Trading Oy, and sits on the board of Finnish construction firm YIT.

name: Billionaires
bio: After a lukewarm performance in 2010, Howard returned to his winning ways last year following a move from London to Geneva. His hedge fund firm's $26 billion master fund led the way in 2011, returning 12.14% net of fees. The $36 billion Brevan Howard Asset Management has become the destination of choice for many traders department banks ahead of Obama's Volcker Rule. The firm, itself born when Howard and four Credit Suisse colleagues went solo in 2002. Howard sold 15% of the business to Swiss Re in 2007 for an undisclosed sum.
title: Founder
employment: {'name': 'Brevan Howard Asset Management', 'title': 'Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Chinese real estate developer Huang Wei controls Shanghai-listed investment company Xinhu Zhongbao. He and his wife own 70% of the Shanghai-listed shares, which have dropped by more than a third year on year. Xinhu Zhongbao purchased coal mining rights in Inner Mongolia for $100 million in June. Headquartered in the eastern Chinese city of Hangzhou, Xinhu Zhongbao has more than 30 real estate projects under development in 20-plus cities. The company is a shareholder in financial service firms including Shengjing Bank, Chengdu Rural Commercial Bank, Xiangcai Securities and Xinhu Futures. In January 2011, Xinhu Zhongbao said it would form a 70%-owned joint venture movie and television production company, in partnership with well-known Chinese film industry figures Hu Mei and He Yanjiang.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stanley Hubbard's ReelzChannel, a movie information and trivia channel, reaches 62 million subscribers. Hubbard created the channel after selling his direct-satellite TV outfit to DirecTV for $1.3 billion in 1999. As chairman of Hubbard Broadcasting, he has passed running of the daily business on to his five children, who all serve as operating officers of the various subgroups. In January 2011, the company acquired 17 radio stations for $505 million. Hubbard Aviation Technologies, a separate venture, makes hush kits that muffle engine noise in older Gulfstream aircraft. Hubbard inherited his love of flying from his father, a pilot who started one of the first commercial airlines in the U.S. Hubbard reportedly donated $385,000 to Newt Gingrich.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Hubbard Broadcasting, Inc.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: While working as an engineer in Russia for ENKA (from which Sarik Tara and Mehmet Sinan Tara make their billionaire fortunes), Erman Ilicak founded his own company Ronesans Construction in 1994 in St. Petersburg. Ronesans Construction builds everything from shopping malls to cement factories and state buildings across Eastern Europe, Commonwealth of Independent States, Middle East and Northern Africa. Ilicak is the chairman of the Turkish-Russian Business Council. He is a self-described family man who spends his free time reading books.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jeremy Jacbos? father Louis started selling popcorn and peanuts in 1915. The company grew into a massive sports concession business. Jeremy took over after his dad's death, transforming Buffalo-based Delaware North into a global player in food and hospitality. It now supplies 200 venues around the world, including airports, sporting venues, national parks and rest stops. Jacobs also owns 20% of the New England Sports Network and the Boston Bruins hockey team, who won the 2011 Stanley Cup after a 39-year drought. Recent estimates put the team near the $325 million mark ($200 million net debt) which makes it the third most-valuable American NHL team.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dallas Cowboys owner Jerry Jones has profited from his team's rise in status to America's most valuable sports team, at $1.85 billion. His new 111,000-seat stadium hosted the 2011 Super Bowl and helped Jones bring in league-leading revenue, even though the team only had six wins last season. Thanks to lucrative seat licenses, Jones took on relatively little debt building his $1.2 billion cathedral to Texas football. He made his first fortune in the 1970s drilling natural gas wells, then bought the Cowboys in 1989 for just $150 million. The team won three Super Bowl rings in the 1990s but have only won one playoff game in the last 15 years. A big Salvation Army supporter, Jones has used the Cowboys to raise more than $1 billion for the charity over the past 11 years. Over the last 25 years Jones has purchased several thousand acres in the Dallas area along the Sam Rayburn tollway, and expects to begin building homes and commercial real estate on the land in the next five years.
title: President and General Manager
employment: {'name': 'Dallas Cowboys', 'title': 'President and General Manager', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: The son of a pharmacist, Daryl Katz took the family trade one step further by piecing together what is now one of the largest drug store operators in North America. The Edmonton-based Katz Group, which began as a few distressed pharmacies that Katz snapped up in the 1990s, now has over 1,800 drug stores across Canada. The group also owns and operates the country's only mail order pharmacy business, Rexall Direct. In late January, Katz Group announced it was selling its Medicine Shoppe pharmacy business and its Drug Trading Co. unit to McKesson Corp. of the U.S. for $920 million in cash; the deal is expected to close in the first half of 2012. Katz owns the Edmonton Oilers hockey team, which he will move to a new stadium following a tug-of-war with the city of Edmonton about development and financing. The cost of the relocation project is projected to exceed half a billion dollars.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Danil Khachaturov is reportedly considering a private placement or an IPO for his insurance giant Rosgosstrakh, one of the highest-volume Russian insurers. After studying construction and finance in Moscow secondary schools, Kachaturov got a job at privately-held BIN Bank, then Slavneft, an oil company led at the time by fellow billionaire Mikhail Gutseriev. Between 2001 and 2003, Khachaturov and his partners spent $60 million buying 75% of the insolvent insurance giant Rosgosstrakh from the government; they purchased the remaining 25% in 2010. The partners managed to transform the Soviet-era company into an insurance powerhouse with $3 billion revenue and $600 million debt; selling shares would allow him to reduce the company's debt.

name: Billionaires
bio: Liu Zhongtian is chairman of China Zhongwang, one of the country's largest non-government-owned aluminum producers.  Liu's wealth edged up to $2 billion despite huge pressure on his business after the U.S. imposed anti-dumping duties on Zhongwang's exports of aluminum extrusion products. Overseas sales plunged to $14 million in the first six months of 2011 from $606.7 million a year earlier. Domestic sales rose 58% to $664 million, helping to pick up some of the slack.

name: Billionaires
bio: A native Indian, Sri Prakash Lohia is now an Indonesian citizen. He is one of three brothers whose fortune spans India, Thailand and Indonesia through numerous public and private companies involved in textiles and plastics. He controls Indorama Synthetics, Indonesia's largest polyester manufacturer. It is reported that Indorama produces one in every three PEt bottles in the US. Lohia is Chairman of Indorama Ventures, which his brother Aloke, who is also a billionaire, runs from his base in Thailand. His brother Om Prakash has his own polyester fibers and yarns business in India. A resident of Singapore, Sri Prakash also has a home in London, where his wife's brother, steel billionaire Lakshmi Mittal, lives.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grocery distribution entrepreneur Drayton McLane's sale of baseball's Houston Astros for $680 million was approved by MLB this past November. He bought the team for $103 million in 1992, and just last year finalized a deal with Comcast to launch a regional sports network with the NBA's Rockets. McLane started as a truck loader on night shifts in the warehouse of his family's grocery distribution center in 1959. He eventually grew the McLane Company into an international holding company spanning 18 divisions, including food service, software and novelty gifts, before selling it to friend and tennis partner Sam Walton for 10.4 million shares of Wal-Mart stock and $50 million in 1991. McLane is a graduate of Baylor University, where he previously served as a trustee and regent, was chairman of the endowment, and currently holds "Regent Emeritus" status.

name: Billionaires
bio: Elon Musk joins our list of the world's billionaires following a 25% stock value gain in Tesla, his publicly traded electric car company, since he appeared on our list of "Ones to Watch" in October. Meanwhile he is prepping SolarCity and SpaceX for IPOs. SolarCity will likely debut later this year, underwritten by Goldman Sachs, and is expected to achieve a valuation of $1.5 billion. Space transportation and innovation company SpaceX could be listed in 2013. Musk is working with fellow billionaire Paul Allen on a project that will launch unmanned rockets from what will be the world's biggest plane. He has divorced his second wife, British actress Taluah Riley, following a very public separation from his first wife, Justine.
title: Founder, CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Shigenobu Nagamori heads Nidec, maker of micromotors used in DVDs, hard drives, robots, game consoles. Natural disasters made for a tough 2011: the earthquake in Japan affected operations and floods in Thailand disabled a plant there. Nidec is launching production of advanced motors for electric vehicles that do not rely on rare earths, based on patents gained from 2010 acquisition of motor unit from Emerson Electric of U.S. The company's stock price is flat over the past year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Aeronautical engineer Martin Naughton founded Glen Electric in 1973, acquired Dimplex four years later, and built it into the world's largest manufacturer of electrical heating appliances (stoves, electrical fireplaces, space heaters, decorative fires, water heaters). Naughton became sole owner of Glen Dimplex in 2003. In the last year, company has diversified, buying the U.K. gas company, Valor. He's also a trustee emeritus at University of Notre Dame in Indiana.

name: Billionaires
bio: These days Dmitry Pumpyansky's companies are busy rebuilding a stadium in Ekaterinburg in anticipation of the 2018 World Cup and constructing the Arkhyz Health Resort in northern Caucasus; the Russian government has promised to repay a major portion of these investments. Like many native sons of the Urals region, Pumpyansky started out as a trader. He graduated from the Urals Polytechnic Institute with a concentration in metallurgy. Throughout the 1990s he ran a variety of metals plants in the Urals. In 1998 he headed up the sales division of the Sinarsky Pipe Factory and quickly became its main owner. Two years later, Sinarsky became part of pipe conglomerate TMK, assembled by MDM Group founders and fellow billionaires Sergei Popov and Andrei Melnichenko. Pumpyansky became chief executive of MDM Group and acquired a 35% stake in the company. At the time, MDM controlled three major pipe plants; it eventually acquired a fourth despite fierce competition from Mikhail Fridman's Alfa Group. In October 2006, Pumpyansky bought out Melnichenko and Popov and listed TMK on the London Stock Exchange, raising $1 billion. During the crisis he had to hand over his controlling stake to state-owned banks as security for a $1.85 billion loan; the loan was extended to eight years at end of 2008 and Pumpyansky got his stake back.

name: Billionaires
bio: Beverly Hills power couple Lynda and Stewart Resnick have built or acquired a number of companies since the 1970s, including POM Wonderful, Fiji Water, and flower delivery service Teleflora. They bought family-operated Justin Vineyards and Winery in December 2010. The Resnicks also own Paramount Farms and Paramount Citrus Companies, making them one of the largest farmers of tree crops in the U.S. Lynda ran a marketing and advertising agency before she joined entrepreneurial forces with her husband. In December, their POM juice company lost a lawsuit that alleged Ocean Spray had misled consumers by selling a Cranberry Pomegranate juice blend with less than 2% pomegranate juice. They claimed the product had cost POM $18 million in sales.

name: Billionaires
bio: Peruvian-born, American-educated, Carlos Rodriguez-Pastor has created an empire that spans anything a consumer could never need in his birth nation. The son of an influential Peruvian banker, Pastor and his family fled Peru after a political coup in 1968, settling in California. Pastor eventually went to the University of California, Berkeley, before earning his MBA at Dartmouth. After a stint on Wall Street and his family's return to Peru, Pastor eventually became head of Banco Internacional Peru following his father's death in 1995. Since then he's diversified and established IFH Peru as massive holding company that owns Peruvian supermarket chains, movie theaters, real estate firms, pharmacies and financial services companies. Holdings include Interseguro, an insurance company, and Interbank, one of the country's largest commercial and retail banks.

name: Billionaires
bio: While his former Harvard classmates celebrated Facebook's IPO at their new Menlo Park, California digs, company co-founder Eduardo Saverin was many miles away. Brazilian-born, he renounced his American citizenship in 2011, news of which broke days before the Facebook offering and drew accusations of tax evasion. Saverin says the move was "based solely on my interest in working and living in Singapore, where I have been since 2009." Saverin, immortalized in The Social Network as Mark Zuckerberg's onetime best friend, provided the social network with early seed money, earning him a one-third stake. This fell to 30% when Zuckerberg's roommate, Dustin Moskovitz, joined. When the others dropped out of school to relocate to California, Saverin stayed behind. Facebook later sued him for allegedly interfering with business and insisting on keeping a 30% stake; Saverin countersued. The parties settled, with Saverin apparently receiving a 5% stake and a co-founder bio on Facebook's site. He has since sold more than half his stake in Facebook and has started to invest in startups including Qwiki and Jumio, which created the online payment Netswipe.

name: Billionaires
bio: Maria-Elisabeth and her son Georg jointly own one of world's largest producers of roller bearings, Schaeffler Group. Georg owns the vast majority of the company?80% to his mother's 20%. Maria has been at the helm of the business since 1996 when her husband died. Georg, who practiced international business law in Dallas, now works at his mother's side helping to run the company. In 2008, the company announced a $15 billion takeover of Continental AG, one of Europe's largest tire and auto parts maker. In 2009, Schaeffler Group restructured the $16 billion debt incurred at the takeover and now holds a 49.9% stake in Continental.
title: Entrepreneur

name: Billionaires
bio: With her brother Dieter von Holtzbrinck and her half-brother Stefan von Holtzbrinck, Monika Schoeller inherited publishing house Verlagsgruppe Holtzbrinck from their father George, who founded it as a book club in 1948. In 2006, she and Stefan bought out Dieter's one-third share. In 2009, they sold Handelsblatt, Germany's biggest financial newspaper; 50% of weekly newspaper Die Zeit and other assets back to Dieter, canceling out financial obligations owed to him. Schoeller heads book publisher S. Fischer Verlag, which dates back to 1886. The group was the original publisher of Thomas Mann, Franz Kafka and Hermann Hesse.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 1966, Richard Schulze founded Best Buy, originally called the "Sound of Music Store," in St. Paul, Minnesota. The company went public in 1986 and was the second-largest consumer electronics retailer by 1993. Schulze stepped down as CEO in 2002 after serving for more than 30 years. In July 2011, Schulze and three other board members were named in a shareholder suit, which claims the executives made "illegal insider trades," pocketing $29 million. (Best Buy and Schulze declined comment.)
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Anatoly Sedykh's United Metallurgical Company, Russia's second-largest pipe producer and biggest maker of railway wheels, struck a deal last year with the state-owned monopoly Russian Railways to prolong its wheel contract for an unprecedented 12 years; by the time the contract is up Sedykh's firm will supply more than 3 million wheels to the government's rail monopoly. UMC has been recovering with help from two massive deals: Sedykh's OMK (United Metals Company) is supplying an oil pipeline to China and a gas pipeline to Germany. The graduate of Moscow State Institute of Steel & Alloys, which several of Russia's tycoons attended, worked as an economist in the Central Research Institute for Ferrous Metallurgy. In 1989 he started a joint venture in scrap-metal recycling with a $1.5 million loan from Sberbank, Russia's largest bank. He then started buying up shares in pipe producer Vyksunsky Metallurgical Plant (VMP), a factory in the Urals region. By 1999, Sedykh and his partners were controlling shareholders. He later established UMC.

name: Billionaires
bio: Industrial equipment, especially Caterpillar earthmoving and mining gear, is the backbone of his business interests, though his investments in media attract the closest attention. Starting with a franchise to sell Cat tractors and trucks in Australia, he has expanded into China where demand for equipment means it will soon be a more important market than home. Once regarded as a minor player in newspapers and television, his media firm Seven Group now has a bigger market share in Australia than the country's better-known media baron (and now U.S. citizen), Rupert Murdoch. Proud of his physical fitness Stokes is a keen skier and swimmer. He is an avid collector of art and military memorabilia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Japanese commerical and residential developer, Daito Trust Construction, Katsumi Tada stepped down as chairman in June. He received a $40 million paying package as a reward for successfully leading the company in a faltering real estate market. His retirement comes on the heels of selling his stake back to Daito Trust Construction in March, netting nearly $2 billion. The company sustained property damage after Japan's earthquake; 14 properties under construction and 176 managed properties (including 94 within 30 kilometer radius of the nuclear power plant zone) have been written off and required repair. Still stock is up over the past 12 months.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairul Tanjung rebranded his Para Group as CT Corp in December. He paid a reported $70 million for country's biggest online media outfit, Detik.com, in August 2011. The group opened its second theme park in Bandung this year and plans to open its biggest yet in Jakarta by 2014. A trained dentist, he got his start selling study guides while in school. He has since made a fortune selling to Indonesia's new middle class. His conglomerate Para Group has interests in banks, TV stations, theme parks, retail. CT has a stake in retailer Carrefour Indonesia. It also owns franchise rights to Baskin-Robbins as well as high-end brands Armani, Jimmy Choo and Valentino.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cable news pioneer Turner invented the idea of the "Giving Pledge" long before Warren Buffett and Bill Gates made it trendy for billionaires to promise to give away half their wealth. Since leaving the broadcast arena, Turner says he has dedicated his life to trying to save the world. His causes range from women's rights to protecting endangered species and achieving nuclear disarmament. He owns 2 million acres of rustic land across 13 states and in Argentina. Turner has donated more than $1.5 billion to charity, including $866 million of his $1 billion pledge to the United Nations Foundation. Turner worked for his father at Turner Advertising until 1963, when his father committed suicide. In 1966 he merged Turner Broadcasting with Time Warner. He created 24-hour news by starting CNN in 1980. He became AOL Time Warner's largest individual shareholder after combining the two companies in 2000. He lost $7 billion in two years after shares collapsed.  A skilled sailor, Turner won the America's Cup in 1977.

name: Billionaires
bio: With his half-brother Dieter and his half-sister Monika Schoeller, Stefan von Holtzbrinck inherited publishing house Verlagsgruppe Holtzbrinck from their father George, who founded it as a book club in 1948. Stefan has run the company--which includes book publishers Farrar Strauss, St. Martins Press and Henry Holt--since 2001. In 2006, he and Monika bought out Dieter's one-third share. In 2009, they sold Handelsblatt, Germany's biggest financial newspaper; 50% of weekly newspaper Die Zeit and other assets back to Dieter. A lawyer, Stefan apprenticed at Bloomsbury Publishing in London before joining the Holtzbrinck company in 1994.  He is very involved in digital media and the Holtzbrinck Group is one of the largest early stage investors. The company's current portfolio includes Groupon, Zalando, Wooga, AdScale, Experteer and GameDuell.

name: Billionaires
bio: After landing in the U.S. in 1969 with little more than a few dollars in his pocket, Romesh Wadhwani rode the tech bubble onto The Forbes 400 in 2000 with the $9.3 billion sale of Aspect Development software firm to i2 Technologies. The all-stock deal depleted his fortune when i2's stock declined during the burst of the bubble. The Persistent Wadhwani then invested $250 million of his own money to start, acquire or build 14 business software and IT companies until his fortune shot back to ten-figures. He heads Symphony Technology Group which is focused on building software and services companies. Wadhwani attended Indian Institute of Technology in Mumbai. He earned a Ph.D. in electrical engineering at Carnegie Mellon. He started Aspect in 1991 and raised funding from Sequoia Capital shortly afterward. The firm made software that allowed clients to track internal spending, inventory, buying behavior. He uses little leverage to buy companies: "Financial engineering is not our game, building great great growth companies is."
title: Founder and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Symphony Technology Group', 'title': 'Founder and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Wong Kwong Yu, also known as Huang Guangyu, is serving a prison sentence for bribery, insider trading and stock manipulation, but business at Gome Electrical Appliances, the electronics and appliance chain he founded, ,  continues to grow. In February, Hong Kong-listed Gome announced an alliance with telecom giant China Telecom to distribute iPhone 4S models in China.  Sales in the first six months of 2011 rose by 20% from a year earlier to $4.7 billion, unaffected by investor criticism of a controversial move by the company to buy real estate owned by Wong.   Gome opened 131 new stores and shut 19 underperforming ones, bringing its total to 938. That doesn't include another 494 stores privately held Gome-branded stores in mainland China, as well as  Wong-controlled Dazhong Appliance stores.  Gome is aiming to boost its online business through its website C008.com.  Bain Capital holds 11% of Gome.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zdenek Bakala is turning his focus to promoting transparency, announced a new NGO that will fight against corruption. His impetus in part is to get the Czech government to auction assets more fairly. Bakala built a coal and mining empire; his investment vehicle BXR has stakes in New World Resources and Ferrexpo, both of whose stock prices have suffered over the past year. New World Resources is reportedly considering a merger with Polish coking coal producer, JSW. The avid cycler bought a stake in the Belgian professional cycling team Quick Step, which is expected to compete in the Tour de France in 2013. Bakala recently invested in a new vineyard in South Africa, one of his cycling hot spots. He is married to a former Miss Czechoslovakia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mikhail Balakin heads up CD-155 (SU-155), a construction company that in 2011 increased turnover by 16%. Most of last year's revenue (70%) came through state contracts, but Balakin plans to go after commercial business. Balakin built homes for people who lost theirs in the 2010 summer heat wave fires; he also took part in reconstruction of the famed Bolshoi Theater.  After graduating from the Moscow Institute of Civil Engineering, Balakin started out at one of the divisions of Soviet construction behemoth Glavmosstroi. In 1993 that division became a private company called Construction Department 155; Balakin is its largest shareholder. He later worked in highly-placed jobs in the Moscow city government and in 2005, after four years as a bureaucrat, turned his focus to his business.

name: Billionaires
bio: With James Coulter, David Bonderman co-founded private equity behemoth Texas Pacific Group. In 1993, TPG bought Continental Airlines for $66 million and then sold it for a $640 million profit. Other hits include Burger King and J. Crew. Bonderman prefers complex deals others shy away from. With affiliates, his firm manages $50 billion today. Bonderman and Coulter are equal partners in TPG. "Bondo" attended U. of Washington, then Harvard Law and became a civil rights attorney for the Department of Justice. Later he studied Islamic law in Cairo. He paid the Rolling Stones to play his 60th birthday party in Las Vegas in 2002. Bonderman now sits on the board of the Russian Direct Investment Fund, which directs Kremlin funds for special projects. He donates to the League of Conservation Voters.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chang Yung-fa 's Evergreen Marine is one of the world's largest  shipping companies with more than 160 container ships. Chang?controlled businesses include EVA Airways and Evergreen International Storage and Transport. Evergreen's hotel chain has over 1,9,00 rooms in Taipei, Paris, Bangkok and other cities. Chang entered the shipping business at the age of 14, working in Miname Nippon Steamship's office in the city of Keelung in northern Taiwan while he attended night classes in vocational school in Taipei. His father died in 1944 after U.S. allies sank a Japanese ship he was on.

name: Billionaires
bio: The twin sister of fellow billionaire George Hearst Jr, Phoebe Hearst Cooke is the granddaughter of media baron William Randolph Hearst, the man responsible for creating "yellow journalism" - that is, sensational, tabloid-style tales. Since 2009, when Cooke was deemed too ill to look after her own affairs and finances, George Jr and his son George III have acted as conservators. The Hearst family's media empire today includes newspapers, magazines, TV and radio stations, and stakes in cable networks ESPN, Lifetime, and A&E. The cable holdings are doing especially well: the Hearst family's stake in ESPN is worth more than $6 billion. The family owns the 90,000-square-foot Hearst Castle in San Simeon, Calif; the state has paid the Hearsts $95 million to preserve the property.

name: Billionaires
bio: With David Bonderman, James Coulter co-founded private equity giant Texas Pacific Group, managing $48 billion in assets. Coulter runs the San Francisco office, while co-founder David Bonderman heads the Dallas HQ. The two met while working for billionaire Robert Bass at Oak Hill, then left to pursue their first deal together in the early 1990s: They salvaged Continental Airlines with a $66 million investment, a stake worth $700 million five years later. In recent deals, TPG sold Turkish spirits company Mey Icki for $2.1 billion in February, bought blood transfusion firm Immucor for $2 billion and real estate listings publisher Primedia for $525 million. In September, to gain better access to the booming Southeast Asia market, the pair reportedly reached an agreement to swap 5% of TPG for up to a 20% stake in Indonesian private equity house Northstar.

name: Billionaires
bio: Davis bought New Balance on the day of the Boston Marathon in 1972. The running shoe manufacturer had six employees at the time. It now has 4,000 globally and revenues topping $1.6 billion. The brand, which originally adopted an "endorsed by no one" philosophy, now has a line of shoes with Heidi Klum (HKNB) and, as of the start of the 2011 season, is the official footwear and apparel sponsor of the Red Sox. The company maintains domestic manufacturing; 25% of its shoes sold in North America are made or assembled in the U.S. Davis also dabbles in real estate; last year he paid $27 million for two parcels near New Balance's Boston headquarters, apparently to build a hotel. Davis summers in nearby Gloucester, Mass., where he owns a large stake in the cruise port and the original Birds Eye facility, where a hotel is planned. He made the largest gift ever to University of Maine, Orono, donating $5 million for new athletic facilities.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Gao Dekang is the chairman and CEO of Bosideng, one of the world's largest makers of down jackets. Sales grew 47% in the six months ending Sepetmeber to $429 million. Flagship Bosideng, a mid- to-high-end brand, is joined by Snow Flying (for younger customers), Kangbo (men's), and Bengen (women's).
