With an eye to international expansion, Bosideng bought a six-story building in London last summer that serves as its European headquarters.  Paid $16 million  last year for a 51% stake in Shanghai Lanboxing Kids Clothing Co., whose brands for kids include D.D. Cat and Mikyo, r100 and M&Q.

name: Billionaires
bio: Roberto Gonzalez Barrera founded and runs Gruma, the world's largest tortilla maker; brand names include Mission, Guerrero and Maseca. U.S. agricultural commodities powerhouse Archer Daniels Midland is a 23% shareholder. The majority of Gonzalez Barrera's wealth, however, comes from his stake in Banorte, a successful Mexican bank that earlier in its history was owned by the Mexican government. In 2011, he returned to the billionaires list after a hiatus of more than a decade, based on the strength of Banorte's stock. This valuation includes his shares alone, and not those of his children.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alec Gores' private equity firm, Gores Group, completed its purchase of the automotive and aftermarket service chain Pep Boys in February 2012, purchasing the company's remaining 24 percent for $1 billion, roughly $15 a share. In February 2011 Gores raised $2 billion for a new fund to focus on telecommunications, technology business services and health care. Gores started the buyout firm in 1987 and has purchased more than 80 companies since. Alec's younger brother Tom is the billionaire chief of his own private equity shop, Platinum Equity. In November 2011 Gores' name was floated as a potential bidder for the Los Angeles Dodgers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Austin Hearst is the grandson of media baron William Randolph Hearst, the man responsible for creating "yellow journalism" - that is, sensational, tabloid-style tales. The younger brother of venture capital investor William Randolph Hearst III, Austin Hearst is a TV and film producer. His most recent project, "The Vow," a romance starring Rachel McAdams, was released in February 2012. Past work includes TV cartoon versions of popular comic strips Popeye and Son, and Beetle Bailey. His family's media empire includes newspapers, magazines, TV and radio stations, and stakes in cable networks ESPN, Lifetime, and A&E. The cable holdings are doing especially well: The Hearst family's stake in ESPN is worth more than $6 billion. The family owns the 90,000-square-foot Hearst Castle in San Simeon, Calif; the state has paid the Hearsts $95 million to preserve the property.

name: Billionaires
bio: David Hearst Jr is a grandson of media baron William Randolph Hearst, the man responsible for creating "yellow journalism" - that is, sensational, tabloid-style tales. He is one of five Hearst cousins on the World's Billionaires list; their media empire today includes newspapers, magazines, TV and radio stations, and stakes in cable networks ESPN, Lifetime, and A&E. The cable holdings are doing especially well: The Hearst family's stake in ESPN is worth more than $6 billion. The family owns the 90,000-square-foot Hearst Castle in San Simeon, Calif; the state has paid the Hearsts $95 million to preserve the property.

name: Billionaires
bio: George Hearst Jr is twin brother to fellow billionaire Phoebe Hearst Cooke, and  he is the grandson of media baron William Randolph Hearst, the man responsible for creating "yellow journalism" - that is, sensational, tabloid-style tales. His family's media empire today includes newspapers, magazines, TV and radio stations, and stakes in cable networks ESPN, Lifetime, and A&E. The cable holdings are doing especially well: The Hearst family's stake in ESPN is now worth more than $6 billion. The family owns the 90,000-square-foot Hearst Castle in San Simeon, Calif; the state has paid the Hearsts $95 million to preserve the property.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former billionaire Michael Heisley passed away in late April 2014 at age 77. He founded Heico Companies, a Chicago holding company that specialized in buying underperforming or bankrupt companies to turn them around. He started in 1979 by buying Conco, a maker of sewer and drain equipment, with $150,000 in profit from selling his home and $10 million in bank loans. Heico expanded and bought several struggling Rust Belt manufacturers. He bought the Vancouver Grizzlies NBA basketball team and moved them to Memphis. He sold the team to a group led by technology billionaire Robert Pera in 2012. The Grizzlies made the playoffs in 2011.  Heisley was last on the Forbes Billionaires list in 2012. He fell off the list the following year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Elie Horn founded Cyrela Brazil Realty in 1978 and built it into the largest publicly traded developer of high-end residential buildings in Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro. He later expanded by inking development deals with partners in various regions of Brazil. Share of the company are down 10% compared with February 2011; that drop knocked $200 million off his net worth since last year. His listed Cyrela Commercial Properties acquires, develops and rents shopping centers and corporate buildings primarily in Sao Paulo and Rio. Horn also owns a slice of agricultural investor BrasilAgro. Long before the Bill Gates-Warren Buffett Giving Pledge came along, Horn told the Brazilian press that he planned to give away most of his fortune at his death; he reportedly gives 20% of his earnings to charity every year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bradley Hughes grew his business from one self-storage facility in 1972 to the $19 billion (market cap) Public Storage chain. Today he's better known for his contributions to the thoroughbred horse breeding and racing industry, and to Republican candidates and causes. Hughes retired as chief executive of Public Storage in 2002 but remains chairman. He's made it clear that he's now in the process of shedding assets to his family, including daughter Tamara Gustavson, who debuted on last year's Forbes 400 and sits on Public Storage's board. His recent political donations include $3.25 million to Karl Rove's right-wing American Crossroads PAC last year, prior to the midterm elections. A thoroughbred enthusiast, Hughes owns 700-acre Spendthrift Farm in Kentucky and is a well-known figure on the horse auction and racing circuit. He often goes by his middle name, Wayne.

name: Billionaires
bio: Pharmaceutical investor Jaharis made his fortune launching Kos Pharmaceuticals in 1988. The firm created the cholesterol-battling drug Niaspan. Abbott Labs bought Kos in 2006 for $4.2 billion. With fellow billionaire Philip Frost, Jaharis took over Key Pharmaceuticals and served as CEO from 1972 until 1986 when the company merged with Schering-Plough Corp. He is a co-founder and director of Arisaph Pharmaceuticals, an emerging biopharmaceutical firm. A big supporter of Columbia U. Medical Center, Weill Cornell Medical College, and Tufts U. School of Medicine, Jaharis is also a benefactor of The Metropolitan Museum of Art, The Art Institute of Chicago and The Metropolitan Opera.

name: Billionaires
bio: Andrei Klyamko together with partner and fellow billionaire Vadim Novinsky owns Ukraine's Smart Holding Group, which has a 24% stake in Ukrainian billionaire Rinat Akhmetov's iron ore producer Metinvest. Klyamko also has stakes in oil and gas company Regal Petroleum and supermarket chain Amstor. He lives in Russia, where he is president of the Sambo Federation of St. Petersburg.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Aloke Lohia took his Indorama Ventures, world's largest integrated polyester producer, public in 2010. Its share price is down 40% from a year ago, though still up 300% since IPO. Company continues to expand. It bought polyester companies in the US, Mexico, Germany, Poland, China. In January, it acquired a polyolefin fiber plant in Georgia. Thai permanent resident is son of Indian entrepreneur and brother of billionaire Sri Prakash Lohia, one of Indonesia's richest, but has lived in Thailand for over 20 years. 


Shares on the rebound with higher expected earnings in second half; spending $3.8 billion to double capacity over next 3 years. Thai permanent resident is son of Indian entrepreneur and brother of one of Indonesia's richest but has lived in Thailand for over 20 years.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 1973, Siegfried Meister founded Rational AG, a German company that manufactures industrial food steamers and ovens, and is the chairman of its supervisory board. A qualified electrical engineer, Meister began as an entrepreneur in the late 1960s dealing with electronics in the field of kitchen technology. Early in his career, he established company locations in Munch and Landsberg am Lech, Germany in southwest Bavaria. His Rational AG now has subsidiaries worldwide.

name: Billionaires
bio: Longtime Japanese billionaire Minoru Mori died on March 8th 2012 of heart failure at the age of 77. Mori inherited his initial fortune from his late father, Taikichiro Mori, the world's wealthiest person in 1991 (net worth: $15 billion) and 1992 (net worth: $13 billion). Minoru went on to build some of Tokyo's best known buildings including swank Roppongi Hills complex that opened in 2003. He later built the 101-story Shanghai World Financial Center, now China's tallest building. His book, "The Making of Vertical Garden Cities", will be published in late March by Penguin. His brother Akira Mori, with whom he split in 1999, is also a billionaire.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vadim Novinsky together with partner and fellow billionaire Andrei Klyamko owns Ukraine's Smart Holding Group, which has a 24% stake in Ukrainian billionaire Rinat Akhmetov's iron ore producer Metinvest. In December 2011, he began negotiating with the Bank of Moscow to purchase its subsidiary bank in Ukraine. Novinsky also has stakes in oil and gas company Regal Petroleum and supermarket chain Amstor. The Russian native studied at Leningrad Academy of Civil Aviation. In the mid-1990s, Novinsky cofounded Lukoil North West and worked as its representative in Ukraine. He began to buy shares of Ukrainian metallurgy companies and in 2006 he united those companies into Smart Holding Group; a year later, he exchanged them for a 24% stake in Metinvest.

name: Billionaires
bio: Real estate mogul Richard (Dick) Peery partnered with John Arrillaga and began buying up tracts of California farmland and converting them into office parks in the 1960s. Now the Peery-Arrillaga firm owns just under 3 million square feet of office space and 290 acres of land in Silicon Valley. Tenants include Google, which leases 15 buildings from the firm. The partners began selling off half their portfolio in 2005, including a 2006 sale of nearly 120 buildings for $1.1 billion. Peery's son Dave runs the family foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Isaac Perlmutter emigrated from Israel to the U.S. with just $250 to his name. A veteran of Israel's 1967 Six-Day War, Perlmutter put his knowledge of Hebrew to work presiding over Jewish funerals in Brooklyn. Along with his partner, Avi Arad, he became the majority shareholder in Odd-Lot Trading Co., and eventually the owner of Toy Biz. In 1998 Perlmutter merged Toy Biz with Marvel Entertainment Group, beating out Carl Icahn and Ron Perelman for control of the bankrupt company. In August 2009, he sold Marvel, along with the rights to use its 9,000-plus characters, to Disney for $4 billion in cash and stock, with Perlmutter remaining on board as CEO. One of the few existing photos of Perlmutter in the public domain is from a 1985 Forbes photo shoot. The most successful Marvel hero to take to the silver screen thus far has been Spider-man, with the trilogy grossing a collective $2.5 billion.
title: Chief Executive Officer
employment: {'name': 'Marvel Entertainment', 'title': 'Chief Executive Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Movie producer Gigi Pritzker is one of 11 members of the extended Pritzker family on the billionaires list this year. Her grandfather, A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert (d. 2011), created industrial conglomerate Marmon and hotel chain Hyatt. In 2007, the family sold control of industrial conglomerate Marmon Holdings to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway for $4.5 billion. Gigi has been buying Hyatt shares from her cousins Linda and James. She owns production company Odd Lot Entertainment, which backed hit film "The Wedding Planner." The company had a big success in 2011 with "Drive," and is slated to release a rendition of Orson Scott Card's science fiction tale, "Ender's Game," starring Harrison Ford, in 2013.

name: Billionaires
bio: Infrastructure group GMR gets its name from the initials of its founder G.M.Rao, a farmer's son. It operates 4 airports, notably Delhi, Hyderabad. Stock of flagship GMR Infrastructure, under pressure due to soaring costs, fell by 20% in past year. Group is building 10 power plants in bid to expand power generation capacity tenfold. To pay off debt, it struck a deal to sell 30% stake in its Singapore energy unit to Petronas. It also sold stake in Dutch power firm InterGen at a loss. He announced plans to donate $315 million worth of shares to his family foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Port operator Enrique "Ricky" Razon controls Manila-listed International Container Terminal Services which has operations in 17 countries. Fortune got boost as stock gained more than 30% in past year. His privately-held property development arm which has one of four casino licences in the country, has invested $500 million in a new casino-hotel complex in Manila. Its first phase is due to be completed this year. Avid golfer, he loves kite surfing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shin Chang-Jae chairs Kyobo Life Insurance, which was founded by his father and is now one of the biggest life insurance companies in South Korea. Shin became the chief executive in 1997. He was educated as an obstetrician and worked as a professor of medicine at Seoul National University. Shin owns a 34% stake in Kyobo Life.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gil Shwed graced the cover of our 2002 Billionaires issue, only to fall off the list in 2003. He returned last year and his net worth continues to move up, as shares of his cybersecurity firm Check Point Software Technologies have skyrocketed. Following protests in Israel, he has been quoted advocating for rate hikes for top tax brackets. His charitable endeavors, including Tel Aviv University for Youth, deal with issues ranging from improving high school matriculation rates to sparking and maintaining interest in science education. Shwed devotes much of his spare time to photography and cooking.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Brooklyn-born son of a bricklayer, Sheldon Solow was a small-time builder when he risked everything on one Manhattan high-rise in 1972. That building is now the prestigious 9 West 57th Street, with tenants like KKR and Apollo Global Management. Solow has been trying to move forward with the Solow Project, a $4 billion plan for seven buildings along the East River. The project stalled due to a lawsuit between Solow and his business partner, the Fisher & Company real estate firm. In 2010, he settled a string of suits including a dispute with Citibank. A major art collector, he reportedly owns paintings by Balthus, Matisse, Bacon, and Kline, and sculptures by Giacometti and Moore. In February he sold a Francis Bacon painting for $33.5 million at auction.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 2003 the Stroher family sold their nearly 80% stake in Wella AG, the world's biggest professional hair care group, to Proctor & Gamble for $4 billion. As a granddaughter of Wella's founder, Sylvia Stroher received $1 billion from the sale. She and her husband, a former nurse, have a well-known collection of contemporary German art that includes works by Baselitz, Immendorff and Kiefer.

name: Billionaires
bio: It has been a sluggish year for Delek Group, the Tel Aviv-traded company from which Yitzhak Tshuva draws the bulk of his wealth. Debt negotiations in Delek Real Estate, a subsidiary, threaten to take millions straight from Tshuva's pockets. Tshuva's other major holding, Elad Properties, which boasts a portfolio containing  The Plaza Hotel, is being dragged down by a $1.24 billion property purchase in Las Vegas at the height of the market in 2007. The recession forced the company to nix its plans to develop a $7 billion hotel/casino there. It has higher hopess for oil and gas field Leviathan, controlled by a subsidiary of Delek Group, which has 16 trillion cubic feet of easily recoverable gas and 4.3 billion barrels of oil.

name: Billionaires
bio: Albert Ueltschi was raised on a farm in Kentucky and developed a passion for airplanes after listening to a radio broadcast of Charles Lindbergh's 1927 transatlantic flight. He opened a hamburger joint called "Little Hawk" to raise money for lessons and was making solo flights by age 16. Ueltschi dropped out of the University of Kentucky to give flying lessons and barnstorm around the country before becoming a pilot for Pan Am. He then founded the pilot training firm FlightSafety International which he took public in 1968. Ueltschi sold the firm in 1996 to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway for $1.5 billion in cash and stock.He is now the chairman of Orbis International, a non-profit that fights blindness in developing countries through a flying eye-surgical center.

name: Billionaires
bio: The great-grandson of Adam Opel, the auto pioneer and namesake of the German car company, Georg von Opel graduated from the University of Rhode Islands in business administration. He inherited $150 million in 1989 after his father's death and carefully invested the money in investment group Hansa AG. In 2009, he sold his share of Swiss Jelmoli Holding to real estate company Swiss Prime Site for $230 million in cash and a 9% stake in the company. Von Opel Also controls 96% of private investment firm Athris through which he has stakes in a Swiss hotel chain, a restaurant chain, a sports store and shopping centers in Russia and Algeria. A long-time Swiss resident, he and his Georg and Emily von Opel foundation fund care and education of underprivileged children and teens in developing countries.

name: Billionaires
bio: China's electric car pioneer and once country's richest man, Wang Chuanfu is facing a bumpy road. His electric car maker BYD's Hong Kong-traded shares have fallen 30% in the past year on slower-than-expected sales and poor profits. It nevertheless managed to raise $214 million in a secondary listing at the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in June.  BYD is about 10% owned by a subsidiary of Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway, which bought its stake for $230 million in 2008. Wang, who co-founded BYD with fellow billionaire Lu Xiang-yang, holds degrees from Central South University and the Beijing Non-Ferrous Research Institute.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhang chairs and owns 73% of Hong Kong-listed United Energy, a Beijing-based oil production and exploration company. In a big move offshore, United completed the purchase of assets in Pakistan from BP for $775 million last year.  Zhang also has interests in retailing, real estate and financial services, and controls Shanghai-listed Orient Group, which also owns 19% of Jinzhou Port in China.  Zhang is a board member of China Minsheng Banking, along with fellow billionaires Liu Yonghao, Lu Zhiqiang and Shi Yuzhu.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alexei Ananyev, together with brother and fellow billionaire Dmitry, started out importing computers to Russia. The brothers then set up a bank and have been active in real estate and media. Alexei heads up their IT business and general strategy. In 2011, they bought the Alfa Arbat Center, an office building in central Moscow, for $230 million. In 2010, the brothers sold their telecom company Synterra to Megafon, which is owned by billionaire Alisher Usmanov and Alfa Group, for $745 million. Despite their wealth they felt a lack of education and completed executive MBAs at the University of Chicago in 2005. Both brothers are very religious. Alexei uses his free time to assist clergymen at Moscow's Church of the Trinity. He holds the largest collection of Socialist realism-style art in Russia. At the end of 2011, he opened a museum displaying his collection.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother and fellow billionaire Alexei, Dmitry started out importing computers to Russia. The brothers then set up a bank and have been active in real estate and media. In 2011, they bought the Alfa Arbat Center, an office building in central Moscow, for $230 million. In 2010, the brothers sold their telecom company Synterra to Megafon, which is owned by billionaire Alisher Usmanov and Alfa Group, for $745 million. Despite their wealth they felt a lack of education and completed executive MBAs at the University of Chicago in 2005. Both brothers are very religious. Dmitry is a Federal Council (Senate) representative for the gas-rich polar region of Yamal. Since he became a senator in 2006, his brother Alexei handles all their businesses.

name: Billionaires
bio: Investor and property baron George Argyros began his career in the grocery business and eventually moved to real estate. His privately held Arnel & Affiliates manages 5,500 apartments and 2 million square feet of commercial space in southern California. Argyros also owns private equity outfit Westar Capital and is the leading investor in software development firm DST Systems. He is the former owner of the Seattle Mariners and a former ambassador to Spain under President George W. Bush. With his wife Julia, Argyros gave $5 million in April to an ambulatory surgery center at University of California, Irvine's Gavin Herbert Eye Institute.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Arnel & Affiliates', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: With business partner Richard Peery, Arrillaga began buying up tracts of California farmland and converting them into office parks in the 1960s. Now the Peery Arrillaga firm oversees just under 3 million square feet of office buildings and 290 acres of land in and around San Jose. Tenants include Google, which leases 15 buildings. The partners began selling off half their portfolio in 2005, including a 2006 sale of nearly 120 buildings for $1.1 billion. A Stanford alum and big booster of Stanford athletics, Arrillaga donated $100 million to the school in 2006 and has a sports and recreation center named after him. Daughter Laura teaches philanthropy at Stanford and is married to Netscape co-founder, venture capitalist Marc Andreesen

name: Billionaires
bio: Syrian-born Wharton MBA Ayman Asfari saw his net worth increase by $100 million a year after his Forbes World's Billionaires list debut thanks to a slight uptick in the share price of his oil firm Petrofac. He joined the company in 1991 when it was one plant in Tyler, Texas, then bought it out in 2001. Asfari took it public on the London Stock Exchange in 2005. Today the company is part of the FTSE 100 with offices in China, Russia and the Middle East and a market cap topping $8 billion. In 2010, Asfari spun off Petrofac's North Sea operations to form a new company, EnQuest; its market cap is $1.6 billion. When he isn't tending to his growing oil empire, he spends time in the south of France on his yacht.

name: Billionaires
bio: Rahul Bajaj chairs 86-year-old Bajaj Group, conglomerate best known for its motorcycles, produced by flagship Bajaj Auto. Run by son Rajiv, it's in gear to increase market share against rival Hero Group, which separated from Honda last year. It has been developing small car with Renault Nissan but recently unveiled prototype of a mini car that's aimed at customers of three-wheeler auto rickshaws. Insurance arm Bajaj Allianz, run by younger son, Sanjiv, has a distribution alliance with Berkshire Hathaway's Indian arm.

name: Billionaires
bio: Onetime rice trader turned media baron Subhash Chandra heads $3 billion (revenues) media giant Essel Group. His biggest asset, TV broadcaster Zee Entertainment which he started two decades ago, claims to reach 500 million viewers in 167 countries through 29 channels. It made news when it forged a distribution partnership with Rupert Murdoch's Star DEN, a onetime partner. Group's Dish TV, which has over 12 million subscribers, is now his second biggest asset. He won an International Emmy Directorate Award for 2011. Practices Vipassana, a Buddhist meditation technique.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jason Chang's Advanced Semiconductor Engineering is one of the world's largest semiconductor testing and assembly firms. The proximity of its home base in Taiwan to several of the world's semiconductor makers and designers has helped the company thrive. Mainland subsidiary Universal Scientific Industrial went public in Shanghai in January. In addition to listed real estate outfit Hung Ching Development in Taiwan, Chang also owns property in China.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chao Teng-Hsiung's Farglory Land Development ranks as one of Taiwan's largest real estate developers. Chao grew up doing farm chores and helping his father. One of his first jobs after leaving junior high-school was mixing cement at a construction company. Farglory shares have gained 10% in the past year. The company is planning to build the high-profile Taipei Dome, featuring an indoor baseball stadium, in downtown Taipei's upscale Hsinyi district. Chao also has investments in tourism, financial services and logistics.

name: Billionaires
bio: Construction and real estate tycoon A. James Clark is chairman of Clark Enterprises, which has built popular sports venues Camden Yards, FedEx Field, Miller Park and Petco Park. The firm also constructs museums, prisons, university buildings, airports and military bases. A supporter of engineering education, in 2011 he pledged $8 million for scholarships at George Washington University. He previously funded the creation of the A. James Clark School of Engineering at his alma mater, University of Maryland.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ralph Dommermuth rode the Internet boom to the top. He owns over 40% of publicly traded United Internet AG, one of the leading Internet service providers in Germany. The company also provides email services and storage and is pushing the growth of mobile applications in Germany and internationally. Dommermuth started in 1988 by offering marketing services for small software suppliers and later developed additional marketing services for clients such as IBM, Compaq and Deutsche Telekom. An avid sailor, Dommermuth and his company sponsored the United Internet Team Germany in the 2007 America's Cup.

name: Billionaires
bio: The grandson of Campbell Soup founder and condensed soup inventor John T. Dorrance, Bennett Dorrance sits on the board of Campbell Soup with his sister and fellow billionaire Mary Alice Dorrance Malone. Today Campbell Soup is the world's largest soup maker with $7.7 billion in revenues and owns other familiar brands such as Pace (salsa), V8 (vegetable juice), Pepperidge Farm (cookies, Goldfish), and Swanson (broth). Dorrance is the co-founder and managing director of DMB Associates, an Arizona real estate development firm that specializes in planned communities. Twenty-seven Dorrance Scholarships, worth $65,000 each, were awarded to 2011 Arizona high school grads who were the first members of their families to go to college.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alexander Dzhaparidze is the controlling shareholder of oilfield services concern Eurasia Drilling Company; last year he sold a 5% stake for $240 million. The geologist predicted the pent-up demand in post-Soviet Russia's deteriorating oil sector; he set up oil-services firm PetroAlliance in 1995. Eight years later, Dzhaparidze sold PetroAlliance to oil-services giant Schlumberger. A year later, with Russian oil companies consolidating and shedding assets, he teamed up with partners including former Halliburton managers to buy Lukoil's well-drilling business. He later helped orchestrate Eurasia Drilling Co.'s listing in London in 2007.

name: Billionaires
bio: Eduardo Eurnekian, a savvy son of Armenian immigrants, made his money through diverse industries. Last August, he sold his chain of airport duty-free shops to Swiss firm Dufry for $957 million. He holds an 84% stake in Aeropuertos Argentina 200, and owns private airports in Argentina, Italy, and Brazil. In 1994, he sold Argentina's largest cable TV station, Cablevision, to the U.S. firm TCI for $750 million. He has never married and has no children, but he has plenty of nephews and  great-nephews who work with him.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jayme Garfinkel controls Porto Seguro, Brazil's fourth largest insurance company and its largest auto insurance firm. Shares are down 13% over last year. That drop sliced $200 million off Garfinkel's net worth compared to 2011. Porto Seguro was founded in 1945 and purchased by the Garfinkel family in 1972. When his father died in 1978, Jayme was groomed to take over. He took the company public in 2004; it has 12,000 employees and is owns 30% by Itau Unibanco. Through Porto Seguro, Garfinkel has supported the creation and maintenance of schools for young children in favelas, or shantytowns, around Sao Paulo.

name: Billionaires
bio: The super-connected Silicon Valley star made a bundle when his business-focused social network, LinkedIn, debuted on the NYSE in May. An original member of the PayPal mafia, he co-founded LinkedIn in 2002. The Stanford and Oxford alum now looks for hot start-ups as a partner at venture capital firm Greylock Partners. He has substantial stakes in other social network powerhouses like Facebook and Zynga.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Thomas Kaplan is an Oxford-trained historian turned investor who made his fortune through natural gas exploration in 2007 and very large personal bets on gold.  He acquired major stakes in mining development firms NovaGold Resources and Gabriel Resources. His natural resources group, Electrum, also expanded quietly into silver assets. The firm had exploration success in Mexico and also acquired Idaho's Sunshine mine. Kaplan remains bullish on gold, maintaining that supply and demand factors have been creating a "perfect storm."

name: Billionaires
bio: Igor Kesaev owns a controlling stake in supermarket chain Dixi, now the third biggest retailer in Russia, thanks to its acquisition of the Victoria chain in February 2011. Amid last year's rumors that Dixi would go public, Kesaev set the record straight stating that there would be no stock offering prior to 2013. Kesaev graduated from the prestigious Moscow State Institute of International Relations. In 1991, he founded Mercury Company, which began as a food and alcohol importer and is now the biggest tobacco distributor in Russia. In 2005 Kesaev bought from former billionaire Shalva Chigirinsky a stake in oil company Sibir Energy. Because of a conflict between Chigirinsky and Sibir Energy shareholders, in the summer of 2009 Kesayev sold his stake in Sibir Energy to state-controlled Gazpromneft.

name: Billionaires
bio: Koo Bon-Moo is the chairman of LG Group, Korea's fourth largest conglomerate by assets, with more than 50 affiliates in electronics, home appliances, chemicals and telecom. He is the eldest grandson of LG Group founder Koo In-hoe and has been chairman since 1995. Part of the $400 million increase in Koo's net worth since March 2011 is due to newly included LG Group holdings owned by Koo's wife, Kim Young-Sik. LG fell behind competitors in the smartphone business, but is working to make up lost ground. Koo has stated that LG's investments in green energy will reach $7 billion by 2015. Koo's son died in an accident in the 1990s; he adopted his brother's son, Koo Gwang-mo, in 2004; he is heir apparent to head LG group. Koo loves wine: He has a collection of over 50,000 bottles stored in special wine cellar in a cave.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lev Kvetnoi is the largest shareholder in Moscow's Vnukovo Airport. He also holds shares in a number of airport service companies including an airplane repair factory. In 2011 he expanded his cement company by acquiring one of Elena Baturina's factories in southern Russia. Kvetnoi joined billionaire Alisher Usmanov's metals group, for a time serving as chief executive of an Usmanov company in 1995. Eleven years later, he sold out to Usmanov. In 2007, he used some of the capital to buy National Standard Bank, which had been affiliated with yet another Usmanov company, and NovorossCement, Russia's third-largest cement producer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Iams chief Clayton Mathile has moved from pet food to high-tech communications with his investment in video chat company ooVoo. He is also helping small business owners take their companies to the next level with his $130 million entrepreneur campus, Aileron, in central Ohio. He started as a Campbell Soup accountant and later joined Iams as general manager in 1970. He bought the firm in 1982. Mathile pushed premium pet food to high-end breeders and vets during the 1980's and ?90s. He sold Iams to Procter & Gamble for $2.3 billion in 1999 and gave employees $100 million out of his personal cut. His wife MaryAnn runs the Mathile Family Foundation, promoting education.

name: Billionaires
bio: Rubens Menin Teixeira de Souza joins Forbes World's Billionaires list for the first time based on his ownership of shares of low cost homebuilder MRV Engenharia. Revenues grew 15% in 2011 to $2.5 billion. The company does almost half its work in Sao Paulo but is active throughout Brazil. Menin founded the company in 1979. He lives in Belo Horizonte, north of Rio de Janeiro.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shares of Mario Moretti Polegato's shoemaker Geox have taken a beating over the last two years as high material costs hurt net profit. The lower share price shaved  nearly $300 million off his net worth since March 2011. A former wine maker, he cut holes in his shoe soles during a hot walk in Nevada in 1989. He then developed a membrane that let shoes breathe, but blocked dirt and water. The idea was turned down by Nike. He founded Geox in 1995 and took it public in 2004. The company makes footwear for men, women and children as well as apparel. It distributes to high-end retailers plus has company-owned stores in large markets. Moretti Polegato champions practical research and development, innovation and the importance of patents.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vadim Moshkovich's Rusagro debuted on the London Stock Exchange in spring 2011, with a $1.8 billion valuation. In the early 1990s, Moshkovich started out selling apartments, vodka, and oil. He put the capital he scraped together into land, creating Rusagro, an agro-industrial holding company that today is one of the largest sugar producers in Russia. In 2005, Moshkovich bought a former cooperative farm, not far from Moscow, that had been established after the revolution to provide fresh milk to intelligence officers. Where cows once roamed, he now plans to build a massive residential and retail development. Moshkovich also serves as a Russian Federation Council Senator.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kazuo Okada heads Universal Entertainment, formerly known as Aruze, maker of pachinko machines; company stock price is down 20% over the past year. He is currently embroiled in several lawsuits with Wynn Resorts, the casino group run by U.S. billionaire Steve Wynn, with properties in Las Vegas, Macau and Manila. Okada's Universal had a 20% stake in Wynn which was redeemed in February after the company's board found that Universal and Okada had allegedly proferred improper payments to Phillipine gamblings officials. A lawsuit was filed against Okada, Aruze USA and Universal Entertainment for breach of fiduciary duty. His Universal issued a statement that Aruze USA would file a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction "to protect its interests in Wynn Resorts and prevent the redemption of its shares."

name: Billionaires
bio: Entrepreneur Mark Pincus, founder and CEO of social media gaming company Zynga (named after his late bulldog), has seen the company's stock price swing since it began trading on the NASDAQ stock exchange in December. Zynga makes games like FarmVille, Mafia Wars and Words With Friends, that can be played on Facebook, which in February announced its own plans to go public. Pincus is known to be an early investor in Facebook and reportedly put $40,000 into the company in 2004.  Zynga recently announced a deal with Hasbro to create real-life versions of the company's online games. The San Francisco-based company is also exploring the possibility of moving into online gambling.
title: Chief Product Officer and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Zynga', 'title': 'Chief Product Officer and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Investor and hotelier John Pritzker is one of 11 members of the extended Pritzker family on Forbes World's Billionaires list.  A former executive at Hyatt Hotels, he sold his Hyatt shares in 2010 to family members. Through his San Francisco-based investment firm Geolo Partners, he bought control of California boutique hotel chain Joie de Vivre in 2010 and is expanding its holdings. Joie de Vivre merged with Thompson Hotels, a 12-hotel chain based in New York, in October 2011. Pritzker's Geolo sold Aidell's Sausage to Sara Lee in May 2011 for a reported $87 million. Geolo also bought and refurbished Carmel Valley Ranch south of Monterey, Calif. A onetime Grateful Dead fan, he funded production of a well-reviewed documentary film about activist and 60s radical Wavy Gravy in 2010. Pritzker collects photography, including works by Richard Avedon. For the past decade, the Pritzker family has been selling off assets it owns jointly.

name: Billionaires
bio: In January, it was announced that Penny Pritzker stepped down as chairman of Vi (formerly Classic Residence), Hyatt's retirement community business. She is now focusing on her investment business, PSP Capital Partners. For the past decade, Penny and her cousin Tom Pritzker have been tasked with selling assets the family owns jointly. Back in 2007, the family sold control of industrial conglomerate Marmon Holdings to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway for $4.5 billion. Penny's grandfather A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), with his sons Jay (d. 1999), Donald (d. 1972) and Robert (d. 2011), created Marmon and hotel chain Hyatt. Penny is a trustee at Stanford University, co-founder of real estate investment firm Artemis Real Estate Partners and a board member at Hyatt Hotels. Penny was a key fundraiser for Barack Obama's presidential run in 2008. Chicago Mayor Rahm Emanuel counts her among his confidants.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hair products success story Leandro Rizzuto formed Conair (formerly Continental Hair Products) with $100 he got selling a Cadillac after his family's Manhattan beauty parlor failed. The company manufactured hair rollers invented by Rizzuto's father and briefly went public in 1972, then private again in 1985 through a leveraged buyout. He has expanded the portfolio to include home appliance brands Cuisinart, Waring and hair product lines Scunci, Babyliss and Rusk. He owns the CuisinArt resort in Anguilla, complete with a hydroponic farm and a Greg Norman-designed golf course.

name: Billionaires
bio: Broadcom founder Samueli is back at his company as chief technical officer after a judge exonerated him from accusations that he'd lied to the SEC in 2008. Sameuli had resigned as chairman and admitted he played a role in alleged stock-option backdating. He met business partner and fellow billionaire Henry Nicholas at aerospace and automotive company TRW. They designed high-speed telecom chips in Nicholas' spare bedroom, founded Broadcom in 1991, and then took it public seven years later. A UCLA grad, Samueli has been a professor in the electrical engineering department since 1985. He also owns the Anaheim Ducks hockey team.
title: Chief Technology Officer and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Broadcom', 'uri': 'companies/broadcom', 'title': 'Chief Technology Officer and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Walter Scott Jr. is Level 3 Communications' chairman and a lifelong friend of Warren Buffet. In high school, he competed with the Oracle of Omaha for girls' hearts, before they became close friends. Today he sits on the board of Berkshire Hathaway, Peter Kiewit Sons' (PKS), Valmont Industries and MidAmerican Energy. The bulk of Scott's fortune comes from Berkshire Hathaway's acquisition of MidAmerican Energy in 2000. Scott studied civil engineering at Colorado State before going to work for his father's employer, Kiewit Construction (now PKS). He worked his way up to become CEO in 1979 and took the company into telecom, fiber optics and power plants before stepping down from his executive post in 1998. He now supports education, the Boy Scouts and the Omaha zoo through the Suzanne and Walter Scott Foundation. He also donated money to help build the new TD Ameritrade ballpark in Omaha.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: One of China's shrewdest investors of the past two decades, Shi Yuzhu is enjoying a rise in wealth in part well-timed purchases of bank shares. Shi is a member of the board of China Minsheng Banking, one of China's largest non-government controlled banks. He is also the chairman of  New York-listed, Shanghai-based online game company Giant Interactive. Shi holds a bachelor's degree in mathematics from Zhejiang University, and studies "software science" at Shenzhen University in 1990.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shin Dong-Bin is the younger son of Lotte Group founder Shin Kyuk-ho, who serves as chairman in chief. In February 2011 Shin Dong-Bin was promoted to chairman of the Lotte Group, known for its sweets and ice cream but active in many businesses including golf course and hotel management. Shin's share of listed department store and cinema arm Lotte Shopping accounts for more than $1.35 billion of his net worth, but a drop in the share price shaved $200 million from his total since March 2011. The Lotte group is expanding globally and has operations in 9 countries. In May Lotte department store will open its second location in Tianjin, China and plans to open additional department stores in Jakarta, Indonesia and Hanoi, Viet Nam; Lotte Mart opened its 200th global location in China, and fast food chain Lotteria entered the Southeast Asian market. In 2011 Lotte Group had revenue of nearly $65 billion, making it the 5th largest Korean conglomerate in revenue terms.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tom Siebel has made a full recovery after a 2009 elephant attack during a Tanzania safari that nearly killed him. He underwent 17 surgeries to save his leg. Siebel is chairman and CEO of C3, an energy and emissions-management company and heads First Virtual Group, which has interests in commercial real estate and agribusiness. He was an executive at Oracle before founding software firm Siebel Systems in 1993, which he sold to Oracle for $5.9 billion in 2005. His Siebel Foundation has donated $220 million to promoting education and alternative energy; it also fights methamphetamine abuse and homelessness. He hired "Black Swan" director Darren Aronofsky to shoot scary anti-meth T.V. ads.

name: Billionaires
bio: Herbert Simon is chairman and director of the Simon Property group, the largest publicly traded real estate investment trust in the United States, which is known for its interest in shopping malls. Herbert founded the company's precursor, Melvin Simon & Associates, with his brother Melvin (d. 2009) in 1960. Today the firm owns or has interests in 263 million square feet of leasable space and 392 properties in North America, Europe and Asia. Simon also owns the Indiana Pacers basketball team. A father of seven and on his third marriage, Simon is married to a former Miss Universe from Thailand.
title: Chairman Emeritus of the Board of Simon Property Group, Inc.
employment: {'name': 'Simon Property Group', 'uri': 'companies/simon-property-group', 'title': 'Chairman Emeritus of the Board of Simon Property Group, Inc.', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Anatoly Skurov is one of the four owners of coal company Sibuglemet; he serves as president. He also owns a 7.8% stake in fertilizer producer Uralkali, which merged with potassium fertilizer maker Sylvinit last year. Skurov's partners in Uralkali are Suleiman Kerimov, Filaret Galchev, Alexander Nesis and Zelimkhan Mutsoev, all billionaires. A former Soviet machine-building factory designer, Skurov worked for state-owned Rosugol, where he took part in the reform of the Russian coal industry. With Vladimir Melnichenko and Valentin Bukhtoyarov (both former billionaires), Skurov founded Sibuglemet in 1995.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kielce-born Michal Solowow owns stakes in four Polish public companies: chemicals firm Synthos, ceramics maker Rovese, real estate developer Echo Investment and flooring outfit Barlinek. The avid racecar driver started out in the late 1980s with construction company Mitex, which he sold in 2002 to French investor Eiffage. He regularly wins medals in the European Rally Championship; he won the Polish and Central European S2000 in 2011 and drove in an early season race in Sweden in January.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner Silas Chou, Stroll engineered the rise of the Tommy Hilfiger label in 1990s, building the brand into a multi-billion-dollar powerhouse. The partners' Hong Kong-based investment company, Sportswear Holdings Limited, struck gold a second time this past fall when Michael Kors Holdings made its debut on the NYSE. Shares have soared more than 75% since the IPO and show no sign of slowing down as the brand's popularity accelerates worldwide. Since Chou and Stroll purchased a reported 85% of the business in 2003, the Kors label has launched the accessible retail brands MICHAEL and KORS, delivering the brand to consumers across the globe. Other brands currently in Sportswear Holdings' portfolio include Tommy Hilfiger Asia, Karl Lagerfield, Pepe Jeans and Hackett. A driving and racing enthusiast, Stroll collects vintage McLarens and Ferraris and is the owner of Canada's Circuit Mont-Tremblant.

name: Billionaires
bio: Glen Taylor's Taylor Corp. does commercial printing, packaging and marketing; it prints yearbooks, training manuals, clothing tags and gift cards. He owns farmland in Iowa and Minnesota and sells liquefied, pasteurized eggs to food companies and restaurants. He is also working to find a permanent solution to hearing loss and invested in Envoy, a micro-device implanted deep within the ear that received FDA approval in 2010. Taylor is the majority owner of pro basketball's Minnesota Timberwolves, serves on the board of directors of Imation Corp., a data storage and security company, and is a former Minnesota state senator.

name: Billionaires
bio: Billboard and hotels magnate Dean White opened a $450 million development in Indianapolis in February with a kickoff celebration featuring Diana Ross. The mega-complex is located next to Lucas Oil Field, home of the NFL Colts, and has five hotels including a 1,005-room JW Marriott, that chain's largest property. White took over his father's billboard business in 1946 and plowed profits into building a hotel empire. He later sold the signage operation for $960 million to Chancellor Media Corp. In 2006 he flipped 100 hotels to BET founder Robert Johnson for $1.7 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Suleyman Kamil Yazici laid the foundation for the Anadolu Group, one of Turkey's largest industrial groups, in the 1950's together with his partner Izzet Ozilhan; now Yazici controls the group with fellow billionaire Tuncay Ozilhan who is Chairman. The group's beverage company, Anadolu Efes, formed a strategic alliance with brewer SABMiller in October; SABMiller will own 24% of Anadolu Efes while Efes will take over SABMiller's operations in Russia and Ukraine. Anadolu is also growing its energy ventures via partnerships. The group joined with the Dogus and Dogan Group to build the Aslancik Dam and Hydroelectric Plant which is expected to be up and running by 2014; other plant build outs are on track including a $150 million investment in Georgia. Yazici has a book titled "Common Sense" where he sums up his memoirs; his start: he worked in his father's little grocery store in Istanbul and learned how to trade as a boy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhang Zhidong, who also goes by Tony Zhang, is co-founder and chief technology officer at  Shenzhen-based Tencent, one of the  world's 10 most popular websites and also one of China's largest by market capitalization (about $47 billion). Its  stock has edged down amid global declines in equities, trimming Ma's wealth.  Tencent's overall business has been growing steadily on the back of games such as League of Legends and its popular QQ messaging service  It holds minority stakes in movie and television producer Huayi Brothers Media Group of Beijing, online travel service provider eLong and security software company Kingsoft. He has a bachelor's degree in computers from Shenzhen University and a master's degree in computer application and system structure from South China University of Technology.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kostyantin Zhevago is having a tough year. The stock price of his iron ore producer Ferrexpo is down 35% over the past year and his bank is struggling with a large loan portfolio. His party's leader, Yulia Tymoshenko, was jailed last fall and Zhevago, a parliamentary deputy in opposition to President Yanukovich's Party of Regions, is mulling moving operations to London. Zhevago is a soccer fan; he owns FC Vorskla football.

name: Billionaires
bio: It's been a rough stretch for Zhu Yicai,  chairman of pork processor China Yurun, whose Hong Kong-traded shares have been hit by fears of accounting irregularities and fallout from a Hong Kong magazine report that company's pig farms in Henan and Anhui provinces were empty. (The sites are owned by Zhu personally and not Yurun.) Ongoing safety worries about Chinese meat haven't helped. The resulting 54% drop in Yurun's stock price in the past 12 months has pushed Zhu's net worth down by $700 million since last year. He worked in shipping before founding business with wife Wu Xueqin in 1993.

name: Billionaires
bio: Anita Zucker inherited her fortune from late husband Jerry Zucker (d. 2008), whose $3.6 billion (estimated sales) InterTech Group is a diversified chemical manufacturer that makes products like sealing devices, gaskets, and woven and nonwoven fabrics. She serves as chairman and CEO. She also owns the Carolina Ice Palace and half of the Carolina Stingrays, a minor league hockey team. A registered Republican, Zucker publicly endorsed Mitt Romney in January's South Carolina primary.

name: Billionaires
bio: S. Daniel Abraham struck it rich with the Slim-Fast line of diet supplements, but not before trying his luck with a few failed products, including itch cream and weight-loss gum. The Long Island-born entrepreneur served in the U.S. Army in World War II, then joined his uncle's medical supplies company. He created Slim-Fast in 1977, took it public two years later and private again in 1987. He sold the outfit to Unilever for $2.3 billion in 2000. Today Abraham is involved in Middle East peacemaking efforts. He founded the S. Daniel Abraham Center for Middle East Peace and is the author of a book called "Peace is Possible."
organization: S. Daniel Abraham Center for Middle East Peace
title: Chairman
employment: {'name': 'S. Daniel Abraham Center for Middle East Peace', 'title': 'Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Consumer goods tycoon Joao Alvez de Queiroz Filho, known as Junior, controls Hypermarcas SA, which manufactures and sells the largest portfolio of consumer brands in Brazil, including food, drugs, cleaning supplies, and beauty and personal hygiene products. The company has been struggling with debt and shares have fallen 40% since February 2011. His net worth is $300 million higher than a year ago due to new information on Queiroz's holdings in a variety of other companies, including a sliver of Burger King (which was bought in a 2010 transaction led by fellow Brazilian billionaire Jorge Paulo Lemann) and the Hotel Nacional in Rio de Janeiro. Queiroz began building his fortune with Arisco, a cleaning product business he started with his father in 1969. Arisco became the biggest in Brazil's food sector and was sold to Bestfoods for $760 million in 2000. Two years later Queiroz created Hypermarcas after buying steel wool companies throughout Brazil. He owns an extensive Brazilian art collection and a Falcon 2000 private plane.

name: Billionaires
bio: Coal industry veteran Kiki Barki took his Harum Energy public in October 2010 and then, in a surprising move, sold a 10% stake at a 5% discount to market price last year. He still retains a majority stake in the firm, run by his son Lawrence, who is its president commissioner. Barki got his engineering degree at Beijing University; he still visits China often and is a supporter of increased China-Indonesia trade. Hobbies are reading, swimming and jogging.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dubin's Highbridge Capital had a rough go of it in 2011, a year in which the average hedge fund lost 5%. The firm's flagship beat the competition slightly, returning -4.2% net of fees, while the firm's long/short equity fund fell 12.63% after fees. Highbridge's Statistical Opportunities fund was a winner however, achieving a 3.48% net return. Dubin founded Highbridge Capital, named for the oldest bridge in New York City, with childhood friend Henry Swieca in 1992. Together the Washington Heights natives built one of the world's premier alternative asset management firms. The pair sold a majority stake to JPMorgan Chase in 2004 for $1.3 billion; while Swieca departed in 2009, Dubin remains on board as Chairman and CEO. Highbridge has approximately $26 billion under management. Dubin and his wife, Eva, herself an MD, recently established the Dubin Breast Center at the Mount Sinai Medical Center, a state-of-the-art, comprehensive breast cancer treatment center. Dubin also serves on the board of the Robin Hood Foundation, an organization committed to fighting poverty in New York City.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Computer scientist Judy Faulkner got her start in the department of psychiatry at the University of Wisconsin in Madison, when faculty members asked her to develop a program to track patients. It became the basis for Epic Systems' electronic health record. Faulkner, who keeps a low profile, founded Epic (originally called Human Services Computing) in 1979. The company, which shuns marketing, grew word of mouth. Faulkner's big break came in 2003, when HMO giant Kaiser Permanente picked the company to implement a massive installation of electronic health records. Her customers now include big hospitals and prestigious academic centers, such as Cleveland Clinic, Johns Hopkins, and Cedars-Sinai.

name: Billionaires
bio: Author of 8 finance-related books, 4 of which have been New York Times bestsellers, Ken Fisher has written a column for Forbes for 27 years. His money management outfit, Fisher Investments, which he founded in 1979, has just over $45 billion in assets under management. Longtime Californian, who is fed up with the state, completed construction of a 150,000 square foot class A commercial office building in Camas, Washington last year and is moving in employees.  Fisher who spends a lot of time with his family in the woods in summer says visits to Yellowstone National Park years ago helped point his youngest son toward becoming a planetary geophysicist.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bargain bank-buying king Gerald J. Ford saw his fortune bolstered $300 million this year thanks to a new investment in Pacific Bank Corp. His Ford Financial Fund bought and recapitalized the flailing California bank in 2010. The Texas farmer's son bought his first bank for $1.2 million in 1975 and later sold it for $80 million. With fellow billionaire Ron Perelman, Ford sold California's Golden State Bancorp to Citigroup in 2002 for $6 billion in stock. He survived the Citigroup meltdown in 2008 by hedging his shares with options. If Ford seems to flip banks, he does the opposite with luxury homes, collecting residences in sought-after spots Dallas, Manhattan, the Hamptons, and Beverly Hills. He also owns a working ranch in New Mexico and thoroughbred farm in Kentucky.
title: Managing Member
employment: {'name': 'Ford Financial Fund', 'title': 'Managing Member', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Gong Hongjia has founded or invested in more than a dozen companies in the past decade, including Techsun, the largest radio maker in China, and Hikvision Digital Technology, which has since become the country's largest supplier of video surveillance products. Hikvision's sales in the first nine months of 2011 rose 44% from a year earlier to $539 million. Gong also owns a stake in Watchdata System, a smart card manufacturer that is expected to go public this year. Wachdata does business in more than 50 countries.  In an interview in 2011 with Forbes China, the licensed Chinese-language edition of Forbes, Gong said the most successful investments in his career have been with school friends.

name: Billionaires
bio: Saad Hariri lost his post as prime minister of Lebanon last year after Hezbollah cabinet members walked out on him for refusing to reject the findings of a tribunal implicating members of the Islamist group in his father's murder. He now leads the opposition against Prime Minister Najib Mikati, a fellow billionaire, but has been living mostly in Saudi Arabia, reportedly for security reasons. He's chairman and chief executive of Saudi Oger, the source of the family's wealth. A recent ski injury temporarily slowed down his relentless tweets against the Syrian dictatorship.

name: Billionaires
bio: London resident Xiu Li Hawken is a director and the biggest shareholder of Renhe Commercial Holdings, a Hong Kong-listed  Chinese real estate firm run by her brother Dai Yongge. As of last June, Renhe had 14 projects under construction in 11 cities. Reportedly, Dai family-controlled China Shouguang Agricultural, an agricultural market operator, is looking to go public after selling a stake to private equity firm Blackstone. A Chinese literature grad,  Hawken  is chairman of Chinese soccer club Shaanxi Renhe Commercial Chanba.

name: Billionaires
bio: Huang Yi is chairman of auto distributor Zhongsheng Group, and has thrived on an increasingly well-off China's love affair with autos.  He co-founded auto dealership group Zhongsheng Group in 1998 in Dalian with fellow billionaire Li Guoqiang and took it public in Hong Kong in March 2010 in an IPO that raised $369 million. Zhongsheng sells Porsche, Lamborghini, Lexus and Toyota brands at the relatively healthy high end of China's market.  Huang is a member of the Lexus China Dealer Council and the National Dealer Advisory Council of the FAW Toyota Motor Sales. He holds a bachelor's degree in economics from Xiamen University.

name: Billionaires
bio: Saleh Kamel runs Dallah Albaraka, a conglomerate with interests in banking, real estate development and food production. His much touted plan for a global Islamic megabank hasn't materialized yet. Kamel is selling off his media assets; his Arab Radio & Television network has been losing viewers.

name: Billionaires
bio: The low-profile billionaire made his fortune with discount cigarettes and today is among the 10 largest landowners in the U.S. A farmer's son, Kelley founded Commonwealth Brands. He left the advertising budget sparse and outperformed big brands by keeping prices low. He sold the company for $1 billion in 2001. His 1.7 million acres extend from New Mexico to Florida and Texas.

name: Billionaires
bio: New England Patriots owner Robert Kraft suffered a tough break in February, losing in the Super Bowl to the New York Giants. It was the team's second loss to the Giants in sports' biggest game in four years. Kraft bought the Patriots in 1994 for a then-record $172 million; it is now worth almost $1.4 billion. His observant Jewish father was a dressmaker in Boston's Chinatown who wanted his son to be a Rabbi, but Kraft went to Harvard Business School instead. He eventually joined packing firm Rand-Whitney, before buying that company outright. Today, the Kraft Group owns real estate, paper companies, private equity, the New England Revolution soccer team, and Gillette Stadium (which he built with $350 million of his own money). Kraft also sponsors an American football league in Israel. His wife of 47 years, Myra, a well-known philanthropist, passed away in July 2011.
title: Chairman & CEO
employment: {'name': 'The Kraft Group', 'title': 'Chairman & CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Angela Leong is Macau gaming tycoon Stanley Ho's fourth "wife" (they never officially married) and mother of five of his kids. When her 90-year-old husband divided his assets among family members that include 16 surviving children from four women, Leong's effective stake in SJM Holdings rose to about 11%. Although the public feud over control of Ho's wealth was said to be resolved with a deed of settlement in March, questions still linger as to how long the truce will last. A former dance instructor from Guangzhou, Leong took over the role of managing director of the gaming concern in late 2010. She's also a second-term lawmaker in Macau.

name: Billionaires
bio: Diamond king Lev Leviev will face a former partner, Arkady Gaydamak, in a London court in May over charges that Leviev allegedly did not pay his commissions and dividends from the export of Angolan diamonds since 2004; Gaydamak also filed a complaint against Leviev with the Israeli police. Leviev has stated he will respond to charges in May. In the meantime, Leviev is focused on rebuilding his real estate holding company Africa Israel; the company's stock price has further declined 50% over the past year. In October the firm sold New York's MetLife Clock Tower building to Marriot International. On the upside, Leviev sold a 18% stake in Angola's Catoca diamond mine to China's Sonangol International for a reported $400 million. Leviev was born in Uzbekistan; his Lubavitcher Jewish family fled to Israel in 1971. He made his name undercutting the De Beers diamond cartel, striking his own deals with diamond-producing countries like Russia and Angola. He is president of the Federation of Jewish Communities in Russia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former stockbroker Peter Lim is one of Singapore's savviest investors. Since selling his stake in palm oil giant Wilmar two years ago, he's been busy making deals. He bought health care chain Thomson Medical and took it private last year. Together with Kuok Khoon Hong, he picked up a minority stake in property developer Yanlord Land owned by fellow billionaire Zhong Sheng Jian. Last August, he invested in British sports car maker McLaren Automotive, joining its board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hong Kong-born developer Vincent Lo is famous in Shanghai for developing one of the city's modern landmarks, the Xintiandi entertainment district. Last year his flagship, Shui On Land, sold part of its latest "Tiandi" project, in Foshan, to Mitsui Fudosan of Japan. The company also received a $570 million loan for another big project, Hongqiao Tiandi, next to Hongqiao International Airport and Hongqiao Railway Station in Shanghai. Lo-controlled SOCAM opened up a Four Seasons Place hotel in Shanghai's Lujiazui financial district. Born into an entrepreneurial family, Lo first started building his business in China in 1985, one of the first in Hong Kong's building sector to do so. He remarried a former Miss Hong Kong in 2008.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mohamed Mansour and his brothers are the biggest sellers of GM vehicles in the world. Strong sales in their Caterpillar business throughout Africa, Russia and Iraq are making up for a slump in Egypt. Their shares in the country's second biggest real estate developer, Palm Hills, plunged following accusations of state land misappropriation in March?but the charges have since been cleared. Other interests include the largest supermarket chain in Egypt, and the Philip Morris franchise which is experiencing a big jump in sales of Marlboro cigarettes to stressed-out Egyptians.

name: Billionaires
bio: Joe Mansueto used $80,000 in savings to start Morningstar in 1984 out of his Chicago apartment. He took the financial research firm public in 2005 and can now afford to give back: he joined Bill Gates and Warren Buffett's Giving Pledge in December, promising to donate more than half his fortune. A library in his name has just been completed at his alma mater, the University of Chicago, thanks to a $25 million gift. His fortune got a $500 million boost this year thanks to Morningstar's stock rise. Mansueto's other assets include the Standard & Poor's fund data business, U.K. media and investor-relations site Hemscott and magazines Inc. and Fast Company.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Morningstar Inc.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Hoteliers Richard and brother Bill Marriott donated roughly $1.5 million this year to Restore Our Future, the group backing Republican candidate Mitt Romney. Romney served on the board of Marriott from 1993 until 2002, and again from 2009 until 2011. Richard Marriott runs Host Hotels, the Marriott spin-off, and has done so for nearly 20 years. Host operates 121 hotels and properties, and is the largest lodging real estate investment trust in the world. The Marriotts' father, J.W. Marriott Sr, opened a root beer stand in Washington D.C. in 1927. He expanded into catering, restaurants and hotels, and opened his first hotel, the Twin Bridges, in 1957. It became the Marriott hotel empire. Richard and his brother Bill split up the company amid bondholder protests in 1993, but Richard still has a stake in Marriott International, run by Bill. The Marriotts are observant Mormons.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dimitry Mazepin heads up mineral fertilizer company Uralchem. The Minsk native attended Minsk Suvorov Military School; in the late 80s he served in Afghanistan as an interpreter. Mazepin graduated from Moscow State Institute of International Relations. Until mid-2000 he worked as a manager with TNK and Sibur, and was deputy chairman of the Russian Federal Property Fund. In 2004, Mazepin founded his own company, which bought up stocks of chemical plants. Later, these assets were merged into Uralchem, which scrapped an IPO in 2010. Together with billionaire Oleg Deripaska, Mazepin is a member of the Supervisory Board of the All-Russian Swimming Federation. In 2012 he will also be sponsor of the Swimming Federation of Belarus.

name: Billionaires
bio: Andrei Molchanov is the largest shareholder in Russian property developer LSR Group. He's also chairman of CIS Affairs in the upper house of Russia's parliament. After receiving his PhD in economics from St. Petersburg State University, Molchanov started a residential construction business with a classmate in 1994. During Russian privatization, he bought one of the largest city-owned construction firms, Lenstroireconstruktsiya, or LSR; he listed its shares in 2007. Last year, Molchanov's step-father, Yuri Molchanov, stepped down from his post as vice-governor of St. Petersburg after a change in the city's governor.

name: Billionaires
bio: Welsh-born venture capitalist Michael Moritz was an early investor in Google, Yahoo and PayPal. He also invested in LinkedIn, which debuted on the New York Stock Exchange in May. A partner at Sequoia Capital in Menlo Park, Calif., he helped orchestrate Google's pending $700 million acquisition of flight data company ITA Software, flipped Zappos to Amazon for $1.2 billion in 2009 and took debit-card company Green Dot public in 2010. Moritz maintains board seats at LinkedIn, 24/7 Customer, Aricent, Gamefly, Klarna, Kayak.com and WeatherBug. A self-proclaimed bookworm, he owns a personal library containing thousands of books.
title: Investor
