name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounder of Indian software bellwether Infosys, N.R.Narayana Murthy, retired as chairman last August when he turned 65, after 30 years with company. He remains chairman emeritus and holds minority stake. Created stir when he said that the quality of students at the elite Indian Institutes of Technology, where he'd studied, has deteriorated. He and wife Sudha co-own venture capital firm Catamaran. They are big donors to Cornell University where their son Rohan studied.

name: Billionaires
bio: Or Wai Sheun's net worth tumbled $300 million along with the shares of his 72% family-owned flagship, Kowloon Development. He also controls real estate developer Polytec Asset Holdings, a Hong Kong-traded subsidiary of Kowloon Development. Wife Ng Chi Man, who shares the fortune, and son Or Pui Kwan are board members.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alexander Ponomarenko and partner Alexander Skorobogatko sold a stake in Novorossiysk Commercial Sea Port, the biggest in Russia, in January 2011 to state-owned Transneft and its affiliate Summa Capital, earning $1 billion each. With money to spend, in March 2011, Ponomarenko purchased a lavish holiday complex on Russia's southern black sea coast, nicknamed "Putin's Palace," for $350 million; the 8,000 sq. meters of the complex leased for $1 million a month that summer. Ponomarenko graduated from Simferopol State University and earned a doctorate in economics at the Russian State Academy of Management. With Skorobogatko, he set up a small perfume factory in Ukraine, then founded Russian General Bank in Moscow, which served the Novorossiysk Sea Trading Port. After the 1998 crisis the partners began buying up shares in stevedoring companies that were working at the port and combined them to form one holding company. The firm, Novorossiysk Commercial Sea Port, went public in 2007, resulting in a windfall of $1 billion for the partners. In 2008 the partners sold 20% of their holdings to Arkady Rotenberg, a powerful businessman who does judo with Russian Prime Minister Vladimir Putin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daniel Pritzker is one of 11 members of the extended Pritzker family on Forbes World's Billionaires list, and a scion of the wealthy Chicago family. He made a silent film, "Louis" about the life of Louis Armstrong, which was released to critical praise in 2010. A second jazz-infused film, "Bolden," is planned for release by 2012. For the past decade, the family has been selling off assets it owns jointly. Back in 2007, the Pritzkers sold industrial conglomerate Marmon Holdings to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway for $4.5 billion. Daniel's grandfather, A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), with his sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert (d. 2011), created Marmon and hotel chain Hyatt.

name: Billionaires
bio: Property baron Chandru Raheja's privately held K. Raheja Corp., headquartered in Mumbai, is among country's leading developers. It has built, among much else, IT parks, hotels, malls and hypermarkets across the country. Mindspace, a 5-million-square-foot commercial complex, is currently under construction in the satellite city of Navi Mumbai. A new mall and Marriott hotel are due to open in Bangalore. Only listed company in group is retail chain Shoppers Stop. He keeps a low profile.

name: Billionaires
bio: Paul Ramsay's decision to start a private hospital in 1964 was visionary; 48 years later his listed Ramsay Healthcare has capitalized on ageing populations in Australia and Europe to create a 117-hospital empire with a market value of $3.8 billion. Ramsay is the biggest shareholder and the company's chair. Ramsay's other major asset is a stake in regional television group Prime Media, which returned to profit last year after a difficult period. He also owns luxury property in the exclusive resort village of Byron Bay and stake in A-League soccer team Sydney FC. He donated $300,000 to actor Kevin Spacey's foundation in late 2011.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shin Dong-Joo is the eldest son of Lotte Group founder Shin Kyuk-ho and the vice chairman of Lotte Holdings. He is also the vice president of Lotte Group in Japan and lives in Tokyo. His stake in listed department store arm Lotte Shopping accounts for some $1.3 billion of his fortune. A drop in the value of Lotte Shopping stock knocked $200 million of his net worth since March 2011. Lotte Group is known for its sweets and ice cream but operates in several sectors, including golf course and hotel management.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alexander Skorobogatko and partner Alexander Ponomarenko sold a stake in Novorossiysk Commercial Sea Port, the biggest in Russia, in January 2011 to state-owned Transneft and its affiliate Summa Capital, earning $1 billion each. The graduate of Slavyansk State Pedagogical Institute founded Russian General Bank with Ponomarenko, which served the Novorossiysk Sea Trading Port. After the 1998 crisis the partners began buying up shares in stevedoring companies that were working at the port and combined them to form one holding company. The firm, Novorossiysk Commercial Sea Port, went public in 2007, resulting in a windfall of $1 billion for the partners. In 2008 the partners sold 20% of their holding to Arkady Rotenberg, a powerful businessman who does judo with Russian Prime Minister Vladimir Putin. Skorobogatko has served as an elected deputy since 2002, barring him from participating in the business. He was re-elected to the State Duma for a third term in December 2011.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jerry Speyer is done licking his wounds from the disastrous Stuyvesant Town and Carr America deals. His real estate empire is back to doing what it does best: buying and selling prime office real estate globally. It has deals in Virginia, London, Berlin and China, where it is developing a $2.5 billion urban complex on outskirts of Shanghai. His eldest son, Rob, continues to gain more prominence at the firm. Jerry is a power broker in Manhattan, sitting on the boards of the Museum of Modern Art and the New York Yankees. A former yo-yo champion, he wears a Mickey Mouse watch to work every day.

name: Billionaires
bio: Thanks to billionaire Woods Staton, the Golden Arches is fast becoming as ubiquitous in Latin America as Starbucks in Seattle. After paying the mega-burger-slinger $700 million, Staton's company Arcos Dorados (which means "Golden Arches" in Spanish) holds the rights to operate McDonald's restaurants and owns 1,775 in 20 countries and territories in Latin America and the Carribbean, from Mexico to Ecuador to St. Thomas in the U.S. Virgin Islands. In June 2011, Staton added another jewel to his portfolio, winning the rights to operate in Trinidad and Tobago. The burger king should feel at home in any of his restaurants; he speaks English, Spanish, and Portuguese. Staton, whose grandfather Albert Staton founded Coca-Cola bottler Panamerican Beverages, became a billionaire in April 2011, when Arcos Dorados debuted on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock price has dipped just slightly since, and with it Staton's fortune by about $100 million, from $1.8 billion to $1.7 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Went into trade during his years as a student in Moscow Institute of Electronics Technology. Together with students of the same year in the beginning of 90s imported wholesale purchases of home appliances and electronics from Singapore. This business is still in operation. Trading house Absolut is the biggest wholesale trader of home appliances in Russia with sales of $1.5b in 2011.
Svetakov's most successful deal to the day is the sale of Absolut-bank. A year prior to the crisis of 2008 Belgian KBC Group bought the bank from Svetakov and partners for $983m. Svetakov used the cash he received to buy land for agricultural needs near Moscow, to invest in construction of offices for lease and economy class appartments.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wei Ing-Chou is chairman and CEO of Hong Kong-listed beverage firm Tingyi (Cayman Islands) Holding, also known for its instant noodles. Tingyi's "Master Kong" brand is one of the best-known and easily recognizable in China by its chubby chef logo. Sales in the nine months to September were up nearly 7% to $2.2 billion.  Wei is one of four Taiwan-born brothers, along with Ying-Chiao, Yin-Chun and Yin-Heng, to get most of his fortune from Tingyi. Its roots go back to 1958, when the father started an industrial oil business. The family's holding company, Ting Hsin International, last year announced plans to partner with Pepsi in China. Other interests include real estate in the mainland and Taiwan, including the iconic Taipei 101 , one of the world's tallest structures. The Weis also own the Dicos fried-chicken chain, which has more than 1,200 stores in the mainland.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wei Yin-Chun is one of four brothers along with Ing-Chou, Ying-Chiao and Yin-Heng from Taiwan's Wei family to derive his fortune from Hong Kong-listed Tingyi (Cayman Islands), ), also known for its instant noodles. Tingyi's "Master Kong" brand is one of the best-known and easily recognizable in China by its chubby chef logo. Sales in the nine months to September were up nearly 7% to $2.2 billion. He's chairman of Wei-Chuan Foods, a Taiwan beverage company acquired by the family in 1998. The family's majority-owned holding company, Ting Hsin International, last year announced plans to partner with Pepsi in China. Other interests include real estate in the mainland and Taiwan, including the iconic Taipei 10, one of the world's tallest structures. The Weis also own the Dicos fried-chicken chain, which has more than 1,200 stores in the mainland.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wei Yin-Heng is one of four brothers along with Ing-Chou, Ying-Chiao and Yin-Chun from Taiwan's Wei family to get his fortune largely from Hong Kong-listed beverage firm Tingyi (Cayman Islands). also known for its instant noodles. Tingyi's "Master Kong" brand is one of the best-known and easily recognizable in China by its chubby chef logo. Sales in the nine months to September were up nearly 7% to $2.2 billion. The youngest of the four, Yin-Heng is leading the family's retail expansion in China. Investments by family's Ting Hsin International include Japanese convenience store chain Family Mart 's Shanghai operation, and  noodle-chain, Master Kong Chef's Table.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wei Ying-Chiao is an executive director of Hong Kong-listed beverage maker Tingyi (Cayman Islands), also known for its instant noodles. Tingyi's "Master Kong" brand is one of the best-known and easily recognizable in China by its chubby chef logo. Sales in the nine months to September were up nearly 7% to $2.2 billion. He's one of four Taiwan-born brothers, along with Ing-Chou, Yin-Chun and Yin-Heng, to get most of fortune from Tingyi.  Its roots go back to 1958, when the father started an industrial oil business. The second oldest, he overseas the family's real estate business. The family's majority-owned holding company, Ting Hsin International, last year announced plans to partner with Pepsi in China. Other interests include real estate in the mainland and Taiwan, including the iconic Taipei 10, one of the world's tallest structures. The Weis also own the Dicos fried-chicken chain, which has more than 1,200 stores in the mainland.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 2011, publicity-shy property baron John Whittaker won a bidding war with fellow billionaire Mohamed Al Fayed for Pinewood, the famous UK film studios where the James Bond and Harry Potter films were shot. Until recently, he owned one of the best-known buildings in Britain, Manchester's massive Trafford Centre shopping complex. He sold out to Capital Shopping Centres in November in return for a 23% stake in the publicly traded mall firm. His Peel Group is behind MediaCity UK, a massive development in the northern English city of Salford that will serve as the BBC's new headquarters. Whittaker lives quietly on a private estate called Billown Mansion on the Isle of Man, a self-governing British dependency in the Irish Sea.

name: Billionaires
bio: Aras Agalarov, one of the first traders of luxury brands on the Russian market, recently left the luxury business, transferring the rights to develop brands including Lanvin, Chloe, Emanuel Ungaro, Nina Ricci and Sergio Rossi to competitors Mercury and Bosco di Ciliegi. In summer 2010, his trade fair operator and retailer, Crocus, opened the first Vegas Mall in Moscow which features over 300 shops (including Starbucks) and an amusement park. Agalarov is also building in Vladivostok in anticipation of the APEC summit scheduled for September 2012. He got his start trading computers, but saw that trade fairs had more business potential. In 1988 he established Crocus, which became one of the country's largest trade-fair operators. He opened the Crocus Inter store, which grew into a retail company with malls offering housewares, and the luxurious Crocus City Mall, the "city of boutiques." Agalarov is seen as the unofficial representative of the Azerbaijani diaspora in Russia. In 2006 his son, Emin, married the daughter of Azerbaijan's president, Ilkham Aliyev. He also publishes Baku magazine, which is edited by daughter-in-law Leyla Aliyeva.

name: Billionaires
bio: Abdulla Al Futtaim owns huge conglomerate Al Futtaim Group. It operates Ikea, Toys "R" Us and Marks & Spencer franchises; sells Toyota and Honda vehicles, and co-owns the Middle East's largest privately-funded urban community, Dubai Festival City. Plans to open residential and commercial complex Cairo Festival City were delayed because of the turmoil in Egypt. In October 2011, the group began construction of another grand real estate project in Qatar called Doha Festival City.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bassam Alghanim and his brother Kutayba have been locked in a nasty fight over the division of assets inherited mostly from their father, including Kuwaiti conglomerate Alghanim Industries and a stake in Gulf Bank. Alghanim is no longer involved in the family holding which sells General Motors vehicles, among other things. He lives in Los Angeles, and has sued his brother in the U.S. alleging that Kutayba and his son Omar have hacked into his email to gain insight into his affairs. In October, a U.K. judge found two individuals liable for hacking into Bassam Alghanim's email on what looked like orders from Kutayba and his son. In the U.S. a judge has put the case on hold, pending arbitration in Kuwait.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kutayba Alghanim and his brother Bassam have been locked in a nasty fight over the division of assets inherited mostly from their father, including Kuwaiti conglomerate Alghanim Industries and a stake in Gulf Bank. The feud intensified when Kutayba's son Omar, a Harvard MBA grad, took over the reigns of the family holding company, which sells General Motors vehicles, among other things. Bassam has accused Kutayba and Omar in U.S. courts of allegedly hacking into his email to gain the upper hand in negotiations. In October, a U.K. judge stated that Kutayba and Omar may have orchestrated the hacking. In the U.S. a judge put the case on hold, pending arbitration in Kuwait.

name: Billionaires
bio: Igor Altushkin is the founder and largest shareholder of RMK, Russia's third-largest copper producer, though in spring 2011 he sold a 25% stake to Ruslan Baysarov. After the deal, the two purchased the Elegest coal field, the biggest asset held by former head of Mezhprombank Sergei Pugachev. In fall 2009, with Iskander Makhmudov's UGMK, Altushkin bought a controlling stake in Chelyabinsk Zinc Factory, the largest zinc producer in Russia. He started out in the early 1990s trading scrap metals. In 1997, Altushkin established Uralelectromed-Vtortsvetmet, which became the main supplier of scrap and copper to UGMK. Altushkin also purchased Madonna's former home in London.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mr. Bollore is best known as a corporate raider who snaps up large stakes in distressed companies, but lately, his Bollore group has entered the electric car industry. He started as a bank trainee at Edmond de Rothschild. He has targeted advertising agencies, and has built up a stake in French agency Havas, where he demanded board seats, gutted management and made himself chairman. He also owns shares in Aegis Group, the British media and market research concern. Eclectic portfolio includes African shipping, Asian palm-oil plantations, plastics. Group is developing an electric car called the BlueCar. Hosted close friend French President Sarkozy on his yacht for a post-election holiday off Malta in 2007. Has a collection of 1,000 comic books.

name: Billionaires
bio: This Basel art fair regular owns a multimillion-dollar art collection, including pieces by Willem De Kooning, John Carmichael, Picasso and Warhol. Braman started in business as a research analyst for a liquor company. He co-founded vitamin retailer Keystone Discount Stores, merged it with Philadelphia Pharmaceuticals in 1967, cashed out for $1 million a year later, and moved to Florida. The former owner of the Philadelphia Eagles bought a Cadillac dealership in Tampa in 1972, and today owns 17 car dealerships in Florida and Colorado. Braman developed a new auto mechanics training program for Miami-Dade graduates at one of his service centers in midtown Miami. Braman has recently been focusing his energies locally, fighting against casinos in downtown Miami and arguing against a new Marlins stadium.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cargill heir Austen Cargill is one of seven billionaire relatives who hold a majority of Cargill, the largest private company in the U.S. Cargill makes money in all areas of food production from animal feed, meat, and crops to commodity trading and risk management. The company divested itself of its stake in fertilizer maker Mosaic in 2011. William Cargill, the son of a Scottish sea captain, founded the Iowa grain storage business after the Civil War. Will's son-in-law John MacMillan took control in 1909, and no family member has run the company since Whitney stepped down as chief executive in 1995.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cargill heir James Cargill is one of seven billionaire relatives who hold a majority of Cargill, the largest private company in the U.S. Cargill makes money in all areas of food production from animal feed, meat, and crops to commodity trading and risk management. The company divested itself of its stake in fertilizer maker Mosaic in 2011. William Cargill, the son of a Scottish sea captain, founded the Iowa grain storage business after the Civil War. Will's son-in-law, John MacMillan, took control in 1909, and no family member has run the company since Whitney MacMillan stepped down as chief executive in 1995.

name: Billionaires
bio: Educated as a pharmacist, Jean Coutu opened his first drug store, the foundations for the Jean Coutu Group, in 1969. The company has grown to one of the largest pharmacy chains in North America, with Coutu serving as it's CEO from its founding until 2002 and then again for a brief stint from 2005 to 2007. The Jean Coutu Group is the largest shareholder in Rite Aid. In September and October, the company sold about 18 million shares of the struggling U.S. drugstore chain for a total of about $22 million.
title: Entrepreneur

name: Billionaires
bio: British media magnate, Richard Desmond, who threw in the towel on his US venture selling OK! magazine to American Media, is benefitting from the demise of Rupert Murdoch's News of the World; Desmond's Daily Express and Daily Star newspapers are doubling circulation. His TV venture is also generating income and buzz. He is now focusing on cross-media deals with advertisers across his Channel 5, newspapers and magazines like OK! and Star. Desmond is considering a move to Luton, 30 miles north of London, where he recently inaugurated a new printing press. Last September, he launched Healthy Lottery, which will donate money it earns from the sale of tickets to British healthcare charities. In January, Desmond testified before Lord Justice Leveson about his newspapers' coverage of Princess Diana and other stories; the inquiry was set up by Prime Minister David Cameron last July to examine the practices of the British press. Desmond is a high school dropout who started his first magazine, International Musician, in 1974. He built a stable of titles including at one time more than 40 adult entertainment publications, which he sold in 2004, but not before earning him the nickname "Dirty Desmond" among media insiders. He bought British newspaper group Express in 2000. For fun and charity, Desmond plays drums with his band RD Crusaders, whose other musicians include folks from The Who and Led Zeppelin. He divorced in 2010; recently celebrated his 60th birthday with his new fiancee (with whom he has a baby girl) and 500 friends.

name: Billionaires
bio: InterActive Corp (IAC) chief Barry Diller is still both behind the news and in the headlines. He's backing internet TV startup Aereo, which streams broadcast channels to subscribers' phones or tablets for $12 a month. In early March, a handful of networks sued, not amused that their content would be used this way. He's also been investing overseas this year. In September, his web dating service Match.com acquired 20% of China's online matchmaker Zhenai. In 2010, Diller's Daily Beast site merged with Newsweek magazine; IAC's stock has climbed since, boosting Diller's fortune by $300 million year on year. Diller famously started out in the mailroom at the William Morris agency after dropping out of UCLA. Worked at ABC, Paramount and Fox between 1964 and 1992; oversaw the launches of hit TV shows including Cheers and The Simpsons during this time. Started IAC in 1995; bought the Home Shopping Network two years later. He is married to fashion designer Diane von Furstenberg.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dinan's York Capital Management produced net returns of 40% in 2009 and 7.5% in 2010. Last year was a different story, as York posted negative returns for just the third time in the firm's 20-year history. York's flagship fund was down 5.93% net of fees in 2011. The Wharton and HBS grad got his start working 100-hour weeks at investment bank Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. He lost his entire life savings on Black Monday in 1987; since then he says he rarely uses debt. He founded York Capital in 1991 with $3.6 million from DLJ colleagues. One bet that put him on map: in 1993 he invested about $600,000, or roughly 5% of York's assets at the time, in Sears stock and doubled his money in six months. Dinan sold a 30% stake in York to Credit Suisse in September 2010 for $425 million. Today the firm, which he still runs, manages approximately $15 billion. Dinan serves on a number of boards, including the University of Pennsylvania and Lincoln Center. Dinan enjoys being a dad, sailing, skiing, exercising and DIY projects. He wears a hearing aid because he lost much of his hearing as an infant after being given the antibiotic streptomycin for a fever.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: The vice-chairman of oil sands miner Canada Natural Resources, N. Murray Edwards has long warned of the growing dependence of Canadian oil and gas companies on the U.S. market. That fear was realized in January 2012, when President Obama rejected plans to construct Keystone XL, a gigantic oil pipeline planned to transport Canadian crude oil from Alberta through the U.S. to Texas' Gulf Coast. Edwards also maintains stakes in hockey team Calgary Flames as well as ski resorts in the Canadian Rockies. Along with Bill Gates, Edwards has invested in Carbon Engineering, a start-up focused on developing technologies to capture and harness carbon dioxide from the atmosphere.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lindsay Fox owns Australia's biggest privately owned logistics company: Linfox. The company has been hammered this year by the east coast's declining manufacturing base and a series of damaging floods in key areas. However, Fox is aggressively expanding into Western Australia to take advantage of the mining boom and is building up his property portfolio. Fox left his school for academically gifted boys at 16 to become a truck driver like his father. He bought his first truck at 19. He is a director on the board of Premier Investments, the retail investment company owned by friend and fellow billionaire Solomon Lew.

name: Billionaires
bio: With the exclusive rights to import and distribute Toyota vehicles in Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas, Louisiana, and Mississippi, Friedkin's Gulf States Toyota has taken a cut on every Toyota sold in those states since 1968. Despite supply chain interruptions caused by March's tsunami in Japan, Toyota sales are slightly up year over year. Friedkin is a former Hollywood stunt pilot and small part actor, having played Miner Tom in Clint Eastwood's Pale Rider. He has amassed a collection of authentic World War II fighter planes and enjoys flying them recreationally. Friedkin also maintains a 4.9 million acre game preserve in Tanzania, offering big game hunting safaris through his Friedkin Adventure Companies. In August, Texas Governor Rick Perry named him Chairman of the Texas Parks and Wildlife Commission.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 1904, Rolf Gerling's grandfather founded Gerling Konzern as a small insurance company. Gerling's father Hans managed to expand that small entity into a global insurance group. In 1991, following the death of his father, Gerling took over the company. Though trained as an economist, he showed little interest in his legacy and in 2005, Gerling sold his 94% stake in the company to Talanx Group for an estimated $1.6 billion. Gerling helped establish the Gerling Academy for Risk Research, a think tank set up to study the industrial world's impact on the environment.

name: Billionaires
bio: Harvard Business School grad David Gottesman has been a friend of Warren Buffett's since 1962. He was an early investor in Berkshire Hathaway and now serves on its board. He founded investment advisor First Manhattan Co. in 1964; it has in excess of $12 billion in assets under management. He and his wife donated $25 million to Yeshiva University medical school in 2008.
title: Chief Executive Officer
employment: {'name': 'First Manhattan Co.', 'title': 'Chief Executive Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: With partners, Israeli-American investor Noam Gottesman sold publicly-traded hedge fund GLG Partners to UK-based Man Group for $1.6 billion in October 2010, creating one of the world's largest hedge funds, with a combined $71 billion in assets. Gottesman received roughly $300 million in Man shares from the sale.  He also has an extensive art collection, including works by Andy Warhol, Francis Bacon and Lucian Freud. The Columbia grad and trustee co-founded GLG in 1995 with an investment from Lehman Brothers. He remains non-executive Chairman of GLG's business and interests in the US, and now runs TOMS Capital, his own private office concentrating on personal investments, art and philanthropy. Divorced, he apparently dates the actress Lucy Liu.
title: Chief Executive Officer
employment: {'name': 'TOMS Capital', 'title': 'Chief Executive Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Last year was a big one for private equity investor Joshua Harris, a co-founder of buyout shop Apollo Global Management. The firm, which has $75 billion in assets under management, went public in March 2011. Last fall, the NBA approved Comcast-Spectator's sale of the Philadelphia 76ers to a group of investors led by Harris. A graduate of UPenn, who also has family in the area, Harris said at the time that he "always felt a strong connection to this City and the 76ers." Harris formed Apollo with his former M&A boss at Drexel Burnham Lambert, Leon Black, and another colleague, Marc Rowan, after Drexel collapsed in 1990. He and the other partners didn't sell shares at the time of last year's IPO but did cash out some of their stake back in 2007, when CALPERS and Abu Dhabi Investment Authority invested.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hans-Werner Hector is a former IBM software engineer who cofounded German software firm SAP in 1972 with four former colleagues. He successfully built up the North American market for SAP then left the firm in 1997 after a falling out with his partners. A trained mathematician, Hector holds an honorary professorship of mathematics from the University of Karlsruhe for his support of students in the math, natural sciences and technology fields. His charitable foundation gives money to cancer and AIDS research as well as art and historic preservation. In 2011, Hector and his wife donated more than $60 million to the German city of Weinheim to renovate their local museum.

name: Billionaires
bio: Johnelle Hunt co-founded J.B. Hunt Transport Services with late husband Johnnie in 1969; now it's one of the largest transport companies in the U.S. with more than 12,000 trucks and trailers. Its latest projects include a rock quarry in Honduras and Pinnacle Hills Memorial Gardens, a cemetery and chapel in Hunt's home state of Arkansas that is scheduled to open in 2012. Her late husband's remains were relocated there in November 2011 in a memorial service attended by heiress Alice Walton and Congressman Steve Womack. Hunt built the cemetery in Johnnie's honor.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vladimir Iorich, a Russian-born German citizen, made his original fortune as a large shareholder of Russian mining and steel company Mechel AOA, run by Russian billionaire Igor Zyuzin. In 2007, after a disagreement with Zyuzin, Iorich sold his shares in the company and established Pala Investments, based in Zug, Switzerland. Pala owns chunks of mining outfits in Australia, Canada and Sierra Leone.

name: Billionaires
bio: At 86, Stephen Jarislowsky goes into the office every day as CEO of Jarislowsky, Fraser, an investment firm with about assets of about $44 billion under management. He still has a good sense of humor about it as well. "In 14 years, I'll be ancient!" he tells Forbes. Jarislowsky, Fraser has been active in the last year, dumping more than half of its stakes in RIM in June after the company began its downward spiral. With a Master's degree in Far Eastern Culture from the University of Chicago, Jarislowsky is also an art buff, whose collection spans from Chinese jade to French impressionism. He also owns Marina Island near Vancouver, a 2,000-acre islet with spectacular beaches and mountain views in the Straight of Georgia, British Columbia.
title: Cofounder and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Jarislowsky & Fraser', 'title': 'Cofounder and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Jiang Bin is chairman of GoerTek, a maker of electro-acoustic devices for the telecommunications industry that has benefited from increased mobile phone sales. Clients include Samsung, Sony, Lenovo and Cisco. Sales in the first nine months of 2011 rose by almost half to $437 million; that helped to increase GoerTek's profit by 82% to $55 million. Jiang Bin owns about 54% of GoerTek; his brother Jiang Long owns 8.2% of the listed company and also is vice chairman. GoerTek went public in 2008 and trades on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange.

name: Billionaires
bio: Samvel Karapetyan heads real estate firm Tashir Group, which owns 19 shopping centers, seven office centers and eight hotels. He made some big acquisitions during the financial crisis and has again been buying. In 2011 he spent $1 billion on new projects. Born in Armenia, he moved to Kaluga, near Moscow, in the 1990s. He apparently has construction and tourism contracts with officials in Yerevan, Armenia's capital. His older brother Karen Karapetyan is a well-known politician in Armenia, former head of the president's administration.

name: Billionaires
bio: Valery Kogan, together with business partner Dmitry Kamenshchik, owns Moscow's Domodedovo Airport, the largest in Russia used by 26 million people last year. A terrorist attack at the airport in January 2011 left 37 dead and intensified relations between the airport owners and the government, which wants to take back ownership. In spring 2011 the airport's managing company, DME Limited, filed for an IPO in London, but later abandoned the plan. Rumors have been flying that the airport is up for sale. Kogan served in the Navy and owns an $18 million estate in Greenwich, Connecticut.

name: Billionaires
bio: Esther Koplowitz, with younger sister Alicia, also a billionaire, inherited Fomento de Construcciones y Contratas from their late father, Ernesto. Their husbands ran FCC from the early 1970s until 1989, when both marriages ended. The sisters took over and ran operations jointly until 1997 when Esther bought her sister's stake for $800 million. Koplowitz now owns 48% of $17 billion (revenue) FCC, and sits on its supervisory board. In January 2012, FCC announced that its water management subsidiary, Aqualia, had received a 7-year, $100 million contract to manage the sewage and water treatment system in eastern Abu Dhabi; in addition, FCC is also searching for and repairing leaks in Riyadh's water network. More than half the company's revenue now comes from outside Spain. Koplowitz sits on board of Cementos Portland Valderrivas and Veolia Environment. She holds the Gold Cross for Social Solidarity for her social work; her Esther Koplowitz foundation, which supports and houses the mentally and physically impaired, has spent more than $115 million to date. She has donated some $20 million to help fund the Esther Koplowitz Center, a new biomedical center that opened in Barcelona in 2010; researches treatments for diseases like cancer, multiple sclerosis and malaria. She is Spanish nobility, holding the title of Marquesa de Casa Penalver. She loves ballet and classical music.

name: Billionaires
bio: Guilherme Leal co-chairs Natura Cosmeticos, a Brazilian version of Avon, with fellow billionaire and Natura founder Antonio Luiz Seabra. Leal helped Seabra build the cosmetics business into a multinational company, with consultants selling makeup and creams across Brazil and seven other Latin American countries. He personally promotes biodiversity and sustainable business practices and has worked with the World Wildlife Fund of Brazil. Two years ago he resigned from the company to run as the Green Party candidate for vice president in the 2010 Brazilian presidential election; he did not win. In July 2011 Brazilian newspapers reported Leal saying he would not run for public office again and that he had severed his affiliation with the Green Party.

name: Billionaires
bio: The president of Shinsegae Group, Lee Myung-Hee is Korea's richest woman. She is the youngest daughter of late Samsung Group founder Lee Byung-Chull and the sister of former Samsung Group Chairman Lee Kun-Hee. Samsung owned Shinsegae Group until the two separated in 1991. The company formed a joint venture with Starbucks in 2000 and now operates more than 180 licensed Starbucks stores in South Korea. In May, Shinsegae spun off its popular discount store operator, E-mart, in an attempt to better specialize its businesses and become more competitive in the Korean retail industry.

name: Billionaires
bio: Li Sze Lim is cofounder and cochairman of Guangzhou R&F Properties with Chinese billionaire Zhang Li. R&F has evolved from a regional leader to national heavyweight; it has projects underway in 12 cities. The company's shares took a beating last year due to the result of government measures aimed at China's real estate market. The shares, and Li's fortune, have rebounded lately; his fortune is down $200 million year on year but up more than $300 million in recent months. Li also holds a minority stake in Chinese brokerage Haitong Securities. Li chairs the Council of Guangdong Chamber of Real Estate and is a part-time professor at Sun Yat-Sen University and Jinan University. Sister Helen Li is an R&F board member.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cargill heir Marianne Leibmann is one of seven billionaire relatives who hold a majority of Cargill, the largest private company in the U.S. Cargill makes money in all areas of food production from animal feed, meat, and crops to commodity trading and risk management. The company divested itself of its stake in fertilizer maker Mosaic in 2011. William Cargill, the son of a Scottish sea captain, founded the Iowa grain storage business after the Civil War. Will's son-in-law, John MacMillan, took control in 1909, and no family member has run the company since Whitney MacMillan stepped down as chief executive in 1995.

name: Billionaires
bio: Colorado cattle rancher Magness inherited hundreds of millions of dollars in stock from his father, Bob Magness (d. 1996), founder of cable television titan TCI, which merged with AT&T in 1999 in a $54 billion deal. Magness owns water rights in Colorado through ranch holdings and also invests in oil, gas and cattle. He founded production company Smokewood Entertainment with his wife, Sarah. They produced the critically acclaimed movie "Precious." They also produced a children's movie and a documentary about a displaced tribe in Brazil, whom Magness taught to be cowboys, and gave a starter herd of cattle. Magness leads off-road truck racing team Mango Racing, and collects vintage cars.

name: Billionaires
bio: Yasseen Mansour, the youngest of Egypt's three Mansour brothers, was put on the Interpol list on fraud charges in June, but was removed after being cleared of corruption charges this past summer over the misappropriation of state land for Palm Hills Developments. Yasseen, his brothers and cousin, the former housing minister who was also accused, but cleared on Palm Hills, are the largest shareholders in the company--Egypt's second-biggest real estate developer. Yasseen resigned as CEO in June, but remains chairman. The majority of his fortune is tied up in the family business; it is the largest seller of GM vehicles in the world.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hotel heir J.W. Marriottt Jr., known as Bill, is at the helm of one of the world's largest hotel franchises, Marriott International. The 79-year-old joined the company more than 50 years ago, and has overseen its growth into approximately 20 different brands and a split (brother Richard runs Host Hotels). Marriott is an active Mormon, who has supported former board member and presidential hopeful Mitt Romney in his 2012 bid for the Republican nomination. Citing both technology changes and morals, Marriott International announced it would ban porn in its hotel rooms earlier this year. The company got its start in 1927 when Bill's father, a Mormon missionary, opened up a root beer stand in Washington D.C.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of broadcasting magnate John Elroy McCaw, Craig McCaw started out selling cable services door-to-door for his dad's firm. He co-founded McCaw Cellular with his brothers, and sold it to AT&T in 1993 for $11.5 billion. McCaw then invested in satellite network Nextel. In January he stepped down as CEO of his troubled high speed wireless network provider Clearwire, who had a troubled relationship with its biggest customer, Sprint. The company is now on its fourth CEO since early 2009. McCaw's Eagle River Investment's stake has lost 67% of its value in the past two years. He backed Utah Governor Jon Huntsman in the GOP primary.

name: Billionaires
bio: Florentino Perez, a civil engineer, holds 12.7% of Spain's largest construction company, $20 billion (sales) Actividades de Construccion y Servicios S.A., which he has headed since 1993. Perez has made news this year in his court fight to gain a seat on the board of alternative enrgy company Iberdrola, in which ACS has a 19% stake. Perez's continued losses in court have made headlines almost as much as his ties to popular Real Madrid soccer club, once the team of stars like David Beckham and Zinedine Zidane. Perez ran the club from 2000 to 2006 and resigned in February 2006 after string of defeats. But he got another chance: the club re-elected him president in 2009.

name: Billionaires
bio: Linda Pritzker is one of 11 members of the extended Pritzker family on Forbes' list of  billionaires, and a scion of the wealthy Chicago Pritzker family. Last September Linda sold 7.3 million shares of Hyatt to her cousins Jean (Gigi) Pritzker and Thomas Pritzker, chairman of Hyatt Hotels. She is a Tibetan Buddhist, a psychotherapist and sometime donor to liberal causes including Planned Parenthood and MoveOn.org. Her grandfather A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), with his sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert (d. 2011), created industrial conglomerate Marmon and hotel chain Hyatt. Over the past decade, the family has been selling assets it owns jointly. Back in 2007, the family sold control of Marmon Holdings to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway for a reported $4.5 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Moroccan entrepreneur Anas Sefrioui made his debut on Africa's 40 Richest list. He formed a real estate development group in 1988, but his big break came nearly ten years later when he won a contract to build a chunk of government-subsidized housing under the patronage of Morocco's late King Hassan II. He won another $1 billion state contract in 2005 to build more housing units. Sefrioui's Douja Promotion Groupe Addoha went public the following year; he owns nearly 62%.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shen Guojun owns 38% of Hong Kong-listed Intime Department Store, one of China's largest department store chains. Intime's roots are in Zhejiang Province, one of China's richest areas and where Shen grew up. The company is expanding into Anhui and Hubei. Buoyed by China's rising consumer spending, Intime's revenues climbed 42% in the first six months of 2012 to $246 million. Shen also has real estate interests.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kavitark "Ram" Shriram was one of the first people to write a check to Google co-founders Sergey Brin and Larry Page in 1998. Shriram would advise them one day a week in their Menlo Park garage. Today he is still a board member and large shareholder of the search giant. He is now running his own investment firm, Sherpalo Ventures, which has stakes in online outsourcer 24/7 Customer and serendipitous website picker StumbleUpon. Shriram also invested in Inkling, which makes interactive textbooks for the iPad, and more recently, Paperless Post, a personalized digital invitation company. The firm cashed in on Mint Software, which sold to Intuit for $171 million in 2009. Born in India, Shriram joined Netscape in 1994. His next company, Junglee, was bought by Amazon in 1998. He also serves as a trustee at Stanford University.
title: Managing Partner

name: Billionaires
bio: Song Zuowen is chairman of the Nanshan Group of  Shandong Province. It controls one of China's largest aluminum companies, Shandong Nanshan Aluminum. Net profit in the nine months through September 2011 rose by more than half to $124 million on sales that increased by about the same amount to $1.6 billion. Business grew in part as a result of expanded production capacity. Nanshan Group traces its roots back to 1978; Song owns 49% of it.  Nanshan Group owns 43% of Shandong Nanshan Aluminum, whose shares trade in Shanghai. Song's elder son Song Jianbo has been chairman of Shandong Nanshan Aluminum since 1999; its subsidiary Nanshan America Advanced Aluminum Technologies is setting up an aluminum alloy factory in Indiana, with an expected total investment of $161 million. The group's Nanshan Jet is the first private jet leasing company in Shandong Province, and reportedly has bought planes from Bombardier and Boeing to expand the business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Disciplined investor Clemmie Spangler is patiently awaiting a housing market rebound to boost demand for his building and construction materials supplier National Gypsum's products. In his words, "We think in ten year cycles". After studying business at UNC and Harvard Business School, Spangler took over his father's failing Bank of North Carolina, merged it with NCNB in 1982, and eventually with Bank of America. A lifelong proponent of education, Spangler served as chair of North Carolina's board of education from 1982 to 1986 and UNC's president from 1986 to 1997. Spangler also served as president of Harvard University's Board of Overseers from 2003 to 2004 and the Spangler Center at HBS is named for him. Through his C.D. Spangler Foundation he donates to his alma maters and to Charlotte's Teach for America. Spangler enjoys restoring antique grandfather clocks; he says the allure is working on something that someone else tinkered with 200 years ago.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tong Jinquan chairs Shanghai-based Summit Property Development which he founded  in 1992. The company today boasts 5,000 employees and business partners that include Capitaland of Singapore. Summit has developed residential, service apartments, hotels, offices and shopping malls around the country. After opening the Longemont Asia-Pacific City shopping mall in Shenyang in 2010, Tong reportedly last year announced plans to invest more than $1.5 billion in Longemont New City mall in Chengdu.

name: Billionaires
bio: Martin Viessmann owns Viessmann Werke GmbH, one of Europe's largest producers of boilers and heating equipment. His grandfather founded the group more than 90 years ago. Viessmann began his tenure at the helm of the company in 1993. In 2008, he moved to the supervisory board to concentrate on company strategy. His company supports the Viessmann Academy to provide training for heating architects and engineers. Viessmann has a professional pilot's license.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of China Zhengtong Auto, one of China's largest auto distributors, Wang Muqing also controls the trust which owns 73% of the company's shares.  Prior to founding Zhengtong in 1999, Wang held various positions over 18 years at the Hubei Industrial Building Group Installation Engineering, an equipment supplier. Today, Zhengtong specializes in the relatively fast-growing luxury segment, selling BMW, Porsche and Audi models. His net worth rose following the company's December 2010 IPO, though shares fell back after said he would cut his own stake to 61.5%.

name: Billionaires
bio: Royal Caribbean co-founder Arne Wilhelmsen's fortune is down nearly 25% as his cruise company hit rough waters. However, the Harvard grad still owns private real estate company Linstow, one of Norway's largest property developers. Wilhelmsen pocketed at least $500 million in 2008 when China Oilfield Services acquired all of Awilco Offshore, including his 40% stake, for $2.5 billion. He chairs the family investment company, with stakes in oil tankers, Russian hotels and Baltic shopping centers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Debutante Jacky Xu is the founder of Trendy Global, which runs successful retail fashion chains Ochirly, Trendiano and Five Plus from its headquarters in Guangzhou. Trendy reportedly sold a 20% stake last year to LCapital, an investment arm of French giant LVMH led by billionaire Bernard Arnault.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhang Li is CEO of Hong Kong-listed real estate developer Guangzhou R&F. The company is chaired by fellow billionaire Li Sze Lim, who hails from Hong Kong. The wealth of both has declined from a year ago amid Chinese government moves to curb real estate prices and inflation in the country, spurring investor worries about profit growth. Yet sales in the first half climbed by year two-thirds, to $1.6 billion, boosting profit to  $317 million from $111 million a year earlier.   Business has remained strong on diversified nation-wide portfolio of projects. The company also  changed some of its product designs to attract first-time home buyers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhou Furen is the chairman of privately-owned Xiyang Group, which produces fertilizer and minerals, and has investments in Russia, North Korea and China. Xiyang ranked No. 166 on a survey of China's 500 largest manufacturers in 2011 conducted by two industry associations.  The company is based in northern Chinese city of Haicheng in Liaoning Province, and has about 20,000 employees.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mohammed Abdulaziz Al Rajhi, with his brothers Sulaiman, Abdullah, and the late Saleh, founded Al Rajhi Bank, one of the largest Islamic banks in the world, with $49 billion in assets. His share of the bank accounts for the majority of his fortune. His conglomerate Mohammed Al Rajhi & Sons has interests in various industries, including plastics, steel and water.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nadhmi Auchi was once a middle man for major oil companies and state-owned oil fields in the Gulf; he settled in Britain in 1980 after fleeing Saddam Hussein's Iraq. This year, his wealth dropped due to a reduced stake in Egyptian billionaire Naguib Sawiris's Orascom Telecom and civil unrest occurring in the countries where Auchi's General Mediterranean Holdings (GMH) operates. GMH owns hotels and office buildings in France, the U.K. and Middle East, and Chicago. His firm also invests in construction, pharmaceutical and finance companies. Auchi also owns Team Lebanon of the A1 Grand Prix Race series.

name: Billionaires
bio: Enrique Banuelos, founder and former chairman of Astroc Mediterraneo S.A., made his debut as a billionaire in 2007 worth $7.7 billion. He lost $6.4 billion within a year amid rumors of inflated earnings and a cooling property market in Spain. Banuelos now holds 23% of the company, which he renamed Quabit Inmobiliaria S.A.., and is now reinventing himself in Brazil. He held 30% of Agre Empreendimentos Imobiliarios S.A., a Brazilian real estate group which merged in May 2011 with realtor PDG Realty, one of Brazil's largest builders. Banuelos now holds 6% of PDG and is the leading individual investor in the company. His latest series of mergers resulted in Vanguarda Agro, Brazil's largest agribusiness, which produces soy, cotton and biodiesel; Banuelos and associates pulled out of that board in December 2011. Banuelos runs a private foundation that promotes Spain's cultural heritage.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ron Baron runs Baron Capital, which manages $17.5 billion. Each year, his firm hosts a popular investors conference at the Metropolitan Opera House featuring surprise performances by musicians and other entertainers. Last year's guests included Sting and James Taylor. Previous performers included Jerry Seinfeld, Jon Bon Jovi and Elton John. Baron grew up in Asbury, NJ, and spent summers doing odd jobs on the Jersey Shore, got his start as a biochemistry teaching fellow and then as a patent examiner in U.S. patent office, while attending George Washington law school. He became securities analyst in 1970 and started his own firm in 1982.Today, Baron owns one of the biggest estates in the Hamptons, 40-acres for which he paid $103 million in 2007. He also has homes in New York City and Vail.

name: Billionaires
bio: With his brothers, Ed Bass controls one of the country's largest privately held oil outfits, Bass Enterprises Production. Father Perry's uncle Sid Richardson was an oil baron who left a piece of his fortune to the Basses in 1959. They made the most of it, in part by putting capital in the hands of legendary investor Richard Rainwater. The brothers sold one division to Southern Union for $1.6 billion in 2005. Ed has historically been the most free-spirited brother. He is an architecture and ecology buff, spending more than $100 million on his Biosphere project. He has also invested in a hotel in Nepal, an Australian ranch and a Puerto Rican rainforest. His best legacy: leading the revitalization of downtown Fort Worth.

name: Billionaires
bio: AOL founder Steve Case is using the money he made during the tech boom to fund a series of new companies, including Groupon rival LivingSocial, and online wine marketplace Vinfolio. Case's venture capital firm Revolution also invested in car sharing service Zipcar, which went public in 2011, and sold financial services division Revolution Money to American Express for $300 million in 2010. Recently the firm invested in Vienna-based FedBid, an online marketplace for governments to access project funds. Case chairs Accelerate Brain Cancer Cure (ABC2), a nonprofit he founded with his late brother, Dan, which has an entrepreneurial approach to funding brain cancer research. He attended prestigious Punahou, the same Hawaii high school as Barack Obama, and was appointed by the President to lead the Startup America Partnership, a nonprofit aimed at spurring the growth of new companies. Late last year, Case bought a winery in Madison County, Virginia, for $10.2 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: A century ago Christopher Cline's grandfather mined coal with a pickaxe in Beckley, W.V. At age six, Cline's dad paid him a penny a bag to excavate dirt from under the porch. In 1980, Dad scraped together $500,000 to buy out a mining partner and gave a share to Cline, then 21. Cline has since parlayed that start into control over 4 billion tons of coal, much of it in Illinois. Now he has a 150-acre estate in Beckley, a 34,000-square-foot oceanfront mansion in Florida and a yacht called Mine Game. Carlyle/Riverstone Group is a big investor in his Foresight Energy, which announced plans for an IPO sometime in 2012. The timing has been rough: Shares of underground miners are off 40% since mid-2011. Cline has also sold millions of tons of reserves to Natural Resource Partners to raise cash to build mines. He is now seeking approvals for an iron ore mine in Wisconsin that would create 700 jobs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Reclusive Texas Rangers owner Ray Davis quietly backed Hall of Famer Nolan Ryan in the purchase of the baseball team in 2010. He had great timing: The Rangers surprised the league by making it to the World Series the last two years. Davis teamed with Kelcy Warren to form gas pipeline company Cornerstone in 1993. The pair bought small pipelines and consolidated the holdings into an efficient network. They flipped the pipelines to El Paso in 1999, using proceeds to create Energy Transfer. He stepped down as co-chief executive in 2007.

name: Billionaires
bio: Irish investor Dermot Desmond is credited with helping transform Ireland's economy in the late 1980s with a proposal for Dublin's International Financial Services Centre. Desmond started his career at Citibank, before working briefly as a banking consultant for Pricewaterhouse Coopers in Afghanistan. He founded NCB Stockbrokers in 1981, eventually Ireland's largest independent brokerage. When Desmond sold NCB in 1994 for $39 million, he started his own private equity firm, International Investment & Underwriting. His current investments include international betting exchange Betdaq, online education outfit Intuition, Glasgow soccer club Celtic PLC, and mapping software company eSpatial. An avid golfer, Desmond's known as "The Kaiser" for his distinctive mustache.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tilman Fertitta is the owner, chairman and CEO of Landry's, a dining, hospitality and gaming company. Its restaurant chains include Landry's Seafood House, Bubba Gump Shrimp Company, and Saltgrass Steakhouse. The Golden Nugget Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas, Houston's Kemah Boardwalk and the Towers of Americas in San Antonio are all under the Landry's umbrella. Fertitta started at Landry's as a real estate specialist in 1986, took over as president and CEO in 1987, and became the controlling stockholder in 1988. He took the company private in October 2010 in a deal worth $1.4 billion. Fertitta recently acquired McCormick & Schmidt and Morton's Steakhouse. His latest project is the 1,130-foot Galveston Pleasure Pier, scheduled to open in May.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': "Landry's Inc", 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Soichiro Fukutake runs Benesse Holdings, which owns leading exam-prep schools, Berlitz language schools, correspondence courses and more than 200 nursing homes. Benesse is expanding schools in China, Taiwan and Korea. Fukutake also chairs and helped fund an R&D outfit called Sim-Drive which is developing new motor designs for electric vehicles. He owns Benesse Art Site, an art park on a group of islands in Japan's Inland Sea featuring top contemporary artists and a museum designed by Tadao Andoh. Fukutake lives in New Zealand.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dan Gilbert's Quicken Loans successfully rode out the mortgage mess of 2008 and 2009, and then wrote $30 billion in new mortgages in 2010 while adding dozens of tech start-ups to the "family." He's now scooping up Detroit real estate at bargain prices to create a tech hub in Motown. In Ohio, where he owns the NBA's Cleveland Cavaliers, he's also building a potentially lucrative casino empire.

name: Billionaires
bio: Legend has it in his native Toronto that SmartCentres President and CEO Mitchell Goldhar paid an unsolicited visit to Sam Walton in the early 1990s, refusing to leave the prolific retailer's Arkansas office until the older man agreed to name Goldhar his exclusive developer in Canada. Though Walton declined, Goldhar's tenacity had impressed Walton enough to give him a shot. The rest is history as Goldhar soon became Walmart's de facto exclusive developer in the country, literally paving the way for Walmart as it moved into the market. Goldhar is still developing his Walmart-anchored SmartCentres, many of which he then sells to Calloway, a real estate investment trust in which he holds a 22% stake. He manages the parallel operations out of SmartCentres headquarters, known as "the Igloo," in Vaughn, Ontario.
title: Owner

name: Billionaires
bio: Tom Golisano sold the NHL's Buffalo Sabres to fellow billionaire Terry Pegula in March 2011 for $189 million. Golisano reportedly rejected a rival bid that would have netted him an additional $70 million because it involved moving the team away from Buffalo. Noted for challenging high property assessments, Golisano has gone so far as to hold a free seminar in Rochester to educate other citizens about how to do the same. In addition to serving as Chairman and CEO of Paychex, Inc., the payroll company he founded in 1971, Golisano sits on the board of trustees of the Rochester Institute of Technology and is the national spokesman and major funder of the National Popular Vote Initiative, an organization dedicated to abolishing the electoral college and instituting the direct election of the President of the United States by popular vote. His charitable Golisano Foundation "is devoted exclusively to supporting programs for people with developmental disabilities so that they may achieve their maximum potentials by integrating independence, self-determination, and productivity into all facets of their lives".

name: Billionaires
bio: Infosys cofounder S.Gopalakrishnan, also known as "Kris", took over as executive co-chairman in reshuffle last August following N.R. Narayana Murthy's retirement. He ran company as chief executive for 4 prior years. Active philanthropist donates to various causes related to education and health, including the Parkinson's & Aging Research Foundation in Bangalore.

name: Billionaires
bio: Joe Jamail is America's wealthiest practicing lawyer and claims he turns down hundreds of cases each year. He built a business on personal injury cases and scored an estimated $345 million in a contingency fee case for Pennzoil against Texaco in 1987. In the last two years, Jamail gave $15 million to the University of Texas, his alma mater, and $1 million to both Rice University and the boarding school San Marcos Academy. Jamail says he once dreamed of becoming a history teacher. He now spends time in the South of France and the Almafi Coast when he's not in the courtroom.

name: Billionaires
bio: Duke University trustee Bruce Karsh and his wife Martha donated $50 million to Duke late last year to support financial aid. The gift includes $30 million for U.S. students and $20 million for international students. The Karshes have given $85 million for undergraduate financial aid at Duke, including this recent gift. A former attorney, Karsh cofounded Oaktree Capital Management with Howard Marks in 1995. With Marks, he raised $1 billion when they sold 16% of their money management firm on a private Goldman Sachs exchange in May 2007. The pair, who each have a nearly 16% stake, now plan to take their alternative asset management firm public, having filed the paperwork in June 2011. Before Oaktree, the Duke Alum served as assistant to SunAmerica chairman Eli Broad until 1987.
title: President
employment: {'name': 'Oaktree Capital Group LLC', 'title': 'President', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Veteran investment banker Kenneth Langone is now CEO of public tech firm Geeknet. He joined as chairman in July 2010, and was named CEO a month later. Langone made his mark taking Ross Perot's Electronic Data Systems public in 1968. He later raised millions in capital to co-found Home Depot in 1978. He left the board in 2010 after 30 years but still has a large stake in the retailer. Langone was also the chair of the New York Stock Exchange's compensation committee from 1999 to 2002 and a board member until 2003. Langone was thrust into the limelight when he was forced to testify in lawsuit over the $187 million pay package awarded to former NYSE chief Richard Grasso. Langone is chairman of the Promise Academy, a charter school in NYC. He gave an unrestricted $200 million gift to NYU Langone Medical center in 2008. He is a graduate of the MBA part-time program at NYU, a program which now bears his name after his $10 million donation in 1999. He led a group of Republican donors to encourage New Jersey governor Chris Christie to run for president, then backed Mitt Romney after Christie declined.

name: Billionaires
bio: Li Shufu is the chairman of Geely Automobile Holdings of Hangzhou, one of China's largest non-government-controlled automakers. Li's wealth has fallen from a year ago amid a slower growth in China's auto market that has pulled Geely's shares down.  In the first half of 2011, Geely shipped 213,000 cars, an increase of 9% from a year earlier. Li hails from Zhejiang Province, near Shanghai;started his career making refrigerator parts.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Chang Chun Group, founded in 1949 by Suhon Lin, Liao Long-shing's late father M.K. Liao, and Tseng Shin-yi, is one of Asia's most successful privately held businesses and largest plastics and petrochemicals manufacturers. From its base in Taiwan, the company has expanded over the years into the mainland and more recently Singapore.  The three families each own a third. Overseas business partners include Bayer and Mitsubishi Gas Chemical.  The three founders all attended what today is called National Taipei University of Technology.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Chang Chun Group, founded in 1949 by Suhon Lin, Liao Long-shing's late father M.K. Liao, and Tseng Shin-yi, is one of Asia's most successful privately held businesses and largest plastics and petrochemicals manufacturers. From its base in Taiwan, the company has expanded over the years into the mainland and more recently Singapore.  The three families each own a third; Lin as chairman. Overseas business partners include Bayer and Mitsubishi Gas Chemical.  The three founders all attended what today is called National Taipei University of Technology.

name: Billionaires
bio: NNiels Peter Louis-Hansen is deputy chairman of the $1.7 billion (sales) Coloplast, a Danish health care company that makes medical devices in the fields of ostomy and urology such as colostomy bags and catheters; Coloplast also makes dressing for wounds. Louis-Hansen owns a 20% stake in the public company, making him its largest shareholder. His late father, Aage Louis-Hansen, founded the business in 1957 and took it public in 1983.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ma Xiagtian is chairman of Kangmei Pharmaceutical, one of China's largest producers of traditional Chinese medicine. The company, founded by Ma at age 28, is now investing in its own plantations across China with an eye to meeting rising demand for high-quality Chinese herbal medicine. Sales climbed 26% in the first nine months of 2011 to $102 million. Ma is an adjunct professor at an herbal medicine institute. Ma's wife has investments in Shenzhen-listed Anhui Gujing Distillery and Shenzhen-listed GF Securities,  one of China's biggest brokerages.

name: Billionaires
bio: Igor Makarov is the main shareholder of independent gas company Itera, which throughout the second half of the 1990s was Russia's main exporter of Turkmen gas. Makarov has made the most of his birthplace, gas-rich Turkmenistan, as well as his connections with high-ranking officials at Russian natural gas monopoly Gazprom; his company acquired Gazprom assets for next to nothing and ended up owning big gas fields. After Putin's team came to Gazprom in 2001, though, Itera nearly lost its business; Makarov managed to save the company by handing some assets over to Gazprom. Itera holds a stake in hockey club Dinamo Riga in Russia's NHL, the Continental hockey league. Makarov is also the president of the Russian Cycling Federation, and was a member of the USSR cycling team.

name: Billionaires
bio: This "Tiger Cub" worked at Mars & Co. and then Goldman Sachs before joining Julian Robertson's Tiger Management as a consumer analyst. Mandel departed in 1997 to launch his own firm, Lone Pine Capital, named for a mythical Dartmouth pine tree that survived an 1887 lightning strike. The firm currently manages approximately $20 billion across long-only equity funds, hedge funds and a fund of funds. Lone Pine's hedge funds reportedly finished 2011 down slightly net of fees. Mandel contributed $134 million to his Zoom Foundation in tax year 2010; past beneficiaries of his foundation include the Children's Aid Society of New York, Phillips Exeter Academy, and the Fairfield County Foundation. Mandel also serves on the board of Dartmouth College and Teach for America.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Youssef Mansour, the older brother of Egyptian billionaire businessmen Mohamed and Yasseen, keeps a low profile. His assets, especially in publicly traded real estate development company Palm Hills Developments, took a hit with the Egyptian uprising early in 2011. Youssef is responsible for building Egypt's largest supermarket chain, Metro, but now devotes time to the family foundation which targets illiteracy and education. The bulk of his fortune comes from the family's business as the largest seller of GM vehicles in the world, and strong sales of Caterpillar machines.

name: Billionaires
bio: Howard Marks and his longtime partner Bruce Karsh filed in June 2011 to take their Oaktree Capital Management public. The pair raised $1 billion when they sold 16% of their money management firm on a private Goldman Sachs exchange in 2007. Marks, who is known for his insightful memos to clients, recently published a book entitled,  The Most Important Thing; Uncommon Sense for the Thoughtful Investor.  Wharton grad he got start in investments with First National Citibank (which later became Citicorp) in 1969, joined TCW in 1985. Marks hired Bruce Karsh in 1987; the pair founded Oaktree Capital Management 8 years later. Oaktree was one of 9 investor groups tapped by the U.S. government in March 2009 to soak up toxic debt from troubled banks under the Public-Private Investment Plan.
title: Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Oaktree Capital Group LLC', 'title': 'Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: This season Bob McNair celebrated the first trip to the playoffs for the NFL's Houston Texans. It was a long time in coming; he and his partners paid $700 million for the expansion team a decade ago Forbes ranks the Texans as the sixth most valuable football team, at $1.2 billion. McNair made his fortune selling power operator Cogen Technologies to Enron in 1999. He still owns stakes in power plants in New York and West Virginia. McNair funds college scholarships for kids in his home state of North Carolina.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dutch businessman Hans Melchers built his fortune by founding the chemical company Melchemie Holland BV. He's now a major shareholder of HAL Trust, an international investment company based in the Netherlands Antilles. In 2005, his 37 year old daughter, Claudia, was kidnapped. Ransom was set at 660 pounds of cocaine but she was released unharmed two days later. After the press insinuated he was involved in the drug trade, he founded the Melchers Fund to provide financial aid to initiate lawsuits and legal aid to victims of slanderous media reports. Melchers also founded the Onstein semi-professional bridge association. Tournaments are held at his castle estate in the Dutch city of Vorden.

name: Billionaires
bio: Robert Miller co-founded Duty Free Shoppers, or DFS, with Chuck Feeney in Hong Kong in 1960. Feeney and two other investors sold their shares to LVMH in 1997. Miller has kept his minority stake. DFS has more than 150 airport and downtown retail outlets worldwide. Miller chairs the Search Investment Group, a private investment concern. The company is a shareholder in Ortelius Capital Partners, an investment firm also backed by Miller's son-in-law Prince Pavlos of Greece. Miller holds a bachelor's degree in hotel administration from Cornell University, where he is a presidential councilor and trustee emeritus. He is also a trustee of the Asia Society.

name: Billionaires
bio: Manuel "Matty" Moroun got an unpleasant surprise in January when a Michigan judge threw him in jail for contempt of court in a dispute with the state of Michigan over improving access to his Ambassador Bridge in Detroit. He was released one day later, pending appeal, but the fight is far from over. The trucking and logistics magnate is desperately trying to fend off competition from a proposed public bridge two miles downriver. His bridge, which handles 8,000 trucks a day and $100 billion in trade every year, accounts for the bulk of his fortune. Other assets include trucking firms, logistics support, air freight and insurance.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zelimkhan Mutsoev's family controls the Regions Group, which owns dozens of shopping centers, as well as an 8.1% stake in major fertilizer producer Uralkali. Mutsoev worked as a dump truck driver on construction sites after finishing school. In the late 1980s, he founded clothing manufacturer that made jackets. In the 1990s he became a co-owner of Pervouralsk, a factory that produces tubes. In 2004 he sold the factory to Andrey Komarov's ChTPZ group. He has been elected as a deputy in the Edinaya Rissiya party three times, but due to a decrease in the number of votes for his party, he did not pass into the State Duma this December.

name: Billionaires
bio: The son of an orthodontist, Nelson grew up in Providence, Rhode Island. After studying economics at Brown University, he worked in China for chemical company Wellman. Upon his return to the U.S. in 1989, he founded Providence Equity Partners, which invests in media, communications, information services and education. The company now manages $26 billion in funds. Last year Providence sold the last piece of its stake in German cable company Kabel Deutschland, an investment that resulted in more than $3 billion in gains. Providence also took two companies private, educational platform Blackboard and security technology firm SRA International. The deals were valued at $1.6 billion and $1.9 billion, respectively. One of the firm's current portfolio companies, Autotrader.com, has made headlines recently because it's considering an IPO.  Nelson sits on the board of numerous Providence portfolio companies, including Univision, Yankees Sports and Entertainment Network, TVB, and Hulu, which is reportedly on the auction block. Nelson is also an avid sailor and big mountain skier.
title: Chief executive officer
employment: {'name': 'Providence Equity Partners', 'title': 'Chief executive officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: One of the most respected figures in the video game business, Newell's Valve Corporation posted a stellar 2011. The Bellevue, Wash. software firm scored hits both as game developer (Portal 2 was a monster hit) and game distributor (digital distribution platform Steam doubled sales for the seventh straight year, and has over 40 million users). Newell owns more than 50% of privately-held Valve, which he co-founded in 1996 after cashing in stock options earned over a decade producing software for Microsoft.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mumbai developer Vikas Oberoi owns 79% of Oberoi Realty, which he took public in 2010. Its stock is up 5% since listing and the company is cash-rich, unlike many debt-laden peers whose shares have tumbled. It has built 34 projects covering 5 million square feet in suburban Mumbai. Showpiece is Oberoi Garden City, an 80-acre complex. It is building a mid-town project that will have a Mandarin Hotel. Qualified pilot, he owns a Cirrus plane that he likes to fly.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bob Parsons, new to the Forbes World's Billionaires list, has used racy Super Bowl ads and sponsorship of Nascar's Danica Patrick to help build his Go Daddy into the world's largest web hosting provider, with more than 5 million active accounts and more than 52 million domain names. In 2011 he sold the majority of the firm to strategic investors KKR, Silver Lake and TCV in a deal that valued the firm at more than $2 billion. Parsons remains the largest individual shareholder and is executive chairman. Success wasn't a given for this entrepreneur: he says he flunked fifth grade and struggled in school. He credits graduating high school to the U.S. Marine Corps, saying his teachers felt sorry for him because he was heading to Vietnam. During the war he received three medals including the Purple Heart. After his return, he got a business degree from the University of Baltimore, and in 1984 started a software company in his basement, writing the computer programs himself. He sold that company to Intuit for $64 million and used the proceeds to start Go Daddy. Known for his over-the-top holiday parties and video blog, Parsons got into hot water in the spring of 2011 for posting a video of himself killing an elephant in Zimbabwe. Parsons said he was shooting problem elephants that eat farmers' crops, and that he had worked with tribal leaders. It is a practice reportedly supported by some groups, but others, such as the African Wildlife Foundation and PETA, were outraged. Last fall he opened the Go Daddy Tech Center at the Boys & Girls Clubs of Scottsdale, and will help fund an educational campaign to fight cyber bullying.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dinu Patriciu has been investing cash from the 2008 sale of his oil company, Rompetrol, to Kazakhstan's state-owned energy operator, Kazmunaigaz, in real estate, retail and oil and gas exploration. His retail efforts are faltering; in February, his MiniMax Discount filed for bankruptcy and his Mic.ro stores are rumored to be sold off to 7-Eleven. Patriciu himself has warned that Europe might be headed for a second recession. Nevertheless, Patriciu is committed to his energy project, reportedly planning to spend up to $1 billion to look for Black Sea oil and gas. He also owns Adevarul Holding which publishes Forbes Romania under license from Forbes Media LLC.

name: Billionaires
bio: Apple hardware engineer turned wireless networking entrepreneur struck out on his own in 2005 with the goal of bringing affordable internet access to the world's emerging markets. Says Pera, "Apple's a great company, but I realized I wanted to have more success faster."Six years later, at age 34, Pera became a billionaire when his Ubiquiti Networks went public in October 2011. Relying on a network of more than 50 distributors and hundreds of resellers across the globe, Ubiquiti maintains no traditional sales team. By keeping costs low, Ubiquiti can afford to outcompete established competitors like Motorola on price while keeping profit margins fat (north of 25% in 2011.) Ubiquiti's product range includes Wi-Fi amplification systems that can provide internet access to as few as 10 people or more than 10,000 customers within a 36-mile radius.
title: Chief Executive Officer
employment: {'name': 'Ubiquiti Networks Inc', 'title': 'Chief Executive Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Jose Isaac Peres joins the Forbes World's Billionaires list this year amid strong performance at Multiplan, the publicly-traded shopping mall developer and owner he founded in 1975. Peres was a pioneer in malls in Brazil, often choosing to build in undeveloped areas far from downtown.  Now the company has 14 malls, primarily in the southern and southeastern regions of the country, and it boasts the highest sales per square meter of any Brazilian mall owner. Ontario Teachers Pension Plan owns 29% of publicly traded Multiplan.
title: Entrepreneur

name: Billionaires
bio: Gregorio Pérez Companc made most of his fortune building up energy conglomerate Perez Companc, which he sold to Brazilian oil giant Petrobas for $1.2 billion in 2002. In December 2009, Perez stepped down from active involvement in the business, gifting his entire 75% stake in food giant Molinos Rio de la Plata, a diversified maker of pasta, flour and frozen vegetables, to his seven children (the value of that business is not counted in his fortune). At his wife Maria Carmen's urging, Perez launched ice cream parlor chain Munchi's. He also established the Bioparque Temaiken, a nature and wileflife preserve outside of Buenos Aires. Perez collects old cars and reportedly paid over $9 million for a Ferrari.

name: Billionaires
bio: A friendship forged with Japan's Toyoda family in the 1960s, founders of Japan's Toyota Motor Company, underpins the second part of a doubled-edged business strategy built on vehicle sales and commercial property. Cash from selling Toyota products in parts of Australia, the last such personal arrangement in the world, generates cash, which is then tipped into one of the country's biggest private property portfolios. Once a keen fisherman, age is keeping Perron closer to home, though he still goes to the office to "read the paper", he says. Perron made his first money as a boy selling hand-carved handkerchief boxes in the Australian gold mining city of Kalgoorlie. He tried his hand at everything from brick-making to running an ice rink before settling on cars and property.

name: Billionaires
bio: Murdaya Poo is the founder of Central Cipta Murdaya, a more than quarter-century old group, with interests in IT, real estate, timber, plantations, consumer goods and engineering.  Mostly private group, it plans to spend $8 billion building a central business district in Kemayoran, Central Jakarta in the next 5 years. It also provides Internet services in 24 cities. Its only listed entity is property developer Metropolitan Kentjana, which went public in 2009. Poo says he believes his wife, Siti Hartati Murdaya, who helps him manage the business, is the main force behind his success.  A vegetarian, he enjoys playing golf.

name: Billionaires
