bio: In 1975, Price started his career in finance as a research assistant at Heine Securities. By 1988 he was the sole owner of the company. Price is considered an expert in value investing, increasing the value of the mutual funds he managed to more than $17 billion before selling Heine Securuties to Franklin Securities for $670 million in 1996. He now manages his wealth through MFP Investors, whose current holdings include Destination Maternity Corp. and Cache Inc. Price recently spoke out about the value of some big financial firms, saying companies like Goldman Sachs and Citigroup are undervalued at current prices. In 1997, Price donated $18 million to the University of Oklahoma to form the Price College of Business.
title: President

name: Billionaires
bio: James Pritzker is one of 11 members of the extended Pritzker family on the Forbes World's Billionaires list. In February he sold some of his Hyatt shares to his cousins Jean (Gigi) Pritzker and Thomas Pritzker, chair of Hyatt Hotels. A retired Army lieutenant colonel, James founded the Pritzker Military Library in Chicago in 2003. For the past decade, the Pritzker family has been selling off assets it owns jointly. Back in 2007, it sold a controlling stake in industrial conglomerate Marmon Holdings to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway for $4.5 billion. James' grandfather, A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), with his sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert (d. 2011), created Marmon and hotel chain Hyatt.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Marc Rowan is the low-profile co-founder of buyout shop Apollo Global Management, which he started in 1990 with former Drexel Burnham colleagues Leon Black and Joshua Harris. The firm, which has $75 billion in assets under management, went public in March 2011; its shares were down  since its listing though they have rebounded from their low.  Rowan and the other partners didn't sell shares at the time of the IPO but did cash out some of their stake back in 2007, when CALPERS and Abu Dhabi Investment Authority invested.

name: Billionaires
bio: Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz is back on the Forbes World's Billionaires list after a five-year absence. Last March, Starbucks generated investor excitement when it finalized a partnership with Green Mountain Coffee Roasters to sell single-serve coffee. Investors also like a joint venture with India's Tata Coffee Ltd. that was cemented in January. Starbucks has signaled its intentions to move into China and the juice business. The company paid $30 million for Evolution Fresh, a small maker of premium juices, in November. The son of blue-collar parents, Schultz was raised in housing projects in Brooklyn, and went to study and play football at Northern Michigan U. He later moved back to New York to sell pots and pans for a Swedish housewares maker before landing a marketing gig at a small coffee bean store called Starbucks. He traveled to Italy and was inspired to open an espresso bar in the U.S. His Starbucks bosses said no, so he started a rival store in 1985, making his java with Starbucks? beans. He bought Starbucks from his bosses two years later for $3.8 million and took it public in 1992. Schultz returned to the company's helm in 2008 after an eight-year break as chairman and turned around the struggling company. A co-founder of venture capital firm Maveron, Schultz is also an investor in consumer businesses such as Pinkberry frozen yogurt, Lucy activewear, eBay and Groupon. He's politically active and has urged fellow business leaders to withhold campaign donations until a bipartisan agreement can be reached on the deficit plan.
title: Chairman and CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: hen Wenrong is chairman of Shagang Group, a steelmaker that was ranked as China's second-largest non-government company in a survey in 2011. At age 66, Shen is winding down his career with flair.  Last year, Jiangsu Shagang Co., a steelmaking affiliate of Shagang Group, soared on its debut at the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in April when trade in its shares resumed after a nearly one-year pause during which Shen bought a controlling stake in its predecessor company, Gaoxin Zhangtong. Unlisted Shagang Group, which is 39% owned by Shen, acquired 75% of Shenzhen-listed Gaoxin Zhangtong in Dec. 2010, when Shagang swapped its 64% ownership of a subsidiary, Huaigang Special Steel, for shares in the listed company. Shagang's move occurred as China, the world's largest steel producer, has been encouraging the consolidation of its steel industry. Jiangsu Shagang's revenue in the first nine months of 2011 climbed 11.8% from a year earlier to 11.8 billion yuan, or $1.9 billion; net profit declined 19% to  249.7 million yuan, or $40 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sit Kwong Lam chairs Hong Kong-listed Brightoil, an oil storage and transportation company. He bought a controlling stake in garment maker First Sign International Holding in 2008, changing its name to Brightoil Petroleum. It has partnered state-owned China National Petroleum to develop natural gas in Xinjiang. Lined up $4 billion credit line with state-owned China Development Bank in January last year; obtained $600 million in March. Investors aren't impressed by the company's coziness with the government:Brightoil's shares have more than halved in the past year. Sit holds a doctorate in philosophy from Nanjing University.

name: Billionaires
bio: Donald Sterling debuts on the Forbes World's Billionaires list thanks to extensive holdings in some 10,000 apartment units in Los Angeles and Orange Counties, as well as the Beverly Hills Plaza Hotel and a large art-deco office building on Wilshire Blvd., where he works. He bought the Los Angeles Clippers basketball team in 1981 for $12.5 million; Forbes now values the team at $305 million. Billionaire music producer and co-founder of Dreamworks movie studio David Geffen once offered to buy the team for $700 million but Sterling refused to sell. Sterling began his career as a lawyer. He regularly runs advertisements for his rental apartments in The Los Angeles Times and The New York Times.

name: Billionaires
bio: Pat Stryker and her siblings are heirs to medical device and software company, Stryker Corp. Her surgeon grandfather Homer Stryker (d. 1980) invented the mobile hospital bed and founded the company in 1941. Her father, Lee, also ran the company but died in a plane crash in 1976. John Brown became chief executive and took the company public in 1979. Today sales are $8.3 billion. A well-known Democratic fundraiser, Pat also donates to education, the arts and community programs through her Bohemian Foundation in Colorado. She owns a California winery.

name: Billionaires
bio: Suh Kyung-Bae is the chairman of South Korea's leading cosmetic company, Amore Pacific, which is making inroads internationally -- especially in China. In 2000, he established a breast cancer foundation. For the past decade Amorepacific has also supported the nation's Pink Ribbon Love Marathon to benefit women with breast cancer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Roustam Tariko, the founder of Russian Standard vodka, made a number of strategic investments in 2011, including buying a 9.9% stake in Polish CEDC, one of the largest vodka producers in the world, and a 70% stake in Gancia, a legendary Italian producer of sparkling wines and vermouths. Tariko earned his first rubles in late 1980s helping foreign tourists find rooms in Moscow hotels. He worked as a consultant for Italian confectionary Ferrero Rocher and then started selling Italian vermouth, winning an exclusive contract with Martini & Rossi. In 1998, Tariko created the first upscale brand of Russian vodka, Russian Standard. In 1999, with the help of McKinsey & Co., he set up Russian Standard Bank, pioneering a consumer credit market that was the market leader three years later. Today the bank is one of the top 30 in the Russian market; it has an exclusive partnership with American Express in Russia. Tariko owns a Boeing 737 aircraft.

name: Billionaires
bio: Peter Thiel is a major backer of Ron Paul's campaign for the Republican presidential nomination, contributing $2.6 million to the Endorse Liberty Political Action Committee (PAC), which supports Paul. In November, Blueseed announced Thiel will lead a funding round for the start-up, which aims to anchor a passenger vessel off San Francisco, allowing start-ups to skirt U.S. visa rules. In May 2011, he announced the first class of Thiel Fellows, a group of 24, all under 20 years old, whom Thiel is paying $100,000 to spend two years "building the technology companies of tomorrow" rather than attending college. Thiel invested $500,000 in Facebook in 2004. He co-founded PayPal in 1998 and sold it to Ebay in 2002 for $1.5 billion, personally netting $60 million. He opened hedge fund Clarium Capital in 2005. The firm's assets, as high as $6 billion in mid-2008, fell below $500 million last year (a quarter of that is Thiel's money). In a July regulatory filing, Clarium said it will invest a "significantly higher percentage" of assets in private equity. Thiel co-produced the film "Thank You for Smoking." A chess champion, he ranked no. 7 in the U.S. in the under-13 bracket; he was rated a master by the U.S. Chess Federation. Thiel enjoys running, hiking, surfing.
title: Partner

name: Billionaires
bio: Tapped rubber in his teenage years to support his family before building his fortune from timber concessions and palm oil plantations in Malaysia, Papua New Guinea and New Zealand. His Media Chinese International publishes more than 30 magazines and newspapers in North America, Southeast Asia and China. Sale of his stake in EON Capital to No. 5 Quek Leng Chan's Hong Leong Bank is pending a court case filed by a dissenting shareholder.

name: Billionaires
bio: With sister-in-law Joan Tisch, Wilma Tisch controls the family fortune built by their late husbands, investors Preston and Laurence Tisch. The duo started with a small New Jersey hotel in 1946 and acquired Loews Theatres in 1959. Today publicly traded Loews Corp. has diverse holdings including oil drilling (Diamond Offshore), natural gas pipelines (Boardwalk), insurance (CNA). Loews stock held steady in the past twelve months. Joan's son, Jonathan, heads Loews Hotels. Wilma's son, James, is CEO of Loews. Her other son, Andrew, is co-chairman of the board with Jonathan.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Chang Chun Group, founded in 1949 by Suhon Lin, Liao Long-shing's late father M.K. Liao, and Tseng Shin-yi, is one of Asia's most successful privately held businesses and largest plastics and petrochemicals manufacturers. From its base in Taiwan, the company has expanded over the years into the mainland and more recently Singapore.  The three families each own a third; Lin as chairman. Overseas business partners include Bayer and Mitsubishi Gas Chemical.  The three founders all attended what today is called National Taipei University of Technology.  Tseng is a devoted Christian, according to Chang Chun's website.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bulat Utemuratov returns to the billionaires list after a profitable payout from the commodity giant Glencore's IPO. His investment vehicle Verny Capital sold stakes in Kazakhstan's largest zinc miner, Kazzinc, as well as gold miner, Altyntau Gold to Glencore; Altyntau is now set to go public this year at a $5 billion valuation and is headed by Utemuratov's son, Alidar. Utermuratov's Verny Capital is also investing in hotels, recently purchasing Ritz Carltons in Moscow and Vienna. A close advisor to Kazakh president Nursultan Nazarbaev, Utemuratov serves as Kazakhstan's special envoy for cooperation affairs with Kyrgyzstan. He is a also passionate tennis player and heads the Kazakh Tennis Federation. The former majority owner of Kazakhstan's ATF Bank profited handsomely in 2007 when Italian bank UniCredit paid $2.1 billion for 91.8% of the bank.

name: Billionaires
bio: Albert von Thurn und Taxis first appeared in Forbes' billionaire rankings at age 8 but officially inherited his fortune in 2001 on his 18th birthday. In June 2008, he received an M.A. in economics and theology from the University of Edinburgh in Scotland. His assets include real estate, art and 36,000 hectares of woodland in Germany, one of the largest forest holdings in Europe. His plan to build one of the world's largest solar energy installations in Bavaria was put on hold after government financial support was cancelled. He lives in the family castle, Schloss Emmeram. The eligible bachelor is also a racecar driver and tours with a German auto-racing league.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zan Shengda is chairman of Nantong Zongyi Investment, whose diversified investments include beverages, energy, pharmaceuticals and IT. Zan's wealth is up from a year earlier in part on buoyant business at Zan-backed spirits producer Jiangsu Yanghe Brewery.  Sales in first nine months of 2011 soared 75% to $1.5 billion, helping to lift the price of the company's China-listed stock by a third from a year earlier. BLX IC Design Corp, which is one third owned by Zhan's Shanghai-listed Jiangsu Zongyi, signed a strategic cooperation agreement with Acer Group last October in Beijing. Jiangsu Zongyi, which builds solar power plants and manufactures solar cells, also said last June it had tentatively agreed buy a construction licenses for a New Jersey solar power plant from Effisolar Energy in New Jersey for $3 million; a total investment of $80 million is projected. Zongyi Group was founded in 1987 in Zan's hometown, Nantong, in Jiangsu Province.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lina Maria Aguiar is one of three daughters of Brazilian banker Amador Aguiar, the founder of Banco Bradesco, one of Brazil's largest banks. Amador's death in 1991 sparked more than a decade of court fights between his widow and his daughters over their inheritance. His widow, 40 years his junior, married him less than 4 months before he died. During ugly public court fights, Amador's widow reportedly demanded her husband's body be exhumed for a DNA test to prove paternity. His daughters eventually prevailed in court. The majority of Amador's fortune was left to the philanthropic Bradesco Foundation, started by Amador in 1956 to benefit education in Brazil. Lina Maria's sister Lia Maria Aguiar is also a billionaire.

name: Billionaires
bio: Some of the biggest deals in the media industry are hammered out at Allen's annual Sun Valley conference. Last year's attendees included Rupert Murdoch, Eric Schmidt, Michael Bloomberg and Walt Disney CEO Roger Iger. The family's investment bank, Allen & Co., has had a hand in numerous high-profile media and tech IPOs over the past decade, including Google, Linkedin, Zynga and Zillow; it also has a spot on the coveted Facebook offering. Allen's uncle Charles (d. 1994) founded the notoriously secretive private firm in 1922. He sits on the board of Coca-Cola and is the largest known individual owner of Coke stock.

name: Billionaires
bio: Babis' chemical, agricultural and food product holding company, Agrofert, is now expanding into healthcare with a new clinic in Prague. It is also growing its forestry business with acquisitions as well as expanding across Central Europe. Babis has launched a new political party, but does not plan to run himself. The son of a diplomat, he was born in what is now Slovak Republic; he began as a trader for Petrimex, precursor to Agrofert. He expanded Agrofert with the help of investors but later became the sole owner. His group encompasses over 200 companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Louis Bacon is one of the world's richest hedge fund managers but this year was not one of his best. His Moore Capital Management was down about 2%. He did manage to beat back Xcel Energy in a battle over power lines to be built across his Trinchera Colorado ranch (which he bought from the Forbes family for $175 million). Xcel has apparently retreated, though another power outfit, Tri-State Generation and Transmission Association, is still battling the billionaire. In addition to the ranch, Bacon owns Robin's Island, a 145-acre spot in New York's Peconic Bay, and his family's original plantation down south that he recently bought back. He has donated to more than 100 environmental groups including Riverkeeper. Bacon spent his summers manning a fishing boat for NYSE board member Walter Frank; fellow angler persuaded Bacon to apply to Columbia Business School. He now sits on its Board of Overseers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Baltimore Ravens owner Steve Bisciotti has seen his team sell out every game since 1996 and make it past the first round of the NFL playoffs for four straight seasons. Bisciotti grew up in Baltimore, stayed in Maryland for college at Salisbury State, and founded engineering staffing firm Aerotek in his basement with his cousin, Jim Davis, a year later. Now called Allegis Group, the company is the largest privately-held staffing firm by revenue in the United States. In his free time, Bisciotti enjoys golfing and boating and is a rabid fan of the University of Maryland men's basketball team.
title: Owner

name: Billionaires
bio: Home Depot co-founder Arthur Blank was unhappy with his Atlanta Falcons' third straight first round playoff loss, saying the NFL team "took a step back" this year. Blank bought the Falcons in 2002 after retiring; he has talked with Jon Bon Jovi about selling the singer a minority stake. Blank founded Home Depot with partner Bernie Marcus (who also became a billionaire) and handed out dollar bills in the parking lot to lure early customers. The company went public three years later and is now the world's largest home improvement retailer with $68 billion in sales and 2,200 stores. Through the Arthur M. Blank Family Foundation, founded in 1995, Blank has donated more than $250 million to charity. He was inducted into the International Civil Rights Walk of Fame in 2011 for his foundation's focus on disadvantaged youth.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Garmin co-founder Gary Burrell retired from the company in 2004 but remains chairman emeritus. He still owns more than 15% of Garmin, which he started with current chairman Min Kao in 1989, to produce navigational tools for pilots and sailors. In 1998, Garmin branched into consumer devices for lost automobile drivers and the company went public in 2000. Garmin still has its headquarters in Kansas City, including a face-to-face customer service center for people who want more technical support than they can get over the phone.
title: Chairman Emeritus

name: Billionaires
bio: William "Chip" Connor II runs the privately held sourcing and logistics business, William E. Connor & Associates, that his late father started in Tokyo after WWII. The company moved its headquarters to Hong Kong in 1985. It now sources consumer products for more than 60 customers across 20 countries. Although India is the company's fastest growing market, about half of its products are still produced in China. Chip's collection of vintage race cars appears annually at the Pebble Beach Concours d'Elegance.

name: Billionaires
bio: Intuit co-founder Scott Cook conceived the idea for Quicken software in response to his wife's complaints about balancing a checkbook. In their early years, the company almost went under twice. Cook, who previously worked at Proctor & Gamble, started Intuit in 1983, took his company public in 1993 and then stepped down as CEO in 1994. He's still a board member and the largest single investor. Intuit was the first company in the software industry to do testing with consumers before launching a product. Most recently, Intuit developed Fasal, a text messaging service that helps farmers in India get real time agricultural prices and information. Cook originally wanted to be an economist but found it boring. While at USC, he turned the university's bankrupt ski club into the largest campus organization in just one year.

name: Billionaires
bio: A lawyer's son, Craft was reared in coal country. He became a lawyer, and then joined diversified coal company MAPCO as an assistant general counsel in 1980. He became president in 1987. Craft was rewarded with a big stake for leading the firm's LBO and conversion into a tax-efficient public master limited partnership in 1996; it was renamed Alliance Resource Partners three years later. He has been chief executive since and overseen subsequent expansion across Appalachia and the Midwest as revenue increased to $390 million. Craft donated $6 million to finish the basketball practice facility at the University of Kentucky where he got his undergraduate and law degrees. Craft and his wife Kathy divorced in late 2011; the net worth reflected here also includes the assets belonging to his former spouse.

name: Billionaires
bio: Syntel co-founder Bharat Desai was born in Kenya but spent his teenage years in India, where he attended the Indian Institute of Technology.  He moved to the U.S. after landing a programming job for Tata Consultancy Services in 1976. He founded Syntel in 1980 with his wife, Neerja Sethi, while earning his M.B.A. from the University of Michigan. Desai took the company public in 1997 and it now has some 16,200 employees. He has since established a foundation supporting entrepreneurship and education.  He also played for India in the 1994 bridge world championship. Shares of Syntel have fluctuated over the last year but have recently managed to bolster Desai's fortune by about $50 million.
title: Chairman and Co-founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Carlos Hank Rhon makes the billionaires list for the first time, thanks in large part to his family's 93.4% holding of Grupo Financiero Interacciones, currently worth close to $800 million. The group controls Banco Interacciones, an integrated financial services firm and investment bank in Mexico. The Hank family also fully controls Grupo Hermes; its Hermes Infraestructura arm builds just about every type of major infrastructure: bridges, roads, hydroelectric plants. In the past several years, the Hank family has been developing Playa Mujeres, a new luxury tourist destination in Cancun. The family also has a transportation business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Global markets might have been tumultuous, but investors continue to support hedge fund manager Michael Hintze, who saw funds under management at his firm CQS increase from about $8.5 billion to $10.5 billion. Hintze also continued to add farmland in Australia to his rural property empire, now valued at over $140 million. Hintze trained as an engineer and served in the Australian army before entering the world of financial services. He had stints at Goldman Sachs and Credit Suisse First Boston before launching CQS in 1999. Hintze, a prominent donor to the UK Conservative Party, spent much of the last 12 months in the headlines of the political pages rather than business pages due to controversy surrounding his donations. He has given generously to the University of Sydney and to restoration projects at the Vatican. He is also Chairman of the Prince's Foundation for the Built Environment, trustee of UK's National Gallery and Chairman of the UK Patrons of the Arts of the Vatican Museums.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chicago native Irsay's fortune comes courtesy of the gridiron. Father Robert (d. 1997) purchased the Baltimore Colts in 1972 for $15 million; 12 years later he shocked local fans, moving the franchise to Indianapolis after years of head-butting with city government. Jim graduated from Southern Methodist U., working his way up from the Colts' ticket counter to general manager in two years. His father's 1997 death ignited a legal battle with his stepmother for team control; Jim emerged as the NFL's youngest owner at 37. He earned his first Super Bowl ring with the Colts' 2006 victory over the Chicago Bears; the team is worth more than $1 billion today.  The Colts have one of the best stadium deals in the NFL for their $720 million Lucas Oil Stadium, which opened in 2008. The team pays just $250,000 a year in rent and the city covers all operating and maintenance expenses. The Colts? NFL-leading streak of nine straight playoff appearances ended this year after quarterback Peyton Manning suffered a herniated disk in his neck and missed the entire season. Irsay fired GM Chris Polian and head Jim Caldwell after the season. Currently, the question swirling around the organization is whether the Colts will draft No. 1 college recruit Andrew Luck and play the Stanford great ahead of Manning, who has said he will play in 2012. As a music fan and collector, James owns guitars previously owned by Jerry Garcia, George Harrison and Elvis Presley. He also owns letters from George Washington and Abraham Lincoln and the original manuscript of Jack Kerouac's "On the Road." Irsay paid $2.4 million for the book.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: This year former MIT engineering professor Irwin Jacobs plans to step down from the board of Qualcomm, the wireless chip manufacturer he started in 1985. While his net worth fluctuates with the company's stock, he'd be much richer if he didn't keep giving his shares away. He's also donating technology, providing, for instance, smartphones for at-risk elderly people in conjunction with the Red Cross and equipment to help medical clinics in developing countries. Jacobs started out in academia, earning his doctorate at MIT and then teaching electrical engineering for seven years. He moved to California in 1966 and taught computer science at University of California at San Diego, where the engineering school is now named after him. Two years later, he founded Linkabit Corporation to develop satellite communication systems. His son Paul took over as CEO of Qualcomm in 2006.
title: Cofounder & Chairman Emeritus

name: Billionaires
bio: Consumer lender Promise, which Ryoichi Jinnai founded, will be acquired by Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group through a stock swap, after Sumitomo rescued the lender with a capital injection of $1.5 billion in December 2011. Promise, along with its peers, was negatively impacted by changes in regulations that set ceilings on interest rates and retroactively applied rules allowing consumers to apply for reimbursement claims. Promise will delist from the Tokyo stock exchange in March. Retired in 2001, Jinnai now raises cattle and grows mangoes and bananas in greenhouses on Japan's northern island of Hokkaido, known for its frigid winters.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kim Tack-Jin founded successful online gaming company NCSoft in 1997. Its hit game "Ion" is popular in Korea, China, Japan, and the United States. NCSoft plans to launch "Blade & Soul" this year. In 2011, Kim Tack-Jin founded a baseball team.

name: Billionaires
bio: Moscow-born banker Alexander Knaster emigrated to America with his parents in 1976 and became a U.S. citizen. He returned to Russia in the mid-1990s and headed Credit Suisse First Boston's Moscow operation. He later became chief of Alfa Bank, Russia's largest private commercial bank. Now he chairs Pamplona Capital Management, a British private equity firm he founded, whose clients include Alfa Group. Knaster is a board member at Alfa Bank and TNK-BP. Last year Alfa Group, where he is a minority shareholder, blocked the mega deal between Russian state company Rosneft and BP. He studied at Carnegie Mellon, where he later established the Alexander M. Knaster Scholarship Fund to aid full-time undergraduate students in the department of Electrical and Computer Engineering; he also endowed the chair of the mathematics department at Carnegie Mellon. He has an M.B.A. from Harvard.

name: Billionaires
bio: Famed investor Tom Lee, whose first private equity shop paid $140 million for Snapple in 1992 and flipped it two years later to Quaker Oats for $2 billion, had a productive year. Dunkin Donuts, in which he's long had a stake, went public as did the Nielsen Company. He was part of the investor group that sold Warner Music Group to fellow billionaire Len Blavatnik; he is back on its board.  His other notable bets include one in Papa Murphy's, a quick-service restaurant that lets you take the pizza home to bake, and in PDR Network, a physicans' reference book on prescription drugs. Lee collects Andy Warhol, Francis Bacon, Mark Rothko, and sits on the board of the Whitney and the Museum of Modern Art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Li Li owns 40% and is chairman of Shenzhen Hepalink Pharmaceutical, which makes the blood thinner heparin and related products. Sales in the first nine months fell 29% from a year earlier to $328 million; net profit plunged by 46% to $81 million amid falling prices. Li's wife Li Tan, a director and vice president, owns 32% of the company.     Li worked in a meat company in Chengdu and a biotech company in Chongqing before he founded Hepalink in 1998.   Hepalink signed a cooperation agreement in June last year to invest $798 million to set up a biomedical manufacturing base in Shenzhen.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lin Li learned about finance just out of college in a job at the state-owned Bank of China before taking the plunge as an investor and entrepreneur. He went on to become a billionaire through an investment in 2003 in Ping An Insurance, one of China's three biggest investment companies.  Of late, however, he has been reducing his stake. The flagship of Li's empire, Shenzhen Liye Group, holds shares in Chinalion Securities and Nanjing Liye  Power Transformer as well as Ping An Insurance.

name: Billionaires
bio: BYD vice chairman Lu Xiang-yang has seen his wealth shrink in the past year amid lower than expected sales and poor profits at the Shenzhen-based electric car maker. He's one of two BYD-related billionaires on this year's list, along with chairman Wang Chuanfu. Lu runs investment company Guangzhou Youngy Management & Investment Group. He sold off  his battery material companies Guangzhou Rongda Battery Materials after BYD said it would engage in the same business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Texas legend Red McCombs got his start moving Ford Edsels. At his peak he owned 55 dealerships. He owns fewer now, but still enough to move 27,000 cars a year. "All other products pale in comparison with the desire to have a car," he says. Over the years he has owned and sold Clear Channel Communications and pro-sports teams the Nuggets, the Spurs and the Vikings. McCombs breeds cattle, owns an oil company and builds condos. He is now preparing for the return of Formula One racing to the U.S. as an investor in a new track being built near Austin for the 2012 Grand Prix. McCombs had  some heated negotiations with racing honcho Bernie Ecclestone. His autobiography last year, "Big Red," gives the secrets of his business success. "Attitude is absolutely the most critical element in selling anything. You can't fake attitude," he writes. His heir apparent, daughter Marsha Shields, is getting more involved in the business.

name: Billionaires
bio: National Inventors Hall of Famer Gary Michelson accumulated his wealth from a record $1.35 billion settlement with medical device giant Medtronic in 2004 after years of litigation over spinal surgery patents. He is credited with more than 250 U.S. patents on orthopedic instruments, methods and devices. The windfall from the settlement freed Michelson to focus on animal welfare. He started the Found Animals Foundation, which focuses on overfilled pet shelters. In 2008 he started the $25 million Michelson Prize for the scientist who invents the first injectable pet sterilant, and gave another $50 million to research in this field. He has donated $100 million to his Medical Research Foundation Trust and Michelson Medical Research Foundation. He recently bought 60,000 acres in Panama and Costa Rica in efforts to reforest and open land for animal sanctuaries. Michelson transitioned into the distressed real estate market in 2009 and began buying up commercial properties in Colorado, Arizona, Nevada and California, as well as distressed securities such as timber and energy. He developed the Twenty Million Minds Foundation to offer free and low-cost digital textbooks for low-income college students. In 2010 he teamed up with actor Pierce Brosnan to successfully pressure the White House to renew a moratorium on whaling. Michelson is also an active participant in congressional bipartisan patent reform legislation, which passed in 2011 by an overwhelming majority.

name: Billionaires
bio: Twenty one years ago, Nicholas launched semiconductor maker Broadcom from a spare bedroom of a Redondo Beach condo with partner and billionaire Henry Samueli, who is now a fellow billionaire. In 2008, he mobilized California to pass Marsy's Law, a crime victim's bill of rights named for his murdered sister. He faced separate charges of drug distribution (ecstasy, cocaine, methamphetamine) and options backdating, but both were dismissed in 2010 and Nicholas has since focused on philanthropy. Nicholas Academic Centers will help send 60 underprivileged graduating seniors to college this year. The divorce settlement with his ex-wife Stacey is costing Nicholas hundreds of millions of dollars.
title: Cofounder

name: Billionaires
bio:
Cofounder and onetime chief executive of Infosys, Nandan Nilekani now chairs the Unique Identification Authority of India, a government arm that's issuing identity numbers to all Indian residents. It has issued 135 million so far, making it one of the world's largest biometric databases. It has rolled out a national payments system that enables subsidies to the poor to be paid directly into their bank accounts. But it faced opposition from the federal home ministry which is developing a similar National Population Register, causing the prime minister to intervene to sort out the tangle. He still holds a minor stake in Infosys but gave up his board seat in 2009.

.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tuncay Ozilhan is Chairman of the Anadolu Group conglomerate which he controls with fellow billionaire Kamil Yazici. The group's beverage company, Anadolu Efes, formed a strategic alliance with brewer SABMiller in October; SABMiller will own 24% of Anadolu Efes while Efes will take over SABMiller's operations in Russia and Ukraine. Anadolu is also growing its energy ventures via partnerships. The group joined with the Dogus and Dogan Group to build the Aslancik Dam and Hydroelectric Plant which is expected to be up and running by 2014; other plant build outs are on track including a $150 million investment in Georgia. The ex-basketball player never misses Efes Pilsen basketball club's games. Ozilhan also has a 3,000-piece pen collection.

name: Billionaires
bio: The only son of former presidential candidate Ross Perot, Henry Ross Perot Jr. sold a majority stake in the Dallas Mavericks to Mark Cuban a decade ago, but held onto 5%. In 2010 he sued Cuban for mismanagment. Last February, an arbitrator ruled in favor of majority owner Cuban. In June, Cuban filed a motion to dismiss, sending a photo of himself with an NBA trophy as evidence. Perot Jr. ran Perot Systems until 2009 when his family sold the company to Dell for $3.9 billion. He pocketed approximately $400 million in cash and joined Dell's board. He runs Hillwood, a massive nationwide real estate firm. Hillwood's biggest project is the 18,000-acre AllianceTexas industrial park near Dallas, which includes homes, offices, a giant railyard and its own airport. Hillwood also drills for oil and gas in Texas, Alabama and Iraq. With Marathon Oil and Maersk Oil it is developing the Sarsang field in the Kurdish region of Iraq. Perot served in the Air Force. At age 23, he became the first pilot to circumnavigate the globe in a helicopter.

name: Billionaires
bio: Since 2008, T. Boone Pickens, the billionaire chairman of BP Capital LLC, has spent more than $70 million promoting his "Pickens Plan," an energy plan aimed at helping America attain oil independence through the use of natural gas, wind and solar energy.  He is lobbying for a congressional bill that would make trucking companies run on natural gas instead of gasoline, a move that would provide a boost to his investment in Clean Fuels Energy, which provides natural gas as alternative fuel to vehicles, and runs fueling stations. Pickens graduated from Oklahoma State with a degree in geology in 1951. In 1956, he started Mesa Petroleum with $2,500 which he then sold to fellow billionaire Richard Rainwater. He currently owns water rights in the Texas panhandle. Among his charitable donations: $500 million to Oklahoma State athletics and academics. He was inducted into the Oklahoma Sports Hall of Fame last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cash-rich pharma tycoon Ajay Piramal sold his Piramal Healthcare's domestic formulations business to U.S.-based Abbott Labs for $3.7 billion in 2010. Company's other interests include critical care, drug discovery and custom manufacturing. He used some cash to diversify: bought an 11% stake in Vodafone's Indian unit after the Ruia brothers sold out. He, in turn, plans to sell out when company lists. Other new ventures include financial services and defence security systems. He also owns Piramal Realty, a privately-held property arm, where his Harvard-educated son Anand works. It's looking to develop 30 million square feet of offices and apartments in Mumbai.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turmeric farmer's son, K.Anji Reddy built his $1.5 billion (revenues) Dr. Reddy's Laboratories into generics champ.  It has a marketing alliance with GlaxoSmithKline since 2009. Last July, it formed a joint venture with Fujifilm Corp. to develop and sell generics in Japan. While it has been investing in drug discovery since 1993, it's had no luck so far.

name: Billionaires
bio: As the best friend of Russian billionaire Roman Abramovich, Shvidler has made his fortune alongside the richer Russian. His biggest holding: a 3.4% stake in Russia's largest steelmaker, Evraz. He also has Moscow real estate, gold mining and cash from the sale of his Sibneft stake to Gazprom in 2005. In February 2011, Millhouse, where he is a minority shareholder, sold 25% of its shares of the most influential TV channel in Russia (The First) to Yury Kovalchuk, a friend of prime minister Putin. Shvidler's vineyard at his Château Thenac in France produces nine grape varieties; the property also has two plum orchards. His 370-foot yacht, Le Grand Bleu, was a gift from Abramovich. He lives in London in Belgravia, but the U.S. citizen also owns a house in Snowmass, Colorado.

name: Billionaires
bio: Edwin Soeryadjaya is the U.S.-educated son of a former billionaire who founded automotive group Astra but eventually lost control and much of his wealth. Soeryadjaya began working to restore his family's fortune, setting up investment firm Saratoga Investama Sedaya in 1998. Today, through his private equity firm Saratoga Capital, he holds big chunk in coal miner Adaro Energy, where he's one of five co-founders. He also has a stake in cell tower company Tower Bersama Infrastructure and bought Mandala Airlines last year with his partner Sandiaga Uno.

name: Billionaires
bio: Helmet Sohmen, an Austrian citizen who lives in Hong Kong, saw his net worth tumble by $700 million over the past year as shares of shipping concern BW Offshore and the value of BW Maritime's very large crude tankers cratered. He chairs BW Group, whose fleet of more than 140 oil tankers and gas carriers is one of the world's largest maritime groups. Sohmen settled in Hong Kong more than 40 years ago and married the daughter of shipping tycoon Yue-Kong Pao. He is the recipient of China's Friendship Ambassador award for his contributions to China-Austria ties. A Southern Methodist University law school alumnus, he supports a graduate scholarship program for Chinese lawyers studying at SMU's Dedman School of Law. His Oxford and Harvard-educated eldest son, Andreas Sohmen-Pao, is chief executive of BW Maritime and BW Gas.

name: Billionaires
bio: Blinds baron Ralph Sonnenberg is the CEO and owns more than 80 percent of the Hunter Douglas Group, a Netherlands company that makes window coverings and architectural products. Sonnenberg's father founded the group in 1919 as a machine-tool manufacturer, eventually developing new technology for the production of lightweight aluminum slats for Venetian blinds. They supplied blinds and ceiling systems to the world's tallest building, the Burj Khalifa tower in Dubai. Sonnenberg's sons, Marko and David, also work for Hunter Douglas.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Hunter Douglas N.V.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Third-generation of Thapar business clan, Gautam Thapar runs $4 billion (sales) Avantha Group, which he's chaired since 2006.  It has interests in power equipment maker Crompton Greaves and papermaker Ballarpur Industries. Shares of Crompton tumbled after its former CEO, who retired last June, sold his shares, and it soon reported big drop in quarterly net profits. Enraged investors reportedly demanded that company sell its newly purchased corporate jet. Thapar bought shares in bid to boost stock. Avid golfer, he's president of the Professional Golf Tour of India.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mustafa Latif Topbas has a significant stake in publicly traded BIM, a chain of discount supermarkets with operations in Turkey and Morocco; the company's stock price is up 18% over the past year. He also owns shares in his family textile business, as well as has partnerships with companies such as Ak Food and Link Food which belong to the Ulker Family, Turkey's largest food producer. The media-shy magnate shuns the press.

name: Billionaires
bio: After spending her way to a gubernatorial loss in California last year, Whitman is back on top as the latest CEO of Hewlett-Packard. Whitman is tasked with turning around the struggling technology firm in the wake of the ousting of her predecessor, Leo Apotheker, fired just weeks after he announced that HP would be getting out of the PC business for good. For the low price of just $1 a year, the former eBay CEO has her work cut out for her: the company's TouchPad Tablet was called a failure in 2011, phones aren't selling well and stock prices are down more than 15 points in the past twelve months. There's a lot at stake, and HP knows it. Her incentive stock options could be worth millions, but only if prices rise by 40% in the next 24 months under her watch. Whitman also serves on the boards of P&G and ZipCar.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Dan Wilks' father, Voy Wilks, took up bricklaying to literally build a house for his family and get them out of the goat shed. He then asked his employer at a Cisco, Texas factory for a small raise. When his employer refused, Voy quit and switched his career to masonry. Following in their father's footsteps, Dan and his brother Farris became masons themselves, founding Wilks Masonry together in 1995. In 2002 the brothers branched into the hydraulic fracturing and oil field services industry with the founding of Frac Tech. This past May, the brothers sold their nearly 70% combined interest in Frac Tech to a partnership lead by Temasek Holdings for $3.5 billion. The pair recently purchased the 66,000-acre N Bar Ranch in Montana from fellow billionaire Tom Siebel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Farris Wilks' father, Voy Wilks, took up bricklaying to literally build a house for his family and get them out of the goat shed. He then asked his employer at a Cisco, Texas factory for a small raise. When his employer refused, Voy quit and switched his career to masonry. Following in their father's footsteps Farris and his brother Dan became masons themselves, founding Wilks Masonry together in 1995. In 2002 the brothers branched into the hydraulic fracturing and oil field services industry with the founding of Frac Tech. This past May the brothers sold their nearly 70% combined interest in Frac Tech to a partnership lead by Temasek Holdings, for $3.5 billion. The pair recently purchased the 66,000 acre N Bar Ranch in Montana from fellow billionaire Tom Siebel. Farris serves as pastor of the Assembly of Yahweh 7th Day in Cisco, Texas.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wong Luen Hei is chairman of Hong Kong-listed China Liansu, a manufacturer of plastic pipes and pipe fittings. His wealth has declined from a year ago on investor worries about the outlook for the building industry at a time of tight monetary policy, which in turn led to a fall in its share price.  The company, however, sees decent long-term prospects from China's policies to encourage urbanization. Wong's wife Zuo Xiaoping and brother-in-law Zuo Manlun are members Liansu's board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chinese entrepreneur Wu Yiling makes the Forbes Billionaires' list for the first time this year.  Wu chairs Shijiazhuang Yiling Pharmaceutical, which debuted on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange last July.  The company produces Chinese medicine for heart diseases and the flu. Sales grew 31% in the first nine months of 2011 to $221 million; that rise helped to increase net profit by 43% to $47 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Elaine Wynn became a billionaire in 2010 after her second divorce from casino mogul Steve Wynn (yes, they were married and divorced two times).  As part of the most recent divorce settlement, Elaine received 11 million shares of Wynn Resorts. She has been a director of the company for more than a decade. Wynn's fortune has held steady since last year, after Wynn shares rose and then fell on weak fourth quarter results and the announcement that Wynn's vice chairman, largest shareholder and co-founder Kazuo Okada is suing the company. A basketball fan, Wynn sits on the board of the Basketball Hall of Fame.
title: Board Member
employment: {'name': 'Wynn Las Vegas, LLC', 'title': 'Board Member', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Xiong Xuqiang is chairman the Ningbo Yinyi Group, a real estate developer based in the eastern Chinese city of Ningbo. The company injected assets into Shenzhen-traded Gansu Languang Science and Technology last year in a backdoor listing; the business is now called Yinyi Real Estate. Xiong, who makes the Forbes World's Billionaires list for the first time this year, also invests in resources, particularly coal and nickel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhong Sheng Jian, the chairman of Singapore-listed, China-focused Yanlord Land Group has escaped the mainland's property market downturn without much damage to his wealth.  One reason: Good future prospects.  The company in the past year has launched or invested in new projects in Nanjing, Tianjian, Shanghai and Zhuhai, all relatively well-off Chinese cities. Yanlord's investment partners include Shanghai Youyou Group and Singapore-listed Ho Bee Investment.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhu Xingliang chairs Shenzhen-listed Suzhou Gold Mantis Construction and Decoration, which designs and constructs hotels, office buildings, hospitals, stadiums and other public building interiors. The company's revenue has increased of late as relatively big developers have been going ahead with large projects, even amid government efforts to curb real estate prices. Zhu's projects include the Olympic Stadium ?nicknamed the "bird's nest" ? in Beijing, China's National Grand Theater, the National Museum of China, and numerous hotels. The company projects that  revenue last year increased by more than half to $1.6 billion, doubling net profit to $123 million. Gold Mantis provides financial support for the Gold Mantis School of Architecture and Urban Environment at Soochow University.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ahmet Nazif Zorlu founded Zorlu Holding with his brother Zeki Zorlu; started out in textiles, expanded to include energy and real estate. His $3.5 billion Zorlu Center is almost complete; it will include a shopping mall, residences, offices and a hotel. His Vestel produces durable consumer goods, white appliances and TVs. Zorlu is a high school dropout who shuttles around Europe in custom-designed helicopter.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mikhail Abyzov owns E4 Group, one of the biggest private construction subcontractors in Russia's energy sector. In October 2011, he sold his entire 25% stake in Russian road and bridge construction company Mostotrest, prior to the company's IPO. Abyzov started out in the early 1990s, while he was a student of Moscow State University, importing food from Bulgaria. Later he built a controlling stake in Novosibirskenergo, the biggest of the regional energy companies which remained independent of the state monopoly. After a stint at the government-owned energy concern RAO UES, Abyzov resigned in 2005 and bought several engineering and construction companies, which he combined to form his E4 Group. He is an adviser to Russian president Dmitry Medvedev, and coordinator of the Public Committee of Medvedev's Supporters.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mohamed Al Fayed sold the famed Harrod's department store in London to Qatar Holding in 2010 for a reported $2.4 billion. He's since shifted his attention to online retail, buying U.K.-based discount fashion website Cocosa in July. He bought for daughter Camilla a controlling stake in Princess Kate Middleton's favorite designer brand, Issa. He's the owner of the Hotel Ritz in Paris, the Fulham football club, a castle in Scotland, and has a ground lease on 75 Rockefeller Plaza in New York. The flamboyant London-based Egyptian still courts controversy. He financed a documentary alleging that the royal family was out to kill Princess Diana and his son Dodi when their car crashed in Paris.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ansin's father, Sidney, used proceeds from the family's Boston shoemaking business to purchase Florida real estate in the 1950s. Several years later Edmund took over the family's operations in southern Florida and expanded into television, buying Miami TV station WSVN for $3.4 million in 1962. Today the station, owned by Ansin's Sunbeam Television and operating as a Fox affiliate, enjoys success as a tabloid news station, with a focus on crime and consumer interest stories. Sunbeam also owns and operates NBC and CW affiliate stations in Ansin's native Boston. Sunbeam recently sued the Nielson Company over its television ratings practices, alleging anti-trust violations; all charges were dismissed by the Southern Florida U.S. District Court. Ansin maintains substantial commercial real estate holdings in the Miami and Indianapolis metro areas.
title: President

name: Billionaires
bio: Roman Avdeev is the owner of Credit Bank of Moscow. The bank successfully survived the crisis of the world's financial system: in the three years since, its assets have risen more than 3 times to $7 billion. Avdeev started in the late 1980s in decoder production, then in the 1990s bought a bank. He also owns agricultural land and commercial and residential real estate. Adveev has 20 children; 16 of them are adopted. He is an aficionado of yoga.

name: Billionaires
bio: India-born Bhargava has had a handful of different careers: demolition man, Princeton undergrad, cab driver, plastics executive. He even spent 12 years living in a Delhi ashram as a monk. But he struck it rich eight years ago with 5-Hour Energy, a two-ounce elixir of caffeine, B-vitamins and taurine that sells for $3 a bottle and has made him a billionaire. 5-Hour's parent company, Living Essentials, nets about $300 million on $600 million annual revenue. Bhargava owns less than 40% of the company, having pledged 45% to philanthropic efforts. He's known to be litigious, so copycat brands beware.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former banker Julio Bozano keeps out of the limelight. A large chunk of his fortune came from the sale in 2000 of Banco Bozano, Simonsen to Spain's Banco Santander Central Hispano. In 2006 he reportedly sold stakes in a coffee plantation and a Rio de Janeiro shopping center to a new Brazilian investment fund. He owns a 6% stake in Brazilian jetmaker Embraer, the world's third-largest maker of airplanes. A devout thoroughbred horse owner, he reportedly has 300 mares at several farms around the world. Has a home in Greenwich, Conn.

name: Billionaires
bio: A disciple of famed Columbia Business School professor and father of value investing Benjamin Graham, Charles Brandes founded Brandes Investment Partners in 1974. Today the firm manages $32.9 billion, down from $120 billion in March of 2007. A stickler for due diligence, Brandes believes in painstaking financial analysis to find companies with high intrinsic values trading at discounted stock prices. Brandes enjoys studying and understanding worldwide economic growth and the lack thereof, and is a fan of Elton John, who he had perform at his 2006 wedding to his wife, Tanya. Brandes also enjoys playing soccer and tennis in his spare time, and is an avid equestrian. Through his Tanya & Charles Brandes Foundation, Brandes supports the San Diego Symphony and Elton John's Aids Foundation.
title: Founder & Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Brandes Investment Partners, L.P.', 'title': 'Founder & Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Hubert Burda is the CEO and namesake of the $2.4 billion (sales) Hubert Burda Media company, which publishes well-known German magazines including Focus and Bunte. In January 2011, he transferred 40% of the company to his two children, Jacob and Elisabeth. He still retains 60%, a stake that represents the bulk of his net worth. A committed philanthropist, Burda supports the Petrarca Prize for German literature. He established the Felix Burda Foundation, which is committed to reducing the number of deaths from colon cancer in Germany. He also formed the Burda Academy of the Third Millennium, an interdisciplinary forum for researchers and thinkers. Burda is married to well-known German actress Maria Furtwangler.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ahmet Calik's Calik Holding is considering proposals to sell its Sabah-ATV media holdings, which publishes Forbes Turkey, under license from Forbes Media LLC. These assets were acquired in 2008 with over a billion in loans. Calik is focusing instead on renewable energy and energy distribution; the group acquired electricity distribution company YEDAS last year. It has also won contracts to build power plants in Iraq, Uzbekistan and Turkmenistan.Calik also owns Aktifbank in Turkey and BKT Bank and is developing billion dollar real estate projects in Istanbul. Next up: expanding his gold mining operations in Turkey. Calik began building his holdings with Gap Guneydogu Tekstil, one of the world's top 10 denim producers, which sells products to Diesel, Levi's, Gap and other Western brands; today this business is less than 5% of total company turnover.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Chick-Fil-A founder remains chairman of the company, which is the second largest fast food chicken chain in the country (only KFC is bigger). Chick-Fil-A is still a family business: Cathy's oldest son Dan has been president since 2001, youngest son Don ("Bubba") is a senior executive, and several grandchildren are now franchise owners.The chain operates more than 1,600 stores in 40 states. Among its most popular items: chicken sandwiches and waffle fries. A devout Baptist, Cathy keeps his stores closed on Sundays. Chick-Fil-A has come under fire in recent months for appearing to oppose equal rights. Its charitable arm, WinShape, reportedly rejected same-sex couples from a retreat, explaining that it "defines marriage from the Biblical standard".

name: Billionaires
bio: The son of a sewing supply salesman, Charney worked his way through Brooklyn Law School by singing in synagogues. He considered pursuing a career as a vocalist but instead chose entertainment law. He represented Sammy Davis Jr., among others. Charney expanded his practice beyond entertainment, maximizing tax benefits for oil partnerships. He acted as an adviser to Jimmy Carter and he helped broker the Camp David Accords between Egypt and Israel in 1978. He then made a foray into real estate, buying his first building, One Times Square, on the night Jimmy Carter lost the presidential election to Ronald Reagan in 1980. He borrowed money and reinvested his income into 12 surrounding buildings. He currently owns three skyscrapers in Times Square, amounting to 1.5 million feet of commercial space. Charney has written four books, including, most recently, "The Mystery of the Kaddish."

name: Billionaires
bio: Che Jianxin is chairman of Red Star Macalline, one of China's largest furniture chains, with 99 stores. It has prospered with the country's boom in real estate. Good profits have attracted new investors to Red Star, including fellow billionaire Guo Guangchang, whose Fosun International owns a minority stake in the company. (Fosun Media is a partner of Forbes Media.)  That healthy demand for its shares may lead the company to undertake an IPO this year.

name: Billionaires
bio: A current Stanford professor, David Cheriton met with students Larry Page and Sergey Brin on his front porch in 1998, eventually signing them one of their first checks to fund then-dorm room startup, Google. That investment has appreciated almost exponentially for the frugal billionaire, who still drives a 1986 Volkswagen Vanagon and hasn't been to a barber shop in 15 years (he cuts his own hair.) Aside from Google, Cheriton has co-founded three successful startups with fellow billionaire Andreas Bechtolsheim including Granite Systems, which was acquired by Cisco in 1996, and Kealia, which was bought by Sun Microsystems in 2004. Their latest venture, Santa Clara-based Arista Networks, builds network switches for high-performance computer environments.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Marcos crony Eduardo Cojuangco who controls San Miguel, food and beverage conglomerate best known for its beer, debuts on list. Spun off brewery in 2007, diversifying into power, infrastructure and heavy industry. In 2010 he sold an option to a group of investors to buy him out for an undisclosed sum. The country's Supreme Court has ruled that his stake in San Miguel, which the Presidential Commission on Good Government had alleged he got because of his links with the former dictator, wasn't ill-gotten.

name: Billionaires
bio: Peter Cruddas founded CMC Markets, a London-based online financial retailer, and serves as CEO. He dropped out of the Shoreditch School at age 15 and started his business a few years later with $16,000 in savings. Over the years he expanded the company and sold a 10% stake to Goldman Sachs in 2007, reportedly for more than $100 million. Cruddas has received honorary degrees from Oxford and Loughborough universities for being a leader in his field as well as for his philanthropic efforts through the Peter Cruddas Foundation, which helps disadvantaged youths discover their potential through education and sports. Cruddas is co-treasurer of the Conservative Party and an avid golfer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Economics PhD Leszek Czarnecki made his first fortune creating Poland's largest leasing company, listing it on the London Stock Exchange in 2000 before selling out to French bank Credit Agricole for $280 million a year later. Since then he's concentrated on real state, banking and insurance; he's the majority shareholder of financial group Getin Holding and controls Poland's Getin Noble Bank, Get Bank and real estate company LC Corp. A cave diver since his 20s, he beat a world record in 2009, swimming 10.5 miles in underground corridors over the course of 10 hours.

name: Billionaires
bio: Head of consumer electronics and appliances group Videocon, Venugopal Dhoot, faced heat over his telecom unit; he and older sibling Rajkumar were among several tycoons to be deposed before the Central Bureau of Investigation over a major corruption scandal involving granting of telecom licenses. While Dhoot denies any wrongdoing, group was among those whose telecom licences were cancelled by government. Oil-and-gas arm claims to have struck oil in Brazil and off the Mozambique coast. Group's power arm is setting up projects of 2,400 megawatts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Italian financier Ennio Doris, a friend of former Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, co-founded financial services group Mediolanum SpA with Berlusconi in 1982. The bank currently has 1.1 million customers and nearly 2,000 employees. He also partnered with Berlusconi's Fininvest Group in 1982. Doris still runs Mediolanum SpA, whose companies provide investment advice, banking services, life insurance and real estate loans. Shares of Mediolanum have fallen since February 2011 due to the country's recession; as a result Doris is worth $200 million less than a year ago. His son Massimo, 42, is heir apparent.

name: Billionaires
bio: When he was 47, David Duffield founded PeopleSoft, mortgaging his house to fund his fourth start-up. PeopleSoft became the world's second-largest application software company. After an 18-month takeover battle with nemesis Larry Ellison, Oracle acquired PeopleSoft for $10 billion in 2005. Once again Duffield is competing with the Oracle chief with his fifth start-up, enterprise software firm Workday. Sales were up 90% to an estimated $100 million last year. With his wife, Duffield donated $2 million to help find homes for rescued animals through Maddie's Fund, an animal welfare foundation named after his beloved schnauzer. He has paid for the adoptions of more than 600,000 pets since he started the operation in 1994. Duffield says he plans to leave his fortune to his animal charity, not his 11 children.
title: Chairman and co-CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Gleb Fetisov owns My Bank in Moscow as well as My Decker Capital, an investment firm in Beijing that includes a fund that poured about $100 million into China's largest retail chain, New Cooperation Trade Chain (NCS), last year. Fetisov studied economics at Moscow State University, earning a doctorate. He headed several investment firms before joining Alfa Group in 1995. He first worked in the firm's food-and-commodities-trading subsidiary, Alfa Eco, then led the group's takeover of an aluminum plant in Siberia. He later became a lobbyist and member of the Federation Council, the upper house of parliament, but stepped down in 2009. Fetisov also maintains a large stake in Altimo, a company that inherited Alfa Eco's assets and now has major holdings in Russia's telecom industry.

name: Billionaires
bio: Andrei Filatov, with partners and fellow billionaires Konstantin Nikolaev and Nikita Mishin, co-owns railway and port operator, N-Trans group. In summer 2011, the partners took Global Ports Investments, one of the biggest port operators in Russia, public, for about $500 million. Filatov was born in Ukraine and earned a degree as a chess teacher and coach from the Academy of Physical Culture and Sports in Belarus. Filatov worked in expedition companies in Murmansk's port before partnering with Nikolaev and Mishin in 1996 to found Severstaltrans; Alexei Mordashov was also an investor. In 2007 the partners bought Mordashov's stake; in 2008 the group was renamed N-Trans. Last fall, partners Mishin and Nikolaev sold their 13% stake in railway operator Transoil to Gennady Timchenko, a close friend of Russian Prime Minister Vladimir Putin. Andrey Filatov kept his 7% stake. Financed memorial in Paris to famous chess master and the first Russian world champion, Alexander Alehin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Yahoo co-founder David Filo still works at the struggling internet portal, even as the company laid off employees and outsourced its search business to Microsoft in recent years. In January 2012, fellow Yahoo co-founder Jerry Yang resigned from the board and all other positions within the company. Filo remains Yahoo's largest individual shareholder despite some active selling. He met Yang when they were both Stanford Ph.D. students, dropping out after creating Yahoo in 1994. The site was originally called "Jerry and David's Guide to the World Wide Web," but the duo changed the name to an acronym representing "Yet Another Hierarchical Officious Oracle." Filo, who was born in Michigan and moved to Louisiana as a child, received a B.S. degree in computer engineering from Tulane University. He donated $30 million to his alma mater in 2005.
title: Chief Yahoo (director)

name: Billionaires
bio: William Fisher's parents, Donald and Doris Fisher, founded the Gap as a San Francisco jeans and music store in 1969. Now with more than 3,000 locations, the Gap empire includes Banana Republic, Gap Kids and Old Navy. Donald died in 2009 of cancer at the age of 81. William has controlled Gap with his brothers John and Robert since 2004 and currently sits on the board. He founded Manzanita Capital, a London-based private equity firm, in 2001.
title: Director

name: Billionaires
bio: Former skiing champ Reinold Geiger saw his net worth dip a year after his rich list debut along with the market cap of his French cosmetics retailer L'Occitane: it hovers around $3 billion -- $1 billion less than at the time of its IPO on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in 2010. The company's natural Provence-made creams and perfumes are increasingly popular in China and Japan, where L'Occitane is focusing its growth plans: revenues in China alone were up 46% in 2011. Geiger started his career in packaging before investing in the French cosmetics firm in 1994. By 1996, he was the majority shareholder, having ousted a venture capital company. Since then, L'Occitane has grown from three shops to an international empire of 1,500 outlets. One of its shea butter products is sold somewhere in the world every 10 seconds.

name: Billionaires
bio: After his June 1967 marriage to Linda Marie Pace, "Kit" took a job cutting vegetables in the production line of her father's Pace Salsa factory. In 1977 Goldsbury was named president of the company and by 1982, he and Marie had bought out her family's remaining interests in the firm. After the couple's 1987 divorce, Goldsbury purchased Linda's half for just $95 million. Nine years later he sold the entire outfit to Campbell Soup for $1.15 billion. Goldsbury soon jumped back into the food industry via his private equity firm Silver Ventures, which has stakes in Desert Glory, MarketFare Foods, and Shadewell Grove Foods. His investments appear to be paying off; Goldsbury sold artisanal bread maker Ecce Panis to Campbell for a reported $65 million in 2009. Silver Ventures has also been investing in San Antonio real estate, turning the former Pearl Brewery site into a park with stores, a spa, an amphitheatre, and high-end restaurants. Goldsbury reportedly bought the city's Alamo Lodge, a cheap motel infamous for criminal activity, in 2010. A noted supporter of the Culinary Institute of America in San Antonio, he recently established a $20 million scholarship fund called El Sueño, to subsidize education costs for low-income students attending the school. He is backing legal action aimed at preventing the town of Aspen from constructing a hydro power plant that would divert water from a creek that runs through his estate.
title: Chief Executive Officer
employment: {'name': 'Silver Ventures', 'title': 'Chief Executive Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Konstantin Grigorishin is the biggest shareholder of Energetic Standard group, which owns several power machine-building factories in Ukraine, where Grigorishin was born.  In the late 1980s, Grigorishin began selling Ukrainian metallurgy products to Russia. He and his partners became big metal traders in the former USSR metals market; when their company privatized it snapped up metallurgy, energy, and machine building assets, some of which were lately sold to Ukrainian billionaires. Grigorishin was one of the sponsors of Orange Revolution in Ukraine. He is keen on swimming.

name: Billionaires
bio: London's "Wizard of Winton" tried to join Wall Street after graduating, but all the American investment banks he applied to turned him down. He took a trainee position at a small broker, then became a futures trader at one of the U.K.'s first futures funds. In 1987 he co-founded a quant-driven firm, AHL, which sold to Man Group. In 1997 he founded his second firm, Winton, his middle name, now the world's biggest managed futures firm. He made a record 20 million pound donation to Cambridge's physics department to advance studies in sustainability. Likes punk rock, hiking. Did textual analysis of the bible.

name: Billionaires
bio: Peter Hargreaves, a chartered financial analyst, co-founded Hargreaves Lansdown in 1981; it's now one of the U.K.'s largest financial services firms and Hargreaves is executive director. During 2011 the company held about $38 billion in assets, the majority ($34 billion) through its online investment management system, Vantage.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ayman Hariri is the son of slain Lebanese Prime Minister Rafik Hariri, who left behind a fortune now shared by his five children. Hariri sits on the board of Saudi Oger, a construction, telecom and real estate conglomerate. He oversees the group's construction division, which is behind mega projects such as the Princess Noura Bint Abdulrahman University for Women, and the King Abdullah Financial District, both in Saudi Arabia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fahd Hariri is the youngest son of slain Lebanese Prime Minister Rafic Hariri. He's lived in Paris, where he got a degree in architecture. While still a student, he opened an interior design studio on the outskirts of the city, and sold furniture to clients in Saudi Arabia. He's now developing residential buildings in Beirut. Hariri told an Emirati newspaper that he doesn't like to talk about money: "It is the French taboo of never speaking of money."

name: Billionaires
bio: Roberto Hernandez Ramirez, the former chief executive of Banamex, reaped an estimated $2 billion windfall when Citigroup bought the Mexican bank in 2001. Hernandez remained on the Citigroup board until 2009; he is currently a board member of Mexican broadcaster Televisa. He has a small investment in Brazilian consumer goods company Hypermarcas (run by billionaire Joao Alves de Queiroz Filho). Hernandez has created two foundations intended to preserve the environment and Mayan cultural heritage and is on the board of the Nature Conservancy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ingeburg Herz and her sons Michael and Wolfgang own Maxingvest AG (formerly Tchibo Holding). Maxingvest AG holds 50.47% of the outstanding shares in Beiersdorf AG and all of Tchibo GmbH, makers of Germany's best-known coffee brand, Tchibo. Herz was involved in an effort to push out her son Gunter and her daughter Daniela from the company in 2003 in a drawn-out family feud. Her son Joachim died in 2008 after being hit by a boat while swimming in a Georgia lake.

name: Billionaires
bio: Douglas Hsu chairs Taiwan's Far Eastern Group, founded by his father Yu-Ziang Hsu in mainland China as Shanghai Mong Mao Hua Trading. A Taipei-headquartered conglomerate of 180 companies today, its businesses include  textiles, mobile phones, transportation, retailing and banking, Hsu backs the relatively liberal economic policies toward the mainland espoused by Taiwan President Ma Ying-jeou which won him  a second four-year term in January.

name: Billionaires
bio: Huang Zelan is chairman of Chongyi Zhangyuan Tungsten, one of the country's largest tungsten producers. Business has benefitted from China's growing industrial production. Revenue in the first nine months of 2011 climbed 64% to $247 million; that helped to boost profit by more than 150% to $37 million. The Jiangxi Province native borrowed $782 to buy a tungsten mine in 1994, parlaying that into today's fortune. Environment issues generated controversy at the company last year, but it didn't dent profit growth.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Ali Metin Kazanci owns 75% of Kazanci Holding, Turkey's largest electricity producer. Its companies  
operate in the fields of generator production, natural gas distribution, electricity production and  distribution. He helped take his Aska Enerji public in 2010; shares down 20% over the past year. Kazanci also owns two farms in Tekirdag, a dairy farm and tree farm where he spends most of his time, while his younger son Cemil Kazanci runs the energy holdings.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vinod Khosla is the rare Silicon Valley venture capitalist able to generate profits from a clean tech portfolio. Two portfolio companies, Kior and Gevo, both biofuel producers, went public in 2011.  Another one, Calera, which converts CO2 emissions from coal/gas-fired plants into cement by-products and clean water, sold a stake to coal company Peabody Energy for $15 million. Khosla keeps a diversified portfolio. He recently took a board seat at hot mobile payments start-up Square, which hit a billion dollar valuation. He also netted nice returns when Beceem Communications (4G technology) sold to Broadcom for $316 million and SKS, the Indian microfinance lender he backed in 2006, went public in 2010. The Indian-born engineer came to the U.S. to attend grad school at Carnegie Mellon and made his early fortune as a co-founder of Sun Microsystems. He joined Sun investor John Doerr at venture firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers in 1996. Khosla left in 2004 to start Khosla Ventures, which closed a $1.05 billion fund in October. Khosla's Three Dog Vineyards, named after his pets, produces 1,000 bottles of cabernet sauvignon a year. Khosla vowed to give away half his fortune to charity when he signed Bill Gates' and Warren Buffett's Giving Pledge in 2011.
title: Investor
investments: [{'name': 'Contrail Systems', 'type': 'investment', 'imageExists': False}, {'name': 'Rearden Commerce', 'type': 'investment', 'imageExists': False}, {'name': 'Xsigo Systems, Inc.', 'type': 'investment', 'imageExists': False}]

name: Billionaires
bio: Yuriy Kosiuk studied food process engineering at  Kiev Food Industry Institute, and began trading grain after the Soviet Union's collapse. While renting grain silos, he saw an opportunity to sell to for domestic grain customers and decided to go into production using grain for poultry production. Kosiuk began the precursor to today's MHP with 10 employees in 1998; he took his poultry producer MHP public in May 2008; the company's stock price is down 25% over the past year. Nevertheless Kosiuk is going ahead with a $1.5 billion poultry plant construction project that is set for completion in 2015; this will increase his output capacity and enable him to enter European markets.

name: Billionaires
bio: 2011 was the second worst year in the history for hedge funds and Marc Lasry's Avenue Capital Management was no exception, reportedly down 10% net of fees last year. The CEO and co-founder of the New York-based fund management company made headlines during the debt crisis, when Lasry met with lawmakers from both parties to urge a compromise on the debt ceiling. An enthusiastic Democratic supporter, Lasry is now fundraising for Barack Obama's 2012 campaign, after doing the same for Hillary Clinton in the 2008 Democratic primaries. Chelsea Clinton previously worked for $12.5 billion (assets under management) Avenue Capital. Last year, Lasry bought up 22% of Trump Entertainment Resorts in Atlantic City. The company has since started paying down its debt.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Richard Li raised his stake in PCCW, then spun off the company's telecom business in late November as HKT Trust. He had made several attempts to either sell or take private the city's biggest fixed-line telecom operator. The spinoff frees PCCW to expand its remaining business units in media and IT solutions. Li split last year from actress girlfriend Isabella Leong, with whom he has three young sons. Youngest son of Asia's richest person, Li Ka-shing, he borrowed $125 million from his father in 1991 to launch satellite outfit StarTV. His father has said in the past that his private holdings are intended for his second son.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nikita Mishin, with partners and fellow billionaires Andrei Filatov and Konstantin Nikolaev, co-owns railway and port operator, N-Trans group. During summer 2011, the partners took Global Ports Investments, one of the biggest port operators in Russia, public. Mishin studied philosophy at Moscow State University. In 1996, he partnered with Filatov and Nikolaev to found Severstaltrans; multi-billionaire Alexei Mordashov was an investor. In 2007 the partners bought Mordashov's stake; in 2008 the group was renamed N-Trans. Last fall, Mishin and Nikolaev sold their 13% stake in railway operator Transoil to Gennady Timchenko, apparently aclose friend of Russian Prime Minister Vladimir Putin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Konstantin Nikolaev, with partners and fellow billionaires Andrei Filatov and Nikita Mishin, co-owns railway and port operator, N-Trans group. In summer 2011, the partners took Global Ports Investments, one of the biggest port operators in Russia, public, for about $500 million. Nikolaev was born in Ukraine and studied philosophy at Moscow State University. Nikolaev worked in expedition companies in Murmansk's port before partnering with Filatov and Mishin in 1996 to found Severstaltrans; billionaire Alexei Mordashov was an investor. In 2007 the partners bought Mordashov's stake; in 2008 the group was renamed N-Trans. He is one of the co-founders of the Moscow school of management, Skolkovo, the first business school in Russia. Last fall, Mishin and Nikolaev sold their 13% stake in railway operator Transoil to Gennady Timchenko, a close friend of Russian Prime Minister Vladimir Putin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ahsen Ozokur is a major shareholder of Turkey's largest food producer Yildiz Holding together with her brother Murat Ulker (also a billionaire). Though, she has no active role in running the company, her sons Ali Ulker and Ahmet Ozokur are on the holding's board of directors. The conglomerate includes milk, baby food as well as high-end chocolatier Godiva, which was purchased in 2007 for $850 million. In 2011, the group bought Italy's largest polyester food packaging film producer Nuroll SpA.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nicholas Pritzker was for many years the head of Hyatt's new hotel development efforts. He retired in 2009. He has recently been working alongside Netflix CEO Reed Hastings and the ACLU to bring an end to the death penalty in California. Nick is a nephew of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who, with his sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert (d. 2011) created industrial conglomerate Marmon and hotel chain Hyatt. The extended Pritzker family has been selling assets it owns jointly for the past decade. Back in 2007, the family sold Marmon Holdings to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway.

name: Billionaires
bio: Known by his nicknames "No. 1 King of All Fun" and "Stewie Rah Rah" the flamboyant Rahr sold his pharmaceutical distributor, Kinray, to Cardinal Health for $1.3 billion in November 2010. Rahr owned 100% of the company, which was founded by his father, Joseph Rahr, in 1944. Rahr is a regular in the New York gossip pages for his list of celebrity friends, including President Clinton and Leonardo DiCaprio. He lines the wall of his Queens office with framed photos of himself posing with celebrities. He is also a close friend of Donald Trump, and helped back Trump's short-lived campaign for the 2012 Republican nomination.
