Rahr bought his soaring Burnt Point estate in the Hamptons in 2005 for $44 million, which was at the time the most expensive single-family-home purchase in the history of New York. Rahr is also the largest donor for the Make a Wish Foundation, and in 2010, pledged $1,000 to the charity for every home run the Mets hit out of Citi Field.

name: Billionaires
bio: Deniz Sahenk is the widow of conglomerate Dogus Holding founder Ayhan Sahenk, who died of a heart attack in 2001. She shares fortune with her two children Ferit Faik Sahenk and Filiz Sahenk, both billionaires. The holding includes finance, media, tourism and construction assets. In May, the group completed the sale of a 6.3% stake in Garanti Bank to Spain's Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argenteria for $2 billion; remaining shares have remained flat over the past year. In October, Dogus bought Turkey's first private TV channel STAR from the Dogan Group for $327 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Richard Scaife is an heir to the Mellon fortune, first amassed by his great uncle, industrialist Andrew Mellon. The value of his trusts became public after 2007 court documents were leaked online during his second, messy divorce. In addition to the Pittsburgh Tribune, Scaife owns Newsmax and other right-leaning media outlets.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brij Bhushan Singal derives bulk of fortune from flagship Bhushan Steel, which he started in the 1970s to produce door hinges. Today, it's a leading supplier of specialized steel to automakers like Maruti, Mahindra & Mahindra and General Motors, and to consumer-durables majors like LG and Whirlpool. It's doubling steel capacity to nearly 5 million tons by 2012. It has access to coking coal mines through its 74% stake in Australia's Bowen Energy. Family split in 2002 when elder son, Sanjay, left to run unlisted Bhushan Power & Steel. In November, they inked a settlement after years of squabbling. Younger son, Neeraj, is vice chairman and managing director in the listed outfit.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tom Steyer rejoins the Forbes World's Billionaires list after a three-year absence following a rebound in performance at his San Francisco hedge fund, Farallon Capital Management, one of the largest in the U.S., with some $22 billion in assets. The 26-year-old fund had its first ever negative year in 2008. Losses were nearly reversed by gains in 2009. The fund was down a few percent in 2011. Steyer is making his mark in politics and the environment. His efforts began in 2010 when he co-chaired the opposition to a California ballot proposition that, if passed, would have quashed a state law to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The No on Proposition 23 campaign won handily. He's now expanding efforts to promote "the advanced energy economy" in Ohio by backing a clean energy council there. He founded a business organization called Advanced Energy Economy that promotes U.S. companies as suppliers of energy technologies. In 2010, Steyer and his wife Kat Taylor signed on to the Warren Buffett-Bill Gates Giving Pledge, promising to give away at least half their fortune. The couple donated $25 million to his alma mater, Yale University, in September 2011, to establish an energy sciences institute. They also gave $40 million to Stanford University (where Steyer got his MBA) in 2009 to establish the TomKat Center for Sustainable Energy and another $7 million in 2010 to create the Steyer-Taylor Center for Energy Finance and Policy. In 2004, they created a foundation to start a community bank now called One Pacific Coast Bank, and have so far spent $50 million to fund it.
title: Founder & Co-Senior Managing Partner
employment: {'name': 'Farallon Capital Management', 'title': 'Founder & Co-Senior Managing Partner', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Tahir got start with car dealerships in late 1980s; when that business failed, he moved into garment business and then later into finance, starting Bank Mayapada in 1990. Today his Mayapada Group has interests in banking, hospitals, duty free shops, media company that owns license to FORBES INDONESIA; it has 11 properties in Indonesia, Bali, Singapore. He became UC Berkeley's first trustee from Southeast Asia in 2007; all three of his daughters graduated from the U.S. school. He gave $1 million to its Haas School for a new endowment to provide scholarships to international M.B.A. students primarily from Asia. He also pledged $23 million to National University of Singapore. Tahir is working on getting his black belt in Karate. His wife Rosy is daughter of another wealthy Indonesian tycoon Mochtar Riady.

name: Billionaires
bio: Whiz kid, Hary started his media empire soon after graduating from college. He has been the founding shareholder and Group Executive Chairman of Bhakti Investama, his biggest holding since 1989. Currently, he holds positions in several other companies, including as Group President & CEO of Global Mediacom and chairman of Linktone.  Workaholic, he holds meetings on public holidays and apparently likes to exercise daily.

name: Billionaires
bio: Peter Unger founded auto parts and repair outfit Auto-Teile-Unger in 1985 and built it into a well-known chain of stores in Germany. He sold 80% of the company to British investor group Doughty Hanson & Co. in 2002 for a reported $800 million. In 2004, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts bought the entire company, including Unger's remaining 20% stake, for which he received an estimated $360 million. Unger is now retired and lives in Bavaria.

name: Billionaires
bio: Reality TV baron Joop van den Ende sold his Big Brother-producing entertainment company Endemol to Spanish telecom giant Telefonica in 2000 for $5.3 billion. Since then, he's focused on theater, a passion he's had since childhood. Now Van den Ende is the founder and owner of Stage Entertainment, a musical theater company that spun off from Endemol. Its U.S. division has won 46 Tony Awards on blockbuster musicals like The Lion King and Mamma Mia. He stepped down as chairman in 2008, but remains president of the supervisory board. Van den Ende started his career as a party-supply salesmen.

name: Billionaires
bio: Low key in the extreme, Chris Wallin lives in the same suburban Brisbane house that has been his home for more than 20 years despite having achieved the status of being the second richest man in the Australian state of Queensland. No media interviews have ever been granted by the man who was once the chief geologist for the Queensland Government, a position which exposed him to the coal industry and gave him a head start when he quit government to try his hand in the private sector. He quickly forged close ties with coal customers, especially Japan's JFE Steel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fujian-born Yu Peidi last year injected his previously private real estate empire into Shanghai-listed company Shanghai Worldbest and renamed it Greattown Holdings. That transparency helped to land him for the first time on this year's billionaires list. Yu currently resides in Hong Kong.  The company's business focus: residential property. His son Yu Jin is a graduate of Royal Holloway University of London, and daughter Yu Li graduated from Hong Kong University of Science & Technology. The two are members of Greattown's board of directors

name: Billionaires
bio: Len Buckeridge trained as an architect. He got his start building high-rise apartment blocks in his home town of Perth and won awards for low cost housing designs. That early success launched him on a career as a house builder on an industrial scale, sourcing most of the products from his own factories. Government interference in his business is one of his major frustrations, including opposition to plans for a private port. That setback is nothing compared to his dislike of union organised labor. He says he prefers private ownership because public investment in his business would mean a need to "buy a suit, and make a speech." The man who has a reputation for being a human bulldozer remains in ill health and fears he might soon be confined to a wheelchair.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fawzi Al Kharafi is the vice chairman of MAK Group, one of the Middle East's biggest holding companies. When his brother Nasser died of a heart attack last April, the Kuwaiti stock market lost almost 1% of its value. Nasser had overseen the family business, which has major stakes in National Bank of Kuwait, and telecom company Zain. Its Americana division operates several fast-food joints throughout the Middle East, including KFC, Hardee's, and Krispy Kreme. The Kharafis are one of the largest shareholders in the donut chain. In the wake of his brother's death, Kharafi is overseeing the restructuring of the group. His brothers Jassim and Mohannad are also billionaires.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jassim Al Kharafi is the eldest brother of Nasser Al Kharafi, who died unexpectedly of a heart attack while on a visit to Cairo last April. Jassim, Nasser, and six other siblings inherited from their father Mohammed the Kharafi Group, one of the Middle East's biggest holding companies; Nasser ran the business. Jassim pursued his passion for politics, and served for thirteen years as speaker of the National Assembly. After the Kuwaiti Emir dissolved the assembly in December, Jassim announced he was no longer seeking the post. His brothers Fawzi and Mohannad are also billionaires.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mohannad Al Kharafi is the younger brother of Nasser Al Kharafi, who passed away last April from a heart attack. Along with brothers Jassim, Nasser, Fawzi and four other siblings, he inherited from father Mohammed a stake in the Kharafi Group, one of the Middle East's biggest holding companies; Nasser had run the business. When he died, the Kuwaiti stock market lost almost 1% of its value. The group has major stakes in National Bank of Kuwait, and telecom company Zain. Its Americana division operates several fast-food joints throughout the Middle East, including KFC, Hardee's, and Krispy Kreme. The Kharafis are one of the largest shareholders in the donut chain.

name: Billionaires
bio: Roberto Angelini Rossi is the nephew of former billionaire Anacleto Angelini, who died in 2007. Angelini Rossi now heads the family business and holds the largest share of the family's holdings. The Angelini Group has investments in fishing, mining, copper, timber and natural gas, through publicly traded companies Antarchile, Siemel, and Eperva--the latter is the industrial fishing conglomerate Anacleto started in 1956. Angelini Group is expanding its holdings in Chile, including construction of a plant in Arica in the north for producing Omega oils from anchovies. Meanwhile, Angelini Rossi also steered the group abroad, striking a deal with Scandinavian paper maker Stora Ensa in 2009 to build a eucalyptus pulp mill in Uruguay. At the end of 2010, the Angelini Group  purchased a 59% stake in Proenergia, a Colombian gas and fuel distributor, for $45 million. This year Angelini Group announced plans to buy nearly 10% more of Proenergia. The Angelini family is very private, typically eschewing publicity.

name: Billionaires
bio: John Brown joined Stryker as chief executive after the founder's son, Lee, died in a plane crash in 1976. Brown spent 32 years as president and chief executive, transforming Stryker from a $17 million hospital bed maker into one of the world's leading medical technology companies with $8.3 billion in 2011 revenues. The company makes joint replacements, software, surgical cameras. Brown retired as chairman in December 2009;  he is now chairman emeritus.

name: Billionaires
bio: Los Angeles real estate investor and developer Alan Casden's net worth is down $700 million from a year ago due to a drawn-out breakup with investing partner Cerberus Partners, a New York private equity firm. The pair stopped making payments in November 2010 on $30 million in debt owed on several Los Angeles-area properties, and as a result are being sued for mortgage foreclosure by lenders led by Comerica Bank. Casden's representative has said the properties will be brought out of default once the dispute is resolved, but given the lawsuit, Forbes is discounting the value of these properties. Casden Properties opened a 276-unit rental home development in Burbank in late 2010 and is planning to develop an apartment and retail complex in West Hollywood. Casden also owns 3,100 luxury apartments in the Los Angeles area. He collects antique Jewish coins. After attempting to buy the Los Angeles Dodgers in 2003, Casden is reportedly interested once again in purchasing the Major League Baseball franchise from embattled owner Frank McCourt; he is one of a handful of billionaires said to be bidding on the team.
title: CEO, Chairman & Founder
employment: {'name': 'Casden Properties LLC', 'title': 'CEO, Chairman & Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Maria Ines de Lafuente Lacroze, 67, is the sole heir to Argentina's "cement lady" Amalia Lacroze de Fortabat, who died Feb. 18. Loma Negra, the cement manufacturing company Lacroze owned and ran?and from which she earned her nickname?was struck hard by Argentina's economic crisis; Lacroze sold the company in 2005 for $1 billion. Her daughter inherits a fortune that includes a Joseph Mallord William Turner painting estimated at $60 million; 90,000 hectares of livestock and crop farms that are part of agribusiness Estancias Unida del Sud; as well as properties in Argentina, Uruguay, and the United States. Lacroze sold her penthouse in New York City's Pierre Hotel for $19.5 million in 2011

name: Billionaires
bio: Diego Della Valle, the lord of Italian loafers, saw his fortune slip $100 million after his stake in luxury retailer Saks, dropped 15% since February 2011. Along with brother Andrea, also a billionaire, Diego owns Tod's, the maker of hand-crafted shoes and bags that are hot among Hollywood stars and fashionistas. Last year, the billionaire pledged 25 million Euros to renovate Rome's crumbling Coliseum, but the project slowed as an Italian trade union sued over Tod's right to use the Coliseum trademark for 15 years. The union dropped the complaint this February, and construction is expected to start this spring.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bulent Eczacibasi got his last name from the honorary title given to his grandfather, Turkey's head pharmacist, almost a century ago. Now the Eczacibasi Group has 39 companies. Bulent shares fortunes with his brother, Faruk, also a billionaire. Bulent is one of Turkey's most important collectors. His collection houses approximately 1,000 paintings and works of art. He is the president of IKSV (Istanbul Culture and Art Foundation) which organizes international art festivals. Along with his wife, Oya, he is a major benefactor of the Istanbul Modern Art Museum; Oya serves as chairman of the museum's board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Robert Fisher's parents, Donald and Doris Fisher, founded the Gap as a San Francisco jeans and music store in 1969. Now with more than 3,000 locations, the Gap empire includes Banana Republic, Gap Kids and Old Navy. Donald died of cancer in 2009 at the age of 81. Robert has controlled Gap with his brothers John and William since 2004. A former chairman and interim CEO at Gap, he sits on the company's board.
title: Director

name: Billionaires
bio: Patriarch William C. Ford Sr., the last surviving grandchild of Henry Ford, must be feeling pretty good these days. Ford Motor netted $8.8 billlion in pre-tax profit (excluding a huge one-time tax gain) for 2011, and the carmaker just reinstated its quarterly dividends to shareholders. Plus, his Detroit Lions football team is on the upswing, qualifying for the NFL playoffs for the first time since 1999.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fu is Guangming the chairman of Fujian Sunner Developer, one of China's largest chicken breeders and frozen meat producers, and a supplier to KFC and McDonald's in China.  Fu and his family own 57% of Fujian Sunner, whose sales soared 50% in the nine months through September 2011 from a year earlier to $333 million. The company raised $238 million by selling 90.9 million new shares in June 2011.  Fu entered the chicken breeding business in 1983, and set up the company that was to become Fujian Sunner in Guangze County in Fujian in 1989.

name: Billionaires
bio: WWII Marine Corps veteran and TV sales and repair shop owner Alan Gerry began constructing an upstate New York cable network in 1956 in an effort to bolster demand for his TV sets. Gerry's original cable system only had the capability to transmit five channels at a time, despite access to seven networks. As such, Gerry often found himself changing channels for the whole region, sometimes swapping out a news program for the Yankees game and vice versa. By the 1990s his Cablevision Industries had established cable networks in 18 states from New York to Florida. Gerry sold CVI to Time Warner in 1996 for $2.8 billion, netting himself $900 million in the deal. Rather than getting back into the business, the self-described "country boy," who grew up in Sullivan County, New York, purchased the site of the 1969 Woodstock festival at the urging of his youngest daughter, opening the Bethel Woods Center for the Arts in 2006. The main pavilion at Bethel Woods seats 17,000 and has hosted artists from the Grateful Dead and Willie Nelson to Elton John and the New York Philharmonic Orchestra. Gerry has been known to plant and harvest an annual corn crop on his Sullivan County farm, and hopes that Bethel Woods will help drive an economic resurgence in the region. In his words, "it's hard to say about anything that it's good for everybody, but this is good for everybody".

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a Fujian farmer, Sam Goi is Singapore's 'Popiah King'. Dropped out of school to work in his father's grocery store. Started repair shop then took stake in struggling food unit which he eventually bought over. Today, Tee Yih Jia Food Manufacturing, flagship of his privately held frozen foods empire, with estimated revenues of $1.3 billion, is world's largest maker of popiah skins that are used for spring rolls. It sells Asian frozen foods in 49 countries from factories in Singapore, China, Malaysia and the US. Big investor in China's property market with holdings in second and third tier cities, including a food industry park in Tianjin. Other interests include energy, manufacturing and healthcare. Collects French antiques and Chinese artworks.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hong Lee Ra-Hee joins the Forbes list of world billionaires for the first time this year thanks to a roughly 10% increase in the value of Samsung Electronics shares over the past year. She is the director of Leeum Samsung Museum and the wife of Samsung Group Chairman Lee Kun-hee (who is also a billionaire). Her father Hong Jin-ki was the former chairman of South Korean newspaper JoongAng Ilbo; her brother Hong Suk-hyeon currently heads the paper, which is one of Korea's largest. Hong Lee is not involved in Samsung's management but is active in running the museum and in philanthropic work. She is known for being a prolific buyer of art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Huang Shih Tsai founded and chairs private property developer Greater China International Investment Group, which has interests in real estate in Asia and North America. Flagship properties include the 300-room Hilton Hotel in central Shenzhen. Daughter Huang Wenxi heads Hong Kong-listed Waytung Global Group, a  real estate firm.

name: Billionaires
bio: A former World War II B-17 bomber pilot, Joseph was working as a door-to-door insurance salesman when he realized that auto insurance companies were not adequately screening customers. He founded insurer Mercury General Corp. in 1962. Joseph was accused of nepotism in May 2010 for employing his nephew as Chief Actuary of the firm without noting it in Mercury's SEC filings. However, the uncle/nephew relationship does not require disclosure, according to SEC rules. The insurance magnate is currently backing a California ballot measure that would give drivers a "good driver discount;" critics say it would drive up prices for people who haven't been able to afford insurance in the past.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jim Justice sold all of his company's West Virginia coal interests to the Russian company, Mechel OAO, in May 2009, for $436 million in cash and 83.3 million Mechel preferred shares. Justice made headlines later that year when he snatched the iconic Greenbrier resort from Marriott, paying $20.1 million. The property was hemorrhaging a reported $1 million a week and on the verge of bankruptcy when Justice stepped in. Born and raised in Raleigh County, W.V., Justice received his undergraduate and MBA degrees from Marshall University before joining his father's coal mining outfit in 1976. Shortly after arriving at Bluestone Industries, Justice launched Bluestone Farms, a commercial grain farming operation. After his father's death in 1993, Justice became President and CEO of Bluestone and expanded the firm by rapidly acquiring new coal reserves. Today the rebranded Justice Companies maintains coal operations in Kentucky, Tennessee, and Virginia and active farmland in West Virginia, Virginia, North Carolina, Kentucky and South Carolina. A former Boy Scout, Justice gave $25 million to the Boy Scouts of America in 2011 to support the creation of a 10,600-acre land reserve near his home in West Virginia. One of the reserve's parks will be named for Justice's father. Justice enjoys hunting, coaching the girls' basketball team at his local high school, and dining at Appleby's. Justice took over coaching duties for the boys' team as well, starting with the 2011-2012 season.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ke Xiping is chairman of Xiamen Hengxing Group, whose far-flung businesses and investments include real estate, mining, auto parts, trade, electronics, transportation and dairy. Ke owns 2% of Hong Kong- and Shanghai-listed Zijin Mining Group, a company that also has ties to fellow billionaire Chen Fashu.  Hengxing real estate properties include the Xiamen Fortune Center, the Changchun Hengxing International City Complex and the Longyan Zijinshan Sports Park.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sidney Kimmel founded the Jones Group apparel chain more than forty years ago, but these days it's his second career as a movie mogul that keeps him busy. The Philadelphia-born retailer stepped down as chairman of Jones Apparel in January and now focuses on his production company, Sidney Kimmel Entertainment. He had a modest hit this year with the Matthew McConaughey "The Lincoln Lawyer," which has made $75 million to date worldwide on a budget of $40 million. Titles in production include the Jennifer Lopez thriller "Parker," due on screens in 2012. Kimmel joined the Gates/Buffett Giving Pledge in November 2010, writing in his pledge letter: "My thinking is rather simple: I learned as a young boy that sharing with others is the right thing to do." Kimmel founded women's outfitter Jones Apparel with a partner while working at W.R.Grace chemical company in 1970 and became chairman five years later. He stepped down as CEO in 2002. The group started snapping up other brands in the 1980s and '90s, and now owns Nine West, Gloria Vanderbilt and Evan-Picone. Kimmel also owns 5% of the Miami Heat basketball team.

name: Billionaires
bio: Pyotr Kondrashev, former head of Russia's second-largest producer of potassium fertilizer Silvinit, has retired. The graduate of the Magnitogorsk Mining and Metallurgical Institute worked for 35 years at the Silvinit fertilizer factory, and became the firm's CEO in 1990. He organized the privatization of the company and became one of its largest shareholders. In summer 2010 he sold his stake to billionaires Anatoly Skurov and Zelimkhan Mutsoev.

name: Billionaires
bio: Andrei Kosogov is board chairman of Alfa's Altimo telecom-holding company, Kosogov oversaw cell network operator Vimpelcom, which merged in 2011 with Egyptian billionaire Naguib Sawiris's telecom holdings to form Wind Telecom, becoming the sixth largest telecom company in the world. Born in then Soviet Republic of Estonia, Kosogov graduated from the Moscow Power Engineering Institute; he served as commercial director at a small firm founded with the institute's help. In 1992, Kosogov was hired by Alfa Group to oversee establishment of a privatization-investment fund. Months later he became chief executive of Alfa Capital, the group's fund-management company. After expanding Alfa Capital, Kosogov became responsible for all of the bank's investment units.

name: Billionaires
bio: Yuri Kovalchuck continues to add to his media holdings; in 2011 his Natisonalnaya Media Gruppa bought a 25% stake in First Channel from fellow billionaire Roman Abramovich, plus a 25.2% stake in CTC Media from Alfa Group. Throughout the 1990s Kovalchuck was good friends with Vladimir Putin, then vice mayor of St. Petersburg; their country houses were both in the Ozero dacha cooperative. When Putin became president, many of the cooperative's members saw their careers improve. Now Kovalchuck is the largest shareholder of Rossiya bank, which controls insurance company Sogas, one of the largest in Russia; its main client is gas behemoth Gazprom. He also holds 40% of Gazprombank, the third-largest bank in the country in terms of capital, whose main client is Gazprom.

name: Billionaires
bio: Andrei Kozitsyn heads Russian copper producer Urals Mining and Metals Company (UMMC). The Urals and its metals industry are in his blood: Kozitsyn grew up in the town of Verkhnaya Pyshma in the Urals region and studied at a metallurgy institute. In 1979 he went to work as a mechanic at Uralelectromed, now the main factory at the UMMC. He served as general director from 1995 to 2002. The company also manages agricultural, construction and telecom companies in the Urals region. Now Kozitsyn is fellow billionaire Iskander Makhmudov's closest partner, helping him build up holdings in Urals mining and metallurgy companies. On January 30, 2012, after large opposition demonstrations in Moscow, more than 1000 UMMC workers attended demonstration in Ekaterinburg to show support for Vladimir Putin.

name: Billionaires
bio: The eldest daughter of South Korea's richest man, Lee Kun-Hee, Lee Boo-Jin became the first female president of a Samsung company when she was promoted to head up Hotel Shilla and Samsung Everland in December 2010. Everland, viewed as Samsung's holding company, maintains diverse interests in construction, food service and resorts. She is the older sister of Forbes World Billionaires list newcomer Lee Seo-Hyun.

name: Billionaires
bio: Progressive insurance billionaire Peter Lewis remains one of the nation's biggest backers of marijuana legalization, going state by state to get the issue on ballots. In February he gave $525,000 to the Committee for Compassionate Medicine in an effort to put medical marijuana to a vote in Massachusetts.  He's supported similar efforts in his home state of Ohio and told FORBES last fall that he's treating his drug reform work with the same seriousness as he did his CEO role at the auto insurance giant his father founded. About 90% of Lewis' net worth is still held in Progressive; the stock was up 8% year on year, boosting his fortune by $100 million. He stepped down as CEO in 2000 but remains chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Known for writing harsh letters lambasting corporate executives and board members, Daniel Loeb has mellowed a bit in recent years. But he is still practicing his brand of activist investing, agitating for change at Yahoo. Loeb recently turned his disapproval toward President Barack Obama, whom Loeb once supported. His hedge fund firm, Third Point, manages some $8.8 billion. A lifelong surfer who grew up in Los Angeles, Loeb is now firmly entrenched in New York and runs triathlons.
title: Investor

name: Billionaires
bio: Anatoly Lomakin won a $60 million lawsuit in December against potash miner Uralkali and Computershare Registrator. He had sued them for compensation for loss of shares in Silvinit, which had merged with Uralkali. Lomakin has long-standing ties to Silvinit. In 1992 he started the International Potassium Company (MMK), convincing three of the largest post-Soviet producers of fertilizer--including Silvinit--to unite. But several years later the alliance broke up over reserve sharing. In 2005, MMK began exporting only fellow billionaire Pyotr Kondrashev's Silvinit's production. After Silvinit and Uralkali merged, MMK lost its potash contracts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Shenzhou International Group, one of China's largest textile producers, Ma Jianrong worked his way to the top job from company's knitting and weaving department. A big rise in Shenzhou's Hong Kong-traded shares in the past year, propels him into ranks for the first time this year. Shenzhou has benefitted from the appreciation of the yen and rising exports to Japan. Ma's brother-in-law, Huang Guanlin and cousin Ma Renhe are both executive directors. He's also vice chairman of the China Knitting Industrial Association.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nikolai Maximov founded steel mini-mill developer Maxi Group and sold his controlling stake to billionaire Vladimir Lisin's NLMK in 2007. NLMK paid a first tranche of $300 million in January 2008, but the second tranche became locked in a dispute: NLMK accused Maxi's former top managers of stripping funds from the group, while Maximov demanded additional payment for his shares. In February 2011, Maximov was detained in Moscow on charges of abuse of power; he posted bail of $1.8 million. The case continues to drag on. The Yekaterinburg native graduated from a mining institute and went on to found family timber and furniture business in 1991. Three years later, he began trading scrap iron, investing income into buying shares of small metallurgy works in Ural. He founded Metallurgy Holding in 2004, later renaming it Maxi Group. Maximov invested wisely during the economic crisis, buying Sberbank stock when prices were low and later selling at nearly five times the purchase price.

name: Billionaires
bio: Through his private equity firm, Metropoulos & Co., Dean Metropoulos paid $250 million in June 2011 for Pabst Brewing Co., North America's largest privately-held brewer. The Greek immigrant has a knack for investing in and turning around faded food brands. In 1996 he and partners formed International Home Foods, then revamped Chef Boyardee pasta products, PAM cooking spray and Bumble Bee seafood. In 2000 he sold IHF to ConAgra for $2.9 billion. Four years later he bought Aurora Foods out of bankruptcy and merged it with Pinnacle Foods (Aunt Jemima, Duncan Hines, Log Cabin). He and fellow investors sold it to Blackstone Group for $2.2 billion in 2007. Metropoulos has also reinvigorated businesses such as U.K.-based Hillsdown Holdings (now public), Premier Foods and Mumm and Perrier-Jouet champagnes.  He moved from Greece to Watertown, Mass., with his family at age 10. At age 25, he went to Geneva, Switzerland, to become a financial director for GTE International's (now Verizon) European, Middle Eastern and African operations; he returned to the U.S. as the company's youngest controller. Metropoulos owns Castle on the Hudson, a luxury boutique hotel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Israeli Marius Nacht co-founded cybersecurity firm Check Point Software with former Forbes cover boy Gil Shwed. As the story goes he both programmed the original code and fetched the soda. Media-shy Nacht still serves on the executive board. Nacht is a veteran of Talpiot, an elite division of Israeli army. He has degrees Physics and Mathematics from the Hebrew University of Jerusalem and in Electrical Engineering and Communication Systems from Tel Aviv University in 1987.

name: Billionaires
bio: Akio Nitori grew Japan's largest home furnishings chain, Nitori, from the first store he opened in 1968, specializing in low cost wares for mass market consumption. Rising yen boosts profits because 80% of products are imported, from places like China and Southeast Asia; but the company's stock price is slightly down over the past year. Nitori launched a shopping mall in East Osaka in the fall, its first real estate venture. After Japan's earthquake last year, the company donated blankets and supplies; Akio himself donated $6 million and visited Japan's Red Cross.

name: Billionaires
bio: Megdet Rahimkulov was a fastidious investor who ran a diversified investment portfolio himself until recently. "I celebrated 65 years and retired," he told Forbes. Now his assets are managed by his company in Cyprus. In the mid-1990s Rahimkulov became chief executive and 10% owner of a joint venture between gas giant Gazprom and Hungary's oil & gas concern, MOL. To process payments from its local customers, Gazprom bought the Hungarian bank Altalanos ErtekForgalmi Bank (AEB); Rahimkulov headed this as well and later bought it from Gazprom. In 2007 he sold AEB and used the proceeds to buy shares in MOL and OTP, the largest bank in Hungary. He also owns shares of Gazprom and VTB.

name: Billionaires
bio: Scion of the Ratanarak family, Krit Ratanark oversees banking and television empire. He's chairman and CEO of of Bangkok Broadcasting & TV, which operates Channel 7, one of country's six major free-to-air channels. Property arm Tonson Property aims to develop the Rama III area as Bangkok's second commercial center. Also has big stakes in Bank of Ayudhya and Siam City Cement, both founded by late father Chuan. Son Chachchon, runs one of family's investment companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: The fertilizer tycoon owns 20 buildings in New York City and recently paid $33 million in cash for the six-story Sloane Mansion on the Upper East Side. This year he sold two factories to Russia's Gazprom entities, earning more than a half billion dollars for the sale. His IBE Trade is still one of the world's largest suppliers of ammonium-based fertilizer. Rovt grew up poor in Ukraine and attended the prestigious Lvov State University of Trade and Economics. He holds a Ph.D in international economics. He ran a high-end Hungarian resort in the U.S.S.R. before moving to New York to sell jewelry. His IBE Trade group of companies controls plants in Russia and Ukraine, and its clients include Yara, Transammonia, ConAgra and Koch Nitrogen.

name: Billionaires
bio: A socialite and philanthropist, Lily Safra splits her time between London and New York and has homes in Geneva and Monaco. She counts among her friends the U.K.'s Prince Charles and his wife Camilla. Safra inherited her fortune from late husband Edmond Safra, a billionaire banker who died in a fire in his Monaco apartment in 1999. She sold 800 lots of furniture and paintings in 2011 at a Sotheby's auction that reportedly brought in $45 million, and donated a $20 million painting by German artist Gerhard Richter to the Israel Museum in Jerusalem.

name: Billionaires
bio: Teddy Sagi founded gaming site Playtech, which he took public on the London Stock Exchange in 2006. He made headlines late last year when he increased his ownership stake in the company from 40% to more than 46%. He still plans to acquire more, although some analysts have pleaded with shareholders to prevent him from doing so.  In November Deutsche Bank resigned as a broker to Playtech, which hurt Playtech shares, but they have since recovered. Sagi also owns several e-commerce services, an e-payment company, instant messenger service Messenger Plus and commercial real estate and hotels in Europe. He reportedly bought the most expensive home in Israel for about $35 million. Israeli tabloids insist he once dated model Bar Refaeli.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nikolai Sarkisov, the younger brother of billionaire Sergei Sarkisov, started his own company in 1990 after quitting his job at a Soviet firm that exported commodities. He traded metals and imported construction equipment. Later, Sarkisov joined his brother's successful insurance company, RESO-Garantiya, and was given oversight of the firm's largest clients. Now he manages the RESO group's construction projects. French insurance company AXA owns a 37% stake in the company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sergei Sarkisov bought a 25% stake in Russia's sixth-largest insurer, Insurance House VSK, in 2011. The insurance magnate got his start at the Soviet state insurance firm Ingosstrakh. He founded his own firm, RESO-Garantiya, in 1991; today he serves as chairman of the board. Sarkisov sold a 37% stake to French insurance giant AXA in 2007 for $1.2 billion, a record sum for a Russian insurer. AXA had an option to buy a controlling stake but eventually opted out; Sarkisov retained control of the company and is expanding the business in Russia. He and his brother Nikolai, also a billionaire, are still its largest investors. Sarkisov is fond of auto racing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Thomas Secunda's wealth is up slightly this year as the company he cofounded 30 years ago enjoys year-on-year revenue growth. Last July, Bloomberg LP named Secunda vice chairman; he will still oversee financial products and head up the research and development team at the data analytics giant. Secunda met Michael Bloomberg at Salomon Brothers, where he was once a researcher. After working as a trader at Morgan Stanley, he joined his former colleague in setting up Innovative Market Systems in 1982. They renamed it Bloomberg LP in 1987. Secuda retains a 4% stake in the company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Leonid Simanovsky is a co-founder of gas company Novatek; at the 2005 IPO, he owned a 6% stake. Now, together with fellow billionaire Leonid Mikhelson, Simanovsky controls First United Bank. In the late 1980s, Simanovsky worked as a deputy of Mikhelson's in a construction company. Simanovsky was recently elected for the third term to the State Duma from Edinaya Rissiya party, as deputy chairman of the budget and tax committee.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ronald Southern founded what would become ATCO in 1947, investing $2,000 alongside his father, S.D. Southern. The pair bought 15 utility trailers and rented them out in the Calgary area under the name Alberta Trailer Hire, later expanding into the importation and marketing of mobile homes from the U.S. By the 1970s, ATCO had developed oil and natural gas operations, and finally expanded into electricity in the 1980s. Under the leadership of Southern's daughter and current ATCO CEO Nancy Southern, the firm is currently expanding Australian operations. In the summer of 2010, ATCO made its biggest purchase in three decades, acquiring Western Australia Gas Networks for $1 billion in cash and debt. Spruce Meadows, the Southern's equestrian facility outside Calgary, has produced numerous champion riders, including daughter Linda, who represented Canada in the 1996 Olympics.

name: Billionaires
bio: John Sperling left his humanities professorship at San Jose State University in 1976 to start the University of Phoenix, which is now part of the Apollo Group. His son Peter joined his father at the company in 1983. Apollo went public in 1994. Since then, John Sperling's pet projects have ranged from longevity research to environmental causes to cloning. He was a major contributor to the campaign of former Rep. Gabby Giffords (D-Az.), who was shot in the head in a January 2011 attack. Today, via the University of Phoenix, 400,000 students take classes for associate, bachelor's master's and doctoral degrees.

name: Billionaires
bio: With his father John, Peter Sperling turned Apollo Group, owner of University of Phoenix, into the country's largest for-profit university. Most of his fortune lies outside of his Apollo holding. John left a humanities professorship at San Jose State University in 1976 to start the University of Phoenix. Peter joined in 1983. Apollo Group went public in 1994. Today 400,000 students take classes toward associate, bachelor's, master's and doctoral degrees. Peter is active in renewable energy politics and was commended in April 2011 as a leading force in establishing a California law requiring renewable energy goals and standards for the state's electric utilities. He is selling two San Francisco homes, for $38.5 million and $14.9 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: A longtime partner at Silicon Valley venture capital firm Sequoia Capital, Mark Stevens joins the World's Billionaires list this year for the first time, thanks in part to a boost from social networking play LinkedIn, which went public in May 2011; Sequoia invested in LinkedIn back in 2003. An electrical engineer, Stevens led Sequoia's early investment in graphics chipmaker Nvidia in 1999 and is still a board member. He has chosen not to be as involved with Sequoia's most recent funds in order to spend more time with his wife and three children; he also lectures part time at Stanford University Graduate School of Business and has invested in some of his students' start-ups. In 2004 he donated $22 million to the University of Southern California, where he is a trustee, to create the USC Stevens Institute for Innovation. In 2008, he and his wife also donated $7 million to Santa Clara University, her alma mater, to finance the Locatelli Student Activities Center.

name: Billionaires
bio: Norwegian hotel baron Petter Stordalen is the owner and CEO of Nordic Choice Hotels, which has more than 170 hotels in the Nordic region. He originally purchased the majority of Choice Hotels' Scandinavian operations in 1996 with investor Christen Sveaas for 100 million Norwegian Krone, but by 1999 Stordalen had bought out his partner for full control. He got his start working in his father's grocery store. By age 24 he was manager of Norway's largest shopping center. A former Ironman racer, Stordalen's also an environmental activist. He chained himself to the UK nuclear treatment plant Sellafield in protest for 9 hours in 2002; more recently, he has rebuilt his sports car to be the world's first biofueled Ferrari. Stordalen proposed to his wife Gunhild on top of a mountain on New Years Eve 2008, then spent $5 million for the most expensive wedding in Scandinavian history.

name: Billionaires
bio: After protests from shareholders, Frank Stronach relinquished his control of autoparts giant Magna International, stepping down as chairman in May 2011. He then spent the rest of 2011 selling his stake in the company. Stronach founded the precursor to Magna International in 1957 and still sits on the company's board. His substantial compensation package from the company earned him $60 million last year. With Magna taking less of his time, Stronach has turned his attention to his other passion: horse racing. The owner of several racetracks (including Santa Anita near Los Angeles) and a successful horse breeder, he recently filed paperwork to find investors for six different companies that will own thoroughbred horses.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Jon Stryker has used his inheritance from medical supply company Stryker Corp. to advance gay rights and protect apes and chimpanzees. In January, his Arcus Foundation donated $23 million to Kalamazoo College to endow a center for social justice leadership. He is one of three heirs to Stryker Corp., founded in 1941 by his surgeon grandfather Homer Stryker (d.1980), the inventor of mobile hospital beds. Today the company sells $8.3 billion worth of surgical equipment, artificial joints, medical cameras and software. His sisters Ronda Stryker and Pat Stryker are also on the Forbes World's Billionaires list.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former partner of Highbridge Capital Management co-founder Glenn Dubin, Swieca left his longtime pal (they grew up together in Washington Heights) and the firm they built together in 2009, launching a new fund management company on March 1, 2011. The firm is called Talpion Fund Management. The name is derived from the term "Talpiot," which refers to a castle's turrets and signifies the "pinnacle of achievement." Talpion focuses on long-short equity with the capability to deploy a variety of other strategies. Swieca returned $100 million of outside investors' capital during the fall of 2011, presumably to avoid new regulatory requirements. Talpion continues to manage approximately $400 million of Swieca's own capital. Swieca began selling out of Highbridge in 2004 when JP Morgan Chase bought a 55% stake for $1.3 billion. Swieca makes charitable contributions through his Swieca Family Foundation. Recent beneficiaries include The Frisch School and the American Israel Education Foundation.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Self-made entrepreneur runs conglomerate Berjaya Group, but fortune sank by almost a quarter over the past year as shares stumbled. Owns social networking website Friendster.com and bought shares of Facebook through his Internet company, MOL.com. Failed to get a sports betting license from the government. Hates golf but loves scuba diving and working out at the gym.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tang is one of four executives from equipment manufacturer Sany Group on this year's Forbes Billionaires list, along with Liang Wengen, Mao Zhongwu and Xiang Wenbo.  Their wealth is little changed from a year ago, but Sany Group's biggest listed arm, Sany Heavy Industry, has been busy with a series of moves of late that will push it further up in the ranks of the world's construction equipment makers. In February, the Changsha-based company announced manufacturing and sales joint ventures with equipment maker Palfinger of Germany. In January, Sany said it would team up with CITIC Private Equity of China to purchase Germany's Putzmeister, one of the world's largest concrete pump manufacturers, in a deal worth $475 million. Putzmeister's CEO will keep his job in Europe and also join Sany's board.  Tang is the CEO of the holding company, Sany Group. Along with Liang, Mao and Yuan Jinhua, Tang was one of the group's founders when the business was formed in 1989 as a small welding materials factory.

name: Billionaires
bio: Named for the famous Italian war hero, Thohir, who has been called Boy since childhood, started out in coal mining in 1992. He and four other investors purchased coal outfit Adaro Energy in 2005. He heads the company, which is the largest single-site coal producer in the southern hemisphere. The company makes its own branded "Envirocoal" that boasts an extremely low ash and sulfur content. He is also the founder of PT Wom Finance, now one of Indonesia's largest publicly listed finance groups.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kenny Troutt made his money in telecom but is now focusing on horse racing. He owns Winstar Farm in Versailles, Ky. A bartender's son, Troutt paid his tuition at Southern Illinois University with money earned selling life insurance. In 1988, he founded long-distance provider Excel Communications and took it public in 1996. He merged it two years later with Teleglobe in a $3.5 billion deal. Troutt reinvested in stocks, bonds and horses. He sponsors his two sons' nationally competitive youth basketball teams. Troutt has been giving big money in anticipation of the 2012 election. In 2011, he gave $500,000 to Karl Rove's American Crossroads super PAC and more than $700,000 to Rick Perry's campaign.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tech tycoon Tsai Ming-tai's main source of wealth is MediaTek, one of the world's largest semiconductor design houses specializing in chips for TVs, DVDs and wireless communications. Tsai's wealth is down from a year earlier amid rising costs and rough competition from the likes of Taiwan's own MStar. Sales in the three months to December fell by 10% to $337 million. In November, it signed an agreement with Facebook that will allow the social network to be embedded into mobile phones that use MediaTek chips.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wagner sold live sports and concert website Broadcast.com to Yahoo for $5.7 billion in stock in 1999, during the height of the tech bubble. The sale made Wagner and co-founder Mark Cuban instant billionaires, and 300 employees millionaires. Wagner avoided the impending crash by shrewdly protecting his shares with put options. He then used his wealth to enter new ventures with Cuban, including 2929 Entertainment, Magnolia Pictures, Landmark Theatres, and HDNet.

name: Billionaires
bio: The granddaughter of condensed soup inventor and Campbell Soup founder John T. Dorrance, Charlotte Colket Weber has sat on the board of Campbell Soup with her cousins Bennett Dorrance and Mary Alice Dorrance Malone since 1990. Today, Campbell Soup is the world's largest soup maker with $7.7 billion in revenues, and owns other familiar brands such as Pace (salsa), V8 (vegetable juice), Pepperidge Farm (cookies, Goldfish), and Swanson (broth). Weber owns and manages Live Oak Stud, a 4,500-acre thoroughbred farm and commercial cattle operation in Ocala, Florida, and was the recipient of the 2005 Penny Chenery Most Distinguished Woman in Racing Award. In 2011 she entered her third Kentucky Derby starter, Brilliant Speed, who placed a disappointing 7th. A patron of the arts, Weber studied art and design at l'Ecole du Louvre in Paris. In 1988, she donated a collection of Chinese art, worth a reported $20 million, to the Metropolitan Museum.
title: Director

name: Billionaires
bio: Yan Zhi, the chairman of Wuhan-based real estate developer Zall Development Holding, debuts on this year's billionaires list after an IPO in Hong Kong last July.  In December, Yan bought a 75% stake in Hong Kong-listed port CIG Yangtze Ports, also located in Wuhan, now worth about $40 million. Yan is a vice chairman of the Wuhan Federation of Industry & Commerce, and a representative of the Hubei Provincial People's Congress.

name: Billionaires
bio: Yahoo co-founder Jerry Yang resigned from the company's board in January after multiple failed attempts to revive the flagging internet portal. Yang, who moved to the U.S. from Taiwan at age 10, created Yahoo in 1994 with fellow Stanford Ph.D. student David Filo. While the website still ranks in the top five for U.S. internet traffic, investors have grown impatient. The company laid off 600 workers in December 2010, and dumped its CEO, Carol Bartz, in early September 2011. Before his exit Yang was reportedly interested in teaming up with private equity investors to take the company private. Yang is a trustee at Stanford; he donated $75 million to the university in 2007.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gavril Yushvaev sold a 19.6% stake in dairy and juice-maker Wimm-Bill-Dann to Pepsico in 2010, as part of the beverage maker's acquisition of all the Russian company's shares; Wimm-Bill-Dann was delisted last year. Back when the company went public in 2002, the prospectus served up a juicy morsel: Yushvaev had served nine years in a Soviet prison camp after being found guilty of a "violent crime" in 1980. Investors weren't scared off. In 1989, Yushvayev was released and started doing business. He was also a founder of Trinity car dealership, Cherry Casino, one of the first in Russia, and Metelitsa dance club, popular in the early 90s.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oilman Kenneth "Bud" Adams parlayed his success in the Texas oil fields to become one of the original football team owners in the NFL. Ross founded ADA Oil Co. in 1946 after returning from the Navy. He later renamed it Adams Resources & Energy and took it public in 1974. He helped found the AFL in 1959 and brought pro football to Houston with a $25,000 purchase of the aptly-named Oilers. After a dispute over a new stadium, Adams moved the team to Tennessee in 1997 and renamed them the Tennessee Titans in 1999. Today the Titans are worth $964 million. Adams was fined $250,000 in 2009 for making "obscene gestures" from his owner's box. Ross is a Governor Emeritus of the Sigma Chi Fraternity and director of the Cherokee Indian National Historical Society.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lia Maria Aguiar is one of three daughters of Brazilian banker Amador Aguiar, the founder of Banco Bradesco, one of Brazil's largest banks. Amador's death in 1991 sparked more than a decade of court fights between his widow and his daughters over their inheritance. His widow, 40 years his junior, married him less than 4 months before he died. During ugly public court fights Amador's widow reportedly demanded her husband's body be exhumed for a DNA test to prove paternity. His daughters prevailed in court. Lia's sister Lina Marie Aguiar is also a billionaire. The majority of Amador's fortune was left to the philanthropic Bradesco Foundation, founded by Amador in 1956 to benefit education in Brazil. Lia started her own foundation, Fundacao Lia Maria Aguiar, to benefit the city of Campos de Jordao.

name: Billionaires
bio: Majid Al Futtaim is the estranged brother of billionaire Abdulla Al Futtaim. Non-family members run his holding company, which operates the glitzy Mall of the Emirates, known for its indoor skiing, and "City Centre" malls in the UAE as well as in Egypt. The group's properties in Egypt suffered damage last year during demonstrations. Increasing violence in Syria, as well as Arab League sanctions on the country, are delaying its construction of a huge mall outside of Damascus.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former owner of steelmaker Arcelor, he backed billionaire Lakshmi Mittal in his successful 2006 bid to merge steel groups Arcelor and Mittal Steel. Now Aristrain holds about 2% of ArcelorMittal, world's largest steel company whose shares have tumbled in the past year. Very press shy, he reportedly never goes out in public without a bodyguard to safeguard him and his family from kidnapping and assassination attempts by Basque separatists. He owns cattle ranch Ganaderias Aguadulce in the south of Spain, where he raises bulls for bullfighting.

name: Billionaires
bio: Elisabeth Badinter, daughter of the founder of French communication firm Publicis Groupe, owes her wealth to a 10.5% inherited stake in the company; recent share price increases have pushed her stake over $1 billion. Marcel Bleustein-Blanchet founded Publicis in 1926; Badinter has been chair of the board since 1996. A professor at the Ecole Polytechnique in Paris, feminist writer and intellectual, and mother of three, Badinter is author of several books, including European bestseller "The Conflict: How Modern Motherhood Undermines the Status of Women."

name: Billionaires
bio: Michigan State grad left Wall Street in 1969 for a fresher perspective on markets; he moved to Denver, where he founded mutual fund giant Janus. The firm enjoyed exceptional returns during the bull markets of 1980s, 1990s; it became fourth-largest mutual fund company in the country. Losses mounted in 2000; he resigned his chief exec post 2002 and stepped down as chairman 2 years later. He also sold his stake in the firm. Now he breeds horses at his Iron Rose Ranch in Carbondale, Colo. and supposedly loves fly-fishing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born into a prominent business clan in Kolkata, Benu Gopal Bangur inherited listed Shree Cement in 1992 after family split. It is now one of India's top 10 cement producers, with stronghold in North India. It has tripled capacity in the last 5 years to 13.5 million tons though margins are lately being squeezed by rising power costs. Shares gained 50% in past year, returning him to the list after two years. He handed over operations to son Hari Mohan who has been managing director since 2002, His grandson Prashant also works with him. He supports the preservation of sand dunes in Rajasthan where his factories are located. .

name: Billionaires
bio: Real estate investor Thomas Barrack founded Colony Capital in 1991, and bought up bad real estate loans from busted S&Ls. The firm now manages $34 billion in assets, including $18 billion in 16 commercial real estate and distressed debt-focused funds. The returns on the funds have varied widely, but Barrack has a history of waiting for bets to pay off. The grandson of Lebanese immigrants to Los Angeles, he has built his fortune through buying out-of-favor assets, including some $200 million in Middle East real estate and $534 million in non-performing German real estate loans. Quirkier investments include Michael Jackson's Neverland Ranch and a $24 million loan to photographer Annie Leibowitz. He is one of many who have expressed interest in buying the Los Angeles Dodgers. Barrack recently lost a battle with Goldman Sachs over the Las Vegas Hilton, which is in the midst of foreclosure proceedings.

name: Billionaires
bio: Elena Baturina, Russia's richest woman, sold her construction company, Inteko, in September to banker Mikhail Shishkhanov and Sberbank-Capital. The price was not disclosed. She also sold one of her cement factories. In 2011, Baturina came under suspicion of fraud as investigators claimed to have found nearly $500 million in misappropriated funds in her personal bank account. Wife of Moscow's former mayor, Yuri Luzhkov, Baturina fled Russia. She now apparently lives in Vienna and London, with her daughters. Meanwhile her disgraced husband still lives in Russia. Baturina started out as a factory worker, then entered the Moscow Institute of Management. She met Luzhkov in 1987 when they were both serving on the Mosgorispolcom, a Soviet-era municipal commission. In 1991, Baturina started plastic-products company Inteko, which produced furniture and crockery before expanding into construction and construction materials. Baturina says she does not plan to continue her business in Russia and says she may invest abroad.

name: Billionaires
bio: New Orleans Saints owner Benson and his wife Gayle received the highest papal honor that can be bestowed upon Catholic laypeople in January. The couple have donated tens of millions of dollars to various Catholic organizations and causes over the years. Meanwhile, the Saints are more popular and more valuable than ever since their Super Bowl win in 2010, and the state of Louisiana has spent $320 million over the past two years to renovate the Superdome. Benson's other New Orleans ventures include auto dealerships, the city's FOX television affiliate, and real estate, including the newly renamed Benson Tower. He also owns a 122-foot yacht, "Lady Gayle Marie," and a 2,500-acre ranch in Texas.

name: Billionaires
bio: Real estate titan Berg has invested millions of dollars in science and technology ventures, including publicly-traded electric vehicle battery company Valence Technology. A former vending machine repairman who worked night shifts to pay his way through the University of New Mexico, Berg bought real estate investment trust Mission West in 1997. His portfolio includes 8 million square feet across 100 properties and he counts Microsoft and Apple among his Silicon Valley office tenants. Mission West recently said it would be exploring opportunities to sell the company. Berg was inducted into the 2010 Developer Hall of Fame by the National Association of Industrial and Office Properties.

name: Billionaires
bio: Emilio Botin, a fourth-generation banker, became head of Banco Santander in 1986. The bank posted $7.1 billion in net profits in 2011, a 34.6% drop over the prior year, as the Spanish economy tanked and real estate prices continued to fall. Santander wrote down $2.4 billion in Spanish real estate and $792 million in Portuguese goodwill. Banco Santander has over 13,000 branches worldwide; it also has a presence in the U.S., through Sovereign Bank; and in the UK.  An early presence in Latin America, the region now contributes 51% to profits. In 2011, Botin's family paid $264.2 million in penalties to avoid charges of tax evasion, related to a secret Swiss bank account of unknown size. Botin's daughter and heir apparent, Ana Botin, runs Banesto, the bank's retail branch. Botin's great-grandfather discovered the famous Altamira caves in northern Spain in 1879. Emilio enjoys golf, hunting and fishing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oleg Boyko, armed with a degree in economics, opened Moscow's first stores with credit card readers in the 1990s. Boyko's diversified company later traded food and electronics, imported fruits, and managed banks, but eventually most of the assets of the group were restructured and sold during the 1995 banking crisis. Now Boyko has switched to gambling; his Ritzio company owns more than 6,000 gambling machines throughout Europe. Through his Finstar private investment firm, Boyko purchased Douglas Rivoli, a perfume and cosmetics shop chain last year; he already owns the similar Rive Gauche chain. Boyko also invests in real estate. He was injured in an accident at a friend's home and appears frequently in a scooter-style wheelchair. Boyko heads the Russian Committee for the Development of the Paralympics Movement.

name: Billionaires
bio: Everything Jim Breyer touches, whether a hoodie-clad Harvard drop-out or a comic book company, turns to gold. His venture capital firm Accel Partners' early $12.7 million bet on Facebook is now worth $5 billion, and possibly more, once Facebook goes public this spring. Accel is Facebook's second largest shareholder, after Mark Zuckerberg (Breyer personally owns an additional 1%). Besides Facebook, Breyer serves on the boards of Dell, Wal-Mart and News Corp., plus smaller start-ups Etsy (crafty online marketplace), Brightcove (online video platform that went public in February), ModelN (revenue management) and Legendary Pictures (film production). He also serves on the boards of Harvard Business School, the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art and is a minority owner of the Boston Celtics. In one 24-hour period, Breyer negotiated the sale of Marvel Entertainment to Disney for $4.3 billion and BBN Technologies to Raytheon for $350 million. Last year Breyer closed four new funds--two in China, two in the U.S.-- that together came to more than $2 billion. He's an admitted oenophile, art connoisseur, film buff and music aficionado who loves everything from Bach to Eminem, Fellini to Christopher Nolan.
title: Investor
investments: [{'name': 'Brightcove, Inc.', 'type': 'investment', 'imageExists': False}, {'name': 'Etsy, Inc.', 'type': 'investment', 'imageExists': False}, {'name': 'Model N, Inc.', 'type': 'investment', 'imageExists': False}]

name: Billionaires
bio: New Brazilian billionaire Antonio Jose Carneiro started out in banking and got into the electricity distribution business in about six years ago, buying a stake in Brazilian electricity distributor Cataguazes Leopoldina at a bargain price when U.S. institutional investor Alliant sold its stake at a loss. Today the bulk of his wealth comes from his shares in Energisa, a publicly-traded company that owns five Brazilian electricity distributors. Carneiro, a high school graduate from the southeastern state of Minas Gerais, also chairs Rio de Janeiro-based real estate construction and sales company Joao Fortes Engenharia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chen Tianqiao, a pioneer in China's online gaming industry, delisted his Shanda Interactive Entertainment from Nasdaq in February. Taking it private would enable it to focus, he said, on longer-term goals. Shanda Games, the Nasdaq-listed online gaming arm, is working to offset declining revenue from cash cow Mir II through newer offerings such as Dragon Nest and Mir III. New titles planned this year include Dragonball, Age of Wushu and World Zero. Chen's brother Chen Danian co-founded Shanda and sits on its board as does his wife Qianqian Luoa.

name: Billionaires
bio: Michael Chiang's Taiwan-headquartered TPK Holding is a supplier of touch screens for Apple's iPhones and iPads. Much of the company's manufacturing is across the Taiwan Strait in China. Its shares are down by more than one third in the past year amid fears that Apple will switch screen technology, harming TPK. Chiang's first company, TVM, supplied video monitors. He majored in management at Fu Jen Catholic University in Taipei. He shares his fortune with his wife.

name: Billionaires
bio: The son of an advertising executive, Chilton grew up in New Jersey and studied finance and economics at Alfred University. After graduation, his first job was at Merrill Lynch, where he worked in mergers and acquisitions. In 1985, Chilton began investing for Alliance Capital Management. He founded Chilton Investment Co. in 1992 and serves as chairman and CEO of the firm, which now has $7 billion in assets under management. Chilton sits on the board of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
title: Founder
employment: {'name': 'Chilton Investment Company, LLC', 'title': 'Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Cho Tak Wong is chairman of Shanghai-listed Fuyao Glass Industry Group, one of the largest makers of automotive glass in Asia, with a customer list that includes GM, Ford and Nissan. His wealth has declined from a year ago amid slower sales in China's auto market and squeezed profit. Net profit in the first nine months of 2011 declined by 11.5% to $185 million, even though sales that rose by 17% to $1.1 billion.   Future growth will come in part from Russia, where Fuyao is building a factory. Cho donated a 15% stake in Fuyao Glass last April, worth $490 million at the time, to the Heren Charity Foundation, set up by him for poverty relief, disease prevention and infrastructure projects. He was member of the 2011 Forbes Asia Heroes of Philanthropy List. Brother Cao Degan is former vice governor of Fujian Province, son Cao Hui is CEO of Fuyao Glass, and his sister Cao Fang is a director and deputy general manager of the listed company Cho's brother and sister spell the family's surname differently than Cho.

name: Billionaires
bio: Coleman is a "Tiger Cub," trained at Julian Robertson's famed hedge fund shop, Tiger Management. He grew up rich and in 2011 he got much richer, investing in hot tech names like Facebook, Linkedin and Zynga, as well as start-ups in emerging markets from India to Brazil. His Tiger Global outperformed just about every hedge fund in the world in 2011, finishing the year up 45%. A direct descendant of Peter Stuyvesant, he's a Deerfield and Williams grad who got going on his own in 2000 with a $25 million stake from Robertson.
title: Investor
employment: {'name': 'Tiger Global Management', 'title': 'Founder & CEO', 'totalEarningEst': True, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Ashwin Dani's father cofounded Asian Paints as garage startup with 3 friends in 1942, the year he was born. Today it's India's largest paints company, with revenues of $1.7 billion and 24 factories in 17 countries. Company raised prices 5 times in last fiscal year because of inflation. It's investing $225 million to expand capacity. Now vice chairman, he joined company in 1968, becoming managing director in 1998. Has been buying up shares since 2010. His wife is a yoga teacher.

name: Billionaires
bio: Darwin Deason makes his second appearance on the World's Billionaires list since selling his outsourcing firm Affiliated Computer Services to Xerox in 2009. His windfall came only after a legal dispute: Xerox agreed to pay him a hefty premium for his Class B shares, and shareholders sued. Once claims were resolved, the former Arkansas farmhand pocketed $800 million, mostly in stock. Deason founded ACS in 1988 as a bank data processor and credits much of his success to having instituted a "hustle" culture in the workplace. When he's not hustling, Deason can be found cruising on his 205-foot yacht "Apogee" or watching his beloved Dallas Cowboys from his private box.

name: Billionaires
bio: Andrea Della Valle saw his fortune slip $100 million after his stake in luxury retailer Saks, dropped 15% since February 2011. Along with brother Diego, also a billionaire, Andrea owns Tod's, the maker of hand-crafted shoes and bags that are hot among Hollywood stars and fashionistas. Della Valle is also an investor in Marcolin, an Italian luxury eyewear company, which sells the Kenneth Cole, Timberland, and Tom Ford brands, among others.

name: Billionaires
bio: Media mogul Aydin Dogan has been restructuring his media empire from re-divvying shares to shedding assets. He now owns a higher percent in the Dogan family stake of the Dogan Group of Companies. Last year, the group sold two daily newspapers and related assets for $74 million to the Demiroren- Karacan partnership as well as Turkey's first private TV channel STAR for $327 million to the Dogus Media group. In January, they sold the  "Hurriyet Media Towers" building which was used since 1993 by Hurriyet, Turkey's largest daily newspaper, for $128 million. The group continues to fight a $2.9 billion tax penalty issued by the Ministry of Finance in 2009.

name: Billionaires
bio: Faruk Eczacibasi shares an industrial and pharmaceuticals fortune with older brother and fellow billionaire Bulent. Faruk has worked in the family business since 1980 except for a stint in U.S. at American Hospital Supply Co.; now he is a vice chairman of Eczacibasi Holding. He is also the founder and, since 1995, president of the Turkish Informatics Foundation. Bulent launched E-Guven which is Turkey's foremost secure electronic certificate providers, and last year bought 51% of BizNet which operates in the field of institutional IT technologies. He sits on the board of the Turkish Technology Development Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Einhorn founded his hedge fund firm, Greenlight Capital, in 1996 and it has generated annualized net returns north of 21% since inception. Einhorn is known for his timely and successful short calls, starting with Allied Capital in 2002; he also shorted Lehman Brothers more than a year before its bankruptcy. Einhorn and Greenlight were fined in 2012 by British regulators for insider trading, an accusation the outspoken hedge fund manager strongly refuted. Einhorn's investors seem to be sticking with him.  A poker aficionado, Einhorn finished 18th at the 2006 World Series of Poker. He made a $200 million bid for a minority stake in the New York Mets in 2011, but the transaction fell through. Einhorn is a major contributor to the Michael J. Fox Foundation and the Robin Hood Foundation.
title: Founder & President

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Harvard hockey star Philip Falcone scored $1.7 billion by betting against subprime mortgages in 2007 but has since lost much of that on an ill-conceived investment in a satellite/cellular communications network called LightSquared. The $3 billion project received a potential death blow in February when the Federal Communications Commission found it would interfere with GPS navigation systems. Falcone's also facing a Securities and Exchange Commission probe of Harbinger Capital, where assets have shrunk to about $4 billion as investors clamor to withdraw their cash. The youngest of nine kids, Falcone grew up in Chisholm, Minn. Money was tight: His father was a utility superintendent, and his mother worked for 80 cents an hour at a shirt factory. Falcone majored in economics at Harvard and started on the junk bond desk at Kidder, Peabody & Co in 1985 after an injury ruined his professional ice hockey career (he now invests in NHL's Minnesota Wild). Up until LightSquared's biggest wipeout, he was losing his entire investment in troubled plastics maker AAB Manufacturing, an event he credits for having "had a profound impact upon my success as a hedge fund manager." Wife Lisa Maria is on the board of the New York City Ballet.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fang Wei's Fangda Group of Beijing has been holding his own in China's steel industry which has been squeezed by slack exports and slower domestic economic growth. Fan controls Fangda Carbon New Material, Fangda Jinhua Chemical Technology, and Fangda Specialty Steel, all listed on China's stock exchanges.  Preliminary results for 2011 looked promising: Net profit at Fangda Carbon New Material rose by more than half from $64 million in 2010, and Fangda Special Steel Technology's net profit more than doubled from $45 million that year. Fang took advantage of a dip in Fangda Specialty Steel's stock prices to add 2.6 million shares, or a 0.2% stake, to his holding in January; in the past 12 months, he added 0.8% to his previous holding of 40.5%.

name: Billionaires
bio: Valentin Gapontsev founded IPG Photonics, which produces powerful lasers used for material processing, telecom, and medicine. Gapontsev started his business at age 51. He studied laser physics at the Soviet Academy of Science's Institute of Radio Engineering and Electronics. In the 1990s, he immigrated first to Germany then to the United States. Gapontsev is considered by Russians to be the father of the fiber laser industry. He lives in Worcester, Massachusetts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Geng Jianming is the chairman of RiseSun Real Estate Development, which is headquartered in the eastern Chinese city of Langfang.  Geng holds degrees from the North China Institute of Aerospace Engineering, Tianjin University, Nanyang Technological University in Singapore, and the Wuhan University of Technology. He is a member of the National People's Congress.

name: Billionaires
bio: Champion of affordable medicines, Yusuf Hamied has been running family's generics maker, the $1.3 billion (revenues) Cipla, for nearly 4 decades. He and brother inherited company after their father, firm's founder, died in 1972. Portfolio consists of 2,000 drugs, including those for AIDS, malaria and asthma. He's battled big pharma most of his career, earning label of "drug pirate" for making cheap knockoffs. Cipla has lately been hiring senior executives from competitors. He's denied rumors that he plans to sell company to a multinational, saying  that " I'm not selling in my lifetime."

name: Billionaires
bio: Richard Hayne took the CEO chair at his trendy chain for urban hipsters after long-time CEO Glen Senk stepped down in January. A former hippie, Hayne opened his first store near the University of Pennsylvania in 1970, selling clothes to college kids and cash-poor urbanites. Today Urban Outfitters is a 371-store, multi-brand empire that includes its eponymous chain, plus Anthropologie, Free People (run by second wife Margaret), Terrain Garden Center, and its latest project, wedding-outfitter BHLDN, launched on Feb. 14, 2011. Urban Outfitters' sales for the 2011 fiscal year were $2.3 billion, a 9% increase over the prior year, but the stock was still down by a third. Analysts blamed changes in top management and low net income for four straight quarters. Hayne has sold approximately $160 million of shares since Sept. 2008. He donated $10,000 to Meg Whitman's campaign for California governor.
title: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
employment: {'name': 'Urban Outfitters Inc.', 'title': 'Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'salary': 1.0, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: He Qiaonv chairs Beijing Orient Landscape, one of China's largest interior design and landscape architecture companies.  Business increased last year as developers moved to reduce their inventories of land and finish off projects amid expectations of prolonged monetary-policy tightening in China.  Sales doubled to $312 million in the first nine months of 2011, boosting net profits to $55 million. One current project: Beijing Orient is working with the city of Jinzhou in Liaoning Province on its plans to host the 2013 World Horticulture Exposition. Although profit grew last year, Beijing Orient's Shenzhen-traded shares have lost about a quarter of their value in the past 12 months on worries that the company can't sustain its growth. That is why He's net worth is down compared with March 2011.

name: Billionaires
bio: Global futures trader John Henry has become one of the most successful owners in professional sports. After building his fortune with the hedge fund J.W. Henry & Company, he bought the Red Sox in 2002 and broke the "Curse of the Bambino" by bringing two World Series championships to Boston. His Fenway Sports Group now owns the Liverpool F.C. soccer team (bought for almost $500 million in October 2010), 80% of the New England Sports Network (NESN), and 50% of Roush Fenway Racing. In his free time, Henry enjoys playing the online racing simulator game he owns, iRacing.com. In 2009, he married his second wife on his private yacht and held the reception at Fenway Park in Boston.

name: Billionaires
bio: Huang Hongyun is the chairman of Jinke Property Group, which in August 2011 injected its real estate business into Shenzhen-listed Chongqing Dongyuan Industry in a backdoor listing.  Huang owns nearly 50% of the listed company with his family.  He holds an executive MBA from Chongqing University, and enjoys hiking.

name: Billionaires
bio: Huang Maoru, a China-born, Belize national, leads retailer Maoye International. The company is  headquartered in tha mainland Chinese boomtown of Shenzhen, located just across from the Hong Kong border. Huang's wealth is off from year ago amid a drop in Maoye's Hong Kong-listed shares on worries that slowing economic growth in China will crimp consumer spending. Yet Maoye's business growth has been healthy. Sales in 2011 increased by more than half to $532 million, helping to boost net profit by 11% to $102 million.   Huang's wife, Huang Jingzhang (who shares ownership in the company), retired as a director of Maoye International in 2010.

name: Billionaires
bio: Huang Shaowu founded telecommunications distributor Shenzhen Aisidi in 1998, and has turned it into one of China's largest distributors of telecommunications products, including Apple and Samsung brands.  Huang debuted on Forbes' Billionaires list last year, following a successful IPO on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in 2010.  Tough competition is putting pressure on profit margins, however. The company projects that net profit last year fell as much as 40% off from 2010's  $93 million. Huang's net worth fell $500 million since March 2011 due to a decline in the Shenzhen Aisidi share price. Huang hails from Jiangxi Province, but Asidi is headquartered in freewheeling Shenzhen, just north of Hong Kong.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mohammed "Mo" Ibrahim founded Celtel, a mobile phone company that now serves 23 countries in Africa and the Middle East; he sold in 2005 for $3.4 billion and pocketed $1.4 billion. Ibrahim now lives in London and spends his time on philanthropy and investing in Africa. In 2000, before becoming CEO of Celtel, he sold off Celtel's former parent company, MSI, for over $600 million. He created the Mo Ibrahim Foundation to improve governance and leadership in Africa; the charitable organization gives a lifetime award of $5 million over 10 years to retired African heads of state who have left their countries materially better off and more transparent. The Foundation also publishes a 300-page index of conditions in 53 developing countries, covering 88 factors such as health, press freedom, and infrastructure.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of income tax officer, Rakesh Jhunjhunwala started dabbling in the stock market in college. Dubbed India's Warren Buffett, he trades on his own account through firm Rare Enterprises, a name coined with the first two initials of his name and that of his wife Rekha. Key holdings include watchmaker Titan Industries, pharma outfit Lupin and credit rating agency Crisil. Recent investments include time-share vacations outfit Sterling Holiday Resorts.
