He's pledged to give away one-fourth of his wealth before he turns 60.

name: Billionaires
bio: Koo Bon-Neung is the chairman of Heesung Group, a seller of display components to LG, which is run by younger brother Koo Bon-Moo. The two companies work closely, and Koo Bon-Neung is a shareholder in LG. A one-time baseball player, he became head of the Korea Baseball Organization in August 2011.

name: Billionaires
bio: Computer Discount Warehouse founder Michael Krasny has stayed out of the news since selling his company to private equity firm Madison Dearborn Partners for $7.3 billion in 2007. An auto dealer's son, Krasny started selling used computers after receiving a huge response to his first $3, 3-line ad in the Chicago Tribune for his old IBM. He founded CDW in 1984, took it public in 1993, then retired from leadership in 2001. Krasny donated more than $350 million in shares to charity. He is now listed as president of Sawdust Investment Management Corporation in Illinois.
title: Investor
employment: {'name': 'Sawdust Investment Management Corp.', 'title': 'President', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Alexander Lebedev is a leading critic of Russian authorities; the former KGB agent refuses to leave his country for fear he'll be forced into exile. Lebedev's National Reserve Bank in Moscow and his Crimean hotel were both searched last year.  Lebedev owns National Reserve Corporation (NRC) and in February 2012 the company nominated him to the board of state-owned Aeroflot, in which it has a 15% stake. Lebedev finances Novaya Gazeta, Russia's leading opposition newspaper; he also owns London's Evening Standard and the UK's The Independent. His son Evgeny, a London socialite, is senior executive director of the Evening Standard. Lebedev's political career has not been as successful as his business life: a member of Russia's parliament until 2007, he then tried to launch a new social democrat party with Mikhael Gorbachev, but the effort fizzled. Lebedev financially supports the Raisa Gorbachev Foundation which has built a free children's cancer hospital in St. Petersburg.

name: Billionaires
bio: A one-time emergency room doctor, James Leininger founded healthcare company Kinetic Concepts in 1976 in a one-bedroom apartment. It began by selling specialized hospital beds but now thrives on sales of wound care devices. Revenues in 2010 hit $2 billion. In July a consortium of private equity firms led by Apax Partners said it would pay $6.3 billion to acquire the company. "Dr. Jim" was the largest individual shareholder and sold all of his shares in the company at the end of last year. Leininger was one of Texas Governor Rick Perry's most generous financial supporters in Perry's bid for the Republican presidential nomination. He is also a proponent of school choice and home schooling; he and his wife have given $100 million to improve education and provide scholarships. Leininger also founded the Texas Public Policy Foundation, a conservative research organization. The father of four children and grandfather of five enjoys fishing, bow hunting, scuba diving, hiking.

name: Billionaires
bio: Solomon Lew has built the small retail business he inherited in 1964 into a conglomerate supplying clothing, shoes and toys to Australia's largest retailers.  Lew has shares in listed and unlisted companies, many of which are supplied by other Lew businesses. He and Gerry Harvey, who fell out of the billionaire ranks this year, set off a consumer backlash against their campaign to get the federal government to end the sales-tax exemption on Internet purchases. The duo got heat as plutocrats trying to raise prices for ordinary folks. He and wife Rosie are keen supporters of Opera Australia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Li Tan owns 32% of Shenzhen Hepalink Pharmaceutical, which makes the blood thinner heparin and related products. Sales in the first nine months fell 29% from a year earlier to $328 million; net profit plunged by 46% to $81 million amid falling prices. Li's husband Li Li, the company chairman, owns 40% of the company  Li Tan serves as a director and vice president.  Hepalink signed an agreement in June last year to invest $798 million to set up a biomedical manufacturing base in Shenzhen.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lin Congying is chairman of men's apparel retailer Joeone. He debuts on Forbes World's Billionaires list after an IPO in May 2011 on the Shanghai Stock Exchange that raised $413 million. Lin has prospered from double-digit growth in China's retail spending. Sales in the first nine months of 2011 rose 32% to  $238 million. The company has approximately 3,000 stores in China. Lin holds and an executive MBA from Xiamen University.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lin Xincheng is the founder and chairman of Sanan Optoelectronics, one of China's most successful electronics companies.  Lin started out in the steel business in his Fujian Province. Sanan Optoelectronics successfully made a backdoor listing on the Shanghai Stock Exchange in 2007. Its shares have dropped by more than a third in the past year, however, on a thin profit outlook in the electronics business. As a result, Lin's net worth is $800 million lower this year than in March 2011. Lin has announced plans to set up a big optoelectronics industry park back in his home county in Fujian. His son Lin Zhiqiang is heir apparent.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born into a well-to-do Boston family, Lurie's grandfather Philip Smith (d. 1961) built the family fortune through movie theater operator General Cinema and other investments. Lurie taught social policy at Boston U., and then abandoned academia for the bright lights of Hollywood. He founded Chestnut Hill Productions in 1985. After a string of so-so films, the documentary he and his wife produced, "Inside Job," about the 2008 global financial crisis, won an Academy Award in 2011. In 1994, Lurie bought the Philadelphia Eagles football team from Norman Braman for a then-record $195 million. The team is now worth $1.1 billion. In 2010, the franchise announced a plan to make Lincoln Financial Field the first major sports stadium in the world to generate its own renewable energy.

name: Billionaires
bio: William Macaulay founded energy-focused private equity giant First Reserve, which now holds $20 billion in 30 portfolio companies with $200 billion in revenues. Last year the company made a 50% return on a $2 billion investment in convertible bonds of newly IPO-ed Glencore. The firm bought 80% of copper company Mettalum Holdings for $960 million. It is also pursuing a joint venture with Sun Edison to build large-scale solar power. Macaulay is already plotting for a new Asia-focused fund, opening an office in Hong Kong. He is planning for the future too, having recently brought on a new crop of younger directors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Yusaku Maezawa founded online fashion mall Zozotown, a wildly popular website with some 1,600 brands, mostly Japanese, and 4 million members. The website is structured like actual mall where stores are set up; sells on consignment. The company is branching out overseas, including a China venture with Softbank's Taobao.com. Start Today's stock price is up 11% over the past year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mao Zhongwu is one of four executives from equipment manufacturer Sany Group to rank as billionaires on this year's Forbes Billionaires list, along with Sany Group cofounders Liang Wengen, Tang Xiuguo and Xiang Wenbo. Their wealth is little changed from a year ago, but Sany Group's main listed unit, Sany Heavy Industry, has been busy with a series of moves of late that will push it up in the ranks of the world's construction equipment makers. In February, the Changsha-based company announced manufacturing and sales joint ventures with equipment maker Palfinger of Germany. In January, Sany said it would team up with CITIC Private Equity to purchase German outfit Putzmeister, one of the world's largest high-tech concrete pump manufacturers, in a deal worth $475 million. Putzmeister's CEO will keep his job in Europe and also join Sany's board. Sany Group was founded in 1989. Mao is also chairman of Hong Kong-listed coal equipment supplier Sany Heavy Equipment International.

name: Billionaires
bio: Aubrey McClendon was one of the greatest oil and gas wildcatters of his generation. As co-founder of Chesapeake Energy he spearheaded the "land grab" of shale gas acreage that ignited the American oil and gas boom of 2009-2015. But McClendon, dubbed by Forbes in 2011 as "America's Most Reckless Billionaire," took too many risks and ran Chesapeake into financial and legal trouble, triggering his dismissal in 2013 - the same year he fell off the Forbes Billionaires List. McClendon tried to start over, and with American Energy Partners he leveraged $6 billion in cash from private equity funds to acquire more oil and gas assets at what turned out to be the top of the market. As oil crashed in 2015, AEP was all but wiped out. He died in a car crash in Oklahoma City on March 2, 2016, one day after being indicted by federal prosecutors on charges of conspiring to rig bids on oil and gas leases. He was a 20% owner of the Oklahoma City Thunder NBA team. McClendon is survived by his wife and three children.

name: Billionaires
bio: Meng Qingshan is chairman of Meihua Holdings Group, one of China's largest suppliers of MSG.  The company also produces starch and organic fertilizer. Meihua is based in Meng's hometown of Langfang  in Hebei Province. His eldest daughter Wang Aaijun and son-in-law He Jun are directors and senior executives at Meihua Holdings. Investors in Meihua include Temasek Holding, a Singapore government entity; and Softbank Investment of Japan. Net profit in the first nine months of 2011 increased 4% to $80 million, on revenue that rose by nearly a third to $730 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oil and gas tycoon William "Tex" Moncrief Jr. made perhaps the biggest find of his life last January with offshore gas field "Davy Jones," which holds up to 6 trillion cubic feet of gas. Moncrief Offshore LLC owns 10% of the exploration and platform, and production is expected to begin in early 2012. Now 91, Moncrief got his start at age 10, when his father, W.A. "Monty" Moncrief Sr. (d. 1986), discovered a 6-billion-barrel East Texas oilfield. Tex wanted to quit school and become a pro golfer back in 1939, but his dad talked him out of it. Moncrief is a fan and benefactor of football at both the University of Texas and Texas Christian University

name: Billionaires
bio: Nihat Özdemir runs Limak Holding, which has businesses in the construction, energy, tourism and cement sectors, with partner Sezai Bacaksiz; they split the company equally. The two classmates left university to found Limak in 1976. Bacaksiz is responsible for Limak's airport and tourism business while Ozdemir oversees cement and energy firms; they work together on building their construction venture. In November, Limak Construction with a partner won the tender for the renovation of the Cairo Airport for $387 million; and in January they took over management of the Iskenderun Port. Özdemir is the vice-president of the Fenerbahce Sports Club. His son and daughter both work at Limak.

name: Billionaires
bio: Despite a failed bid for deep discount retailer Family Dollar in the winter of 2011, Wendy's chairman Nelson Peltz led his Trian Fund Management to another positive year. The hedge fund firm's flagship long/short equity fund, Trian Partners, returned 7.02% net of fees. Trian divested its CBS and PepsiCo stakes in 2011, and reduced its stake in Kraft while calling for State Street Corp. to spin off its investment management operation. During the summer of 2011, Wendy's completed the sale of its Arby's division to Roark Capital Group for $430 in cash, debt, and a retained equity stake. Peltz is rumored to be in pursuit of the of the NHL's New Jersey Devils through the acquisition of the club's debt. Peltz completed his first major deal in 1985 when he successfully merged his Triangle Industries with National Can; three years later he sold the entire outfit for $4.2 billion. Peltz's Palm Beach estate, Montsorrel, languished on the market at a list price of $75 million for years before Peltz quit his efforts to sell the property.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Former race car driver Roger Penkse founded his eponymous company in 1969, distributing diesel engines for GM. Today, Penske Auto Group operates more than 300 car dealerships, both in the United States and abroad. While the recession briefly knocked Penske's net worth below a billion dollars in the middle of 2011, Penske is back up in 2012. He owns Penske Racing, which competes in NASCAR and the IndyCar Series and has15 Indy 500 victories. In 2009, Penkse abandoned his attempt to buy car-maker Saturn from GM and turn it into an independent company. An alumnus of Lehigh University, Penske is a director of GE and the Universal Technical Institute, Inc.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shares of Kevin Plank's Under Armour have been on a tear since bottoming out at approximately $12 per share in March 2009. With shares changing hands in the mid-eighty-dollar range as of February 2012, Under Armour's performance has finally propelled the upstart Nike challenger to billionaire status. Plank founded Under Armour in 1996 at age 23 after experiencing firsthand how a drenched cotton t-shirt could slow an athlete down as a member of the University of Maryland football team. After producing his first moisture-wicking prototype during his senior spring, Plank opened up shop in the basement of his grandmother's D.C. townhouse, financing the enterprise with the proceeds from a flower distribution business he ran in college and help from several credit cards. In the early days, Plank served both as Under Armour's CEO and the young company's entire sales force, selling his synthetic shirts to teams up and down the eastern seaboard out of his Ford Explorer. Things have come a long way since; Under Armour generated revenue of nearly $1.5 billion in 2011.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Under Armour, Inc.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: The cousin of Edwin Soeryadjaya, Theodore Rachmat is also a billionaire. He is Vice­ President Commissioner of Adaro Energy and President Commissioner of Adira Finance. He got his start at Astra International, then run by Soeryadjaya's father.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of insurance giant Aon Corp, Patrick Ryan retired in 2008 to focus on Chicago's failed big for the 2016 Olympic Games. In 2010 Ryan reentered the insurance business by launching Ryan Specialty Group with $275 million of his own money. Ryan Specialty has been rapidly expanding over the past year, acquiring Jubilee Group Holdings, Concord Specialty Risk and Wells Fargo's Wholesale Insurance Unit, among others. A 20% owner of the NFL's Chicago Bears, Ryan attended Northwestern University on a football scholarship and was a member of Sigma Chi fraternity. He founded Pat Ryan & Associates in 1964 at age 26 after selling insurance policies for five years after graduating. In 1982, Ryan merged his company with Combined International and renamed it Aon Corp., eventually becoming the world's largest reinsurance broker. Earlier this year, Aon Corp. announced that it would be moving its headquarters to London.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Ryan Specialty Group', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Lord David Sainsbury of Turville inherited a stake in $30 billion (pre-tax revenues) Sainsbury's, one of the U.K.'s largest grocers. Sainsbury served as chairman and CEO of the supermarket chain but withdrew in 1998, when he was appointed to the government; he spent 8 years as UK's Minister of Science and Innovation but resigned in 2006. He has been loyal to the Labour Party, donating over $15 million since 2000. However, he has reportedly been disinterested in supporting the party since Ed Miliband took the helm; Sainsbury supports Ed's brother, David Miliband.

name: Billionaires
bio: Though assets under management have been scaled back to $750 million from $7.5 billion just four years ago, Sandell continues to outperform the competition. In a year when the average hedge fund returned -5%, Sandell Asset Management's funds produced a weighted average return of approximately 2.5% in 2011 and are up approximately 7.5% through mid-February 2012. A Swedish badminton prodigy, Sandell attended college outside Stockholm before spending two years in Paris covering European equities for Atlantic Finance. He then earned an MBA at Columbia and joined Bear Stearns in 1988, where he was a colleague of famed investment banker Ace Greenberg. While at Bear Stearns, Sandell worked on billionaire Kirk Kerkorian's bid for Chrysler before departing to found fund manager Sandell Asset Management in 1998.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Hajime Satomi is the founder and chief of Sega Sammy, pachinko machine and gaming software firm. With the company's software sales softening especially in the US and Europe, Satomi is looking to mergers and acquisitions and social games to lift revenue and profit. He is also directing the construction of a new plant and distribution center to expand the company's pachislot and pachinko machines business, which is set to open in 2013.  After last year's March earthquake, the company donated $2.5 million to relief efforts; its own amusement facilities in eastern Japan remained closed.

name: Billionaires
bio: Washington, D.C. real estate mogul and businessman, known as B. Francis Saul II, controls publicly traded Saul Centers, which operates a real estate portfolio of 9 million square feet mainly in the D.C. and Baltimore areas and extending to Florida, Georgia, Delaware, North Carolina, New Jersey and Oklahoma. He heads private BF Saul Hotels with more than 3,400 rooms. Saul sold Chevy Chase Bank, which he set up in a trailer in 1969, to Capital One for $476 million in 2009, but kept Chevy Chase Trust, which services high net worth individuals and has $3 billion in assets under management.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Saul Centers Inc.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Sezai Bacaksiz is the vice-chairman of Limak Holding, which has businesses in the construction, energy, tourism and cement sectors. Splits fortune equally with fellow billionaire, Nihat Ozdemir. The two classmates left university to found Limak in 1976. Bacaksiz is responsible for Limak's airport and tourism business while Ozdemir oversees cement and energy firms; they work together on building their construction venture. In November, Limak Construction with a partner won the tender for the renovation of the Cairo Airport for $387 million; and in January they took over management of the Iskenderun Port.

name: Billionaires
bio: Washington Redskins owner Dan Snyder filed a $1 million defamation lawsuit against the Washington City Paper in the spring of 2011. He has since dropped the suit, but the episode has not helped his reputation with D.C. football fans. Snyder bought the Redskins for a record $750 million in 1999, and the team is now worth nearly $1.6 billion, making it the second most valuable NFL team. The Redskins have posted only three winning seasons since his arrival. The University of Maryland dropout made his first million at age 20 by selling advertising at colleges. He built his wealth with his marketing company, Snyder Communications, which he sold off in 2000. Through his Red Zone Capital, he now owns chunks of the Johnny Rockets restaurant chain, Red Zebra Broadcasting, and Dick Clark Productions.

name: Billionaires
bio: San Diego Chargers owner Alexander Spanos started as a baker in his parents' bakery. He later founded his own catering company in 1951 with an $800 loan, and then funneled his profits into real estate. A.G. Spanos Companies is now one of the country's largest apartment developers, building 120,000 apartments in 19 states over 6 decades. Spanos bought a controlling stake in his NFL team in 1984. His son Dean is now president of the Chargers franchise. Spanos has been a big donor to Republican candidates and causes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Precious metals fanatic Eric Sprott has recently claimed to hold 90% of his assets outside of Sprott Inc. shares, in gold and silver. The Merrill Lynch research-analyst-turned-fund-manager sold his entire interest in his first independent venture, Sprott Securities, to the firm's employees in 2001. That same year he donated $10 million to his alma mater, Carleton University, which proceeded to rename its business school in Sprott's honor. He took his current operation, Sprott Asset Management, public on the eve of the 2008 financial crisis; shares fell more than 73% in the months that followed. After a comeback in 2011, shares are down just 27% from their debut.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mehmet Sinan Tara runs Turkey's largest construction company, Enka. In 1985 he took the reins from his father Sarik Tara, also a billionaire and the company co-founder. ENKA is active in Turkey and Russia where it owns 10 shopping centers, 9 in Moscow and 1 in St. Petersburg. The holding is also Turkey's largest private electricity producer. Mehmet started the Enka Schools in 1996, one in Istanbul and the other in Adapazari; 2,000 students are enrolled. Known for his modest character, his office has bare white walls.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wang Wenxue chairs China Fortune Land Development, a property developer based in Beijing. He injected his real estate business into domestically traded Zhejiang King Refrigeration Industry last year, and renamed the company China Fortune Land Development. It is focused on industrial, logistics and commercial real estate, including Gu'an Industrial Zone, the Dachang Chaobai River Industrial Zone, and the Huailai Ecological New City near Beijing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Allan Wong is chairman and co-founder of VTech, one of the world's most successful manufacturers of electronic toys and educational learning devices. He got interested in electronic toys as a player of "pong" games in the 1970s, and went on to set up VTech as a maker of game consoles in 1976. These days the company is selling kids' versions of e-readers and electronic tablets. VTech is also one of the world's biggest maker of cordless phones (the premobile kind) and a contract manufacturer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Xiang Wenbo is one of four executives from equipment manufacturer Sany Group on this year's Forbes Billionaires list, along with Liang Wengen, Tang Xiuguo and Mao Zhongwu.  Their wealth is little changed from a year ago, but Sany Group's main listed arm, Sany Heavy Industry, has been busy with a series of moves of late that will push it further up in the ranks of the world's construction equipment makers. In February, the Changsha-based company announced manufacturing and sales joint ventures with equipment maker Palfinger of Germany. In January, Sany said it would team up with CITIC Private Equity of China to purchase Putzmeister of Germany, one of the world's largest concrete pump manufacturers, in a deal worth $475 million. Putzmeister's CEO will keep his job in Europe and also join Sany's board.  Xiang is president of Sany Heavy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Xiu Laigui is chairman of Xiuzheng Pharmaceutical Group, one of China's largest pharmaceutical companies. From his headquarters in northeastern China's Jilin Province, Xiu leads 80,000 employees. Sales in 2010 (the latest year available): $2.7 billion, generated from assets worth $1.2 billion.  Xiu acquired  Tianlong Pharmaceutical, based in neighboring Liaoning Province, last September for an undisclosed amount. Tianlong makes injections used to freeze-dry medicine tablets.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ye Chenghai's Shenzhen Salubris Pharmaceuticals has benefitted from increased spending in China on pharmaceutical products. Sales in the first nine months of 2011 climbed 11% to $171 million, increasing profit by 13% to $45 million. Growth in sales of cardiovascular drugs contributed to the improvement. Though business is up, Ye's wealth has declined from a year ago amid a broader market downturn at China's stock exchanges. Son Kevin, the company's chief executive officer, holds an MBA from Yale and is a U.S. citizen. Daughter Ye Yujun is the chief financial officer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Albert Yeung opened his first watch shop in 1964. Now his Emperor Watch & Jewelry, run by his daughter Cindy, is one of Hong Kong's largest watch retailers; LVMH's L Capital is a strategic investor. His Emperor Group's far-flung interests include hotels, finance, retail, gaming and entertainment. Casino operations in North Korea reportedly suspended after December death of Kim Jong Il. Hong Kong-born Yeung traces his roots to Chaozhou in Guangdong Province.

name: Billionaires
bio: Larry Yung hails from one of China's most colorful clans. Grandfather Rong Desheng was one of Shanghai's richest before the Communist revolution. Father Rong Yiren stayed during Communist rule, while much of the family went overseas, and rose to become vice president and helped Deng Xiaoping rebuild.  Yung went to Hong Kong to develop CITIC Pacific, an offshoot of government-controlled China International Investment and Trust Corp.  Though he resigned as chairman in 2009 amid a financial crisis, Yung still holds a minority stake in the company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhang Zhixiang chairs the privately held Jianlong Group, based in Beijing.  The company has interests in mining, equipment manufacturing, shipbuilding and shipping.  It entered the steel industry by buying a struggling plant more than a decade ago and renamed it Jianlong Iron & Steel. Zhang is active in business groups, including the China Metallurgical Construction Association, where he is vice chairman.   Zhang's brother, Zhang Weixiang, is a business partner.

name: Billionaires
bio: Michael Yu, also known as Yu Minhong,  set up New Oriental Education and Technology Group to offer TOEFL test preparation classes. The company has since become one of the world's wealthiest educators.  New Oriental went public at the New York Stock Exchange in 2006, and today ranks as the largest provider of private educational services in China in terms of students, programs and geographic swath.  For the year ending last May 31, Yu had two million students.  Revenue for the year ending in May totaled $558 million, generated through 54 schools, 433 learning centers and 28 bookstores. Yu holds a bachelor's degree in English from Peking University, where he also taught as an English instructor before setting up New Oriental.

name: Billionaires
bio: Rochester, N.Y. native Robert Agostinelli earned his MBA at Columbia University before a stint at Rothschild. Joining Goldman Sachs in 1982, he contributed to the founding of the bank's international M&A business before departing the firm as a senior partner for Lazard in 1987. Together with partner Steven Langman, Agostinelli struck out on his own in 1995 with the founding of New York-based private equity shop Rhone Group. The outfit, of which Agostinelli owns approximately 50%, now manages approximately $8.5 billion. Agostinelli is a supporter of numerous right-wing causes and a founding member of the Friends of Israel Initiative and the Council on Foreign Relations. He counts Nicolas Sarkozy, George Bush and José María Aznar as close friends. While based in New York, he maintains homes in London and Paris and is a collector of wine and art.
title: Founder and Managing Director
employment: {'name': 'Rhone Group', 'title': 'Founder and Managing Director', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Alberto Alcocer is ex-husband of billionaire heiress Esther Koplowitz. He and his first cousin, Alberto Cortina, who married Esther's sister Alicia, ran Construcciones y Contratas (now called FCC), the large industrial company their wives inherited, together from the early 1970s until both marriages ended in 1989. Los Albertos, as they were dubbed by the press, then moved into banking, running Banco Zaragozano. They sold their combined 40% stake to Barclays in 2004. The cousins now hold their wealth in investment arm Alcor Holding. Alcocer reportedly enjoys hunting.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lord Michael Anthony Ashcroft debuts as a billionaire on this year's list. A serial entrepreneur, Ashcroft started numerous companies and sold before their bottoms fell out. His most significant acquisition was camping equipment manufacturer Hawley-Goodall, which he transformed into one of the security industry's leading firms through the acquisition of U.S. security firm ADT Security Services. Ashcroft's wealth comes from selling ADT to Tyco in a multi-billion dollar reverse merger, landing him a windfall in Tyco shares, which he later sold. His fortune has grown over the years as he sold companies and shares. Ashcroft once served as the Deputy Chairman of the Conservative Party and is a loyal supporter. Lately, though, his British Caribbean Bank has come under scrutiny for its role as creditor to a Oxford Ventures, a company in the Turks and Caicos Islands that collapsed and that reportedly, Ashcroft secretly controlled. Ashcroft sued the UK's Independent newspaper for libel over its 2009 reports on the business matters.

name: Billionaires
bio: Keeping a low profile, Mehmet Rustu Basaran, derives his wealth from Habas, a well-known producer of industrial and medical gases, heavy machinery and LNG, as well as Anadolu Bank. He has two seaside residences by the Bosphorus, one in Kanlica and the other in Yenikoy. Basaran also has an atomobile collection of 80 cars including a McLaren F1, Superamerica, Enzo and a $4.5 million Ferrari FFX.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sara Blakely was 29 when she  invested her entire life savings, $5,000, trying to come up with something flattering to wear under her white slacks. Six months later, the one-time Disney World ride greeter and door-to-door fax machine salesperson found her new line of shaping underwear, Spanx, named one of Oprah Winfrey's Favorite Things. Since then, Blakely has taken Spanx from a one-product wonder sold out of her Atlanta apartment to a billion-dollar powerhouse with just under $250 million in annual revenues and net profit margins estimated at 20%. She owns 100% of the private company, has never advertised and never taken outside investment. Blakely turned 41 in February, making her the youngest female self-made billionaire in the world.

name: Billionaires
bio: After splitting off from his brother, Richard, in 2006 to invest on his own, Christopher Chandler heads Legatum Capital, a private multibillion dollar investment firm that focuses on the world's capital markets. The son of a beekeeper from North Island, New Zealand, Chandler and his brother first started by taking proceeds from the sale of their parent's department store and investing in Hong Kong real estate. The siblings then formed investment firm Sovereign Global in Monaco to focus on transitioning industries in Russia, Latin America and Eastern Europe. At Dubai-based Legatum, Chandler has focused on socially sustainable enterprises such as microfinance. More recently, Legatum Capital has been supportive of entrepreneurship initiatives in Africa, leading the Africa Awards for Entrepreneurship. Legatum has also seeded the $100 million END fund, which focuses on the eradication of tropical diseases in Sub-Saharan Africa.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cheung Yan is the chairlady of Hong Kong-listed Nine Dragons Paper, one of Asia's largest manufacturers of paper products. Her wealth has dropped from a year ago amid as weak Chinese exports cut into demand for packaging, its profits and its share price. Net profit in the 12 months to June 2011 fell by 9% to $312 million.  The company is looking to boost business in the future in part through expansion of its production capacity in Tianjin, Chongqing and Shenyang. Cheung's husband Liu Ming Chung, a Brazilian national, is deputy chairman and CEO. Her brother Zhang Cheng Fei and son Lau Chun Shun are also on the board of directors. Lau holds an undergraduate degree in economics from the University of California at Davis and a graduate degree in industrial engineering from Columbia University.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chung Yong-Jin is the son of Lee Myung-Hee, chairman of department store Shinsegae. He joined Shinsegae after graduating from Brown University in 1994, and became general vice chairman in December 2009. Last May, he split discount store E-mart from Shinsegae. He's also a shareholder in Samsung Electronics. A casual dresser, he allows employees to wear jeans and t-shirts to work. He also set up a college fund for children of retired employees. Once one of South Korea's top twitterers with more than 110,000 followers, Chung Yong-Jin has closed his Twitter account.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turgay Ciner owns electric power plants, copper aluminum and soda ash mines, hotels and a media company in Turkey. He got his start selling auto parts; in the mid 1980s he began importing Mercedes vehicles to Turkey. Lost his bid downpayment after electricity tenders he won in 2010 were recently cancelled. There may be more upside in his two-year-old venture, Ciner Shipping, which has orders of $600 million on new ships and plans to build a fleet of 40 ships over the next six years. He owns apple farms on the outskirts of Istanbul.

name: Billionaires
bio: A Silicon Valley mainstay, Jim Clark returns to the Forbes World's Billionaires list after making some savvy investments in the valley's biggest companies. With a significant stake in Apple as well as early investments in Facebook and Twitter, the Netscape co-founder last appeared on the billionaires list in 2008. A former professor who got his teaching start at Stanford, Clark became a start-up addict and went on to found Silicon Graphics in 1982 and Healtheon (now WebMD) in 1996, along with Netscape. He also invested in Shutterfly; MyCFO.com, a wealth management company, and Neoteris, a computer security firm that was acquired by Juniper Networks. Clark maintains a large impressionist art collection, with several pieces from Picasso, Monet, Matisse and van Gogh, as well as a 300-foot sailing yacht, Athena. He calls his 40,000-bottle Burgundy wine collection his "liquid asset." Clark was the major financial backer for the Academy Award-winning documentary on Japanese dolphin hunting, "The Cove." He is also the namesake for Stanford's James H. Clark Center for Biomedical Engineering and Sciences, to which he donated $90 million. Daughter Kathy is married to YouTube founder Chad Hurley and fourth wife Kristy is a former Victoria's Secret and Sports Illustrated model.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alberto Cortina is ex-husband of billionaire heiress Alicia Koplowitz. He and his first cousin, Alberto Alcocer, who married Alicia's sister Esther, ran Construcciones y Contratas (now called FCC), the large industrial company their wives inherited, together from the early 1970s until both marriages fell apart in 1989. Los Albertos, as they were dubbed by the press, then moved into banking, running Banco Zaragozano. They sold their combined 40% stake to Barclays in 2004. The cousins now hold their wealth in investment arm Alcor Holding. Cortina is said to enjoy boating, collecting art, and hunting.

name: Billionaires
bio: Portuguese businessman Belmiro de Azevedo has seen his net worth drop by a third from a year ago, as his publicly-traded holding company suffered. The son of a carpenter founded Sonae SGPS in 1959 as a maker of decorative laminates. He later diversified into supermarkets, eventually becoming Portugal's biggest retailer through his Modelo Continente superstores and supermarket. As chairman, Azevedo holds a 53% stake in Sonae, which today has interests in tourism, car parks, real estate, shopping centers, a radio station, a newspaper, and a maker of wood panels. His son Paulo is CEO, and his son Nuno and daughter Claudia also work at the company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounder of Infosys. K.Dinesh retired from its board last June after 26 years as director. His last assignments included overseeing quality control and the Australian subsidiary. Said he plans to devote himself to social work in the areas of health care, education and governance.

name: Billionaires
bio: Charles Dunstone founded Europe's largest mobile phone retailer, The Carphone Warehouse, and was CEO until 2010; now he serves as chairman. The company has joint venture investments with Best Buy Europe and Virgin Mobile France, as well as ownership of numerous properties and other assets in the U.K. With about $12,000 in savings, Dunstone started the firm from his London apartment; now the company has more than 2,400 stores across Europe. Over the last few years the firm has undergone significant change, including the successful demerger of U.K. telecom firm Talktalk, which Dunstone and partners listed on the London Stock Exchange. The firm has expressed the desire to move into the U.S. Dunstone is an avid yachtsman and participates in sailing regattas across the globe.

name: Billionaires
bio: John Edson was enrolled in the University of Washington but left to join the Army during the Korean War. Upon his return, he started building sailboats in his Seattle garage. Edson officially founded Bayliner Marine Corp. in 1955, focusing on affordable plywood motorboats. He sold the enterprise to the Brunswick Corporation for $425 million in 1986. In 2005, he donated $5.4 million to an Arizona State University entrepreneurship program. Edson is a longtime supporter of Seattle's Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center and enjoys flying and spending time on his 164-ft yacht, Evviva (Italian for "long live"). He retains a small stake in Bayliner and also has an equity stake in Westport Shipyard.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gabriel Escarrer opened his first hotel, the Altair Hotel, over 50 years ago at the age of 21 in Palma de Majorca. His recently renamed Melia Hotels International now has over 300 hotels and resorts in 27 countries, and $1.7 billion in revenues. It is one of the world's largest hotel chains and the largest in Spain. Last year, Melia announced the sale of a 50% stake of its 522-room Sol Tenerife hotel on the Canary Islands to a group called Tertian XXI. Melia also sold 58.5% of its 228-room Melia Milana hotel in Milan. Escarrer still runs the show with help from his two sons. He's received numerous awards in his career, including Tourism Personality of the Century and Corporate Hotelier of the World, and is a major figure in the development of the Spanish hotel industry. He's also an avid golfer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fan Zhaoxia is co-founder of  Beijing Jingyuntong Technology, a maker of photovoltaic equipment used by the solar energy industry.  The company went public on the Shanghai Stock Exchange in September 2011, raising  $400 million for  new investments. Revenue in the first six months of last year totaled $162 million. Fan's husband Feng Huanpei is chairman of the listed company.  Her brother Fan Zhaoming, the vice chairman, her sister-in-law Han Lifen, and Prax Capital also own minority stakes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mikhail Fedyaev is a minor partner of Vladimir Gridin's in Siberian Business Unit (SDS-Holding). In 2011 the group bought several companies, including Azot Kemerovo, a fertilizer producer, and European Media Group, which manages several commercial radio stations. After graduation Fedyaev worked as a mechanic in a car factory. In the 1990s he met Gridin and with support from Aman Tuleev, the governor of Kemerovo Oblast, the businessmen became owners of a coal field. Now coal subsidiary SDS-Holding produces more than 20 million tons. Fedyaev's son Pavel became State Duma deputy for the Edinaya Rissiya party in December.

name: Billionaires
bio: Feng  Hailiang chairs of the diversified Hailiang Group based in the city of Zhuji in Zhejiang Province. His biggest business: copper processor Zhejiang Hailiang, which went public on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in 2008. Today, it is about a third owned by Feng and enjoyed a 28% rise in sales in the first nine months of 2011 to $1.4 billion. Feng also has interests in education and real estate.  The latter includes development projects in Chongqing, Inner Mongolia, Tibet, Ningxia and Shanghai, among other cities.  Feng's sister Feng Yali is chairman of the listed company Zhejiang Hailiang.

name: Billionaires
bio: Henry Fong Yun Wah leads Hip Shing Hong Group, which owns the On Hing Building and the Hip Shing Hong Center in central Hong Kong; group is profiting from rising rents, strong demand for commercial space. Fong and his father Fong Shu Cheun arrived in Hong Kong from the mainland in 1927, starting out in business with a sesame factory. By 1948, after the devastation of World War II, they had started an import-export operation. In 1951, Hip Shing Hong was the largest cinnamon exporter in Hong Kong. The company entered the real estate business in 1953 with the purchase of a plot of land at Wong Chuk Hang Road. Today, that real estate empire includes serviced apartments, commercial, industrial and residential projects.  He is a longtime golf buddy of Li Ka-shing.

name: Billionaires
bio: The stock price of Funai Electric, which Tetsuro Funai founded in 1961, is down a third over the past year on slumping US sales of its LCD TVs, sold under brand names like Emerson, Magnavox and Sylvania. Funai is starting a joint venture to make and sell LED lighting in China as a new secondary business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vladimir Gruzdev is the governor of Tula Oblast, 200 kilometers south of Moscow. His early career was in the Army, where he served as an interpreter and in military intelligence. In 1993 he retired from the military and went into business. Gruzdev managed several shops for fellow billionaire Oleg Boyko, and later founded supermarkets chain Sedmoi Kontinent. In 2007 before the crisis Gruzdev sold his stake in the company to his partner Alexander Zanadvorov. Gruzdev's family continues to control retail network Fashion Continent, owns land near Moscow, and also holds a stake in RGI International, a luxury real estate developer in Moscow. Gruzdev became governor last summer, after two terms in the State Duma.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mehmet Nazif Gunal joins the billionaires list for the first time this year. He is the chairman of MNG Holding, which spans an array of investments including hotels, energy, transportation, plane maintenance and repair, finance, construction and media. Two of his hotels in Antalya are exact replicas of the Kremlin and Topkapi palaces. Gunal started working on construction sites at 14. After graduating from the Middle East Technical College in 1971 as a civil engineer he founded the MNG company (from initials of his name) in 1976.

name: Billionaires
bio: The majority of Suat Gunsel's wealth comes from Yakin Dogu, one of the largest universities in Northern Cyprus, which he founded in 1989 after starting and running a tutorial college, Basari Dershanesi. Gunsel also has vast real estate holdings in Northern Cyprus, which Forbes was able to confirm this year. He also has interests in a hospital, bank, hotel, gas station, molding, plastics and cable production companies. After studying physics at ODTU (Middle Eastern Technical University) in Turkey, he returned to Cyprus and worked for a short time in the public sector. Now, Gunsel spends his spare time jogging, riding horses and playing tennis; he also collects stamps and antique cars.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mubariz Gurbanoglu runs Palmali Navigation which owns roughly 135 ships that transport oil and petroleum products. He also owns a small media company with two Istanbul radio stations, as well as real estate including a new hotel in Istanbul. Gurbanoglu took his surname at 40. Originally from an Azeri background, he was sent to military school, later working for Soviet internal intelligence. After he resigned in 1989, he worked as a cook on ships and applied for an old Soviet ship during privatization. Gubanoglu is an animal lover; owns 12 dogs and builds shelters. He sleeps at most 4 hours a day and flies his Falcon jets at least 120 hours a month.

name: Billionaires
bio: Joaquin Guzman, known as "El Chapo," is a criminal and the leader of the illegal drug smuggling Sinaloa cartel, responsible for an estimated 25% of the illegal drugs trafficked from Mexico into the U.S. Guzman is believed by drug experts to be spending more money to defend the cartel than in previous years due to stepped up enforcement efforts by the Mexican government, and has expanded cartel operations to Central America, particularly Guatemala. But authorities are closing in: December 2011 brought the arrest of a top Sinaloa lieutenant, quickly followed in February by the capture of the leader of the cartel's armed wing. Circumstances must be less than cozy in the mountains where El Chapo hides out; in August, the drug lord reportedly sent his 22-year-old wife to Los Angeles County to give birth to the couple's twin daughters.
title: Drug Trafficker

name: Billionaires
bio: The bulk of Alfredo Harp Helu's fortune comes from the 2001 sale of Mexican bank Banamex to Citigroup. Harp was the bank's former head and a significant shareholder. He currently chairs publicly traded Grupo Marti, which owns a chain of sporting goods retailers. Harp is the principal shareholder. He is also a cousin of Carlos Slim Helu, Mexico's richest man. A baseball fan, he owns the Diablos Rojos (Red Devils) Mexican team. In 1994, Harp Helu was kidnapped and held for several months.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mehmet Hattat is chairman of Hattat Holding, with investments in the automotive, energy, tourism and construction sectors. He plans to launch coal operations in May which will feed a new power plant in Amasra, which is on Turkey's Black Sea coast. Hattat owns a sofa and vases that once belonged to Napolean Bonaparte.

name: Billionaires
bio: Morris Kahn made his fortune as an original investor in Amdocs, a customer-relationship management-and-billing software firm for large telecom outfits. Since Amdocs went public in 1998, he has cashed out nearly $1 billion worth of shares. Kahn now focuses on venture capital and philanthropy in Israel. As principal of Aurum Ventures, he has invested in a dozen emerging life-science and tech companies like Atlantium, which specializes in water disinfection, and N-Trig, which makes a multitouch screen for computers. The firm also invests in other telecom, automotive and renewable energy outfits. Kahn lives on Israel's Mediterranean coast and spends most of his time on a 100-foot yacht. He is a cofounder of Coral World International, a string of aquariums in locations such as the Bahamas and Australia. His son Benjamin is a marine biologist and president of the company. He helps fund a camp for children with terminal diseases, a therapeutic riding camp for the disabled and cataract surgery in Ethiopia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dmitry Kamenshchik, together with business partner Valery Kogan, owns Domodedovo Airport, the largest in Russia used by 26 milion people last year. A terrorist attack at the airport in January 2011 left 37 dead and intensified relations between the airport owners and the government, which wants to take back ownership. In spring 2011 the airport's managing company, DME Limited, filed for an IPO in London, but later abandoned the plan. Rumors have been flying that the airport is up for sale. As a Moscow State University philosophy student, Kamenshchik started his business in 1992 by chartering  a  plane, which flew goods from China to Moscow. Business grew; Kamenshchik built a cargo terminal in Moscow's Domodedovo airport and later took control of the entire airport. After reconstruction in 1999-2000, Domodedovo gained popularity among airlines and became the largest airport in Russia.

name: Billionaires
bio: William Kellogg is the former CEO of the department store chain, Kohl's.  He became chief executive after working as a store manager and taking over the company with partners John Herma and Jay Baker in a 1986 management buyout. The 40-store chain only in Wisconsin at the time, but now has 1,067 stores in 49 states. The company went public in 1992 and Kellogg stepped down as CEO in 1999.  He holds more than $450 million in Kohl's stock and also owns a stake in used car conglomerate, CarMax.
title: Director and Member of Executive Committee
employment: {'name': "Kohl's", 'uri': 'companies/kohls', 'title': 'Director and Member of Executive Committee', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Nasser Khalili is an Iranian-born academic and former art dealer who holds one of the world's largest private collections of Islamic art, with over 20,000 items spanning 1,400 years; the art is both his passion and the basis of his wealth. Nicknamed the secret sultan, Khalili left Iran before the 1979 revolution and now lives in London as a dual U.S.-British citizen. He holds artifacts including rare Koranic manuscripts, paintings, ceramics, glass, and textiles. He started his collection as a teenager, when as his first purchase he bought a 19th century Qajar lacquer pen box. He also owns Japanese Art from the Meiji period, Indian and Swedish textiles, and Spanish metal works. Khalili owns commercial and retail properties in and around London, including tony Mayfair. He is reportedly building an innovative energy-efficient office block dubbed "The Wave." Khalili is co-founder and chairman of the Maimonides Foundation, a charity that promotes interfaith peace and understanding.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mustafa Vehbi Koc is the eldest son of Mustafa Rahmi Koc, and since 2003, chairman of the board of industrial group Koc Holding. The family holding company plans $3.4 billion in new investments in 2012, focused mainly on Ford Otosan, its joint venture with Ford Motor, and Tupras, the country's sole refiner. Group company Arcelik purchased South African appliance manufacturer Defy Appliances in July for over $300 million. His father Mustafa Rahmi Koc and his aunts Suna Kirac and Semahat Arsel are also billionaires.

name: Billionaires
bio: Marc Ladreit de Lacharriere is the chief executive and chairman of the board of Fimalac, the parent of Fitch Ratings, which operates in 50 countries. Recently he has been criticized for his firm's role in the sub-prime real estate disaster. Ladreit de Lacharriere founded the company in 1991. When he was 21, he started a teen magazine, which he sold a few years later. He attended the prestigious Ecole Nationale d'Administration before moving into banking and finance. Eventually he landed at L'Oreal, where he worked for 15 years, becoming executive vice president of finance. He is currently on the board of L'Oreal, Renault, and Casino Guichard-Perrachon. A theater buff, Ladreit de Lacharriere helped renovate the Theater du Rond Point in Paris; he also serves on the board of the American Friends of the Louvre organization. In 2009, he was named goodwill ambassador by UNESCO.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born into one of Hong Kong's most prominent textile families, Law has successfully put his efforts of late into real estate and hotels.  His Park Hotel chain, which has locations in China, Japan and other Asian countries, may be getting ready to shop. Daughter Wendy says lower prices in some markets make it a good time to buy hotels. Wendy runs Law's Knightsbridge Department Store. Law's father founded the family empire as a textile company.

name: Billionaires
bio: The eldest grandson of late Samsung founder Lee Byung-Chull, Lee Jay-Hyun inherited the CJ Group, which officially separated from Samsung in 1997. Founded in 1953 as Cheil Jedang, the company began as a sugar mill and boosted domestic sugar production just after the end of the Korean War. Today, it is a Korean conglomerate with interests that include food, food services, bio pharmaceuticals, home shopping and entertainment. In November, CJ Group acquired a 40 percent stake in Korea Express, one of the nation's largest distribution companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lee Seo-Hyun is the youngest daughter of Samsung Chairman Lee Kun-Hee. She joins the Forbes World's Billionaires list for the first time this year thanks to an increase in value in her inherited stake of Samsung Everland, a company active in construction, food service and resorts. She is a vice president in the luxury goods and fashion division of Cheil Industries (part of the Samsung Group) as well as a vice president at Cheil Worldwide, an advertising company. Lee attended Parsons The New School for Design in New York.

name: Billionaires
bio: Li Guoqiang is CEO of auto distributor Zhongsheng Group, which has thrived on increasingly well-off China's love affair with autos.  He co-founded auto dealership group Zhongsheng Group in 1998 in Dalian with fellow billionaire Huang Yi and took it public in Hong Kong in March 2010 in an IPO that raised $369 million. Zhongsheng sells Porsche, Lamborghini, Lexus and Toyota brands at the relatively healthy high end of China's market.     Li has been deputy chairman of the China Automobile Dealers Association since December 2009.

name: Billionaires
bio: Liang Zhaoxian is the largest shareholder of Chinese microwave oven producer Galanz. He is also the son of Liang Qingde, who is widely seen as the force behind the success the company. Galanz also produces  air conditioners, washing machines, refrigerators, pressure cookers and wine coolers. The company traces its roots to 1978, when it was founded as a feather product plant.

name: Billionaires
bio: Liu Canglong is chairman of Sichuan-Province-based Hongda Group, whose businesses include minerals, real estate and finance; it employs 18,000 people. The group expects sales in 2012 to total about $5 billion, little changed from 2011. Hongda Group actively donated to charity, and has given $8 million to AIDS prevention and cure in China. Liu's son, Liu Jun, is president of Hongda Group. The father was an early beneficiary of China's agriculture reforms in the late 1970s, and started off in business by selling fertilizer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Liu Ming Chung is the deputy chairman and CEO of Nine Dragons Paper, one of Asia's largest manufacturers of paper products. His wealth has dropped by more than a third because of a decline in the company's earnings and share price  spurred by an easing of China's exports in the past 12 months.  Net profit in the 12 months to June 2011 fell by 9.2% to $312 million.  The company is looking to boost its business in the future in part through factory expansion in Tianjin, Chongqing and Shenyang. Liu's wife and fellow billionaire Cheung Yan is the chairlady of Nine Dragons. His brother-in-law Zhang Cheng Fei also sits on the board of directors. Lau holds an undergraduate degree in economics from the University of California at Davis and a graduate degree in industrial engineering from Columbia University.

name: Billionaires
bio: Politician Mangal Prabhat Lodha founded property firm Lodha Developers, run today by his 2 sons Abhisheck and Abhinandan. It has 27 upcoming projects covering 30 million square feet, mostly in Mumbai, including 117-story World One, an ultraluxury residential tower in the center of the city. Jade Jagger, Mick Jagger's daughter, is designing apartments in its new high-rise project in suburban Mumbai. He recently paid $500 million to Deutsche Bank towards repayment of a debt. In 2010, he snatched a 23 acre plot in Mumbai for $825 million, in what was India's biggest land deal. Listing of his flagship has been postponed.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cash-strapped liquor baron Vijay Mallya is struggling to save his debt-laden Kingfisher Airlines from collapse. In bid to stem losses, he took controversial decision to shut down budget carrier Kingfisher Red at a time when low-cost segment was expanding. Got into trouble with airline regulator when he grounded airplanes and cancelled flights. He's reportedly looking to offload part stake to a foreign airline.  Bulk of fortune comes from liquor empire, including United Spirits, which claims to be world's largest liquormaker by volume; Whyte & Mackay; and beer joint venture with Heineken. Sold part stake in Formula One team, Force India. Still owns cricket team Royal Challengers Bangalore.

name: Billionaires
bio: Yuri Milner, the savvy internet investor every tech investor wants to emulate, hit the billionaires list for the first time last year thanks to the growing value of his social media holdings especially Facebook, Zynga and Groupon. In 2011 he added to the portfolio: his new fund with partner Alisher Usmanov and others, DST Global II, bought stakes in Twitter, Spotify, Airbnb and Chinese online retailers 360buy.com and Alibaba Group. In 2010, Milner divided his Digital Sky Technologies into two parts, taking email portal Mail.Ru public. In 2009, DST paid $200 million for a stake in Facebook; this initial investment has grown an estimated five-fold since. Milner plans to invest in every startup that comes out of Silicon Valley-based incubator Y Combinator without reading the business plan. The former particle physicist plays chess for fun. His wife, Julia, is contemporary artist.
title: Investor

name: Billionaires
bio: Better known as B.K., Bhupendra Kumar Modi runs $2 billion (revenues) Spice Group from his headquarters in Singapore. It has interests in mobile devices, entertainment and financial services. Chunk of his fortune comes from his holding in telecom flagship S Mobility (formerly Spice Mobility). He's bought telecom companies in Thailand and Indonesia. Plans to list holding company Spice i2i Mobility in London. Son Dilip is its chief operating officer and daughter Divya sits on board. He wears a 23 carat diamond encircled by  five symbols representing Hinduism, Christianity, Judaism, Buddhism and Islam. BK recently became a Singapore citizen.

name: Billionaires
bio: A former Honeywell executive, John Morgridge became chief of networking firm Cisco in 1988 at age 55. He took Cisco public in 1990, stepped down in 1995 and became a billionaire the next year as Cisco's stock continued to climb. Cisco's chairman emeritus now teaches at Stanford University's Graduate School of Business, where he received his MBA. He's an avid hiker and chairs the Nature Conservancy, which uses private funds to buy and protect land from development. With his wife Tashia, he's donated to his undergradute alma mater, the University of Wisconsin, and has gifted $175 million to set up a fund for college-bound students.

name: Billionaires
bio: Berkshire Hathaway lieutenant Charles Munger gave shares he co-owned with his wife, Nancy, to his eight  children after she died last February ("I don't need them where I'm going."). In June 2011, Berkshire acquired the remaining 20% of Wesco Financial, the holding company Munger ran, to make it a wholly owned subsidiary. The Omaha native dropped out of the University of Michigan to serve as a meteorologist in the U.S. Army Air Corps. He later attended Harvard Law. The pragmatic investor met friend and business partner Warren Buffett at a dinner party in 1959.
title: Vice Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Niu Yishun, new to the World's Billionaires list this year, is chairman of Hixih Rubber Industry Group. Founded in 1989, the company is one of the mainland's largest non-government-controlled tire suppliers, with joint ventures with Goodyear and Pirelli Tire. Hixih is additionally is one of the world's largest maker of conveyor belts.  Hixih employs about 7,000; sales totaled $3.6 billion in 2011. The chairman's son, Niu Teng, is an executive director, and holds a degree in business from prestigious Fudan University in Shanghai.

name: Billionaires
bio: New billionaire Maxim Nogotkov got his start selling computer programs while in school and later began selling cordless phones. He dropped out of college in order to have more time to focus on building his business. In 2000 he began trading cell phones wholesale; he later founded cell phone retailer Svyaznoy; the privately held company is now the second-largest cell phone retailer in Russia. In 2010, Nogotkov founded Svyaznoy Bank. He also owns a chain of jewelry shops under franchise from Danish company Pandora.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former minister of trade under Marcos regime, Roberto Ongpin has investments in property, gaming, mining and telecommunications. Top Frontier, the investment company he heads, has a controlling interest in San Miguel Corporation. Last November he appeared before a senate inquiry over a loan from a state-owned development bank, which he claims was above board. He's a certified public accountant and Harvard Business School graduate.

name: Billionaires
bio: Peter Peterson is the former chief executive of Blackstone. He received $1.85 billion in pre-tax cash after exiting the firm in 2008. Peterson joined the Warren Buffett/Bill Gates Giving Pledge, saying in his letter, "On our current path, I fear we are imperiling their future by passing on massive, hidden debts and unthinkable taxes."  He has pledged more than $1 billion to be transferred incrementally over the years to his eponymous foundation, which aims to create initiatives to fight the growing national deficit. Peterson previously acted as the Commerce Secretary under Nixon, the chairman of Lehman Brothers, and the head of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York from 2000 to 2004. He has written many books, including an autobiography, and is married to Joan Ganz Cooney, the creator of Sesame Street.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ukraine's "chocolate king" Petro Poroshenko joins the billionaire ranks as his company, Roshen, continues to dominate Ukraine's sweets market and begin expansion into Europe; last year he purchased a starch plant in Germany. Poroshenko also has holdings in agriculture, automobiles and shipbuilding; he took over popular magazine Korrespondent as well. A former Minister of Foreign Affairs for Ukraine, Poroshenko heads Ukraine's National Bank Council; in March he was expected to accept a new cabinet level appointment as Ukraine's Minister of Economic Development and Trade. He got his start selling cocoa beans, then purchased several confectionery plants, uniting them in Roshen in 1995.

name: Billionaires
bio: Que Wenbin is the biggest shareholder of Gansu Duyiwei Biological Pharmaceutical, a supplier of Tibetan herbal medicine. Que and his wife also control Sichuan Western Resources Holding, a mining firm in China's Gansu and Jiangxi provinces. Growth at the mining company has topped medicine:  Sichuan Western's net profit last year climbed 92% to $41 million, whereas the drug company's rose only by 8% to $11 million. Sichuan Hengkang Capital Management, which is owned by Que and his wife, holds a 9% stake in Shenzhen-listed coil maker Xianyang Pianzhuan.  Que reportedly has set up a private jet leasing company and purchased jets from Gulfstream.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ren Zhengfei is the CEO of Huawei, China's largest manufacturer of telecom hardware with sales of $29.4 billion in 2010. It has 20 research and development centers around the world and has filed over 49,000 patent applications. Son of two school teachers, Ren spent much of his youth in a remote town in Guizhou Province before graduating from the Chongqing Institute of Civil Engineering and Architecture in 1963. He later served a decade in the People's Liberation Army's engineering corps after which he worked for Shenzhen South Sea Oil before setting up Huawei in 1987.

name: Billionaires
bio: Arkady Rotenberg is a childhood friend and judo compatriot of prime minister Vladimir Putin. He  owns Stroygazmontazh Corporation (SGM Group), one of the biggest construction subcontractors of Russian gas giant Gazprom, and also a pipes supplier for Gazprom. He also holds a 26% stake in Mostotrest (big road construction corporation), SMP Bank (together with his younger brother Boris), and a concession company for a toll road from Moscow to Saint Petersburg which is under construction. In 2011 Rotenberg bought fertilizers producer Minudobreniya Rossosh and another Gazprom subcontractor, Gazprom Burenie.

name: Billionaires
bio: As the heir apparent to the centuries-old European banking dynasty, 40-year-old Nathaniel Rothschild (he prefers Nat) is building on his inheritance with canny investments in commodities, including a stake in Indonesia's largest coal producer, Bumi. Rothschild has also teamed up with ex-BP boss Tony Hayward on Vallares, an oil investment vehicle they merged with Turkish giant Genel in 2011. The Eton and Oxford graduate is well-connected: he's close with Russian billionaire Oleg Deripaska, once acting as an adviser and a cornerstone investor when his metals company Rusal floated. Other prudent investments include a stake in Glencore, the billionaire-backed commodities titan. Nat's known for his love of the finer things in life, and spends much of his time at his home base in the affluent ski resort town of Klosters, Switzerland. His 40th birthday party in Montenegro last July drew celebrities, socialites and billionaires alike -- as well as a slew of press coverage. As a scion of one of the world's wealthiest families, he can expect more attention to come. In January, he launched a libel suit against the UK's Daily Mail for suggesting that he used his connection to Deripaska to set up £500 million deal with former EU trade commissioner Peter Mandelson while they were all in a sauna together.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chinese-Thai entrepreneur Chanchai Ruayrungruang, also known as Yan Bin,  leads the Reignwood Group, which a partner of Red Bull drinks in China and also runs the Pine Valley Golf Resort and Country Club  in Beijing. In February, a deadline for the planned investment by Reignwood International Investment (Group) for a minority stake in gold mining interest Citigold Corp. of Australia passed without completion, though the two sides are still talking.  In December, Reignwood teamed up with the Empire Asia Group to buy a minority stake in Aminex, a Dublin-based oil and gas exploration company.  Chanchai is chairman of the Asian Golf Course Owners Association.

name: Billionaires
bio: Suzan Sabanci Dincer is chairman of publicly traded Akbank, a unit of the family-owned Sabanci group; she took over in 2008 after her father Erol Sabanci stepped down. The bank's stock price has been flat over the past year. Suzan began working at Akbank in the 1980s after receiving business degrees from Richmond College in England and Boston University. Her husband Haluk Dincer is chairman of Sabanci Holding's retail group. Suzan is a dance afficianado and has taken rumba, mambo, salsa and tango.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sevket Sabanci is a shareholder of publicly traded Sabanci Holding, founded by his deceased father, Haci Omer Sabanci; the stock price is flat over the past year. He also has a stake in publicly traded Akbank. In 2000, Sevket went on to establish Esas Holding together with his children Ali Sabanci and Emine Sabanci Kamisli. Esas owns Pegasus Airlines and has started investing in real estate. With its partners F&C and Area Property Partners, Esas has bought offices and shopping malls in towns in the UK; these efforts are spearheaded by Sevket's grandson, Kazim Koseoglu.

name: Billionaires
bio: Known as Canada's Harry Kravis, Gerald Schwartz serves as CEO of private equity firm, Onex. After stints at Bear Stearns and CanWest, Schwartz founded Onex in 1983, and today it has completed more than 260 deals. An honorary director of the Bank of Nova Scotia, he also serves as a director of Indigo Books & Music, where his wife, Heather Reisman serves as CEO. Schwarz owns homes in Toronto, Malibu, Nantucket, and Palm Beach--where he keeps his 19-foot dinghy "Know Heather," named after his wife.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nobutoshi Shimamura started out with one small kimono shop and eventually turned it into one of Japan's leading discount retailers with 1600 locations including shoe stores. His Shimamura shops now sell everything from baby shoes to home decor; group, which quickly recovered from last March's earthquake and tsunami despite impact on 402 stores, is expanding in big cities and has a new outlet catering exclusively to women. Shimamura retired twenty years ago and is no longer involved in the business, choosing instead to keep a  low-profile.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hedge fund pioneer Paul Singer founded Elliott Management, the $19 billion hedge fund firm specializing in distressed debt investments. This former Wall Street lawyer is also known for playing hardball after scooping up sovereign debt of countries like the Republic of Congo and Argentina. Singer has been critical of recent Federal Reserve policy and Wall Street's bonus culture, arguing for governments to limit financial firm borrowing and risk taking. A big supporter of Republican Party candidates and causes, including Mitt Romney's Super PAC, Singer also played an important role in the effort to allow same-sex marriages in New York state.
title: Investor

name: Billionaires
bio: Thomas Straumann is the grandson of Reinhard Straumann, who founded an alloy research institute in 1954, and invented metals for use in watch components. Thomas' father Fritz led the push into dental implants. The company opened offices in the United States in 1989 and went public in 1998. Thomas retired as chairman of Straumann Holding in 2002, but still sits on the company's board. Its stock price is down 29% over last year, leading the company to buy back $1 billion in shares. Thomas Straumann's Swiss luxury hotels, Hotel Les Trois Rois and Grand Hotel Bellevue, are faring better. He also chairs dental implant maker Medartis, which he founded in 1997. Straumann keeps a stable of race horses.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sun Piaoyang is the chairman of Shanghai-listed Jiangsu Hengrui Medicine, whose chemotherapy drugs have ranked No.1 in sales in their category in China in the last seven years. Jiangsu Hengrui obtained U.S. Food and Drug Administration approval at the end of 2011 to sell in the U.S. market injections to treat rectal cancer. Net profit in the first nine months of 2011 rose 19% to $107 million; revenue grew 18% to $527 million, helping to increase Henrui's share price by 10%. Hengrui has a research center in New Jersey. Sun's wife Zhong Huijuan chairs Jiangsu Hansoh Pharmaceutical Group, one of China's largest pharmaceutical companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: The sixth out of 10 siblings, Susanto only reached the 1st grade. He had to drop out of school because the Indonesian government banned students with Chinese names (he later changed his last name).  At age 17 he started managing his parents' modest 560-foot stall inside Pasar Arjuna, a traditional market in Jakarta. The stall sold groceries at the time, but soon Djoko was peddling cigarettes and opening more stalls.  His success attracted the attention of clove cigarette tycoon Putera Sampoerna. Together they opened similar stalls and then opened a discount supermarket chain. When Putera sold his cigarettes business to Altria, Djoko bought out the retail business and developed it into Alfa Supermarket, which he later sold 2008. Nowadays he operates several mini-mart formats.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alain Taravella, founder of $3 billion (property portfolio value) Altarea Cogedim, France's third-largest real estate firm, makes the billionaires list for the first time this year. Tarvella is CEO and board chair. In 1994, he started Altarea SA, a real estate firm focused on developing retail properties, specifically shopping centers. In 2007, Altarea acquired Cogedim and formed Altarea Cogedim, with a presence in both the residential and commercial property development markets. The company operates primarily in France and Italy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sergei Tsikalyuk sold his 25% stake in VSK insurance company to RESO, the group owned by billionaire brothers Nikolay and Sergey Sarkisov, for $220 million last year. Tsikalyuk graduated from Military College and Military Academy and served 16 years in the Army; he retired in 1992 at the rank of colonel. That same year he founded Military Insurance Company (VSK), which initially provided health and life insurance for army personnel. In 2002, AIG announced that is interested in buying VSK, but the army was against the deal. Tsikalyuk then broadened his company into a general insurance firm; today half its portfolio comes from car insurance deals.

name: Billionaires
bio: Murat Vargi founded Turkey's largest cell phone operator Turkcell with the start up capital of fellow billionaire Mehmet Emin Karamehmet. He sat on Turkcell's board from 1993 until 2005; still owns 2.5%. His MV Holding operates in telecom, energy and tourism. He owns a stake in KVK, the biggest mobile phone retail network in Turkey; he has also built a 10% market share in Turkey's wind power market. Vargi rents out his 120-foot yacht, Jasmin, docked at Antibes, France, for $70,000 per week in low season.

name: Billionaires
bio: Andrey Verevskiy started as a grains trader when he was 20; over the next several years he actively acquiring farms to build agribusiness conglomerate Kernel Holding. In 2007, he took the company public on Warsaw stock exchange. The company's stock price is down 12% over the past year. Verevskiy is diversifying his investments; he purchased Ukrainian real estate developer KDD Group this year. Parliamentary deputy adroitly switched parties from Yulia Tymoshenko's bloc to new president Victor Yanukovich's bloc when the political winds shifted.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wen Yibo is chairman of Sound Environment Resources, a Shenzhen-listed waste reclamation and treatment company that's benefitted from China's urban growth. Sales in the nine months through September 2011 rose 60% to $163 million, helping to increase its net profit 37% to $30 million. Wen also leads Sound Global, formerly known as Epure, one of China's leading wastewater treatment businesses, whose shares trade in Hong Kong and Singapore. Sound Global's sales during the first six months of 2011 totaled $168 million, a 64% increase from the same period of 2010. Wen holds an undergraduate degree in environmental engineering from Lanzhou Railway College (now called Lanzhou Jiaotong University), and earned a masters in environmental engineering from Tsinghua University in Beijing.  He was a government engineer between 1990 and 1993; he co-founded Beijing Sound in the latter year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Fine Blanking, a manufacturer of auto and motorcycle parts based in central Taiwan, Wu Chung-yi debuts on list this year. Made most of his money through a stake in Hong Kong-listed beverage maker Tingyi, along with the billionaire Wei brothers, before he cashed out in 2007. Wu sits on the board of Wei Chuan, a food company that is partly owned by Tingyi. He studied at the University of California in Los Angeles.

name: Billionaires
bio: Xu Jingren chairs Yangtze River Pharmaceutical Group, one of China's largest pharmaceutical manufacturers.  Xu founded the forerunner of the group in 1971. The company produces antibiotics, chemotherapy drugs and drugs to fight cardiovascular disease. Sales in the first six months of 2011 rose 26% to $2.3 billion. The company was no. 53 on a ranking of China's largest 500 non-government companies in 2010. Xu is a member of the National People's Congress.

name: Billionaires
bio: San Francisco 49ers owner Denise DeBartolo York scored a big victory in 2010 when the city of Santa Clara voted to approve construction of a new 68,500-seat football stadium. Plans call for construction to begin in 2012 and for the 49ers to move the 40 miles from their current hometown before the 2015 season. Daughter of real estate magnate Edward DeBartolo Sr., York is the former co-chair of the family's private holding group, The DeBartolo Corp. She took control of the 49ers franchise in 2000 after her brother, Edward Jr., was convicted on federal bribery charges. Her son Jed, 31, is the 49ers president and CEO.
title: Co-Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhang Guiping is one of two Zhang brothers from the eastern Chinese city of Nanjing to make the billionaires' list, along with Zhang Jindong, chairman of Suning Appliance. Guiping owns 64% of Shenzhen-listed real estate company Suning Universal with son Zhang Kangli.  Looking to diversify beyond its core residential property development business, Suning Universal signed an agreement with Starwood Hotels & Resorts in June 2011 to open a Sheraton Hotel in Wuhu in Anhui Province and another with Marriott in March to open five-star hotels in Shanghai, Nanjing and Yunnan. Zhang is vice chairman of Jiangsu Federation of Industry & Commerce, vice president of Jiangsu Chamber of Commerce, and an adjunct professor and director at Nanjing Normal University.
